DOC.HEAD: American Continental Founder Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Charles H. Keating Jr., chairman of American Continental Corp., and five other top executives of the Phoenix-based corporation resigned Friday following two legal defeats, Keating's attorney said. Also resigning were corporation president Judy J. Wischer, and Robert J. Kielty, Robert M. Wurzelbacher Jr., Andrew F. Ligget and Bradley J. Boland. On Thursday, a federal judge in Washington ruled that Keating and his associates had looted Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of millions of dollars in federally insured deposits. The day before, a Los Angeles judge said Keating must prove that he is out of money and ordered him not to transfer funds out of the country. Keating could not be reached to comment on his resignation. Stephen C. Neal, his personal attorney, released a short statement on his behalf. ``While we vigorously disagree with the opinion expressed yesterday by Judge Stanley Sporkin of the United States District Court, it has become clear that my client must now concentrate all his energy on aggressively defending the legal charges against him,'' Neal said. ``Because of that, and in light of the fact that these individuals are no longer in a position to effectively direct ACC, they have resigned from all of their positions, effective immediately.'' Boland, Keating's son-in-law, had been the corporation's public-relations chief. Kielty was senior vice president and general counsel, Ligget was the chief financial officer, and Wurzelbacher had been president of a commercial real-estate subsidiary. American Continental and 11 subsidiaries filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of federal bankrupcty laws on April 13, 1989, and federal regulators took control of Lincoln, a $5.8 billion, California-based S&L which was the corporation's primary asset. Keating claimed that the Federal Home Loan Bank Board and its successors, the Resolution Trust Corporation and the Office of Thrift Supervision, had waged war with him because of his stands against government regulation. Sporkin heard more than 30 days of testimony before ruling Thursday that Keating and the others abused their positions in what ``amounted to a looting of Lincoln.'' Sporkin also dismissed Keating's suit to recover Lincoln. Regulators have estimated that Keating's use of Lincoln's federally insured deposits to finance various junk bond, stock and real estate ventures and the institution's subsequent collapse could cost taxpayers as much as $2 billion. The government already has spent $1.2 billion keeping Lincoln and its more than 20 branches in Southern California afloat, according to lawyers in the case. The government also has a $1.3 billion civil fraud and racketeering suit pending against Keating.

DOC.HEAD: Student Aid Rising, But Not Enough To Beat College Inflation
DOC.TEXT: Student aid climbed during the 1980s to a record $27.9 billion, but not nearly fast enough to keep pace with college costs, the College Board reported. Aid from all sources grew just 10 percent between 1980 and 1990, adjusted for inflation, the board said in its annual report, ``Trends in Student Aid: 1980-1990.'' In current dollars, total aid increased by 62 percent from the $17.23 billion available in 1980-81. But the cost of attending public universities rose by 105.3 percent in current dollars and 40 percent in inflation-adjusted dollars during the 1980s. At private universities, costs rose 133.9 percent in current dollars, and 59.5 percent in inflation-adjusted dollars, the board's Washington, D.C., office said in the report released Thursday. A record 13.5 million students attended undergraduate and graduate programs in the last school year, compared with 12.1 million in 1980, federal statistics show. Institutional aid _ grants and loans awarded by colleges and universities from their own resources _ grew by 178 percent during the decade, from $2.06 billion to $5.73 billion. After adjusting for inflation, such aid was up 90 percent over the last 10 years. State grant programs grew by 123 percent during the decade, from $801 million to $1.79 billion. Adjusted for inflation, such grants were up 52 percent. Offsetting those gains, however, was an effective decline in federal aid. Preliminary figures for 1989-90 showed that the federal share including all grants and loan programs totaled $20.36 billion, compared with $19.95 billion a year earlier. A decade ago, $14.37 billion was available. Adjusted for inflation, however, federal aid declined 3 percent from 1980-81 levels, the report found. The drop reflected the end in 1985 of college benefits provided by Social Security as well as a 76 percent decline in veterans benefits. Such assistance totaled $601 million in 1989-90, compared with $1.71 billion a decade earlier, the report found.

DOC.HEAD: 1979 Sentences Against Havel, Dienstbier, Others Annulled
DOC.TEXT: A court has annulled the 1979 prison sentences given President Vaclav Havel and two other leading officials convicted of subversion by the ousted Communist government, the CTK news agency reported. Havel, Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier and CTK's current head, Peter Uhl, were prominent dissidents when they were sentenced to up to five years for alleged subversion. The three, whose sentences Prague's City Court annulled Thursday, were founders of the Committee for the Defense of the Unjustly Persecuted, a dissident group that cooperated with the Charter 77 human rights group. Havel was sentenced to 4{ years in prison at that time, Dienstbier to three years and Uhl to five years. The three were sentenced to jail terms repeatedly under the Communists for their dissident activities, but became leaders of the country after last November's peaceful revolution.

DOC.HEAD: New Policy of Disengagement Frustrates Soldiers and Palestinians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The army plans to lower the Israeli flag and remove a tent encampment near Gaza City as part of a new policy intended to reduce friction with Palestinians. Soldiers have orders not to open fire and to avoid confrontations with stone-throwing youths. Patrols rarely enter the villages and crowded refugee camps. The disengagement reflects a radical shift in the army's military doctrine, and its effectiveness is reducing bloodshed in the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories that began in December 1987. No one has been killed since May in the Gaza Strip, where the uprising began. In July, three Palestinians were killed in the West Bank, the lowest monthly toll of the revolt, in which Israelis have killed well over 700 Palestinians. ``This can't be called turning a blind eye . . . but whoever thought of it was brilliant,'' a military commander said, on condition of anonymity. He said the policy had been implemented gradually after the massacre of seven Gaza workers by an Israeli gunman May 20 started 10 days of riots in which 18 Palestinians died. Israel is changing its tactics at a time of of increasing conflict among Palestinians. Since June 1, twice as many Palestinians have been killed by other Palestinians as by soldiers, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israeli authorities. Assad Saftawi, an elementary school principal and leading PLO supporter in the Gaza Strip, described the new policy as a ploy by Defense Minister Moshe Arens to improve Israel's image abroad. Some prominent Palestinians say the uprising is in trouble and seek a new, longer-term strategy to revive morale. Hamdi Faraj, a journalist in Bethlehem, said PLO chairman Yasser Arafat should acknowledge the revolt, or intefadah, has flagged and is unlikely to bring Palestinian statehood in the new future. ``There is a gap between what the PLO says and what the people see,'' he said. ``The state is not a stone's throw away like they claim in slogans.'' At the Dheishe refugee camp in the West Bank, several activists blamed Palestine Liberation Organization policy for the revolt's loss of impetus and accused Arafat of making concessions without getting anything in return. Khaled, 25, who says he has been wounded three times and served 10 months in jail without trial, said Arens timed his change of strategy well. ``The intefadeh has cooled down and Arens played his cards at the right time because people are tired and not chasing after the army,'' he said. Ibrahim, 33, said: ``The intefadeh has almost stopped, and the people have to start realizing that they have to take the solution in their own hands and do it themselves.'' He said younger men should be brought into the PLO leadership. Neither gave his last name. For the army, the Arens policy signifies reversal of a longstanding military doctrine of taking the offensive and confronting each small demonstration to keep riots from developing. ``It was very strange for the soldiers, who have been drilled to charge, to attack and to fire, to be told, `halt . . . restrain yourselves','' the military commander said. Because of the relative quiet, he said, an army encampment set up in the middle of the village of Beit Hanun would be dismantled and the troops evacuated. Villagers were told soldiers would return in force at the first signs of violence. Restraint also was evident elsewhere. From an army lookout post near the Jabalia refugee camp, black smoke could be seen rising as Palestinian youths ignited a tire in the streets. In the past, such an act would have brought swift action by an army patrol, and possibly casualties. This time, Itzik, a 21-year-old first sergeant, looked at the smoke and shrugged his shoulders. ``We'll probably let it burn itself out,'' he said. ``Besides, it creates a lot of heavy black smoke and the (Palestinians) have to breathe it. If it were four or five tires, then we'd probably go in with a company'' of about 100 men, he said. Politicians have praised the army for restraint, but military sources said some soldiers of lower rank felt it could be interpreted as a sign of weakness. Young Palestinians say they will carry the fight to the army. ``Arens might pull back the soldiers, but in that case we will start chasing the army,'' said Fuad, 17, who showed a reporter wounds behind the ear and on his arm from rubber-coated steel bullets.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Intervention In Gulf Holds Long-Term Perils
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The United States may have saved Saudi Arabia's rulers from being toppled by Iraq, but in the long run the military intervention in the Persian Gulf is fraught with peril for America and its Arab friends. Unless the United States ``takes into account all the long-term implications of the situation, its actions may produce a recipe for permanent upheaval rather than the regional stabilization which is its aim,'' Middle East analyst Charles Snow stressed. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's Aug. 2 conquest of Kuwait has shaken the Arab world, polarizing it and triggering new, and often surprising alliances. ``In the immediate future . . . the region will be very lucky indeed if there's not an explosion of potentially epic proportions,'' Snow said. ``Even if this can be avoided, the future looks bleak,'' said Snow, a veteran analyst with the Nicosia-based Middle East Economic Survey. Saddam's internment of U.S. and British hostages in Baghdad and Kuwait and President Bush's decision to beef up the U.S. military commitment, including calling up military reserves for the first time in 20 years, has raised the temperature in recent days. Apart from the prospect of war and the danger Saddam will use chemical weapons, there is the threat of a new wave of terrorist attacks on U.S. and Western targets in the Mideast and beyond. U.S. intervention in Lebanon in 1983 as part of a multinational peacekeeping force ended in disaster, with nearly 300 U.S.and French servicemen killed in suicide bombings by Shiite Moslem zealots. The Middle East was restive and uncertain even before Saddam invaded Kuwait. The Palestinian uprising in Israeli-occupied territories; the end of superpower rivalry that cast the regions adrift; and the flood of Soviet Jews to Israel combined to radically alter the Mideast equation. By portraying himself as the Islamic champion of the Arab world and linking a withdrawal from Kuwait with Israel's occupation of Arab land, Saddam has widened his appeal to Arab masses and the Moslem world. Arab moderates have reluctantly gone along with U.S. intervention in Saudi Arabia, at King Fahd's request, because they were unable to check Saddam themselves. But they're uneasy about the American presence in such a sensitive and strategic region. ``The less time the Iraqis are given to whip up anti-American sentiment in the Arab world, the better as far as Washington is concerned,'' Snow noted. Shahram Chubin, a Middle East specialist with Geneva's Graduate Institute of International Studies, noted: ``The U.S. presence in such force in the land of Islam's holiest places is likely to create a lot of discontent in the Moslem world. ``The semi-permanent presence of the naval armada in the gulf could well eventually antagonize Iran, even though it has opposed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait,'' he said in a telephone interview. ``The longer the Americans stay in the gulf, the worse it will look for them,'' he said. ``The change in the Arab order caused by Iraq's actions will not necessarily be in America's favor. The U.S. intervention may have saved the Saudi royal family for now, but it could ultimately undermine them.'' Much depends on what Saddam does next. He basically has three options: try to sit out the siege, capitulate and withdraw from kuwait, or fight. Capitulation is unlikely. If he meekly returns Kuwait to its emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmad al-Sabah, Saddam would suffer a catastrophic loss of face in the Arab world he seeks to lead. He would likely meet serious unrest at home. That would raise the possibility of a putsch by the army. His generals might feel that on top of Saddam's ill-advised invasion of Iran in 1980, a planned blitzkreig that bogged down into an eight-year war, his miscalaculation over Kuwait has made him a liability. But the Iraqi leader is cunning, unpredictable and a ruthless survivor. Nothing can be taken for granted. The Americans also face the risk that if Saddam opts for the long haul, the international support Washington has mustered could begin to dissipate. If Saddam, threatened with economic strangulation by U.N. sanctions and a barricade, moves into Jordan to secure his only lifeline, he would trigger a powerful Israeli response. That would intensify the bitterness in many Arab quarters against the United States, Israel's main protector. The Americans, some believe, might move against Saddam in Kuwait if they detected signs he planned to play the Israeli card in a bid to unite the Arabs behind him. Israeli Defense Minister Moshe Arens stressed Aug. 7: ``The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait does not represent a geo-strategic change for Israel. But the moment we see that we're facing a change like the entrance of the Iraqi Army into Jordan, we will act.'' King Hussein of Jordan, Saddam's key Arab ally, is extremely vulnerable. If he goes along with the sanctions, he risks Saddam turning on him as well as serious internal upheaval among his 3 million people, many of them Palestinians who are strongly pro-Saddam. ``It seems unlikely to the point of improbability that the Americans are assembling this kind of firepower merely to watch the Iraqis dig in in Kuwait, and if they intend to take more positive action they may have cogent reasons for doing so sooner rather than later,'' Snow noted. ``Once the United States has finished marshalling its forces in the region ... the battle for the gulf will be joined in earnest. The only uncertainty seems to be when, not whether, the storm will break,'' he added.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Ed Blanche has covered Middle East events for several years and since 1985 has been Middle East news editor for the AP based in Nicosia, Cyprus.

DOC.HEAD: American Troops Hungry for News of Home
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report. This story is based on a pool report
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-Reserves, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An American Marine from New York had one question when he arrived in this desert kingdom: ``Are the Mets in first?'' Most of the thousands of U.S. troops here have no access to American publications or any television, so they incessantly ask visiting reporters about the situation back home. ``Do the American people want us here?'' an Army private on a desert exercise this week wanted to know. ``Is President Bush saying we'll go to war?'' asked an Air Force supply officer. A mimeographed newsletter attempts to fill the void with a story headlined: ``Secretary of Defense Explains Why We Are Here.'' But it does little to satisfy the appetite of the news-hungry Americans. ``The situation is very uncertain,'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney says in the newsletter. ``We don't know how long it will last.'' However, there are signs the troops will be getting more access to the news. A daily shipment of newspapers has been sent to some camps this week. ``They get passed around and read again and again and again,'' said a spokesman for the 82nd Airborne. ``The guys are hungry for news.'' A few issues of the military newspaper Stars & Stripes have turned up in the past few days, and the small newsletter that carried Cheney's remarks is being published at one Saudi airbase where U.S. forces are positioned. Iraq is trying to fill the news void with radio broadcasts suggesting that while Americans are protecting Saudi oil fields the ``petrol emirs'' are in the United States and have ``enjoyed'' the company of American women. ``I thought it was pretty funny, actually,'' said a member of the 82nd Airborne Division who listened to the broadcast earlier this week. ``If that's their idea of psychological warfare I don't think we have much to worry about.'' The Saudi media also has had its fair share of recent propaganda. Local television, which can be seen by some U.S. forces staying in hotels or Saudi barracks, frequently includes lengthy segments showing the arrival and exercises of troops in the kingdom. There is no narration, but patriotic music booms. Saudi papers carry daily dispatches from a state press agency designed to assure the public that the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait will not affect Saudi Arabia's food supplies, economy or security. The Saudi papers also have published numerous wire service stories about the crisis. Americans who live here say the local press never has been this open before. But one 20-year-old Army driver didn't really need a newspaper to tell him what was going on. He says he was told at a briefing that U.S. troops were on ``a peacekeeping mission,'' but he said he knew there was a good chance for combat. How did he know? ``They issued live rounds instead of blanks,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi TV Announcer Is Saddam's Voice To World
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's voice to the world in his war of words with President Bush is a dapper television anchorman named Miqdad Muradi. In the last two weeks, while Saddam has kept a low profile in the escalating crisis triggered by his Aug.2 invasion of Kuwait, Muradi has read a string of statements from the president on Iraq's state-run television network. These broadcasts, carried around the globe by Cable News Network, have made the Iraqi something of a TV star. Murad, who bears a striking resemblance to Saddam, is always impeccably dressed in a dark suit and sober tie. Murad, who is in his mid-40s, shows no sign of strain when he reads Saddam's often rambling statements, calling Bush ``a liar'' or announcing that thousands of Americans and Britons held by Iraq are ``guests'' of his country. Muradi has been chief announcer on the Iraqi network for several years. During the 1980-88 war against Iran, he frequently read important statements, usually announcing Iraqi ``victories.''

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts from Saddam Hussein's Taped Meeting with Hostages
DOC.BYLINE: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt ^By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Following are excerpts from Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's meeting with a group of hostages, which was made public in a televised tape Thursday. Saddam's questions and comments were made by a translator. Site and time of the meeting was not known.

Saddam: You were playing volleyball. Just now you were playing? Ian Morton: No, yesterday. S: Do you have a team here, do you play with Iraqis? I: Yes. S: Don't you play anything? Don't you play games, Stuart. Like what? What do you play? Stuart: Football. S: And the ladies, how are you passing time? Unidentified lady: I can't say. S: I am an Iraqi and I realize if I were in your shoes, I would rather be in Iraq, my country. But sometimes one is forced to face situations that are not of his own choice. ... Your presence here and in other places is meant to prevent the scourge of war. To avoid war. In Arabic, we say preventing danger. There is a semantic and linguistic problem here. We, in our communique, used the word Dar'a in Arabic, which means to put away or to prevent or to avoid the scourge of war or the danger of war. We used the word Dar'a, which means to prevent. But when we used this word, Western media used ... misunderstood the pronunciation of the word Dar'a into Der'a, which means shield and they thought that we were using people as a Der'a, which means shield rather than a Dar'a, which we meant, which means to prevent war. So there was a mis ... uh ... perhaps deliberate misinterpretation or inadvertant misinterpretation of our wording of our communique. Stuart, for instance, Stuart will I'm sure be happy to have as part of his life or his history, personal history, that he played a role in maintaining peace. So when he, along with his friends and all those present here, have played their role in preventing war, then they will all be heroes of peace. I'm sure that you all have your own journals and your own diaries, perhaps, and you will jot down whatever you have as feelings or recollections or impressions of these days. And in any case your presence now and in this sort of atmosphere is not a source of pleasure to us. This does not make us happy. What would make us happy would be to see you back in your countries, or back in Baghdad in the normal way you used to do.

S: What is your name? I: Ian S: So please forgive us because we, like you, have our own children like Ian and Stuart and we also have our own women like you and have our own families and we know how you feel, but we are trying to prevent a war from happening and we hope that you, as guests, wont't be here for too long. Now I'm prepared to listen to whatever you have to say and to answer any questions you may have. Unidentified woman: First and foremost, we appreciate that he (Saddam) has come in person simply because no one else has been able to answer our questions. S: I am here to answer all your questions. UW: We have school-going children. Here, my son's got two sons. School begins in about a week's time and on the first of September and some of them are in the middle of important exams and that itself is going to cause immense problems. S: We hope that your presence here is not going to be long. ... If by the time schooling begins and you are still here in Iraq, we are going to (go to) unusual efforts to make sure that the children are not deprived of their continued schooling. And we will send to you experts from the Ministry of Education to see the curricula and the levels of schooling in which your children are so that everything will be prepared for the children not to lose the opportunity of school. All religions urge us to learn more and more and in our religion the first time God Almighty addressed his prophet Mohammed, praise be on his soul, through Gabriel as God said to Mohammed through Gabriel: Read. So reading and learning is a fundamental thing in the life of man and we know what it means. One would have wish that the kind of coincidence which occurred to you should have been reversed. ... But it has happened, and we are faced with the outcome of acts some of which have come by chance, by pure coincidence and some which have come actually by deliberate feeling. But we, for our part, will try to treat you in the same way as we treat Iraqis because you are not hostages here. We want nothing from Britain or the U.S. We want nothing from them. They owe us nothing. We owe them nothing. (A) question should be addressed to them: what has Iraq taken from you that has made you come with your forces threatening Iraq and the lands and territory of God and Moslems? What has Iraq done to deserve this? We want nothing from London or from any English-speaking ... we have take nothing away from the U.S.

UW2: We're very concerned about our families at home. We don't mind that we're ... we realize that we're of unknown destination but we would like them to know that we are fit and well. Our parents are old and in ill health. S: Yes, we shall make sure your messages will reach your family in England. As of now, you can write your letters and messages including photographs here, then you can send it to them, this is my instruction to my people here and it will be implemented as of now. ... S: I must be exact. That regrettably nobody has conducted any negotiation or dialogue with us yet. ... And (garble) he announced that Iraq would be prepared to get into negotiations. And the response ... was immediate. It was quick, the same way the U.S. has responded to all our entreaties. They said immediately that they were not prepared to conduct any dialogue with Iraq until Iraq has left Kuwait, as if Kuwait were Washington. Our response to this is that neither the Iraqis nor the Arabs in general would be prepared to accept dialogue and the blackmail or with preconditions. If anybody is prepared to come and talk to us, then they are welcome, but not to blackmail.

UW: If it takes awhile, will he (Saddam) at least consider sending the children back to school? S: You must rest assured the more days you spend here, your hopes should grow in the fact that we would be seeking, energetically seeking, a solution, any possibility, to resolve the situation and to clear it up. 1stman: You tell us that there has been no negotiation with the West. Can he tell us is there any contact with the Soviets? S: Yes, the East is more understanding as to the importance of dialogue, especially if it were to be done in an atmosphere of peace. We have so far issued two initatives and I'm sure you've seen those two initiatives, or known about them one of which is concerned with you in which I addressed myself to your families. One of the most regrettable ironies here is the fact that President Bush, who is the president of the greatest and biggest power on Earth as they say in fact, refused the initiative only a few hours after I issued it, even before asking for the text. In any case both Bush and others are going to learn a great deal from Iraq. On the human level and even on the level of more accurate planning or considered planning ... all of this will be the fact that the Iraqi people and Arabs in general will teach them how to be closer to God. And this is going to happen. I'm happy to have seen you now even though I would have wished to have met you under different circumstances.

If I didn't have Iraqi friends, and I didn't have to be in other places now I would have liked to have had lunch with you. ... Let's have a collective photograph to remember. You are accumulating memories of this occasion.

DOC.HEAD: Bias: A New Battle of the Bulge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CX6 sent Aug. 23.
DOC.TEXT: A convention _ er, smorgasbord _ of fat people? Funny, right? Not so, the National Association to Advance Fat Acceptance said Thursday as its members met to discuss their progress in the battle against bulge bias. The group, which claims some 3,000 members nationally, is dedicated to improving the quality of life for the obese, or nearly so, through public education, advocacy and support. Personal testimonials topped Thursday's agenda, as some 250 conference participants listened and applauded to the travails and successes of their fellow members. Catherine Johnson, of San Diego, described the embarrassment of having to ask for seat-belt extenders while traveling by air. Then there are the problems buying clothing. ``When you ask for a 44D (bra), sales clerks look at you and say, `We'll have to check in the back,''' Johnson said, as members laughed. Fat is serious business, said Bob and Linda Sponaugle, of Atco, N.J. They showed a letter they received from Hallmark agreeing to discontinue some greeting cards and a coffee mug offensive to fat people. ``It's your birthday and tons of women want you,'' said one of the cards on the outside. Inside was a picture of two fat women in clown costumes. ``These are the women,'' the card said. Frances White, a 340-pound belly dancer from San Francisco, told attendees her six-member dance troupe performs at private parties, festivals and restaurants. ``We call ourselves the `Voluptuous Jewels,''' the 47-year-old White said. ``We perform any place, any time _ as long as we get paid.'' Among those attending the session Thursday, called ``Our Victories: Public and Private,'' was a Baltimore woman who recently had to take a driver's test for a second time, to prove she was not too fat to function behind the wheel. ``I'm not phony,'' said Regina Guy, who ran into trouble with the Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration after being pulled over because of faulty car headlights. ``I'm not afraid to say I'm a fat person,'' said Guy, who has threatened to sue over the July incident. Another woman said her fight for the rights of fat people goes to the U.S. Supreme Court this fall. Sharon Russell, a former nursing student, sued a Rhode Island college where she said she was forced to sign a weight-loss contract and then told to leave the school when she failed to shed weight. Russell, now 25 and a pediatric nurse, was awarded $44,000 by a lower court. The case against Salve Regina College goes to the Supreme Court on appeal from the college in October. The money was not the important part, she told the crowd, which gave her a standing ovation. ``It's more important that people recognize that size discrimination is a valid issue,'' Russell said. ``There's nothing in the law right now about size. It only lists race, creed, religion, color.'' The group's annual convention runs through Sunday and includes a fashion show, a presentation on the dangers of dieting, and workshops in aerobics and belly dancing. Also on the agenda: organizing a grassroots letter-writing campaign against products, media coverage and advertising with an anti-fat bias.

DOC.HEAD: Matchcover Collectors Widespread, Little-Known, Fraternity
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Bobbie MacKenzie started out simply enough, stuffing handfuls of matchbooks into a little box as mementoes of trips and special nights out. Thousands of matchbooks later, she got serious. ``Like every other collector, I thought I was the only one doing this,'' recalled MacKenzie, one of about 500 matchbook cover collectors meeting in Springfield this week. ``Matchcover collecting is probably one of the biggest hobbies in the world but one of the least known,'' said Chuck Ledger, chairman of the 50th Annual Rathkamp Matchcover Society meeting. ``Suddenly you find out that there are people who do this,'' he said. ``It becomes very engrossing after a while.'' The Rathkamp Matchcover Society traces its roots to 1939, when a group of enthusiasts visited the Brooklyn Navy Yard in New York to pick up service and ship matchbooks and visit the New York World's Fair. An informal meeting was held that year at the home of Henry Rathkamp of Newport, R.I., who died in 1940. ``A group of the fellows got together and thought it would be kind of neat to go to the Navy yards because it was World War II and there was a lot of matchcovers available at that time,'' Ledger said. ``They had such a good time doing it that they decided to make it an annual thing.'' Today, the society has more than 1,500 members in 16 countries. On Thursday, groups of collectors ruffled through stacks of free matchcovers piled up on ``grab tables'' and wandered past exhibits. The covers varied from scantily clad ``girlies'' of the 1940s to advertisements urging Americans to buy war bonds and ``Remember Pearl Harbor.'' There were rafts of matchcovers commemorating battleships and nostalgic covers plugging Big Band groups. More modern displays included complete sets of hotel chains and shiny gold and silver foil covers. One of the club's oldest members, 81-year-old Bob Oliver, began collecting matchcovers in 1932 after he spied a shiny gold cover on the ground at the Brooklyn Navy Yard. From that casual start, Oliver, who now lives in Mira Loma, Calif., became an avid collector, once traveling 87 miles in Manhattan as he and his son collected matchbooks from different hotels. Most collectors strip the books of matches, hence the term ``matchcover.'' Some amass labels from matchboxes. Serious collectors call themselves ``phillumenists.'' Explaining their hobby to outsiders can be difficult, Ledger said. ``They think we're crazy, that's the first reaction,'' he said. ``It's followed very closely by ``well, what are they worth?' My standard answer is they're not worth a darn thing.'' In fact, matchcover collectors call their passion ``the poor man's hobby.'' Auction prices generally range in the tens of dollars, rather than the hundreds. Collectors, many of whom are retirees, said the most important thing about matchcover collecting is the friendships that go with it. ``The key to this whole thing is the word hobby,'' Ledger said.

DOC.HEAD: South Africa's Whites Watch Black Violence From Sidelines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Although violence surrounds them, many whites are watching the savage fighting between black factions as if it were happening in another country. Some whites worry about the turmoil and what it means for South Africa and the chances of a peaceful future. Others say it proves the 5 million whites cannot share political power with the 30 million blacks. Many whites just shake their heads and ignore the fighting. ``It's terrible. There's no need for it, but there's nothing we can do,'' said Jane King, a white secretary. In the white suburbs, the fighting is something residents just read about in newspapers or watch on television. Some 500 blacks have been killed and at least 1,400 injured in fighting in black townships around Johannesburg this month. The segregation of neighborhoods and the positioning of black townships in a belt around Johannesburg has kept the killing at a distance, even though some white and black areas are just a few hundred yards apart. Many whites rarely mix with blacks unless the blacks are workers or servants. But Moira Smith, a white woman who saw children fleeing fighting in the Katlehong township, was devastated by the scene. ``There was blood on their clothes. I will never forget the absolutely haunting look of terror in their eyes. It was the most dreadful thing I have ever seen,'' she said. Whites opposed to ending apartheid say whites will be killed if a black government ever takes power. A white woman looking at a picture of armed black fighters while reading a newspaper in a shop exploded with anger. ``Look at them ... And they want our country. It's sickening,'' she said. Some whites have written to newspapers warning the country is on the brink of war. ``I can think of no parallel in recent history where a ruling powerful minority voluntarily abdicates control in the full knowledge that by so doing they are condemning themselves to permanent political subjugation by a largely semi-literate Third World majority,'' said a letter to The Citizen newspaper signed ``Alarmed and Disturbed.'' J. Allen said in another letter, ``For how long is the white electorate going to allow this anarchic situation to continue?'' President F.W. de Klerk is negotiating with the African National Congress on ending the apartheid system of racial segregation and sharing power with blacks. The latest fighting has pitted Zulu supporters of the conservative Inkatha movement against Xhosas, many of them tied to the ANC, the largest black opposition group. In the eastern province of Natal, black-on-black violence still continues after five years of fighting and some 5,000 deaths. The pro-apartheid Conservative Party, the main opposition white party, has attempted to use the black violence to bolster its challenge to de Klerk. It says the violence vindicates its position that a black government would lead to anarchy and bloodshed. ``If one white person dies it will be on the government's conscience. We will mobilize our people and stop them with violence,'' said party spokesman Koos van der Merwe in a recent speech. But so far there has been little indication of what impact the black violence is having on white political opinion. Government officials say the majority of whites still support de Klerk's reforms. But political observers have expressed fears of a bloody power struggle between rival black groups if white rule ends. ``Nobody in his right mind can this time blame apartheid or the police. This is a bloodletting between black and black that is something no one can excuse,'' said The Citizen newspaper in an Aug. 20 editorial.

DOC.HEAD: List of Foreign Forces Dispatched to Persian Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is the breakdown of the multinational force in the Persian Gulf: UNITED STATES

The U.S. Air Force general in charge of transporting troops to Saudi Arabia, Gen. Hansford T. Johnson, said Tuesday at least 35,000 troops were already in Saudi Arabia or en route. Deployments could go as high as 250,000. They include elements of the 82nd and 101st Airborne Divisions, the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, the 11th Air Defense Artillery Brigade and the 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment. Also dispatched to the gulf were a contingent of 45,000 Marines. The American fleet in the gulf and Arabian Sea waters immediately outside it totals about 30 ships, including three aircraft carriers, a battleship armed with Tomahawk cruise missiles, more than a dozen missile cruisers, destroyers, supply ships and an undisclosed number of submarines. Two hospital ships are sailing for the gulf. Another seven ships are expected in the Mediterranean. The Pentagon has also sent 22 Stealth fighter-bombers and dozens of other aircraft. BRITAIN

The British, who have a flotilla permanently in the gulf, have contributed a destroyer armed with Sea Dart missiles and two Frigates armed with Exocet missiles. Three minesweepers and four support vessels are en route, but the minesweepers are expected to stay in the eastern Mediterranean.. Also dispatched were three squadrons of Tornado and Jaguar fighter-bombers. A squadron totals 12-16 planes. One squadron is based in Saudi Arabia and the Jaguars are at Thumrait airbase in neighboring Oman. The third squadron is expected to arrive from a base in West Germany to Bahrain within a week. FRANCE

It has expanded its force in the gulf region to nine ships, including the aircraft carrier Clemenceau with anti-tank helicopters, a guided-missile cruiser and two destroyers equipped with anti-ship Exocet missiles, one frigate and two corvettes. One company of 180 paratroopers has been sent to the United Arab Emirates for reconnaissance, but military sources said their role could change. They are equipped for chemical warfare. GULF COOPERATION COUNCIL (Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Oman, United Arab Emirates, Qatar and until Aug. 2, Kuwait) A rapid deployment force of up to 10,000 troops based in northeast Saudi Arabia. They would be supported by Saudi Arabian forces. SOVIET UNION
So far, Moscow has sent an Udaloy-class destroyer armed with surface-to-air missiles and an anti-submarine ship. Further deployments have not been ruled out. EGYPT
It has sent 4,000 ground troops. MOROCCO
1,200 ground troops sent. SYRIA
2,000 ground troops sent. AUSTRALIA
Two-guided missile frigates and a supply ship are en route. BANGLADESH
1,200 ground troops promised. BELGIUM
Two minehunters and a supply ship left for the gulf last week. CANADA
Two destroyers and a supply ship are heading for the gulf. GREECE
Athens has said it will send its top frigate, the Limnos, to join the multinational armada, but it has put off deciding on the departure date. ITALY
Two frigates, two corvettes and a support ship are en route. JAPAN

Its post World War II constitution bars it from sending troops overseas. But it has said it is willing to pay some of the costs and send medical teams, as it did during the tanker war during the final years of the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. NETHERLANDS
It has sent one air defense frigate and one standard frigate sailed Monday. Expected to arrive next week. PAKISTAN

Has promised troops, but not said how many or when they would leave. Reports in Pakistan estimate the force at 5,000 men. The government-in-exile of Afghanistan based in Pakistan said it will send 2,000 mujahedeen fighters from Afghanistan. No departure date set. SPAIN
Spain is sending one frigate and two corvettes. Reportedly set to leave ports Sunday. WEST GERMANY
Its constitution bars sending its troops outside NATO's areas of operations, so it plans to send several minesweepers to the eastern Mediterranean.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaiti Prince Says Countrymen Arming for Liberation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
Eds: This is based on a pool report
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait's government in exile is ``alive and well'' and forming a liberation army to help in any military action to free the country from Iraqi occupation, the Kuwaiti crown prince says. ``We will fight and fight and fight until we drive out the aggressors from our country,'' Prince Saad Abdullah al Sabah said Thursday. ``We the Kuwaitis will never submit or surrender to threats or to aggression or to occupation.'' Such talk is taken lightly here. One Saudi official, for example, said, ``Kuwait has a stealth army _ nobody's ever seen it.'' But Abdullah said some Kuwaitis who fled their homeland after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion already are going back to help with a resistance movement. Others, he said, are planning to arm themselves and join the multinational force defending Saudi Arabia. ``We will be reorganizing, rearming, reequipping with necessary arms to take part as an advance team in liberating our country,'' he said. Abdullah, the No. 2 official of the Kuwaiti government, met with reporters at a hotel in a Saudi mountain resort. The hotel, heavily guarded by Saudi military police, is serving as the headquarters for the Kuwaiti royal family. Another family member said the government-owned Kuwait petroleum company would be operated from London during the Iraqi occupation. A third member of the al Sabah family, speaking privately, said the Kuwaiti government would prefer that the United States attack Iraq and cut off its supply lines to Kuwait, ultimately forcing a withdrawal from Kuwait. ``We hope we do not have to destroy our country with war to get it back,'' he said. Abdullah said two or three members of the al Sabah royal family had been arrested in Kuwait. Aides said the Emir of Kuwait was in the hotel but would not meet with reporters. Although many Kuwaitis have taken refuge in Saudi Arabia and other nations, Abdullah declared: ``The Kuwaiti government is alive and well.'' ``We will do everything,'' he said. ``We are willing to sacrifice everything, not only our money and our funds but also our blood to liberate our country.'' Abdullah implored world leaders to enforce economic sanctions against Iraq and said he believed Iraq's Saddam Hussein would use his troops in Kuwait to satisfy his ``aggressive designs'' on Saudi Arabia. ``The unjustified and unlawful aggression has shown to all the world the real designs and the real expansionist ambitions of the Iraqi regime,'' he said. A Kuwaiti resistance movement, he said, ``is growing day by day. It has been escalating and will continue to escalate.'' Before Abdullah spoke, Ali Jaber al Sabah, a member of the royal family who serves as marketing director for the government-owned Kuwait Petroleum Co., said Kuwaitis still in their country have reported that two palaces are being used as ``concentration camps'' for women and children arrested at demonstrations. Jaber said recent reports indicate food is getting scarce in Kuwait but that looting was not as common as in the days immediately following the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Kurdish Problems Play Role In Turkey's Gulf Crisis Policy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In shaping their policies on the gulf crisis, Turkish leaders had on their minds the nation's problems with its large Kurdish minority, according to official sources and commentators. They suggest that Turkey is taking an active role in the crisis now so that it will be listened to later. According to these commentators, Turkey wants to make sure that any new order that might emerge in the region does not include an independent state for Kurds. So far, Turkey has refrained from any military involvement in the crisis, triggered by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, but this option has not been ruled out. But the NATO ally gave a major push to an international economic embargo by cutting off two Iraqi oil pipelines across its territory. It also imposed a trade ban and forbade Iraq, its neighbor, from using Turkish roads or airspace to transport goods. Many Turks, including opposition party leaders, have questioned the swiftness of these moves. They say Turkey's longstanding policy of not antagonizing Mideast neighbors may have been jettisoned for dubious returns and without sufficient deliberation. President Turgut Ozal, however, thought this was no time for procrastination and staying on the sidelines, sources close to the president report. The reasoning goes this way: The United States appears determined to bring down Iraq's Saddam Hussein and make the Persian Gulf oilfields secure. Probably this will lead to war. A peace conference will eventually follow, maybe carving up Iraq and setting up a new order in the region. Turkey would like to sit at the conference table to make sure that an independent Kurdistan does not emerge and national interests are not jeopardized. ``Those who say `Let's not get involved' should also answer the question how Turkey could prevent it if the idea was brought to a conference table for the establishment of a Kurdish state,'' said Ertugrul Ozkok on Monday in the independent Istanbul daily Hurriyet. Similar commentaries appeared in other papers after Ozal gave a background briefing to commentators and editors of Turkish newspapers over the weekend. An estimated 20 million Kurds live in an area where the borders of Turkey, the Soviet Union, Iran, Iraq and Syria converge. Turkey has the largest group, an estimated 10 million out of a population of 55 million. Several thousand guerrillas, members of the Marxist Kurdish Labor Party, PKK, have been fighting for an independent Kurdish state in Turkey's southeastern provinces. About 2,500 civilians, security personnel and guerrillas have been killed since the fighting began in 1984. The guerrillas operate from bases in Iraq and Syria, staging hit-and-run attacks on Turkish settlements and military convoys. The mainly Kurdish local population basically remains loyal to the central Turkish government. But they have been complaining of being caught in the middle of the guerrilla war, suffering mistreatment from the security forces, and facing bullets from the guerrillas. Also, the Kurds are demanding some form of cultural autonomy, allowing them to use their language publicly without harassment. Currently they cannot speak Kurdish in official places or use it in broadcasts, education and publications. They also want increased state investments to improve the economic lot of their backward region. These demands have received support from the main opposition Social Democrat Populist Party. Before the outbreak of the gulf crisis, the United States appeared to be supporting Kurdish aspirations, giving them voice in a congressional report on human rights issued last spring. On the Iraqi side, the Kurds fought the Baghdad government during the eight-year Iran-Iraq war. Shortly after a cease-fire with Iran two years ago, Iraq attacked its Kurdish population with chemical weapons. Some 60,000 Kurds fleeing chemical bomb attacks took refuge in Turkey and about 40,000 still remain in refugee camps in southeastern Turkey.

DOC.HEAD: Mecham Still Alive in Gubernatorial Race
DOC.TEXT: Reports of the political demise of ousted former governor Evan Mecham may have been premature. The feisty former car dealer's campaign to reclaim the Arizona governor's office is very much alive and he remains in the thick of the five-way race for the Republican nomination. ``He has a good chance. He has a very good chance,'' said Phoenix pollster Earl de Berge. Other pollsters and consultants are careful to hedge their bets. ``If the turnout is under 35 percent, Mecham could win it,'' said Bruce Merrill, director of the media research center at Arizona State University. Major polls show that millionaire land developer Fife Symington is leading the GOP race, with Mecham battling former congressman Sam Steiger for second place and two other candidates trailing. Former Phoenix Mayor Terry Goddard is the odds-on favorite to win the Democratic primary, facing only token opposition. The governor's race was thrown wide open when Democrat Rose Mofford, the former secretary of state who inherited Mecham's job in 1988, decided not to seek election this year. Polls show large numbers of Republicans still have not made up their minds less than a month before the Sept. 11 primary. Thirty-two percent remained undecided, according to de Berge's latest survey, and Merrill's most recent poll showed 43 percent undecided. Mecham, 66, captured the governor's office in 1986 on his fifth try. But his term was cut short in April 1988 when he was impeached by the state House and convicted by the Senate of misusing money from supporters and interfering with a police investigation of an alleged death threat by one of his aides. His opponents were quick to pronounce Mecham politically dead, but polls consistently have shown that he maintained the base of support that helped him win the three-way gubernatorial race four years ago. None of the GOP candidates has done extensive advertising, and all seem to be having trouble raising money, analysts say. ``Developers, banks, savings and loans, most of the big sources of money have dried up this year,'' Merrill said. ``Most of those people are struggling to save their own butts.'' Some potential contributors reportedly have become reluctant to give to Republicans because they believe ``as Ev Mecham rises in the polls, it makes a Goddard win in November almost a certainty,'' said Jeff Hill, a Republican state senator and political consultant. Political consultant Bob Robb said Mecham is the candidate who will suffer the least from a lack of contributions. ``Mecham has all the support he's going to get,'' Robb said. ``People have already made up their minds about him, one way or the other.'' Mecham also is closely identified with many of this year's key issues _ including the Martin Luther King holiday, taxes and voter dissatisfaction with government. Mecham has campaigned actively against the King holiday, passed by the Legislature this year. He spearheaded the referendum drive to place the holiday on the November ballot, and could cash in at the polls on a strong anti-holiday sentiment among Republicans. The King holiday has become a partisan issue, with Republicans generally opposing it and Democrats in support, Merrill said. Mecham's campaign also got a boost when the Legislature passed a $265 million tax increase at a time when the state's economy already was suffering, analysts say. ``I have never seen so much dissatisfaction with incumbents, with government,'' Merrill said. ``I have never seen an anti-incumbent feeling as high as it is this year.'' Mecham's best shot at winning the primary is for voter turnout to be low, pollsters say. Merrill said a generally lackluster campaign almost ensures that most voters will stay at home. ``It's not unfair to say that none of the candidates has captured the imagination of the voters,'' he said. Hill agreed that a low voter turnout would favor Mecham, who appears to have the most solid core of support of any of the candidates. ``Mecham's base makes him real tough,'' Hill said. ``If he is able to hold onto those people he'll be hard to beat if there's no turnout.''

DOC.HEAD: People Talking About Saving Oil, But Not Much Action Yet
DOC.TEXT: The Mideast crisis has people talking about conservation again. But few are actually doing anything about it. Phone lines started ringing at energy conservation advice lines right after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, as consumers fearing higher prices sought tips to cut their consumption. In Minneapolis, the Metropolitan Transit Commission used Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's picture and the slogan ``Stop pumping him up,'' in an advertising campaign to suggest that people use city buses rather than their cars. So far, however, little suggests people are driving less, investing in more efficient home heating or following the Bush administration's cautious suggestions for gasoline savings. ``They aren't feeling the pinch as they did in the 1970s,'' said Mary Ann Dittmer, director of communications for the Washington-based Alliance to Save Energy. ``They aren't standing in line for gasoline. Prices for home heating oil haven't gone through the roof.'' Nonetheless, she said, ``We have received many phone calls from consumers who want to do something.'' Callers are sent brochures telling how better light bulbs, programmable thermostats, special windows and high-efficiency burners can save money and help reduce imports of foreign oil. The Energy Department said calls to its toll-free energy-saving tips line went from about 500 a week to 1,200 a day immediately after the invasion. At the gas and electric utility Consolidated Edison in New York, spokesman Marty Gitten said some callers are thinking about converting from fuel oil to natural gas heat, as happened after the oil shocks of the 1970s. ``We've had a surge in people interested in converting to gas heating,'' he said. ``I can't say it's going to translate into action.'' The story is much the same at the gas pumps. ``I think about it, but I'm trimmed down to what I can to,'' said Gary Oddi of Reston, Va., after driving into a gas station in Washington. ``My wife and I share a car.'' ``I have a certain driving pattern and there's not a lot I can do about it,'' said the next customer, William Leedy, as he pumped gas into his car. ``I think I've got my automobile usage down as low as it'll go.'' In Minneapolis, bus revenues for the first two weeks in August were about the same as last year's _ but officials said that was an improvement, because revenues earlier had been falling. Last week, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins proposed steps to boost U.S. oil production while asking drivers to trim their gasoline use by joining car pools, obeying speed limits and keeping their tires properly inflated. Geoff Sundstrom, a spokesman at American Automobile Association headquarters in Orlando, Fla., said regular nationwide checks show no signs that drivers are cutting back to save on gasoline. ``The stations are telling us they do not see a change in the sales pattern for this time of year,'' Sundstrom said. ``People aren't panic buying, but at this point they don't seem to be conserving, either.'' Auto sales have dropped this month, but analysts say that's because of general economic worries, not concern about gas guzzlers. ``People are not switching to smaller cars. There's no evidence of that whatsoever,'' said Joel Pitcoff, manager of research and analysis at Ford Motor Co. A Wall Street Journal-NBC News poll published Thursday found that 80 percent of those questioned said they favored ``tougher conservation measures that would mean less gas consumption,'' but it was not clear what steps would really be popular if enacted. The same poll found just 32 percent backing a higher gas tax to encourage conservation, with 62 percent opposed and 6 percent not sure. Secretary Watkins and President Bush have been careful not to let any note of sacrifice enter their calls for conservation, frustrating activists who want more vigorous steps. Bush told reporters Wednesday that now is a good time to conserve energy, but he does not plan to give up using his speedboat and doesn't think Americans should change their vacation plans. ``I'd have to lay part of the blame on the administration for not making conservation seem as urgent as it is,'' said Ms. Dittmer of the Alliance to Save Energy. ``While the president finally used the words `energy conservation' as U.S. troops were on their way to the Persian Gulf, he has so far failed to propose any significant policies to reduce dependence on oil,'' Christopher Flavin, an energy expert at Worldwatch Institute, said at a news conference Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Bill Cosby doesn't care for smart alecks like Bart Simpson, and says the Huxtables are ready to take him on. Beginning this week, Fox TV moves its runaway hit, ``The Simpsons,'' from Sunday nights to a Thursday night slot, pitting it against NBC's hit ``The Cosby Show.'' Cosby posed for the cover of Entertainment Weekly wearing a T-shirt with Bart Simpson on it declaring, ``Yo, Bill!'' But he had little praise for the animated series. ``The mean-spirited and cruel think this is `the edge,' and their excuse is, that's the way people are today,'' Cosby said in an interview being published next week. ``But why should we be entertained by that? TV should be moving in a direction from the Huxtables forward, not backward.'' Cosby said he's been re-energizing ``The Cosby Show'' with nine new writers, as a matter of principle. ``I'm working harder and enjoying it more. And whether the audience is there in the numbers or not, I am proud of what we've done,'' Cosby said. ``All of the changes were made B.B. _ Before Bart,'' he said.

Roseanne Barr's former husband filed a palimony lawsuit seeking at least $15 million from the comic and $3 million from her new husband, Tom Arnold. William Pentland's 14-year marriage to Miss Barr ended in divorce in January. In a lawsuit filed Thursday in Superior Court, Pentland claimed he is entitled to half her property as well as support payments. ``When they started living together they had nothing,'' said celebrated divorce lawyer Marvin Mitchelson, who represents Pentland. ``They agreed to be lifetime companions, confidants and share everything they have. We are trying to enforce that agreement.'' The lawsuit accused Arnold of undermining the marriage from January 1979 by telling Miss Barr her husband was ``unreliable, non-supportive and a detriment.'' Miss Barr and Pentland, a writer, were married in 1975. Their three teen-age children live with Miss Barr. A divorce and custody hearing was scheduled for Sept. 18. ``I really feel this lawsuit is specious and is just an opportunity to get publicity,'' said Miss Barr's attorney, Arlene Colman-Schwimmer. Miss Barr plays a sarcastic, overweight housewife on ABC-TV's popular series ``Roseanne.''

Tango composer and musician Astor Piazzolla, flown home in a coma from a clinic in Paris, has regained consciousness and may recover, his son said. ``Right now, my father is listening to a work by Bach,'' Daniel Piazzolla was quoted Thursday as telling the newspaper La Nacion. ``He is conscious in every sense, and his recovery seems almost a miracle.'' Piazzolla, 69, is the country's best-known tango composer and a master of the bandoleon, the Argentine accordion that forms the instrumental basis for most tango music. He suffered a brain hemorrhage in early August while in Paris between concerts in England and Italy and has been hospitalied since.

Todd Bridges, who played Gary Coleman's brother Willis on NBC's ``Diff'rent Strokes'' for eight years, has been acquitted of assault in the shooting of a narcotics dealer at a drug den. It was the second trial clearing the actor of criminal charges. ``I feel a lot of relief that it's over,'' Bridges said shortly after the Superior Court jury announced its verdict Thursday. Bridges was retried in the February 1989 shooting of convicted drug dealer Kenneth ``Tex'' Clay at a Los Angeles drug house. Clay recovered from gunshot wounds to his arms and chest. In the first trial, jurors acquitted Bridges of attempted murder but deadlocked on the charge of assault with a deadly weapon. Prosecutors retried him on the assault charge. Deputy District Attorney William Hodgman contended that Bridges shot Clay because he allegedly stole the actor's BMW. But defense attorney Johnnie Cochran argued his client was in the middle of a four-day cocaine binge during the attack at the drug den, and that someone else shot Clay.

Lionel Aldridge, a former pro football player who suffered mental health problems and became a drifter, led a rally to raise funds for the mentally ill. Aldridge, 49, a defensive end for the Green Bay Packers from 1963 to 1971, marched Thursday with about two dozen other self-described ``mental health consumers'' to the office of Milwaukee County Executive Dave Schulz. The group sang Schulz a song to the tune of Bob Dylan's hit ``Blowin' In The Wind,'' describing the need to keep $200,000 in the 1991 county budget for a program to support those recovering from mental illness. Aldridge entered a psychiatric emergency ward in 1977 after his wife sued for divorce and underwent treatment for severe depression. He started drifting around the country in 1980, and ended up living among the down-and-out at the Milwaukee Rescue Mission. By 1985, however, he got a job at the Milwaukee post office, and later worked part-time as a radio sportscaster. He was inducted into the Packer Hall of Fame in 1988, and now spends his time speaking on behalf of the mentally ill.

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Kills At Least 105 in Coastal China
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Yancy has killed at least 105 people this week in coastal China, an official report said today. Heavy rains and flooding were blamed for the deaths in Fujian and Zhejiang provinces, the China Daily said. It said the typhoon was the most devastating storm to batter the two provinces, which have been hit several major storms this summer. The typhoon, which killed 13 people in Taiwan early in the week before heading for China, hit the Fujian coast three times in 24 hours Tuesday and Wednesday, previous reports said. More than 530 million people in the two provinces were directly affected by the storm, with economic losses estimated at $170 million, the China Daily said. In the Zhejiang city of Wenzhou alone, 61 people died and 264 were injured, it said. The report did not give details about the remaining deaths. In the two provinces, 494,000 acres of farmland have been flooded by heavy rains that in some areas topped 22 inches. An earlier report said the flooding would reduce Fujian's grain output this year by about 100 million pounds.

DOC.HEAD: Highway Safety Chief: More Police Needed to Spot Drugged Drivers
DOC.TEXT: More police need to be trained to detect drugs other than alcohol when they pull over suspicious drivers, but some state laws prevent such tests, the nation's top highway safety official says. Jerry R. Curry, head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said 26 communities in 10 states have police trained to spot both drugged and drunken drivers. But he said officers in 15 states and Puerto Rico may not be trained for drug detection because their laws either do not allow more than one chemical test or forbid testing for drugs other than alcohol when a driver is stopped on the highway. ``We encourage these states to change their laws during the next legislative cycle,'' Curry said in a statement released this week by his office. ``Drug-impaired drivers, like drunk drivers, cause crashes, injuries and deaths on our highways.'' Curry said studies indicate that 10 percent to 22 percent of all drivers in serious and fatal crashes have drugs other than alcohol in their systems, and many have alcohol as well as other drugs. Alcohol use has been found in accidents accounting for about half of the 45,000 annual traffic fatalities. Curry said that wherever possible, the federal government has been helping train police to test accurately for other drugs and present the evidence in court. More than 1,000 police officers have been trained in the communities, he said, with one-fourth of them certified to teach other officers. Officers trained in drug detection look for physical clues in suspects to determine which drug they have taken, Curry said, including analysis of the suspect's appearance, behavior, performance in physical tests, eyes and vital signs. Officers undergo a training course that consists of seven days of classroom study, followed by drug examination on people arrested on suspicion of drug impairment, he said. States that have communities where officers have received the training are Arizona, California, Colorado, Florida, Indiana, New York, Nevada, Texas, Utah and Virginia. States that have laws which would not allow for drug-detection training are Alabama, Alaska, Connecticut, Hawaii, Kentucky, Massachusetts, Mississippi, Montana, New Jersey, North Carolina, Oregon, South Dakota, Tennessee, Washington and West Virginia.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Ambassador on the Defensive
With PM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed Sadiq al-Mashat, like his boss Saddam Hussein, is very much on the defensive these days. The U.S.-educated diplomat, until recently one of the faceless legions of foreign representatives who swim unobtrusively in Washington's diplomatic backwaters, has been much in evidence as the world vilifies Iraq for one alleged transgression after another. In television appearances, letters to newspapers and embassy news conferences, the graying, mustachioed al-Mashat vigorously defends Iraqi policy. But ABC-TV newswoman Barbara Walters told The Washington Post after she interviewed al-Mashat that he dodged her questions. ``This ambassador obviously knows nothing,'' Walters said. Al-Mashat turns aside allegations that Iraq is violating international norms, most recently with Baghdad's announcement that Westerners will suffer alongside Iraqis if the U.N.-sanctioned economic embargo persists. ``When you deny our children food and milk, what do you expect?'' al-Mashat said Sunday in an assertive, sometimes bellicose interview on ABC-TV. Al-Mashat, ambassador to the United States since last September, said recently in Dossier magazine that his priority was to reverse ``a tide of unflattering press reports'' about his country. In a letter to The Washington Post last month, he said a July 5 op-ed piece on Iraq ``bordered upon irresponsible and dishonest journalism.'' He said Iraq's policy was one of deterrence in the face of many enemies, and that Baghdad was seeking only peace after a protracted, destructive war with Iran. He denied that Iraq had used poison gas on its Kurdish population and labeled as ``a cheap shot'' the Post writer's assertion that Iraq was giving office space to terrorist Abu Nidal. In a May 4 opinion piece in The New York Times, al-Mashat said ``many lies have been told about Iraq.'' He said Iraq does not have or intend to produce nuclear weapons and that Saddam ``has proposed the elimination of production, storage and use of all instruments of mass destruction _ specifically, a ban on all chemical, biological and nuclear weapons'' in the Middle East. Al-Mashat, 59, is a former ambassador to the United Kingdom, France and Austria. He also has held high-level posts in education and scientific research in his country. He was a professor of sociology at Baghdad University. He received a bachelor's and masters' degree in criminology at the University of California at Berkeley and a Ph.D. in sociology from the University of Maryland.

DOC.HEAD: America's Man in Baghdad Experienced in Hardship Posts
With PM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Joe Wilson has built a career on hardship posts, but nothing compares with his current job as America's top diplomat in Baghdad. Joseph C. Wilson IV, deputy chief of mission at the U.S. Embassy in Iraq, is Washington's ranking diplomat in Baghdad. He is the man who every day must confront Iraqi officials to tell them that Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait and release the 3,000 Americans held hostage in Iraq and Kuwait. With Ambassador April Glaspie out of the country, it was Wilson who went face-to-face with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein for two hours on Aug. 6, demanding that the safety of Americans be guaranteed and listening to Saddam's steely warnings against U.S. intervention. He has been out on the streets talking to and tracking down Americans, and is a frequent visitor to the Iraqi Foreign Ministry, where his appeals for access to Americans have been spurned. It's a heady task for the 40-year-old career diplomat, who once worked as a carpenter and served mainly in African backwaters before going to Iraq. President Bush, for one, believes Wilson has the right stuff. ``We've got a very able person there in Baghdad who is prepared to talk,'' Bush said at a Wednesday news conference. If the Iraqis want to open discussions on ending the crisis, ``well, there he is, available to talk.'' ``He can handle himself quite well in a crisis,'' said Jack Bryant, deputy executive director of the State Department Bureau of African Affairs and Wilson's longtime colleague. ``He can deal with anyone,'' including Saddam, Bryant said. ``Joe could go in and be very forceful.'' Wilson worked for a time as a carpenter in northern California after graduating from the University of California in 1972, Bryant said. He joined the Foreign Service in 1976 and was assigned to the French-speaking Africa desk because of his fluency in French. As a boy he had lived four years in France, when his father was a freelance reporter for the San Francisco Chronicle and other newspapers. Bryant said Wilson's first big assignment was doing the groundwork for Secretary of State Henry Kissinger's first African tour in the late 1970s. He was posted in turn to Niger, Togo and South Africa, and in 1982 became deputy chief of mission, or DCM, in the tiny central African state of Burundi. It was there he met his second wife, a French citizen friends say was of Vietnamese descent. In 1986 Wilson was appointed DCM in The Congo, a post he held until taking his first non-African position, as second-in-charge in Baghdad, in 1988. One foreign service colleague, who asked that his name not be used, said Wilson's lack of training in Middle East affairs should not affect his performance in the current crisis. ``He's very bright, very energetic. As a generalist he has a broad scope of things he has to take care of. He's certainly capable of standing up to Saddam Hussein to make any message, and he would do it unflinchingly.'' The foreign service officer said Wilson ``liked the challenge of a hardship environment. When you go to an African post you have more responsibility and Joe liked being a generalist.'' Another diplomat who worked with Wilson in The Congo said Wilson was ``a damned good DCM. He's an expert at managing the embassy inside while keeping contacts outside _ that's the kind of guy you want in this spot.'' Wilson's wife returned to her family in France soon after Iraq's invasion. His mother, Phyllis Wilson of the Palm Springs area, said she was able to talk to her son this week and ``he sounded great. He's in good spirits.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Envoy Left Behind in Kuwait as `Captain of the Ship'
With PM-Gulf-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Almost three years to the day since he arrived in Kuwait, Ambassador Nathaniel Howell, described by a State Department spokesman as ``captain of the ship,'' is prepared to stay with it as it sinks. The career Foreign Service officer elected to remain in his embassy to await today's expected arrival of Iraqi troops whose government says Kuwait has vanished along with the invisible shield that protected the diplomats there. But first Howell saw to the safe departure of most of the embassy staff in a 33-car caravan that took them from Kuwait City to Baghdad, Iraq. He then returned to wait. ``He's captain of the ship,'' State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Thursday. Howell, 50, has spent nearly half of his life in the Foreign Service, serving in Egypt, France, Belgium, Lebanon, Jordan, the United Arab Emirates and Algeria. He is married, the father of two and is a native of Virginia. He speaks Arabic. When he arrived in Kuwait on Aug. 25, 1987, U.S. warships were escorting that country's oil tankers through the Persian Gulf to protect them from attack by Iran, which was at war with Iraq. The following year, Howell was summoned to the Kuwaiti Foreign Ministry to listen to that government's complaints about U.S. policies, once over the refusal to allow Palestine Liberation Organization Chairman Yasser Arafat into the United States and another time to express ``extreme concern'' over American allegations that Iraq had used chemical weapons. ``Kuwait regrets the way the American media exploited such allegations to launch a campaign against Iraq at a time when neutral parties ... announced they did not find evidence that Iraq has used chemical weapons,'' Kuwait's Foreign Ministry said at the time. The Kuwaitis were worried that this would damage chances for peace between Iran and Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: US Farm Imports to Reach Record Levels
DOC.TEXT: The United States imported record levels of farm goods in the first half of this year but also increased its share of sales on the world market, the Agriculture Department says. Imports rose 6 percent at $13.5 billion to break a record set last year. The Agriculture Department predicts that purchases from foreign countries will reach $22 billion before the year is over, topping the record set last year of $21.5 billion. The freeze in the United States last winter was a big factor in increased imports. It drove up the average import unit values for fresh vegetables by 37 percent through April, said USDA. ``Tomato import unit values alone doubled in the first half of fiscal 1990,'' the department said. ``Fruit imports rose 10 percent in the first 7 months and will probably maintain that pace for the entire fiscal year, primarily due to higher orange juice imports.'' The Agriculture Department said beef imports from Australia were stronger than anticipated because of dry weather there, high prices in the United States and frozen beef storage problems in Japan. Other large quantity imports included live cattle from Canada and Mexico. On the other hand, more overseas sales of cotton, corn and vegetables offset decreases in wheat, soybeans, soybean meal, animals and dairy products to raise total exports to $25.2 billion during the first seven months of fiscal 1990, a 3 percent increase over the comparable period in 1989. ``U.S. export volume rose largely because of an increased U.S. share of world markets, rather than an increase in world demand,'' said USDA. ``China, Thailand, Argentina and Canada all relinquished market share to the United States, leaving what was likely the second largest U.S. share of world corn trade ever.'' Japan, America's best customer for the last three years, bought 21 percent of the agriculture products exported in 1989, USDA reported. ``Japan's 1989 purchases were more than double the value shipped to the Soviet Union, the second leading importer of U.S. farm products,'' it said. Japan spent more than $250 million on each of the following commodities: live animals and meat, feed grains, soybeans, fruits, cotton, wheat, hides and skins, feeds and fodders, vegetables and tobacco. The other top markets for U.S. farm products, in order, are Mexico, South Korea, Canada, The Netherlands, Taiwan and China.

The potato leafhopper, which attacks crops from the Northeast through the Corn Belt, has an enemy that may eventually be a cheaper way for farmers to destroy it than chemical pesticides. Zoophthora radicans, a fungus imported from Europe and South America, can kill the leafhopper in three to four days, according to entomologist Raymond Carruthers of the Agriculture Department's research service. The fungus spews spores that fall onto leafhoppers and also sticks to leaf surfaces where the pests might cross. ``Leafhoppers attack more than 200 crops, including potatoes and alfalfa,'' said Carruthers. ``Farmers in the Northeast and Midwest probably apply more insecticides to control potato leafhoppers than any other pest in alfalfa.''

_greater than WASHINGTON (AP) _ The Agriculture Department is authorizing construction of three telescopes on Arizona's Mt. Graham in the Coronado National Forest as long as the habitat of the endangered Mt. Graham red squirrel is not disrupted significantly. ``As a practical matter, this means that the project would be halted and consultation re-initiated if the project resulted in more than six squirrels being harmed in any year,'' said George M. Leonard, associate chief of the U.S. Forest Service. The University of Arizona proposed construction of the telescopes in 1984. The university said the project would significantly advance the state of astronomical science. Sponsors of the observatory include the Smithsonian Institution, the Vatican and the Max Planck Institute of West Germany. Leonard said the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service will monitor and report on the effect of construction on the squirrel population. He said a buffer zone around the observatory site would carry special restrictions.

DOC.HEAD: Draft Registration Jumps After U.S. Forces Sent to Middle East
DOC.TEXT: Draft registration jumped to 29 percent above average after U.S. forces were sent to Saudi Arabia, but there are no plans to restart the military draft because of the Persian Gulf crisis, the Selective Service says. Lew Brodsky, assistant director for public affairs at the Selective Service System, said 36,485 draft-eligible young men signed up during the week of Aug. 13-17, compared with a weekly average of 28,289 in the preceding 12 months. Brodsky said Selective Service officials assumed that the U.S. response to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait made young people more aware of the registration requirement. ``They may have thought that if a draft might be imminent they would want to get their names on the books,'' Brodsky said Thursday. However, he said, there are no plans to seek congressional approval for a draft, and there have been no discussions about it with the White House, the Defense Department or members of Congress. Sen.
