Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., has introduced a bill in most recent sessions of Congress to reinstate the draft, saying the present volunteer system puts the burden of military service unfairly on blacks and other minorities. John Patterson, Hollings' press secretary, said Hollings has not reintroduced the bill in this session and ``we have not talked about it in light of what just happened.'' Hollings was in South Carolina and not available, Patterson said. The last U.S. military draft ended in 1973. Under current law, men have to register when they reach 18, but it would take action by Congress before they could be drafted. Pentagon leaders have said in recent years that they do not favor a return to the draft and have told Congress they believe the nation can continue to attract enough recruits to avoid one. Samuel Lessey, director of Selective Service, told the Senate Armed Services Committee in 1987 that the aim of the service was to be able to produce the first inductee within 13 days _ and 100,000 within 30 days _ if a draft were instituted. He said 14 million to 15 million men were registered, about 96 or 97 percent of the total number eligible. Rep. Peter Defazio, D-Ore., introduced a bill in May to end draft registration, saying the need for it had been eliminated by the wave of democracy spreading through the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Neither DeFazio nor his spokesman could be reached Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Camp Opens Wilderness to Kids Who Depend on Medical Technology
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Maren cq in 2nd graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MP2
DOC.TEXT: Oxygen tanks, respirators and intravenous tubes share cabin space with sleeping bags and backpacks at S.K.I.P Camp, a retreat for children whose medical needs make them dependent on technology. ``They're doing things they thought they would never do,'' said Susan Spielman of Bloomington, whose 8-year-old daughter, Maren, prepared to go water skiing on Wednesday. The girl undertook the adventure although she suffers from central sleep apnea, a condition that requires she have a tracheostomy, or a permanent opening in her neck, so she can be connected to a respirator while she sleeps. The opening was covered and secured with a thick white towel for the water-skiing outing. The camp is a project of Sick Kids need Involved People, a New York-based national organization. In its fourth year, S.K.I.P. Camp offers children and their families a chance to break routines that often keep them sheltered from outdoor activities. ``So many of these kids were prisoners in their homes or hospitals,'' said camp director Barbara Donaghy, who volunteers her time along with the other 50 medical and 75 non-medical staffers running the one-week camp. Eighteen children from around the nation attended this year. Donaghy, a registered nurse and respiratory therapist, said the idea behind the camp is to balance improved technology with similar steps toward bettering patients' quality of life. ``Most of these kids would not have lived 10 years ago,'' she said. ``There's more and more technology. But we don't always follow through with other things.'' S.K.I.P Camp is unique because it involves entire families, doesn't focus on a specific disease and is run at no cost to campers, Donaghy said. The annual budget of about $50,000 is funded by donations and volunteer efforts. The 24-hour medical staff reassures parents that their children's needs will be met, despite the camp's rustic atmosphere. Families share living quarters in cabins where sophisticated machines hum alongside spartan bunk beds. At mealtimes, the campers, families and volunteers gather in a large dining hall. Youngsters whose medical conditions require they be fed intravenously sit next to others who chomp on peanut butter sandwiches, Jell-O and other camp fare. Betty Pankratz of Wichita, Kan., said the camp is giving new confidence to her 10-year-old son, Scott, who was born with a malfunction of his trachea and esophagus that requires he have a tracheostomy, receive oxygen and have supplemental feedings through a tube in his stomach. ``He fits right in,'' said Pankratz, whose husband, Glen, and 6-year-old son, Phillip, also attended the camp. ``It doesn't seem unusual for him to have to leave the group to take meds.'' ``It's a lot of fun, and I'm meeting people that I like,'' said Scott, who tried horseback riding, swimming, boating and other outdoor activities. ``I know I wouldn't be doing this stuff at home. ``There's really nothing to be afraid of,'' he said. Donaghy, who helped found S.K.I.P Camp in the Miami area four years ago, said she hopes the camp will let technology-dependent children focus on their abilities instead of their disabilities. Most of the campers' medical problems will continue throughout their lifetimes, but the camp experiences can show them how to overcome limitations. ``It doesn't have to stop your life,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Workers Find Uranium Leak at Sequoyah Fuels Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS penultimate graf to CORRECT Sen. to Rep. Synar
DOC.TEXT: Workers excavating storage tanks at a uranium processing plant found levels of radioactive uranium in underground water as much as 35,000 times higher than federal safety standards allow, officials said Thursday. Sequoyah Fuels Corp. Vice President Ron Adkisson said there was no danger to the public because the contamination was contained inside the plant's restricted area. None of the company's 243 workers were exposed to radiation, he said, and no evacuations were ordered at the plant, which is 60 miles southeast of Tulsa in a sparsely populated area. ``There's been no exposure to personnel,'' he said. ``There is no off-site danger.'' The U.S. Nuclear Regulatory Commision is investigating the discovery. Adkisson said workers discovered the contaminated water Wednesday, while the plant was in its annual shutdown for maintenance. Some of the water samples ranged from 1 to 8 grams of uranium per liter. Guidelines set by the NRC allow no more than 225 micrograms of uranium per liter. A gram contains 1 million micrograms. Adkisson said he didn't know when the company could reopen the factory, which refines uranium to be made into fuel rods for nuclear reactors. Plant officials believe the uranium leaked years ago from the solvent extraction building, where pure uranium is dissolved using an acid solvent. An acid-resistant floor installed in the building in 1984 would have prevented such leaks, Adkisson said. ``In some years past, very early in the operation, the material apparently ate through the floor and got through the substructure,'' Adkisson said. ``We discovered it yesterday.'' The NRC was notified the same day and sent an investigator from its Arlington, Texas office, he said. ``They have a fellow out right now. He's just trying to figure out what's going on, trying to assess best he can, just like us.'' Sequoyah Fuels is owned by General Atomics of San Diego, which bought the plant from Kerr-McGee Corp. in 1988. In January, as many as 20,000 pounds of uranium tetrafluoride powder spilled at the plant after a valve failed and the powder was dumped into a too-small container. A small amount of the powder was released into the air through a ventilator, and one worker underwent hospital testing. The company suspended operations but did not notify the NRC until the following day, drawing criticism from Democratic U.S. Rep. Mike Synar, whose district includes the plant. In 1986, an accident killed one man who inhaled toxic fumes after an overfilled cylinder of uranium hexafluoride exploded. Thirty-five of 42 workers at the plant suffered kidney damage, and 100 people living or traveling near the plant required medical treatment. The plant was closed nearly a year.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Embassy in Kuwait: Functional, Not Fancy
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Embassy in Kuwait _ the latest storm center of the growing Persian Gulf crisis _ is recalled by diplomats who served there as a cluster of modest buildings across a six-lane highway from the beach. It normally has a contingent of about a half-dozen Marines, who were withdrawn Thursday as today's Iraqi-set deadline for the closing of foreign embassies in Kuwait approached. ``It's not a very fancy embassy, but a very functional one,'' said Francois Dickman, a retired Foreign Service officer who was U.S. ambassador to Kuwait from 1979 to 1983. ``It's not one of the new fortresses that many American embassies around the world are increasingly,'' said another diplomat who has served in Kuwait, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Dickman, speaking by telephone from his home in Laramie, Wyo., said the embassy is in a compound surrounded by a wall eight or nine feet high. It is a rectangle running north and south with the east side facing Gulf Road, a six-lane highway. Just east of the highway is the Persian Gulf. ``It's not much of a beach,'' said Dickman. The compound is roughly two city blocks wide by four blocks long, the former ambassador said. Directly to the south is a Hilton hotel, seven or eight stories high. The only entrance to the compound is a steel gate on the west side, about 100 feet from the southwest corner. ``As you enter, you see the chancery,'' he said. ``The chancery is one story. It was a plain stone building with a corrugated roof.'' Dickman said the road then bends north to the site of the administration building, a brick structure that was destroyed in a terrorist bombing on Dec. 12, 1983. The building has since been rebuilt. Also in the compound are the two-story ambassador's residence, a warehouse, a parking lot and a garden just east of the ambassador's house, in which vegetables were grown in Dickman's day. There also is a swimming pool. In the 1983 bombing, Shia Moslem terrorists crashed a truck loaded with gas cylinders through the steel gates. It smashed into the administration building, demolishing it and also damaging the chancery and warehouse, Dickman said. Six people were killed, including the truck driver, but none were Americans. Since then the security system has been strengthened, according to the diplomat who spoke anonymously. ``I suppose a tank, like an Iraqi tank, could get through, but it has been reinforced, the wall has been upgraded and the entry gates,'' this diplomat said. Dickman said that when he was ambassador the Marines lived a block away from the embassy compound, but he later heard they were living within the enclosure. He applauded the decision to withdraw them. ``It makes sense,'' he said. ``These Marines can't do anything. There are only six of them. It is possible the number has been increased, but normally it is only a contingent of six.'' ``They don't really serve as guards,'' Dickman said. ``They man the entrance to the chancery and in the evening they make sure that things are locked up and provide elementary security.'' The diplomats obviously had pleasant memories of the place. ``The time I was there we had a little victory garden along the edge of the wall,'' said Dickman. ``I remember it being very green and pretty,'' said his colleague.

DOC.HEAD: Israelis Stock up on Chemical Antidote, Emergency Supplies
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israelies are stocking up on emergency supplies including baking soda _ an antidote to chemical weapons _ while government broadcasts urge citizens to prepare for a possible Iraqi chemical attack. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Thursday the Persian Gulf crisis is ``mounting toward a peak'' and caused a minor flurry when he appeared to hint a preemptive Israeli strike against Iraq was possible. When questioned, however, he said Israel had no such intentions. In the government's first public response to Israelis' growing fear of war, a top civil defense officer urged Israelis to stockpile food and prepare their homes for a possible Iraqi chemical attack. Later, the government put out an announcement saying the radio and television statements weren't intended as orders to citizens, but as general advice. The announcement described how to mix a homemade antidote to chemical weapons. Newspapers published advice on how to seal a home against chemical attack with tape and how to rig a makeshift gas mask using a handkerchief or towel soaked with water and baking soda. At the Supersol supermarket in downtown Jerusalem, baking soda was sold out Thursday, and shop workers said they were selling four or five times more baking soda than usual. At Houminer's hardware store in Jerusalem, manager Avraham Yosha reported a 40 percent increase in the sale of insulating tape, emergency lights, cans for water, as well as portable toilets and wash basins for shelters and sealed rooms. Addressing visiting American contributors to the United Jewish Appeal at the Parliament, Shamir said: ``In the circumstances, our major task is to prevent war, or to preempt it and if, heaven forbid, these two fail, and there is no alternative, we have to win quickly and decisively.'' But speaking later to reporters, Shamir qualified those remarks, saying Israel's aim was still ``to prevent any military involvement of our country'' in spite of Iraq's attempts to drag it into the three-week-old crisis. Asked specifically whether Israel planned a preemptive strike in the aftermath of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Shamir said: ``No, not at all.'' But in his speech, Shamir said Israel must be on alert in view of developments in the region. He said the crisis in the Persian Gulf, ``is mounting toward a peak.'' ``We are ready for any development that may take place. There are factors in the region that would like to draw us into an armed conflict. We need strong nerves, patience and a high state of readiness,'' Shamir said.

DOC.HEAD: Keating, Associates Looted Lincoln S&L of Millions, Judge Says
DOC.TEXT: All he wanted, Phoenix financier Charles H. Keating Jr. said, was a day in court to tell his side of how his Lincoln Savings & Loan Association came to represent the epitome of the quarter-trillion-dollar S&L debacle. U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin gave Keating his day _ in fact more than 30 days of hearings _ and then ruled Thursday that Keating and his associates used a ``dishonest scheme'' to loot Lincoln for tens of millions of dollars in federally insured deposits. ``Bluntly speaking, their actions amounted to a looting of Lincoln,'' said Sporkin, an accountant by training and formerly the top enforcement officer at the Securities and Exchange Commission. ``This was not done crudely. Indeed, it was done with a great deal of sophistication.'' Dismissing Keating's suit to recover the collapsed Irvine, Calif., thrift, Sporkin said it was ``abundantly clear'' that Keating and other officials of Lincoln's holding company, American Continental Corp. of Phoenix, ``abused their positions.'' It was the second legal setback in two days for Keating, who complained he was being made a scapegoat for the S&L crisis because of his $1.3 million in campaign gifts to five senators who intervened on his behalf with federal thrift regulators in 1987. A federal judge in California said Wednesday that Keating must prove he's broke, may not send any money out of the country and must give 48 hours notice before spending more than $5,000. The federal Office of Thrift Supervision sought that action as part of an effort to recover $40.9 million from Keating and five associates in connection with three soured business deals at Lincoln. Bradley Boland, a spokesman for American Continental and a son-in-law of Keating, said in response to Sporkin's ruling that the company ``is reviewing all of its options and has no comment at this time.'' Keating had indicated earlier that he would appeal a negative decision. ``We'll be fighting to the day I'm dead,'' he told reporters in June. ``I have no intention of being raped by the U.S. government.'' Timothy Ryan, director of the Office of Thrift Supervision that last year succeeded the Federal Home Loan Bank Board as the S&L industry's chief regulator, called the ruling ``an extremely important decision.'' ``As the courts are now confirming,'' Ryan said, ``OTS has the authority to see that those who have abused the savings and loan system and the American taxpayer will not be permitted to do so again. And they will not be permitted to retain one cent of their ill-gotten gains.'' Regulators have estimated that Keating's use of Lincoln's federally insured deposits to finance various junk bond, stock and real estate ventures and the institution's subsequent collapse could cost taxpayers as much as $2 billion. The government already has spent $1.2 billion keeping Lincoln and its more than 20 branches in Southern California afloat, according to lawyers in the case. The government also has a $1.3 billion civil fraud and racketeering suit pending against Keating. ``This is a saga that demonstrates the excesses of a misconceived and misapplied regulatory program along with a group of individuals who were bent on exploiting these excesses,'' Sporkin said in his 51-page ruling Thursday. But the judge also blamed the ``literally scores of accountants and lawyers'' that Keating ``surrounded himself with'' to give an ``aura of legality'' to transactions that regulators claim were fraudulent. ``While we in this nation have been trying to place blame for the savings and loan crisis on the various governmental participants ... this court believes far too little has been focused on the private sector,'' Sporkin said. Five senators now being investigated by the Senate Ethics Committee have cited the audits by the accounting firm of Arthur Young & Co. and a favorable report by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan as reasons for interceding on Keating's behalf. The five _ Sens. Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich.; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; John Glenn, D-Ohio, and John McCain, R-Ariz., have denied any wrongdoing.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Prove Normal Gene Can Suppress Cancer Growth In Laboratory
DOC.TEXT: Researchers say they have isolated a normal gene that can prevent test-tube colonies of cancer tumors from growing. The experiment with a gene called p53 could lead to finding natural proteins to switch off cancer. The results of the research at the Johns Hopkins Oncology Center in Baltimore appear today in the journal Science. ``They have reached the genetic root of the problem of malignancy,'' said Dr. John S. Macdonald, director of the Temple University Cancer Center in Philadelphia. ``The observation that you change the growth properties (of cancer cells) by inserting the normal gene is significant,'' said Dr. Berton Zbar, a National Cancer Institute scientist. P53 is one of a group of what is known as suppressor genes because they appear to act as a brake on cancer formation, said Suzanne Baker, a Hopkins cancer researcher. Suppressor genes have been found to be either missing or mutated in the cells of several types of solid cancer tumors, she said. ``What we assume is the fact that a normal copy of the p53 gene missing in these cells is important in the formation of the cancer,'' she said. Baker said inserting the normal p53 seems to reestablish the normal regulation of cell proliferation. The unregulated division of cells is a primary characteristic of cancer. Researchers at Hopkins and at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland also put the p53 into benign colon tumors and found that these tumors, which have the gene, were not affected. The researchers additionally put a mutated p53 gene into colonies of colon cancer cells and found that the abnormal gene did not suppress the cell growth. These experiments, said Baker, verified that the action of the normal gene prevented the cancer from growing. Zbar and Macdonald said that p53 is missing or mutated in a several types of cancer _ including brain, bone, breast and adrenal carcinoma _ and that the Hopkins study may also apply to those cancers. Other researchers, also working with laboratory cultures, proved earlier that restoring other suppressor genes can block growth of cancers of the eye and of the kidney. But the Hopkins study is the first to demonstrate the effect of a suppressor gene on one of the major cancer killers. Colon cancer, which kills about 60,000 people annually in the United States, is second in mortality to lung cancer. Baker cautioned that despite the success of the laboratory experiment, it does not prove that colon cancer can be treated by inserting a normal gene into a patient. This may never be possible, a Hopkins statement said. But Baker said that if the action of the suppressor gene can be understood, then researchers could develop an agent, such as a protein, that mimics the work of p53 and stops cancer growth. Baker said the Hopkins team is now studying the mechanism of the suppressor gene. Coauthors of the study with Baker were Eric R. Fearon and Bert Vogelstein of Hopkins, and Sanford Markowitz and James K. V. Willson of Case Western Reserve. Science, which published the study, is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Studies Fail to Resolve Debate Over Milk Hormone
DOC.TEXT: Two scientific reports this week conclude that cows treated with an experimental synthetic hormone yield higher volumes of milk that is as safe as ordinary milk. But Food and Drug Administration officials say it will take at least until next spring to determine if the treatment is safe for the cows, and critics remain unconvinced the genetically-engineered hormone is safe at all. If the FDA approves the hormone, bovine somatotropin, or bST, it would become the first biotechnology product on the agriculture market. ``There are a lot of unanswered questions,'' Jeremy Rifkin, president of the Foundation on Economic Trends and a biotechnology critic, said Thursday. ``The public deserves to have a thorough study of all this and not a rush to judgment, and that's what the FDA is trying to do.'' FDA scientists, in an article in this week's edition of the journal Science, laid out the evidence it believes shows that milk and meat from dairy cows treated with the hormone are safe for human consumption. Rifkin criticized the FDA for using old studies that tested with natural bST rather than the synthetic hormone. The FDA's submission of the report to the journal for review by an expert panel of scientists was unusual, since the agency as a rule does not tip its hand publicly on products before they are approved. The FDA's action was ``a response to congressional and public interest'' over the safety of bST, said FDA spokesman Jeff Nesbit. Some consumer activists say long-term effects of the bST are still not known, and farmers worry that consumers might shy away from products from treated cows. Farmers also are concerned that increased milk production would lower prices. But Nesbit said: ``Whether bST will hurt small farmers ... does not fall within (the FDA's) regulatory scope. We only look at the safety and efficacy of a drug, not the economics of it.'' Earlier this week, the Journal of the American Medical Association published the work of two researchers who concluded that bST can boost milk production in dairy cows by 10 percent to 25 percent while causing no significant changes in composition of the milk. Rifkin said that report was ``shameful'' because the authors are consultants to Monsanto Agriculture Co., one of the companies making bST. JAMA also published an editorial by an independent researcher backing the conclusions. Besides Monsanto, the FDA has allowed three other companies _ Eli Lilly Co., Upjohn Co. and American Cyanamid _ to conduct limited farm tests of their products and to sell the milk from the test cows.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Fear Fatal Blow From Persian Gulf
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Will be topped with 8:30 a.m. EDT release of new report
DOC.TEXT: A stagnating U.S. economy that has survived many close calls to expand for a peacetime record of nearly eight years may receive its crippling blow from the Middle East, analysts fear. Regardless of whether regional hostilities escalate, many analysts predict an economic downturn is imminent because of the runup in oil prices that has already occurred since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. More information on the economy will be known today when the government releases a revised look at the broadest measure of economic health _ the gross national product. A month ago, the Commerce Department said the GNP grew at a lackluster annual rate of just 1.2 percent in the April-June quarter. In advance of today's report, many analysts believe that estimate would be revised upward, but only slightly to perhaps 1.4 percent, based on a modest improvement in the country's trade performance. However, analysts said an upward revision would not change their basic feeling that the U.S. economy has ground to a near standstill and could well topple into a recession before the year is out. Recession fears and the three-week-old Persian Gulf crisis have rattled financial markets worldwide. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged by 76.73 points on Thursday to 2,483.42 and has lost 17 percent of its valued since the market peaked at an all-time high just below the 3,000 mark on July 17. The price of crude oil, which has jumped by nearly 50 percent since Aug. 2, rose 71 cents to close at $31.93 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Even the administration, while insisting that a recession can still be avoided, is predicting that economic growth could be trimmed in half by the rise in oil prices. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said that the GNP, which averaged 1.5 percent through the first six months of this year, may grow at a barely perceptible 0.75 percent in the last six months. Private forecasters, however, are far more pessimistic, predicting that an outright recession, normally defined as two consecutive quarters of negative growth, will begin, perhaps by the final three months of this year. ``The longer the crisis in the Middle East lasts, the more inevitable a downturn becomes,'' said David Wyss, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill, a Lexington, Mass., forecasting firm. Rising oil prices will only exacerbate an already gloomy inflation outlook in the United States and keep the Federal Reserve from administering its normal anti-inflation medicine _ a dose of lower interest rates, many analysts believe. The latest survey of 49 top economists, taken this month after the Iraqi invasion, showed them slashing their GNP forecast for this year to 1.3 percent, down from a 1.9 percent GNP estimate the month before. It marked the second largest one-month drop in economic expectations in the 13-year history of the survey by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a monthly newsletter. Editor R.J. Eggert told subscribers, ``It's safe to conclude that the United States now faces the greatest risk of recession in the last eight years.'' The current recovery from the 1981-82 recession is nearing its eighth birthday. Only the almost nine-year expansion during the 1960s, which occurred during the Vietnam War, lasted for a longer period.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Asks Oil Companies for Help in Investigation
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department's antitrust division is taking a crash course in the petroleum industry, and its tutors _ oil companies summoned for meetings in the capital _ may end up targets of prosecution. The antitrust division is trying to uncover whether illegal tactics were used when the price of oil leaped following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. As a first step in its investigation, the division is learning the intricacies of how the industry works from the people who live it daily, the oil companies. ``I have called the major oil companies and requested that they come in on a one-by-one basis to meet with the staff and on several occasions with me,'' Assistant Attorney General James Rill, who heads the division, told reporters Thursday. Already, representatives of three major oil companies and two independent marketers have met with some of the 10 antitrust officials working on the inquiry, Rill said, declining to identify the companies. The need for the background briefing is the complexity of the situation, he said. ``We're dealing with an entire industry, multiple levels of distribution, a worldwide situation,'' Rill said. ``It seemed to me ... prudent to get a very quick process going to attempt to get the scope of the issue, the dynamics of the industry in hand before we went to the kind of focused inquiry which may be the next phase.'' The company representatives _ ``top level people in these companies'' _ are explaining the industry's price practices, ``the circumstances of the sharp increases in detail and the reasons why those increases have occurred,'' Rill said. The average price of gasoline at the pump has jumped some 18 percent since Iraq overran Kuwait on Aug. 2, American Automobile Association surveys report. The average pump price of unleaded regular gasoline increased from $1.05 a gallon on July 25 to $1.24 a gallon on Monday, the AAA found. Prosecutors are looking for suggestions of collusion, unlawful contacts or contacts suggesting anti-competitive activity and ``pricing and supply behavior that may not be fully explained by market forces,'' Rill said. The inquiry's general fact-finding phase should be completed within the next four weeks and should direct prosecutors to ``the most promising lines of inquiry'' to pursue, he said. The companies have been forthcoming with information, even though they know prosecutions may occur later, Rill said. They have been promised confidentiality, he said, but he would not say whether they had been offered any kind of immunity from prosecution or other incentives to reveal information. Thus far, no subpoenas have been issued to compel cooperation, but Rill said if any companies refuse to cooperate, ``We'll know how to deal with them.'' Rill had announced Aug. 6 that he was beginning such an inquiry. That announcement, he said Thursday, was inspired both to alert the industry that ``we were on the job and looking for evidence of illegal conduct'' and to encourage any potential whistle-blowers to come forth with information.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Higher
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 24,165.76, up 428.13 points or 1.8 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Intelligence Reports Show Saddam Repositioning Troops in Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein is repositioning his elite Republican Guards, which led the attack into Kuwait, behind other troops on the front lines, according to an intelligence source. ``They're withdrawing the Republican Guard to positions behind the front lines,'' said the source, who has access to intelligence information and spoke Thursday on condition of anonymity. The source said the specialized troops were being positioned behind another line of Iraqi troops but still would be capable of contributing to a possible attack of Saudi Arabia from Kuwait. ``You put your forces in front of you to screen them, and then you make your attack through them. There's no indication he's withdrawing at all. He's adding to his forces,'' the source said. The key is the positioning of artillery, the source said. ``Artillery has a limited range. If you are in a defensive position, you move it backward so you can withdraw under the protection of your artillery. When you attack, you move it forward to attack under its protection,'' the source said. ``His (Saddam's) artillery is still forward.'' NBC News reported Thursday that intelligence reports showed that thousands of the guards, perhaps more than 50,000, were heading away from the Saudi border. The intelligence source said Saddam's troops were involved in a ``classically Soviet'' military maneuver and that they retained the ability to attack on short notice, within eight to 12 hours. U.S. intelligence has various means of detecting in great detail the movements of Iraqi troops, but the source refused to discuss how such information is obtained. It is well known that the United States makes extensive use of satellite reconnaissance, however. There still appear to be about 160,000 Iraqi troops inside Kuwait, the source said, adding that there appeared to be more divisions moving into southern Iraq. American military officials assume that Saddam's heavily mechanized forces could make a drive across the border and simultaneously use air power in such an attack. Intelligence reports have indicated that the Iraqi army has stores of food, ammunition, supplies and artillery in positions that could be used to launch an attack into Saudi Arabia. The source described the situation as still being ``ambiguous'' and that it was not clear what Saddam intended to do. The source said Saddam's troops had thrown up what is known as a ``hasty defense.'' Troops didn't mount a defense in depth, a kind of ``layer cake defense'' that would create severe difficulties for an attacking opponent, the source said.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Recommends Federal Courts Open to Cameras and Microphones
DOC.TEXT: Federal courts may open their doors just a crack to radio, television and photographic coverage. A five-judge committee of the policy-making U.S. Judicial Conference will recommend an experiment in lifting the longtime ban on such coverage when it meets next month, conference spokesman David Sellers said Thursday. ``What the five-judge committee will recommend is a three-year experiment,'' Sellers said. ``The conference could accept, amend, reject or merely table the recommendation.'' The experiment, if approved, would be limited to two federal appeals courts and six federal trial courts. The committee, headed by U.S. District Judge Robert Peckham of San Francisco, is not recommending which courts be selected for the experiment. Civil _ but not criminal _ proceedings could be open to TV cameras and other coverage now barred by federal court rules, Sellers said. Judges would have broad discretion to bar such coverage in any particular case, he said. Sellers said the committee's recommendation would entail no government expense. ``Any expense would be borne by the news media,'' he said. Peckham's committee is recommending that the experiment begin in July 1991. The Judicial Conference is composed of 27 federal judges, and is headed by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. The conference has been asked repeatedly in recent years by news media representatives to open federal courts to TV, radio and photographic coverage. Peckham's committee told the conference last year that it lacked sufficient information to make any recommendation for changing the longtime ban. Most state courts allow some type of electronic or photographic coverage of civil and criminal proceedings.

DOC.HEAD: Products Preparing To Absorb Cost Of Coffee Maker Recall
DOC.TEXT: The Proctor-Silex Co. is setting aside ``several million dollars'' to provide free coffee makers to an estimated 800,000 consumers who purchased a model mow declared a fire hazard, company officials say. Arnold Dreyfus, the corporation's chairman, declined to say Thursday exactly how much the recall would cost, remarking only that it would depend on how many recalled coffee makers are turned in. Commenting in a telephone interview from Proctor-Silex headquarters in Richmond, Va., Dreyfus said the recalled models were made in 1985 and 1986 and have since been discontinued. ``This problem did not manifest itself until much later,'' he said. Proctor-Silex says it believes the recalled coffee makers are subject to potentially dangerous over-heating because their thermostats and thermal fuses may malfunction. Dreyfus said the company is trying to identify the vendors that provided the allegedly ``bad fuses.'' The company said more than 200 telephone operators are fielding calls about Proctor-Silex automatic drip coffee makers and issuing instructions on how to turn in recalled models and receive a free appliance. Company officials acknowledged that the initial volume has been so heavy that many consumers get repeated busy signals. The toll-free number set up by the company is 1-800-341-3333.
DOC.HEAD: Flight Tests Show New Wing Design Could Cut Costs
DOC.TEXT: Tests show that airlines could save hundreds of millions of dollars in fuel costs with a new wing design that reduces drag from air flowing over a passenger jetliner's wings, NASA says. A joint government-industry flight test program produced results that were much better than expected, officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said Thursday. The tests were conducted for five months on a Boeing 757 on which a 22-foot wing section had been replaced by a wing surface designed to produce a smooth air flow, the space agency said. If the modification had been made along the entire wingspan on both sides, drag would have been reduced by 10 percent, the space agency said. Each percent of drag eliminated by the U.S. transport fleet would result in an annual fuel savings of $100 million for the industry, NASA said. The modified wing section includes millions of tiny, laser-drilled holes in a titanium skin covered by a flap along the leading edge to shield against insects and dirt during takeoffs and landings. The holes create a suction effect that diverts turbulent air from the surface of the wing and allows a smoother air flow. The design resulted from earlier flow tests on military jets, NASA said. A future flight test is being considered that will use the system on other wing sections. The testing is jointly funded by the government and Boeing Commercial Airplane Group, which builds Boeing jetliners.
DOC.HEAD: Author Sues New York Times Over Book Review
DOC.TEXT: An investigative reporter angered by The New York Times' review of his book on the alleged links between organized crime and the National Football League has filed a $10 million libel lawsuit against the paper. Dan E. Moldea filed suit Thursday in U.S. District Court in Washington over the newspaper's Sept. 3, 1989 review of his book, ``Interference: How Organized Crime Influences Professional Football.'' The New York Times's top attorney expressed confidence that the suit would be thrown out of court and said the review was based ``on accurate facts.'' The review by Times sportswriter Gerald Eskenazi said, in part, that Moldea's book contains ``sloppy journalism'' as well as ``errors and unfounded insinuations.'' The lawsuit alleges that the review ``was intended to protect the NFL by personally attacking Moldea, discrediting his reputation and smearing his good name as a careful investigative reporter.'' ``The review gave false impressions through use of false and misleading examples intended to injure Moldea's reputation, impeach Moldea's honesty and integrity and destroyed the likelihood that `Interference' would become a widely read book by the public,'' the suit says. Moldea said in an interview that his publisher, William Morrow and Co. Inc., had printed 33,000 copies of the book because initial sales had been strong. But after The New York Times review came out, sales dropped off precipitously, and only about 21,000 were sold. ``This thing could have been stopped so long ago had they just published a correction or my letter'' that countered, point by point, statements in the review, Moldea said. Eskenazi declined comment on the matter, referring questions to Times executives ``even though this is something I'm appalled at when people do it to me.''

DOC.HEAD: American Who Catalogued Destruction of Liberian Rain Forest Escapes
DOC.TEXT: American Andrew Voros walked out of a jail in war-ravaged Liberia with only a pair of jeans _ and many horror stories. Voros, who spent the last four years documenting the destruction of the last virgin rain forest in West Africa, had his work looted. He also saw a friend tortured by soldiers who later told him his friend had been killed. And he has memories of bodies littering streets in Liberia's capital, Monrovia. The 33-year-old New Jersey man was jailed for eight days in Monrovia by soldiers loyal to President Samuel Doe. The U.S. Embassy engineered Voros' release, U.S. Marines got him out of the country Saturday and he returned Tuesday to his home in Rahway, 10 miles southwest of Newark. ``Since I was released, I've kept the loss of my friends and work out of my mind,'' he said Thursday by telephone from his home.``I'm so happy to be alive.'' The eight-month-old rebellion to oust Doe reached Monrovia in June. Since then, the city has been battered by rockets and mortars, bodies litter the streets, and beleaguered residents have gone without fresh food supplies, water and electricity. At least 5,000 people have been killed, most of them civilians. Front-end loaders regularly drove through town with their buckets loaded with corpses, Voros recalled. ``There were people eating dogs and dogs eating people in the street,'' he said. A month ago, he helped care for survivors of an army massacre of hundreds of refugees in a Lutheran church. ``It was horrifying _ there were children with feet and hands blown off, women with legs ripped open and breasts blown off,'' he said. Voros said he survived prison because of the deference Africans show to white Americans. ``I got to wear my jeans during the day. Everyone else was stripped,'' he said. Soldiers would accuse him of being a CIA agent at one point and then ask for his help in getting a visa to the United States. ``You don't know how many soldiers took my U.S. address down,'' he said. Voros and his close friend, Col. Christopher Doe, a former finance director for the army who is not related to the president, were arrested at Voros' house by soldiers who accused them of supporting the rebels. On the fourth day of their imprisonment, ``Christie was brought in, stripped and beaten with a cartridge belt in front of me,'' Voros said. The next day a soldier told Voros his friend had been killed. The house was looted of all valuables, he said. ``Everything I worked for four years was in my house,'' he said. A biology graduate, Voros worked in Yosemite National Park and spent two years in Liberia with the Peace Corps until 1984. He returned 1{ years later primarily to document the destruction of the country's virgin rain forest, which he said is the last one remaining in West Africa. Voros also videotaped secret tribal societies and scenes of urban life in Monrovia, took shots of elephants and monkeys and interviewed elderly Liberians about their homeland. Freed American slaves founded Liberia in 1822. He had accumulated $50,000 in grants from U.S. government agencies for his rain forest project, and worries he'll have to pay it back because he has nothing to show for it. Over half of the rain forest has been destroyed by logging companies that bribe government officials to get into the forest's towering hardwoods, Voros said. Peasants then move into the area and create farmland by slashing and burning the remaining forests. ``In 25 to 30 years, the rest of the forest will be destroyed,'' he said. If some semblance of peace returns, Voros said he'd like to return. ``If the city is not destroyed completely, I'd like to go back and post rewards for the return of my videos,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets, U.S. Disagree on Military Action Behind Sanctions
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. and Soviet Ambassadors have disagreed over whether the five permanent members of the Security Council back a resolution allowing military force to put teeth in the U.N. embargo against Iraq. After a private meeting Thursday at the French mission with the ambassadors of the Soviet Union, Britain, China and France Thursday, U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering told reporters: ``We agreed on a text to send to capitals.'' He said there would be a vote on the resolution ``as soon as it can be arranged.'' Pickering's statement appeared to indicate earlier Soviet objections to using force to back up the international had been overcome. Objections by Moscow have posed the biggest obstacle to U.S. efforts on the issue. But when asked later whether the text was approved, Soviet Ambassador Valentin V. Lozinskiy, replied: ``It's not. No. No, that's the wrong impression.'' Lozinskiy said, however, there could be a Security Council meeting ``this week, probably.'' When asked about a breakthrough, Lozinsky said: ``Hopefully, hopefully. It takes time. Not today.'' President Bush has said he wants the Security Council's blessing to use force to halt Iraq's shipping. But he has also said the United States already has the right to enforce the U.N. trade sanctions against Iraq. U.S. officials contend the United States is authorized to enforce the embargo at the request of the ousted Kuwaiti government, and by the U.N. Charter, which grants nations the right to self-defense. Soviet objections to wording in a U.S.-proposed U.N. resolution on military enforcement of sanctions have in the past days been the major obstacle to raising the issue. Moscow has said it wanted evidence the U.N. embargo was being violated before the Security Council should authorize force to police its sanctions. It has said it would not participate in an international military operation unless it was organized by the United Nations. It also has sought a larger role for the Security Council's Military Staff Committee. The United States, however, seeks a loose arrangement in which various national navies are free to use their own rules of engagement and possibly operate in their own sectors to enforce the embargo. U.S. officials have said they would not call a meeting of the full 15-member Security Council unless they have approval of the five permanent members, or a promise not to veto the U.S. initiative. The economic sanctions were ordered by the United Nations on Aug. 6 to punish Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait four days earlier. Meanwhile, a U.N. statement said two top U.N. officials checking on foreigners in Iraq met nine foreign men held at an undisclosed location about one hour from Baghdad. The two U.N. envoys in Iraq are Undersecretary-General Virendra Dayal and personnel director Kofi Annan. They arrived Monday with instructions from the Security Council to help ensure the safety and secure the release of foreigners being held in Iraq and Kuwait. The council has demanded their release. The envoys have been meeting senior Iraqi government officials, but details of the discussions have not been disclosed. The United Nations is removing about 310 staff and dependents from Iraq and Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Shares Up, Dollar Down in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Share prices in Tokyo rebounded Friday for the first time in seven trading days, closing higher after fluctuations influenced by reports Iraqi troops were withdrawing from Kuwait. The dollar inched down against the Japanese yen. The dollar closed at 145.70 yen, down 0.18 yen from Thursday's 145.88-yen finish. It opened at 146.00 and ranged between 145.67 and 146.25. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average regained 428.13 points, or 1.8 percent, ending the day at 24,165.76 in the first gain since Aug. 15, when the index soared 1,439.59 points. After peaking at mid-morning, the Nikkei fell almost 900 points by mid-afternoon before rising back. Traders said last-minute bargain hunting helped the late recovery. The index started lower on rapid selling in the wake of the previous day's plunge, but regained nearly 700 points by mid-morning as market players began buying after an NBC news report that Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein had ordered some elite troops withdrawn from the Kuwaiti-Saudi Arabian border, said Tomoya Koda, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. The troops were to be replaced by second- and third-string units, the report said. The market first took the news as a sign that Iraq was withdrawing from the border, because many investors were desperately seeking an excuse to buy after Thursday's hugo Stock Exchange announced it would tighten regulations, effective Friday, on speculative future trading to stop share prices from falling further. Also, the Finance Ministry on Friday eased restrictions on limiting security firms from trading more than 30 percent of the total trading volume of one issue per month. ``As financial authorities started moving to defend the stock market, a sense of confidence began to take root among investors,'' said Akira Shimoda, an equity analyst with Yamaichi Securities. But Koda said he saw little hope of market recovery by technical measures, since psychological factors are having more impact on the market movements.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Fixes Magellan's Computer Memory; More Venus Pictures Due
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Magellan pictures . . .', with 2 grafs to CORRECT that Saunders did not specify which pictures would be released today; pick up 7th graf, `The Soviet . . .'. SUBS penultimate graf with 1 graf to RESTORE full explanation for communication problem. Pictures to be released after 3 p.m. EDT; should stand.
DOC.TEXT: Engineers performed a partial memory transplant on one of Magellan's computers as they tried to make sure they don't lose touch with the unruly space probe for a third time as it orbits Venus. Engineers haven't pinpointed the problem that made them temporarily lose contact with Magellan twice during the past week. They replaced the faulty computer memory because ``we're fixing the symptoms,'' Ed Sherry, technical assistant to Magellan's project manager, said Thursday. Scientists at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory today planned to release more of Magellan's early pictures of Venus, made during a test just before the first communications breakdown Aug. 16. The National Aeronautic and Space Administration released Magellan's first Venus images Tuesday, only hours before losing radio contact with the wayward spacecraft the second time. The first batch of test pictures showed numerous ``Venusquake'' faults, old lava flows, craters, cinder cones, valleys and ridges on Venus. That means at least part of Venus is shaped by some of the same violent forces that sculpted Earth. A laboratory official said Thursday that one of the pictures being released today showed an interesting crater on the planet's surface. Earlier this week, Magellan's chief scientist Steve Saunders said that unreleased Magellan pictures showed a 20-mile-wide crater that also had been seen by the Soviet Venera 15 and 16 spacecraft in the mid-1980s. The Soviet pictures were about 10 times less detailed than Magellan's radar images, so it wasn't clear if the crater was volcanic or caused by a meteorite impact. Magellan's pictures clearly show it is an impact crater, but the floor of the crater is extremely smooth, indicating it was flooded by lava that later solidified, Saunders said. He said the crater may have filled with lava from an eruption triggered when a meteorite punched completely through Venus' crust. Or the lava simply may have filled the crater much later in an eruption unrelated to the impact. Magellan is on a $744 million mission to use its radar to peer through the clouds of Venus and make the most detailed pictures and maps yet of the second planet from the sun. It went into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10, about 15 months after it was launched from the shuttle Atlantis. It now is nearly 150 million miles from Earth. Sherry said engineers don't yet know how long Magellan's troubles will delay the official start of its mapping effort, which was to begin the first week of September. The ultimate problem that caused the malfunction remains unknown. But flight data show that Tuesday night the spacecraft's automatic safety systems were unable to maintain radio contact as expected because part of the memory was ``corrupted'' in a backup computer that helps point Magellan, Sherry said. He said engineers replaced the faulty contents of that computer's memory with a rewritten version that was radioed to the spacecraft Thursday. Magellan's main computer found ``something was not kosher'' in the backup computer's memory and, as a result, assumed Magellan was pointing in the wrong direction _ which it wasn't, Sherry said. That made Magellan try to turn to what it thought was the correct position, but it actually turned its antenna away from Earth, losing contact. The series of malfunctions ``have shaken the spacecraft, but the overall spacecraft remains very healthy, and we're very optimistic we'll be back to a fruitful mission soon,'' Sherry said.

DOC.HEAD: International Fleet Of About 70 Ships For Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf `Soviet Union...' with 1 graf to CORRECT that Soviets have two ships in region, sted six. Pickup 19th graf `Italy: Five...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 70 ships from 11 nations are being deployed to the Persian Gulf or other Middle Eastern waters in response to the Persian Gulf crisis, with more than half of them flying the American flag. The U.S. Navy has a total of 37 ships either in the gulf or en route, an unofficial count showed. Among them were four aircraft carrier battle groups and the battleship Wisconsin. Here is a list of U.S. warships in the area or en route: In the gulf: the flagship La Salle, the Aegis cruiser Antietam, missile cruiser England, destroyer David R. Ray, missile frigates Vandegrift, Reid, Taylor and Robert G. Bradley, and frigate Barbey. Aegis is an advanced computer-linked system of radar and weaponry. In the north Arabian Sea: carrier Independence, missile cruiser Jouett, missile destroyer Goldsborough, frigates Brewton and Reasoner, ammunition ship Flint, oiler Cimmarron, replenishment ships Andrew J. Higgins and White Plains. The latter two technically are not part of the Independence battle group but supply U.S. ships in the area. The battleship Wisconsin should have arrived in the north Arabian Sea in the last day or so, and may enter the gulf where its Tomahawk cruise missiles could be brought to bear on targets in Iraq. Navy sources said the battleship apparently sailed from through the canal without accompanying escort. In the Red Sea: the carrier Saratoga arrived via the Suez Canal on Wednesday, accompanied by the Aegis missile cruiser Philippine Sea and the missile cruiser Biddle. Three other members of its battle group, the missile destroyer Sampson and frigates Elmer Montgomery and Thomas C. Hart, were scheduled to follow it through the canal in the next few days. The Saratoga group replaces the nuclear powered carrier Dwight D. Eisenhower, which has been in the Red Sea for the past two weeks and is returning to the Mediterranean. Navy sources declined to say whether the Eisenhower, which was just completing a Mediterranean tour with the U.S. 6th Fleet when the crisis arose, will remain in the area. The Eisnhower battle group includes the Aegis missile cruiser Ticonderoga, missile destroyer Scott, missile destroyer Tattnall, destroyer John Rodgers, the oiler Neosho and the ammunition ship Suribachi. En route to the Mediterranean is another battle group headed by the carrier John F. Kennedy and including the nuclear powered missile cruiser Mississippi, Aegis missile cruisers San Jacinto and Thomas S. Gates, and the missile frigate Samuel B. Roberts. A number of landing assault ships and large supply vessels are en route to the gulf, carrying Marine combat units and heavy equipment for the Marine and Army units in Saudi Srabia. Three of the latter are transiting Suez this week, and three others were sent from the Diego Garcia base in the Indian Ocean. Here are the naval forces of other countries in the gulf region now present, en route or scheduled to deploy: Britain: Four ships. The destroyer York, frigates Jupiter and Battleaxe, and supply ship Orangeleaf, are in the gulf. The British also have said they will send three minesweepers and support ships. France: Nine ships, including the carrier Clemenceau, the cruiser Colbert, destroyers Duplex and Montcalm, supply tanker Var and ocean tug Buffle. They are in the Arabian Sea. Soviet Union: The Soviets say they have two navy vessels at anchor in the Oman Straits _ a destroyer and an anti-submarine vessel. Moscow, which until recently maintained seven to 10 ships in the gulf region on a regular basis, has said it does not plan to send more at this time and would only take part in a naval blockade under full United Nations auspices. Italy: Five ships. The frigates Orsa and Libeccio, and the supply ship Stromboli, were to pass through the Suez Canal on Friday en route to the gulf, provided the Italian Parliament gives final approval for their deployment to the crisis zone. Two corvettes, Minerva and Sfinge, left Italy last Thursday for deployment off the coast of Turkey. Belgium: Announced plans to send two minehunters and a support ship to the Mediterranean, possibly on to the gulf. Netherlands: Two frigates en route to the gulf. West Germany: announced it would send several minesweepers to the Mediterranean to take up slack of U.S. ships redeployed to the gulf, a policy decision also adopted during the Iran-Iraq war in 1987-88. Spain: Planning to deploy one frigate and two corvettes. Australia: Two missile frigates and a supply vessel en route to the gulf. Canada: planning to send two warships and a support vessel to the gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Cracks Appear in Soviet Union with Independence Moves
DOC.TEXT: More cracks have appeared in the Soviet Union, with Armenia declaring independence, Turkmenia announcing its sovereignty and Estonia beginning talks toward separation. However, struggling to keep the nation whole and the economy afloat, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Thursday managed to neutralize the Russian republic's attempt to take control of its own vast natural resources. Also Thursday, heavily armed KGB border troops rolled tanks up to the Polish-Lithuanian border to prevent unauthorized crossings on the 51st anniversary of the pact that allowed Stalin to seize the Baltic republics. Armenia, a republic of 3.3 million people on the border with Turkey and Iran, is the fifth of the Soviet Union's 15 republics to move toward complete independence from the Soviet Union. Armenia's independence resolution ``declares the beginning of the process of establishing independent statehood,'' according to an English translation sent to The Associated Press. Armenian legislator Samvel Shakhmuradyan said he expects the republic to remain part of the Soviet Union only during an undefined transition period to complete separation. Armenia's path to independece, however, might be complicated by the bloody two-year conflict with neighboring Azerbaijan over the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh. The declaration calls for creation of Armenia's own armed forces to safeguard the border, and for Nagorno-Karabakh, a largely Armenian area of Azerbaijan, to become part of the Armenian republic. The move threatened Gorbachev's struggles to develop a new union treaty attractive enough to keep his nation whole. Gorbachev, however, seems to be bowing to Baltic demands for complete independence. Kremlin officials began formal negotiations with Estonia on Thursday. The two other Baltics, Latvia and Lithuania, were expected to begin independence negotiations soon. Georgia has also requested talks with the Kremlin on independence. The Estonian and Soviet delegations plan to meet weekly for two months and present a final document to Gorbachev's Presidential Council by the end of October, reported the official Soviet news agency Tass. Seven republics have declared sovereignty, or the right to overturn Soviet laws on their territory. The republic of Turkmenia passed such a declaration Thursday, joining Russia _ the largest Soviet republic _ the Ukraine, Azerbaijan, Byelorussia, Moldavia and Uzbekistan. The Armenian resolution was approved by a vote of 183-2, Armenian legislator Samvel Shakhmuradyan said in a telephone interview from Yerevan, the capital of the small republic. It invalidates the Soviet Constitution on Armenian territory and says that only the republic's Constitution is in effect, and demands a share of the Soviet national wealth, Shakhmuradyan said. The resolution calls for the creation of Armenia's own currency, banking system and customs duties and claims Armenia's right to conduct its own foreign policy. It also bars other nations' troops and bases from its territory, a clear reference to the Soviet armed forces. The declaration changes the name of the ``Armenian Soviet Socialist Republic'' to the ``Republic of Armenia.'' It says Armenia will have a multiparty political system and freedom of expression, press and religion, Tass reported. Meanwhile, Thursday, Gorbachev issued a presidential decree that nullified the Russian attempt to wrest control over its natural resources. But on the same day, Russia, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics, backed away from its order earlier this month that declared invalid contracts signed by the Soviet government. Its action averted _ or postponed _ a critical battle between the national Soviet government and the resource-rich republic over both the acquisition of badly needed foreign currency and the division of power. Also Thursday, Soviet authorities refused to relinquish control of the border station between Lithuania and Ogrodniki, Poland, and reinforced that determination with a heavy show of force. In Lithuania, Independence activists had hoped to take control of the border crossing from Soviet authorities in a one-day demonstration of their desire to open Lithuania to the rest of Europe. Lithuania and the two other Baltic republics, Latvia and Estonia, were independent between the two World Wars but lost that independence as a result of the Molotov-Ribbentrop non-agression pact the Soviets signed with Nazi Germany in 1939. On a field about a mile inside the border, an estimated 30,000 rain-drenched Lithuanians took part in a Roman Catholic Mass as part of the event dubbed ``One European Road.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Workers Walk from Wreckage After Plane Crashes on Takeoff
LaserPhoto HT1
DOC.TEXT: A private plane carrying oil-rig workers returning from a tour of duty in Europe crashed and burned at Houston International Airport, killing three men and injuring 12 others. Several passengers walked away from the wreckage virtually unscathed. ``The last thing I said when we were going down was, `God help me,' and I believe he did,'' said Edward Odom, 28, Stonewall, Miss., who suffered scratches on one hand. Federal investigators planned to resume an investigation today into Thursday afternoon's crash shortly after takeoff of the New Orleans-bound twin-engine Grumman G-159 turboprop. The plane, carrying employees of Houston-based Rowan Drilling Co., crashed about a mile south of the airport's main terminal complex, officials said. The fuselage was torn nearly in half and a fire scorched sections of the aircraft. Authorities identified the dead as pilot Billy Jack Keefauver, 60, of Houston; copilot Wayne D. Kay, 49, of Katy, Texas; and Gregory Hunter, 30, Covington, La., who was traveling in the cockpit. Three men were treated and released, and nine others were hospitalized with conditions ranging from stable to good, hospital officials said. Odom and his colleagues had been working on oil rigs in the North Sea. They had just arrived on a British Airways flight from London and were continuing to Louisiana and Mississippi on the private plane. ``We were all sitting down, talking and it seemed like a perfectly normal flight,'' Odom said. ``For some reason, the left side was dipping and kept dipping. ``It was going through my mind that it was going down,'' he said. ``The next thing in my mind was that it had stopped and I had to get out. After I got out, I said, `Man, how lucky can you get?''' ``The only thing we could tell that was different was that it was taking off early, but it was picking up altitude,'' said Patrick Michael Duran, 33, of Meridian, Miss., who suffered a sprained arm. ``But instead of going straight off the runway, it went to the right.''

DOC.HEAD: Honorary Consul General Helps Liberians Adapt
With PM-Liberia-Freed American, Bjt
LaserPhoto CX3
DOC.TEXT: Alexander Gbayee lets strangers sleep in his home, buys them food and clothing and bails them out of jail. He's done that job for free since 1978, when Liberia appointed him its honorary consul for the Midwest. Now, 38 years after leaving, Gbayee plans to resettle in his troubled homeland. ``I think I can help more people, do more good over there,'' he said. Gbayee and other Liberian immigrants are organizing an emergency relief fund to help civilians trapped by an eight-month-old civil war in which more than 5,000 people, mostly civilians, have been killed. ``It's strictly a humanitarian effort,'' Gbayee said. ``We're not going to be helping any faction involved in the fighting. It's the average person, the common person, who's dying daily, and they have nothing to do with the government.'' Gbayee, 52, recently returned from a two-month visit to Monrovia, the Liberian capital, and said he expects soon to return for good. Operating out of a carpet shop on the South Side, Gbayee said he has helped many of the estimated 3,000 Liberians who have moved to the Midwest. ``It's an honorary position, there's no salary for that. I serve out of love for my country,'' he said. With his departure, the consulate will close until a successor is appointed, he said. In 1957, Gbayee traveled from his small African village of Dodoken to attend school in Chicago. He had been studying with missionaries from Chicago's Church of God and Christ, and, to a 13-year-old, America seemed ``almost like heaven.'' Village elders sold a cow for $24 to help finance the trip, he said. Gbayee graduated from a private Christian school and went on to earn a master's degree in education from Loyola University. Now, he said he uses his experience and education to help Liberians who sometimes arrive in the United States with no arrangements for shelter, no warm clothes and little money. All expenses come out of his own pocket, he said. When Africans have gotten in trouble with immigration officials and police, Gbayee said he's traveled as far as Texas to vouch for them or pay bail. In 1984, he said, 25 Liberian students arrived to attend Chicago State University, only to find themselves without room and board. Gbayee and his wife, Musu, took 11 into their four-bedroom apartment, found homes for the rest, and helped many get part-time jobs. ``I think he's gone beyond the line of duty to help people,'' said Willie Nebo, one of the students who spent six months camped in Gbayee's apartment. ``He does very well, not only for Liberians but for other Africans,'' said Nebo, who graduated this year from Chicago State University with an economics degree. Chernoh M. Sesay, Chicago State's vice president for academic affairs, said, ``He could just deal with people on an official level. But he loves people. He's one of a kind.'' Gbayee doesn't mind the lack of payment or gratitude from his country. ``What I do, the good is never lost,'' he said. ``I'll get greater reward from the Creator than human praise.''

DOC.HEAD: Gunship Strafes Bicycle-borne Tamil Rebels
DOC.TEXT: A helicopter gunship strafed and killed at least 100 Tamil rebels riding bicycles toward Jaffna to help stave off a government offensive against their stronghold, military officials said today. The Tamils were among 150 guerrillas who were attacked Thursday at Kopay, 5 miles northeast of Jaffna, according to the officials. The rebels accused the government of indiscriminate bombing of civilians. Jaffna town is the rebels' chief stronghold in their 7-year-old war for an independent state in the north and east of the island nation. The town lies on a lagoon on the Jaffna Peninsula at the northern tip of this Indian Ocean island nation. The only government presence in the town is 250 policemen and soldiers trapped in the 17th century Jaffna Fort since June 11 when the Tamil Tiger guerrillas broke a 13-month cease-fire with the Sinhalese-dominated government. On Wednesday, the government launched a new offensive and landed troops on Kayts Island, which faces the fort across 4 miles of water. So far, the government has said four soldiers were killed and 16 wounded by land mines in their push to reach the mainland. No independent reports have emerged on the fighting in Jaffna, 185 miles northeast of Colombo. Communications with the peninsula were cut this summer when the latest round of Tamil-Sinhalese fighting broke out. A Tiger statement, issued in London, charged that ``indiscriminate aerial and naval bombardment on heavily populated areas in the whole of the Jaffna Peninsula was claiming many civilian lives.'' The Tigers said Manthikai and Moolai hospitals in the heart of the peninsula were hit. The statement gave no casualty figures. The government says it bombs only ``identified rebel targets.'' It declared an around-the-clock curfew before launching the offensive. On Tuesday, airplanes dropped leaflets warning the peninsula's estimated 850,000 civilians to stay indoors until further notice. The government has declined to say how many troops have been deployed, but it said planes and boats landed 5,000 men in the peninsula in the last three days to join a force moving up the isthmus. Since the Tamil insurrection began in 1983, both sides have used heavy firepower and civilian casualties have been high. Tamil guerrillas have massacred whole villages of Sinhalese and Moslems in northern and eastern Sri Lanka as well as entire police garrisons. In the early years of the revolt, the government responded with massive land and air assaults that prompted neighboring India to intervene in 1987. The Indian peacekeeping force left in March after failing to quell the jungle war. At least 14,000 people have been killed in the war that grew out of Tamil complaints of discrimination by the Sinhalese majority. Moslems are caught in the war, accused by the Tamils of siding with the government. Sinhalese, who make up 75 percent of the 16 million people of Sri Lanka, have dominated the government and military since the Indian Ocean island became independent from Britain in 1949. Tamils comprise 18 percent, while Moslems account for 7 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``I think the manipulation of children in that way is contemptible ... It showed us a man completely unscrupulous in his choice of means. But I think it also showed us that he completely misunderstood the people that he is dealing with.'' _ British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd on Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's parading of Western captives before television cameras.

``The last thing I said when we were going down was, `God help me,' and I believe he did.'' _ Edward Odom, 28, of Stonewall, Miss., who suffered scratches on one hand in the crash of a private plane at Houston International Airport that killed three and injured 11 others.

``They aren't feeling the pinch as they did in the 1970s ... They aren't standing in line for gasoline. Prices for home heating oil haven't gone through the roof.'' _ Mary Ann Dittmer, director of communications for the Washington-based Alliance to Save Energy, saying the Mideast crisis has led few people to conserve more energy.

DOC.HEAD: Share Prices Up, Dollar Down in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Share prices in Tokyo rebounded today for the first time in seven trading days, helped by bargain hunting and a sense of confidence resulting from official efforts to save the suffering stock market. The U.S. dollar fell slightly against the yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average regained 428.13 points, or 1.8 percent, ending the day at 24,165.76. It was the first gain since Aug. 15 and followed two days of steep plunges. About 550 million shares, up from Thursday's 450 million, traded hands in moderate trading on the first section. The U.S. dollar closed at 145.70 yen, down 0.18 yen from Thursday's finish of 145.88 yen. The currency opened at 146.00 yen and ranged between 145.67 yen and 146.25 yen. About $9.4 billion changed hands in spot trading. The Nikkei was swayed throughout the day by reports that Iraqi troops were withdrawing from Kuwait. After peaking at mid-morning, the Nikkei fell almost 900 points by mid-afternoon before surging back. Traders said last-minute bargain hunting helped the late recovery. Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co., said a sense of confidence, resulting from the government effort to save the market, was gradually taking root among investors and supported the market. ``Their measures are not directly helping the market's recovery, but their action is at least a big psychological support,'' he said. Following Thursday's sharp decline, the Finance Ministry today eased restrictions on the amount of shares each security firm can trade on each issue. Also, the Tokyo Stock Exchange announced it would tighten technical regulations beginning today to restrict speculative trading. Earlier today, market players began buying when they heard a news report that Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein had ordered some elite troops withdrawn from the Kuwaiti-Saudi Arabian border, said Tomoya Koda, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. But Koda said the index lost its early gains when investors started selling ``because they reinterpreted the move negatively as a sign of Iraq's preparation in case of a U.S. attack.'' Meanwhile, on the foreign exchange market, the dollar weakened as a result of technical adjustments with the yen amid continuing uncertainties over the Gulf crisis, said Naohiko Yasuda, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo. He said investors tended to buy the yen based on their speculation that the Bank of Japan will have to raise its official discount rate to stem growing inflationary pressure resulting from soaring oil prices. North Brent crude oil for October delivery was notionally valued at $30.65-$30.75 per barrel at late afternoon. The level was lower than the $30.80 dollar-per-barrel level Thursday in Asia. Oil traders said participants pushed down oil prices by selling part of their overbought positions to take profits following a dramatic price increase since earlier this week.

DOC.HEAD: N.Y. Air National Guard Unit Activated
With PM-Gulf-Reserves, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon has begun calling up military reserve units to help U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf region. An Air National Guard unit in New York state was ordered to report for duty by midnight tonight. The 137th Military Airlift Squadron, a unit of the 105th Military Airlift Group of the New York Air National Guard, was activated late Thursday, squadron Lt. Col. John Perez said. The squadron, which has about 150 members, is based at Stewart International Airport in Newburgh. Many members are pilots, dock handlers and load masters trained to fly cargoes great distances, and they likely will be used to fly troops and materials into the Gulf region, Perez said. Nationwide, about 46,700 part-time soldiers will have been called by Oct. 1, about 9,800 of them by the end of this month, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Thursday. Williams said he could not rule out the possibility of more reserves being activated later. President Bush has the authority to call up as many as 200,000 reserves for up to 180 days without declaring a national emergency. The call-up of reserves, authorized by Bush on Wednesday, is the first since the Vietnam War.

DOC.HEAD: Robber Posing as Policeman Fatally Stabbed After Chase with Angry Neighbors
DOC.TEXT: A group of angry neighbors chased down a robber posing as a policeman, beating and kicking him as he slashed his victim before someone fatally stabbed him. After the stabbing, the crowd of Bronx neighbors dispersed and police were unable identify those involved, Lt. James Malvey said Thursday. ``They're tight-lipped,'' Malvey said of residents in the crime-ridden neighborhood. ``They saw a group of people struggling, period. They don't want to get involved.'' The dead man, found with stolen jewelry in his pocket, was identified as Jose Abreu, 49, of Queens, police said. The victims, Carlos Rosario and his wife, let two men into their apartment late Wednesday after the robbers yelled ``Open up. It's the police.'' Threatened with a gun, the couple was robbed and the thieves tried to tie them up. A struggle between Rosario and the robbers ensued, allowing his wife to flee through the fire escape. Her screams alerted neighbors and the robbers fled, followed by Rosario. The two men split up and Rosario followed the one he believed had his wife's jewelry, Malvey said. About 10 men joined in the chase and descended on Abreu after Rosario caught up with him about two blocks away. Rosario said Abreu slashed him on the shoulder during the scuffle, prompting him to roll out of harm's way. Rosario told police he did not see who stabbed Abreu and witnesses declined to help investigators, although officers believe the killing was justified. ``They are very wary of getting involved with anything that has to do with someone's death,'' Malvey said. ``At this point in the investigation, there is no reason to believe anything other than this is a good Samaritan act.'' The other robber got away. Rosario was treated for a knife wound at a nearby hospital. Violence in the West Farms section of the Bronx is commonplace, with drug dealing and drug-related robberies plaguing the area, residents say. There were as many as seven shootings there last summer, Jose Resto said. ``The kids don't have little .38s anymore, they have Uzis,'' he said. Police declined to call the mob attack vigilantism. But Thomas Reppetto, head of the Citizens Crime Commission, said: ``The signs are there that people are losing faith in the criminal justice system to protect them.'' Sandy Ayala, back in West Farms for a visit, said she moved away when a flying bullet grazed her son's head. ``The neighborhood is so bad that the cops are scared of it,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Long-Term Coil Said Highly Effective
DOC.TEXT: A Finnish company has introduced a five-year hormone-releasing contraceptive coil that doctors say is highly effective. The intrauterine device called Levanova-R was put on the Finnish market by the Leiras company on Thursday after getting government approval. Levanova-R releases levonorgestrel, a synthetic hormone that prevents fertilization, said Maija Haukkamaa, chief physician at Helsinki University Hospital. The coil is inserted for five years at a time, then replaced, unless pregnancy is desired. The advantage of the hormone-releasing coil is that fertility returns quickly after it is removed, Haukkamaa said in an interview. ``The new coil has a factor of 0.1 percent on the Pearl Index (which indicates the likelihood of pregnancy). That is the same as for sterilization. The factor for traditional IUD coils is as high as 1 percent to 3 percent,'' Haukkamaa said. The hormone-releasing IUD contraceptive is not recommended for young women or women who have never given birth. For such users, it could cause miscarriages and ectopic pregnancies, as other coils. ``But otherwise it is much safer and more comfortable,'' said Haukkamaa. Haukkamaa said she has tested the new IUD on thousands of Finnish women over 10 years, with good results. It also has been clinically tested in 25 countries, including in the United States.
