Professor Tapani Luukkainen, a member of the New York-based Population Council, said the coil would not have materialized after 18 years of research without support of the international council. ``They financed the research and we have a duty to try and market the coil in the United States, but the U.S. markets are very problematic,'' Luukkainen said. The coil is expected to sell in other European countries within two years and possibly before then in Scandinavia. Luukkainen said the new coil, at $90, compares favorably in price to traditional copper IUDs or other forms of contraception. The T-shaped plastic coil has a silicon cylinder which contains the contraceptive hormone. A thin film regulates the release of the hormone. ``The levonorgestrel hormone is completely safe and has been tested worldwide in countless forms, including in contraceptive pills, for many years,'' Luukkainen said. ``It stops menstrual bleeding and pain, and gives similar infection-protection as oral contraceptives. It also can be used as a cure for heavy menstrual bleeding,'' Luukkainen said. He added that it therefore could be used as a treatment for heavy bleeding and other ailments which often require hysterectomies.

DOC.HEAD: Pearl Bailey Remembered as Love Personified
DOC.TEXT: About 2,000 people filled a church to say goodbye to legendary entertainer Pearl Bailey, remembering her for her talent and loving personality. ``You'll always be here in our hearts where you belong,'' said entertainer Cab Calloway, borrowing a line from the broadway show ``Hello Dolly!'' Calloway co-starred with Miss Bailey in the all-black version of the show that earned her worldwide acclaim and a Tony Award. ``I mean it from my heart and soul, that Pearl Bailey was something you'll never see again,'' said Calloway, a pallbearer at Thursday's funeral service. Miss Bailey, who spent much of her childhood in Philadelphia, died here last Friday at the age of 72. About 2,000 people filled the Deliverance Evangelistic Church to pay their last respects to the singer and actress. Flowers from Lena Horne, Ella Fitzgerald and B.B. King were among those displayed in the church, but most mourners were family and friends from Philadelphia. ``If you knew Miss Bailey, she would like it to be plain and simple, not a lot of fanfare,'' the Rev. Timothy Jones, assistant pastor at the church, told the gathering. The service for the singer born in Newport News, Va., featured hymns, poetry and fond recollections. She was buried at Rolling Green Memorial Park in nearby West Chester, where her mother and brother are buried. ``Pearl was an original. She was a trailblazer, a teacher for all of us,'' singer Tony Orlando said. ``If you wanted to learn to do it right, you watched Pearl Bailey.'' Miss Bailey's show business career started in Philadelphia at age 15 when she sang ``Poor Butterfly'' in an amateur contest. She went on to a successful career as a jazz singer, star of stage and screen, and best-selling author. Once dubbed the ``ambassador of love,'' Miss Bailey endeared herself to generations of fans with a ready smile and abundant personal warmth. ``She loved everybody,'' said her husband of 38 years, jazz drummer Louis Bellson Jr. ``They will remember her as a great entertaineer,'' he said. ``She was a person of love. She believed `show business' was `show love.' ''

DOC.HEAD: Couple Wants to Get to the Bridge on Time
DOC.TEXT: Tom King plans to take a plunge of a different sort on his wedding day: He says he'll hurl himself off an 876-foot-high bridge. King plans to wed Vivian Campbell on Oct. 20 during the annual Bridge Day festivities at the New River Gorge Bridge. Then he plans to don a parachute and jump into the gorge, along with two groomsmen and several wedding guests. Bridge Day is the only day of the year people can legally jump off the bridge, one of North America's tallest. The event attracts hundreds of parachutists from around the world. King, 39, and Campbell, 34, both of Memphis, Tenn., got engaged on Bridge Day last year. She is a registered nurse. King, a real estate appraiser and keen skydiver for two decades, found out about Bridge Day in 1984 and has taken part every year since.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Officials Urge `Decisive' Force Against Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Pentagon officials are urging a ``decisive'' attack against Iraq using air, naval and ground force if President Bush orders the use of U.S. military might in the Persian Gulf crisis, a newspaper reported today. The Joint Chiefs of Staff are urging that any military action against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and his huge war-making capacity be sweeping, simultaneous and deadly, the Los Angeles Times reported today. ``We will attempt to be decisive,'' said Air Force Chief of Staff Gen. Michael J. Dugan. Dugan and other officials stressed that the U.S. would not take military action without provocation. Saddam is holding an estimated 3,000 Americans and 3,000 Britons hostage in Iraq and Kuwait and has ordered some of them held at potential military targets. The Pentagon is compiling an exhaustive list of Iraqi targets for U.S. airplanes, the Times reported. The Air Force has dispatched an estimated 250 fighters bombers and fighters, and the Navy has an extra 270 aircraft ready. Those targets could include Saddam's presidential palace; military command centers; Iraq's chemical and nuclear weapons complexes; ballistic missile sites; military airfields; oil refineries and pipelines; water purification plants; ports, rail lines and highways, analysts said. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Thursday the United States was organizing a significant military presence in the Middle East and would respond aggressively if provoked. ``If (Saddam) were foolish enough to attack U.S. forces, we clearly are in a position, if the President so decides, to respond very forcefully against those things he cares about _ and specifically, those are his forces and his capabilities inside Iraq,'' Cheney said. Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, delivered an explicit threat to Saddam on Thursday. ``We will defend our interests. Don't try to scare us or threaten us. It won't work,'' Powell declared in a speech to the Veterans of Foreign Wars convention in Baltimore.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq TV Shows Saddam Visiting Hostages; Some Smile, Others Wary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with British teen freed; Edits to trim; No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY26,NY27,WX7, LaserColor NY126,NY127 of Aug. 23
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein, parading some of his Western captives on TV, ruffled the hair of a British child and told the uneasy group they are not hostages but peacemakers. The Iraqi president today freed a British teen-ager traveling alone caught in the standoff over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. But Saddam's TV performance, which Western governments denounced as a sham show of sympathy, gave no hope that Americans and other foreign captives would soon be freed from their role as human shields to deter an attack on Iraq. The smiling Iraqi _ who traded his customary military uniform for a gray suit for the broadcast Thursday _ told about 20 adults and children they were being held ``to prevent the scourge of war.'' ``You are not hostages here,'' he said, calling them ``guests.'' Some of the hostages smiled back; others appeared wary. The Westerners' names weren't given, but at least two families were identified by British relatives. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd called the broadcast ``the most sickening thing I've seen for a long time.'' ``I think the manipulation of children in that way is contemptible,'' he said. ``It showed us a man completely unscrupulous in his choice of means. But I think it also showed us that he completely misunderstood the people that he is dealing with.'' In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said: ``Saddam Hussein is obviously more interested in some sort of shameful theatrics than in dealing with the two issues that really matter, and that's withdrawal from Kuwait and freedom for innocent civilians.'' A 45-minute tape of the meeting was broadcast on Iraq's state television showing the hostages taken in the aftermath of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. It was an apparent attempt to show the hostages were not being mistreated, It wasn't known when the tape was made or where the meeting was held. British Airways said 15-year-old Alex Barnett arrived in the Jordanian capital of Amman this morning on an Iraqi Airways flight from Baghdad, after Iraq freed him to leave. Barnett had been traveling alone on a British Airways flight heading from London to Madras, India and Malaysia that was stranded in Kuwait City during the Aug. 2 invasion, the airline said. An airline official said Barnett, Hamilton, Scotland, would be put on the first available flight from Amman to London. Saddam has said the foreigners _ including 3,000 Americans and 4,500 Britons _ will be held until the U.S.-led multinational force is withdrawn from Saudi Arabia and an international embargo against Iraq is lifted. Flanked by army officers and speaking through an interpreter, the Iraqi president said on the tape he ordered the Westerners interned at potential military targets ``to deter war.'' ``If the Western media and governments chose to describe that as using them as a human shield, that's their own interpretation,'' he said. Saddam, 52, made jokes, arranged a group photograph, and attempted to draw a friendly response from some of the children shown on the broadcast. At one point, he ruffled the hair of a boy who was standing by his side, and the boy appeared to lean away. Saddam asked two boys if they had enough room to play sports, and if they were getting enough milk and food. One said he was getting enough milk and corn flakes. Saddam then laughed and, turning to one of his officers and said: ``He is getting more than our Iraqi children. I don't think Iraqi children can get corn flakes.'' Iraq has warned that if a United Nations embargo imposed on Iraq brings food shortages, Westerners will suffer first. Saddam asked the foreign captives to forgive him for keeping them in Iraq. ``This does not make us happy. What would make us happy would be to see you back in your countries, or back in Baghdad ... in the normal way you used to do,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in the East, Hot and Muggy in the South, Some Showers Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: Summer rain fell along the East Coast early today from New York to North Carolina, cloudy skies and some fog blanketed parts of the Midwest, while clear skies and dry weather prevailed in most of the West. Scattered showers were feared from North Dakota southward to parts of New Mexico and Texas, and elsewhere. Thunderstorms today were expected to worsen the threat of flooding along the mid-Atlantic coast. Rain was possible from New York into Florida. High temperatures and muggy weather continue to plague the South, with intense heat also expected in much of Arkansas, where advisories of temperatures between 105 degrees and 110 degrees were in effect. In the West, temperatures were cooling somewhat. Patchy mountain showers from northern California to western Montana were forecast, with rain also possible in northwestern Washington state. Mostly dry weather was forecast for the Midwest, with some scattered rain in the Plains. The nation's high on Thursday was 108 degrees at Lake Havasu City, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Seven OPEC Ministers To Hold Informal Talks on Sunday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE with countries expected to attend. Pickup 7th, `Fears of...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: OPEC oil producing nations meeting this weekend in Vienna will discuss how to respond to the Persian Gulf crisis, which has tightened world supplies and sent crude prices soaring. Venezuela and oil giant Saudi Arabia would like OPEC's approval to boost production to help meet the shortfall, but the Saudis have said they'll pump more regardless of what the cartel decides. An OPEC source speaking on condition of anonymity said the cartel's president, Algerian Oil Minister Sadek Boussena, will be in Vienna Sunday and ``he will consult with anybody who cares to come.'' But the informal meeting could turn into an emergency session in which decisions could be made, said Venezuela's energy and mines minister, Celestino Armas. Oil ministers from most of the 13 nations making up the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed to attend the talks in Vienna, the cartel's headquarters, Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez said in Caracas. An OPEC official said on condition of anonymity this morning that ministers from Algeria, Indonesia, Nigeria, Iran, Gabon, Ecuador and Venezuela would attend. Fears of military escalation in the Mideast and shortages of oil on Thursday sent futures prices for crude oil up 71 cents to $31.93 a barrel. Perez did not say the meeting would mean increased production to make up for the international embargo of Kuwait and Iraq, imposed after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of its oil-rich neighbor. Boosting production to make up for the decline in Iraqi and Kuwaiti shipments, which amounts to about 4 million barrels of crude oil daily, has received insufficient support among OPEC members. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency quoted Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh as saying his trip ``is a positive response to (Boussena's) call for an exchange of views on the current situation in the world oil market.'' One source said Saudi Arabia also was likely to attend, but there was no official confirmation of the report. Indonesian Oil Minister Ginandjar Kartasasmita was quoted by a local newspaper in Jakarta as saying neither Iraq nor Kuwait would attend the weekend talks. Boussena made a surprise visit Thursday to Jiddah, Saudi Arabia, for talks with Hisham Nazer, the kingdom's oil minister, who was rebuffed earlier in the week in an attempt to call an emergency session of all 13 nations. Nazer, along with Venezuela's Armas, had requested the meeting to discuss the turbulent situation. But OPEC headquarters issued a statement Monday saying there was not enough support among the others to hold a formal meeting. Nazer said last weekend Saudi Arabia, which produces about a quarter of the cartel's oil, would lift pumping to 2 million barrels a day, with or without the nod from OPEC.

DOC.HEAD: Police Officers Shot; Kill Man
DOC.TEXT: Two police officers shot a man to death early today after the man shot and wounded both of them, police said. The name of the dead man was not immediately released. Officer Christopher Knight, 27, was in stable condition at San Francisco General Hospital with a wound to the left knee, a nursing supervisor said. Officer Nicholas Shihadeh, 28, was treated for a wound to the chin and relased, she said. The officers responded to an apparent suicide attempt in the Potrero Hill neighborhood shortly after 1:30 a.m. and found a man wielding a gun, Sgt. Marsha Ashe said. When the man fired, the officers returned fire, she said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Israel and Jordan Watching Warily
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 14 with new grafs 14-15, updating.
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Israel and Jordan, two small Middle Eastern nations that exist side by side in an uneasy and unofficial state of peace, are watching Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's moves with apprehension. The lightning invasion of Kuwait Aug. 2 reminded the world what Israelis and Jordanians always have known: Small nations can disappear in the twinkling of an eye. Their survival in the volatile region requires skill and considerable luck. Neither enjoys Saudi Arabia's benevolent resources. Neither can depend on others to fight their battles. As they watch and wait, Israel is counting on its military might and the tactical resourcefulness that sustained it against overwhelming odds in the past. Jordan is depending on Iraq being engaged elsewhere and on King Hussein's diplomatic footwork. Neither is looking to the United States to dispatch tens of thousands of troops as President Bush has done to protect the Saudi oil fields. Israeli leaders consistently have said they do not want Americans fighting their wars. American weapons have made Israel the most powerful military state in the area. The Israelis are willing to take it from there. As for Jordan, the king also is bolstered by U.S. weapons and economic aid. If he felt threatened by Iraq he would be unlikely to call for U.S. troops to defend the country. Inviting American military intervention could provoke Saddam Hussein, his far more powerful neighbor, and, a U.S. official said privately, probably would be a ``death sentence'' for the king. Saddam's denunciation of Zionists leaves no doubt about his attitude toward Israel. A Jewish state has no place in his vision of the area. His approach to Jordan is less clear. Aqaba, the kingdom's port on the Red Sea, has a strategic attraction. There is support for Saddam Hussein among many of the king's subjects. And Jordan stands between Iraq and Israel. Saddam's goal probably is a pliant Jordan rather than occupation of the country. That could give him access to Aqaba and use of Jordanian territory for Moslem fundamentalists to antagonize Syria, an old Iraqi foe. King Hussein is in a tough spot. He has tried not to cross either Saddam or President Bush. That's almost impossible in the current state of high tensions, but the King, looking out for No. 1, is trying his best. On the one hand, he gave assurances to Bush last week in Maine that Jordan would observe the economic boycott of Iraq. On the other, the king said he was not clear about the exact terms of the sanctions, thereby leaving himself wriggle room. The king moved on Thursday to close Jordan's border with Iraq, which could make escape from that country and from Kuwait more difficult for trapped foreign nationals. But thousands made it over, and today Jordan's interior ministry announced the border would remain open. Hussein challenged Bush's defense of Saudi Arabia, saying there was no evidence Iraq was about to launch an attack when the president rushed troops and warships to the region. Probably the best insurance the king has taken out is to offer himself as the potential mediator between Iraq and the United States. The two sides are too far at odds right now to look for a negotiated way out of the crisis. Saddam's terms for releasing the 3,000 trapped Americans is a U.S. withdrawal from Saudi Arabia. But should the Iraqi leader find his back against the wall _ and the economic squeeze could accomplish that _ he might offer enough to get negotiations started. In the meantime, Israeli leaders have warned Iraq not to move troops into Jordan. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has said he would like to believe that Saddam ``knows that any attempt to harm us will cost him and his army dearly.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid has covered Mideast diplomacy for The Associated Press since 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Florence American Legion Post Will Invite Rejected Black To Apply
DOC.TEXT: A veteran whose application to join an American Legion post was rejected last month because he was black will be invited to join after all. And Thurman Thompson said he'll accept. Inviting Thompson to join the Fred H. Sexton Post 1 in Florence is just one of the actions that enables the post to resume its normal activities after being suspended last week, said Norris Kinion, state commander for the American Legion. ``What I would hope is that those who didn't want me, they would re-evaluate their thoughts and situations,'' Thompson said Thursday night. ``I hope that everything ends on a positive note.'' According to mintutes of a July meeting, members of the post said they did not want a black in the all-white post, which has more than 200 members. At the time, the post required just two votes to reject an applicant. But the post changed its bylaws Tuesday to call for a majority vote on all applications, Kinion said. The bylaws now conform with state and national rules, Kinion said. The other American Legion post in Florence, post 228, has no by-laws on race but has only black members. The suspension of post 1 has not been formally lifted, he said, ``but they're being permitted to function until such time as the investigative committee can make its report.'' Al Stein, commander of the Florence post, said Thursday he would like Thompson to apply again. He had originally proposed Thompson as a member before other Post members voted against it. Thompson is a former Navy petty officer and signalman who served in Vietnam in 1972 and 1973. The rejection of Thompson prompted several members to resign, and the Florence County legislative delegation fired Maria Lewis, the county's veterans affairs officer, for her role in the incident. Ms. Lewis was the post's secretary. She had been under fire for opposing Thompson's membership on grounds that bylaws prohibited the integration of black and white posts.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Couple Tied Up in Apartment, Woman's Sister Charged
DOC.TEXT: A woman was tied up for six days and her boyfriend suffocated while five people, including the woman's 16-year-old sister, allegedly partied and sold the items in their apartment, police said. Freddy Thomas, 32, suffocated while locked in a closet and bound with duct tape, said Sgt. Mary Wrensen, a police spokeswoman. Thomas, who also had been hit on the head with the butt of a shotgun, was believed to have died Saturday, Wrensen said. His girlfriend, Orpah Sanders, 34, managed to escape Wednesday, six days after the ordeal began, Wrensen said. She was treated at a hospital and released. Locked in the bedroom, Sanders freed herself from duct tape, climbed down the fire escape and told neighbors to call police. Arrested and charged Thursday with second-degree murder, robbery, and unlawful imprisonment were Sanders' sister, Hope Kelly, 16; William Fennel, 21; Samuel Rivera, 17; and Barbara Redding, 17, all from the borough of the Bronx. A fifth suspect had not been found, Wrensen said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Coast Guard Plane Crashes, Four Killed
DOC.TEXT: Fire broke out aboard a U.S. Coast Guard plane and it crashed early today near a Navy base, killing all four crewmen, the Coast Guard said. The crew reported the fire and radioed for permission to land before the twin-turboprop Grumman E-2C Hawkeye crashed, Coast Guard spokesman Bruce Pimental said. The cause of the crash was being investigated. Pimental said it was believed that a hydraulics problem caused the fire. The names of the victims were being withheld pending notification of relatives. Pimental said the plane is one of four based in St. Augustine, Fla., that are used for anti-drug-smuggling operations. The plane crashed near a gate of the Roosevelt Roads naval base in Ceiba, in eastern Puerto Rico.

DOC.HEAD: California Man Charged After Wife Commits Suicide In Michigan
DOC.TEXT: The inability of authorities to prosecute a suburban doctor who helped a woman commit suicide apparently led a California man to believe he could help his cancer-ravaged wife end her life in Michigan. But while Dr. Jack Kevorkian remains free, Bertram R. Harper is being held at Wayne County Jail on charges of murder and conspiracy to commit murder. Harper, 72, of Loomis, Calif., was arrested Sunday, shortly after his wife Virginia, 69, died in a room at the Comfort Inn in Romulus on Detroit's outskirts, court records show. Their daughter, Shanda McGrew, was present but was not charged. Kevorkian gained attention when he used a suicide device he had created to help an Alzheimer's disease patient end her life June 4. Mrs. Harper developed breast cancer two years ago, and brought to Michigan a note from a physician indicating she had only two weeks to live, said Derek Humphry, executive director of the Hemlock Society, a nationwide death-on-demand organization. Before ingesting sleeping pills and placing a plastic bag over her head, she wrote a note saying she wished to die in the presence of her husband and daughter, Humphry said. A cause of death has yet to be determined. The family flew to Michigan on Saturday after learning from the widely publicized death of Janet Adkins, 54, of Portland, Ore., that Michigan has no specific law against suicide or assisting in it, Humphry said. Kevorkian has not been charged in the death of Adkins, 54, of Portland, Ore. The 62-year-old retired pathologist used his device, which released lethal chemicals into her system, in his van at a county park about 40 miles north of Detroit. As to why one suicide resulted in charges and the other hasn't, Wayne County Prosecutor John O'Hair said: ``You'll have to ask (Oakland County Prosecutor) Dick Thompson that. We felt we had a legal and factual basis to charge Mr. Harper.'' O'Hair refused to comment on Harper's specific role in his wife's death or give details on why he was charged with murder. Thompson said Thursday the Adkins case remained under criminal investigation. ``We are waiting for the results of toxicology tests'' on Mrs. Adkins' body, Thompson said. ``When we get those test results, we will make a determination whether what he did was a crime.'' Humphry said the Harpers did not attempt to contact Kevorkian, who has been barred by court order from further use of his device. Harper called police shortly after his wife died, Humphry said. The charges against Harper are each punishable by up to life imprisonment, District Court administrator Nancy Schuette said. Harper was held on $25,000 bond pending a preliminary hearing Aug. 29, she said. Humphry said his Eugene, Ore.-based society will help find a lawyer for Harper and, if necessary, pay for it. The Harpers joined the group in 1988 but did not consult with it before traveling to Michigan, Humphry said. ``They went to Michigan thinking they'd be free of prosecution,'' Humphry said. ``I think it's a major reaction against Dr. Kevorkian. They can't charge Dr. Kevorkian with anything. This looks as though it's a knee-jerk reaction.'' Under California law, assisting in suicide is a crime punishable by up to five years in prison, Humphry said.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Pleads Guilty to Money Laundering for Cartel
DOC.TEXT: A Colombian who prosecutors say was the Medellin drug cartel's financial minister faces 30 years in federal prison after pleading guilty to helping launder more than $1.2 billion. Eduardo Martinez-Romero submitted the plea Thursday in U.S. District Court during a hearing held amid tight security after the death of co-defendant Gustavo Gaviria in a shootout Aug. 11 with Colombian authorities. Speaking through an interpreter, Martinez-Romero told Judge WilliaO

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Begins Call-Up of U.S. Military Reserves
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 12 grafs on Air Force activation announcement; picks up 5th graf pvs, The Pentagon.
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force said today it has activated six reserve units to supplement its air transport operation for the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf area. The callup of Air National Guard and Air Force Reserve units from six states marks the start of a national mobilization of reserves that President Bush authorized on Wednesday. The mobilization is expected to continue at least until Oct. 1. Army, Navy and Coast Guard reserve forces also are scheduled to be activated. ``The calls are going out,'' said Air Force Maj. Doug Hart, a Defense Department spokesman. Hart also disclosed that about 14,000 members of the Army and Air Force reserve forces already have voluntarily gone on active duty. The six units announced by the Air Force are: _183rd Military Airlift Squadron, Air National Guard from Jackson, Miss., flying C-141B Starlifter transport planes. _137th Military Airlift Squadron, Air National Guard from Stewart, N.Y., flying C-5A Galaxies. _136th Mobile Aerial Port Squadron, Air National Guard from Dallas, Texas, to provide an airlift terminal and cargo managers. _732nd Military Airlift Squadron, Air Force Reserve from McGuire Air Force Base, N.J., flying C-141B Starlifters. _756th Military Airlift Squadron, Air Force Reserve from Andrews Air Force Base, Md., flying C-141B Starlifters. _337th Military Airlift Squadron, Air Force Reserve from Westover Air Force Base, Mass., flying C-5A Galaxies. The Pentagon announced on Thursday that about 46,700 reserves will be called to active duty over the next five weeks for Operation Desert Shield and that most of the part-time soldiers will be posted in or near Saudi Arabia. Most reserves sent to help defend Saudi Arabia against a possible Iraqi attack won't be driving tanks or digging foxholes. But they will tackle two of the most important tasks in desert warfare: getting water and protecting against chemical attacks. It's unclear whether any reserve combat units, such as the Georgia National Guard unit that comprises one of three brigades in the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division at Fort Stewart, Ga., will be dispatched to the forbidding Saudi desert. The two active-duty brigades in the 24th already are on their way there. Pete Williams, the Pentagon press secretary, said most of the Army and Air Force reserve forces called to active duty will be deployed to Saudi Arabia. Of the Navy reserves who are activated, about half will be sent there, he said. Many of the military's key skills are held mainly by reserve units. Among those considered most important for Desert Shield are water distribution and purification specialists and experts in chemical decontamination, officials said. Van D. Hipp Jr., deputy assistant secretary of the Army for reserve forces and mobilization, said in an interview that 100 percent of the Army's water purification and distribution manpower is in the reserves. In the Saudi desert, where temperatures in summer often top 120 degrees, American GIs are drinking as much as six gallons of water a day to avoid dehydration. Water also is needed for cooking, washing and other vital functions. Also, 65 percent of the Army's chemical decontamination manpower is in the reserves, Hipp said. The prospect of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ordering a poison gas attack on U.S. forces is one of the biggest concerns of troops hunkering down in the desert. Doctors, nurses and other medical personnel also are largely in the reserves. Williams said Thursday that about 9,800 part-time soldiers will have been called to leave their civilian jobs by the end of August. The total is expected to reach about 46,700 by Oct. 1, and Williams said he could not rule out the possibility of more reserves being activated later. President Bush has the authority to call up as many as 200,000 reserves for up to 180 days without declaring a national emergency. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney approved the services' requests for reserve call-ups and also authorized them to force an unspecified number of active-duty soldiers, sailors and airmen already in the Middle East to put off plans to retire or quit. The call-up of reserves, authorized by Bush on Wednesday, is the first since the Vietnam War. Under an order signed by Cheney, as many as 49,703 Army, Air Force, Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard reserves could be activated by Oct. 1, but Williams said the Marine Corps was not planning to use the 3,000 reserves it is allowed to call. Those called to active duty will serve 90-day tours, but the period could be extended another 90 days if Cheney decides that is necessary, Williams said. Williams gave the following breakdown of expected reserve call-ups by service: _Army: 24,734 by Oct. 1; to fill immediate needs, 4,912 of the total will be called by Aug. 31. _Air Force: 14,476, of which 1,002 will be called by the end of the month. _Navy: 6,243, with 3,030 activated by Aug. 31. _Coast Guard: 1,200, including 700 by the end of the month. Williams said the numbers represent what each service believes it will need to supplement its active duty force and that Cheney approved the figures as upper limits. The actual number called up could be slightly less, Williams said. ``We will call up only what we need and only when we need it,'' Williams said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Imposes State of Emergency in Townships
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Vlok news conference, adds details on state of emergency, background. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The government imposed a state of emergency today in black townships hit by savage tribal fighting that has cost more than 500 lives and said troops and police would be poured into the areas. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok declared black townships around Johannesburg ``unrest areas.'' The action gives police widespread powers under the internal security laws to detain people and to take action to suppress demonstrations and violence. ``It is in the interest of South Africa and all its inhabitants that further bloodshed, disorder and chaos be prevented at all costs,'' Vlok said in a statement issued in Pretoria. The government action came as riot police strung razor wire and fired shotguns and tear gas today to keep warring Zulus and Xhosas apart as military reservists were called up to help stop the fighting. Vlok also ordered that people in the unrest areas would not be allowed to carry a wide range of weapons at public meetings. The banned weapons included firearms, spears, battle axes, pitchforks, knives and machetes. He said the emergency declaration in each area would last up to three months. The minister also promised that police and army units in the areas would be ``drastically increased,'' but gave no details. The declaration gives police authority to take almost any steps they regard as necessary to maintain order in affected areas. But Vlok told journalists the measure would not include bans on reporting in the areas. A nationwide state of emergency imposed in 1985 had restricted reporting on unrest. The government lifted the emergency on June 8 in all areas except for Natal Province, where black factional fighting has killed thousands. The African National Congress had demanded lifting of the nationwide state of emergency as a condition of formal talks with the white-led government on a new constitution. ANC officials had no immediate response to Vlok's statement. Police strung razor wire today around Zulu hostels in Kagiso township west of Johannesburg to keep hundreds of heavily-armed Zulus from fighting local Xhosa residents. Riot squads demolished barricades put up by residents in the town where four people were killed Thursday. Residents were demanding Zulus be driven out of the migrant worker hostels. ``Kill them, that's the only way. An eye for an eye. They must go back to Zululand,'' said one angry woman. Police also clashed today in Vosloorus township east of Johannesburg with stone throwing protesters who tried to block streets with burning car tires and other debris. Senior police commanders said most townships around Johannesburg were tense but quiet. A lull appeared to have set in, and police hoped to restore order, said one commander, who spoke on condition of anonymity. A South African Defense Force spokesman said military reservists were being called up in Johannesburg to beef up police and regular army units deployed in the townships. The spokesman, who declined to be named, gave no figures on how many reservists were being called to duty. Zulus, mostly loyal to the conservative Inkatha movement, and Xhosas who support the ANC have been battling since Aug. 12 with guns, spears, axes, knives and other weapons. More than 500 people have been killed in the fighting around Johannesburg. ANC leader Nelson Mandela said Thursday the government should place soldiers and police around migrant workers hostels in the townships where much of the violence has occurred. Asked if he thought the violence was easing, Mandela said: ``I don't think so. I think it's too early to say that.'' The fighting has continued despite pleas from government and black leaders for peace and a strong police and army presence in the townships. It is considered the most serious violence since nationwide unrest in the mid-1980s. Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu, who cut short a visit to Canada because of the violence, on Thursday toured parts of Tokoza, one of the hardest hit townships. ``We have come to express solidarity with them,'' Tutu said of the residents. ``Their pain is our pain.'' Tutu has called for an international peacekeeping force to halt the fighting. Meanwhile, ANC spokesman Pallo Jordan said the ANC and Inkatha plan to hold exploratory talks soon. ``We have, in the last week, tried to initiate talks at the grassroots level,'' Jordan told government-run television. ``Talks can take place at any number of levels.'' However, he said there was no guarantee Mandela would meet Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi. The ANC blames Inkatha for spreading black factional fighting from the eastern province of Natal Province to the townships near Johannesburg. Political violence between ANC and Inkatha supporters has killed some 5,000 blacks in Natal in the past five years. Inkatha accuses the ANC of trying to wipe out any competition for power among black opposition groups. Both groups oppose apartheid, the system of segregation and white dominance, but differ on the shape of a future South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Jordan Still Allowing Refugees In; American Couple Arrives
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Turkey saying it may close border. Pickup 11th graf pvs, `Earlier today...'
DOC.TEXT: Jordanian officials were again allowing thousands of refugees to cross over from Iraq today, despite an announcement earlier this week that the border would be closed to them. But Turkey, another escape route for refugees, said today it might close its border with Iraq. Also today, two Americans, a young married couple, were among those arriving in the Jordanian capital aboard an Iraqi Airways flight with two dozen other people. United Nations officials at the airport identified the couple as ``Mr. and Mrs. Gray,'' but did not provide their full names or hometown. Meanwhile, Jordan's King Hussein returned from a short visit to Sudan and Yemen, where he discussed the Persian Gulf crisis with leaders of both countries. Jordan had said Wednesday it was closing its border with Iraq, effective Thursday, because of the strain caused by tens of thousands of refugees who have flooded the country since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. But a senior border security official said 6,000 foreigners, mainly Arabs or Asians, had crossed from Iraq at the Ruweishid border post, 210 miles northeast of Amman, by midday today. The official Jordanian news agency Petra quoted an unidentified Interior Ministry spokesman as saying that border officials had been told to allow in 20,000 evacuees today. Also arriving today aboard the Iraqi Airways flight was a 15-year-old Scottish boy, Alex Cameron-Barnette, who had been stranded in Kuwait for 22 days. Airport officials said he was traveling alone. AP Photographer Max Nash, who was at Queen Alia International Aiport, reported the arrivals. Meanwhile, in Turkey, which also borders Iraq, beleaguered officials said they may close the frontier with Iraq unless countries whose nationals are coming through take steps to ensure quick transit. Premier Yildirim Akabulut said Turkey's only crossing point with Iraq, the Habur post, was built for commercial truck traffic and lacks facilities to handle large numbers of people. Turkey's semi-official Anatolia news agency said today that 56 foreigners, including Austrians, Swedes and Finns, had since arrived late Thursday night. Earlier today, a Jordanian government official said many countries had appealed to Amman to rescind its order to close the border, one of the few escape routes from Iraq. ``We want to tell the world that we closed the borders only because the massive influx of people was creating serious problems for us,'' the official said on condition he not be identified. An international effort to help Jordan cope with the refugees picked up steam today. In Geneva, a United Nations official said a planeload of 30 to 40 tons of emergency aid, including food, drinking water, blankets and garbage bags to promote hygience would fly from Itay to Jordan on Monday or Tuesday. Mohammad Khatib, spokesman for the Office of the U.N. Disaster Relief Coordinator, said the United Nations has allotted $30,000 for immediate aid to Jordan to handle the refugee influx. In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher told reporters Thursday that the U.S. Embassy in Amman released $25,000 from the embassy's discretionary relief fund to Jordan to help care for refugees. Belgium said today it would send two military transport planes to Jordan to help airlift refugees. Also, the Netherlands and France contributed a total of $848,000 dollars to the airlift.

DOC.HEAD: Teen-ager Charged with Capital Murder
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager who is confined to a wheelchair was charged with capital murder today after he and another teen-ager allegedly chased down and killed a woman during a robbery, police said. Sgt. Chip Pippen said Janie Howell, 44, was shot on a city street, apparently as she tried to reach the police department on foot. Pippen said Mondrick Bradley, 18, and a 13-year-old boy were arrested a short time later and charged with capital murder. Bradley has been confined to a wheelchair since being shot last year. Pippen said Bradley, whose wheelchair was pushed by the younger boy, allegedly had a pistol and fired shots at the woman as she fled. ``They apparently caught up with her and she was shot in the right side of the head and was dead at the scene,'' Pippen said. ``Her watch was missing.'' Authorities said Bradley had a history of gang-related activity but they were unsure whether the shooting that left him paralyzed was gang related.

DOC.HEAD: Industrial Carcinogens Could Be Cause of Alarming Cancer Rise
DOC.TEXT: Alarming increases in the occurrence of certain cancers in the elderly could be the result of increasing exposure to industrial carcinogens, researchers said Friday. In a report in the British journal The Lancet, researchers from the United States, Europe and Asia concluded that brain and other nervous system cancer had roughly doubled in people aged 65-84 from 1968 to 1987. Breast cancer, kidney cancer, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, myeloma and melanoma have also increased in people 55 or older, the researchers said. These patterns have previously been reported in the United States, but this study finds the same trends in selected countries in Europe and Asia, said the researchers, led by Devra Lee Davis of the National Academy of Sciences in Washington, D.C. They speculated that changes in exposure to carcinogens in the environment could be one explanation. Older people have had greater exposure to industrial carcinogens, including badly regulated exposure to newly introduced household pesticides and chemicals in the 1940s and 1950s, the researchers said. The elderly have also experienced greater exposure to carcinogens in the workplace, because they have worked longer and worked at a time when there were fewer environmental controls on such carcinogens, the researchers said. Exposure to other illnesses, such as influenza during the large epidemic in 1918, might also have helped predispose older people to cancer. The findings summarized in the article in The Lancet are the outgrowth of a workshop held in October 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Journalists Must Give Information in Civil Suits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `Allyn' is cq in last graf.
DOC.TEXT: A court has ruled that journalists must give unpublished photographs and notes to people involved in lawsuits over fires and other public events. The 2-1 ruling, released Thursday by the Michigan Court of Appeals, was the first time a Michigan court considered the issue. ``The obligation of all persons to give evidence necessary for the proper administration of justice is a fundamental civic duty applicable to both criminal and civil cases,'' the ruling said. The decision involved The Ann Arbor News, a member of Booth Newspapers Inc., which appealed a Washtenaw County Circuit Court order that it turn over unpublished photographs of a fire scene. No decision has been made on appealing to the Michigan Supreme Court, said Timothy White, the paper's publisher. ``Clearly it's not favorable to us and we were very confident of winning on appeal.'' A Michigan State University associate professor of journalism said the ruling is similar to those in other states which lack broad press shield laws. Todd Simon, who is co-author of ``Mass Communication Law,'' said, ``They treat the photographer or reporter observing something as no different from any other witness.'' The photographs, taken of a Jan. 4, 1986, fire at Mark Video Enterprises Inc., were sought by American Employers Insurance for use in a civil lawsuit brought by business owner George J. Marketos after the company rejected his claim. The company claimed arson was involved in the $1.3 million fire. The News turned over its 20 unpublished photographs after the appeals court agreed to decide the broader issue. The pictures were not used in the trial. A majority of the court said no privilege exists under the First Amendment, the Michigan Constitution or the Michigan Press Shield Law. The shield law protects journalists from disclosing before grand juries confidential information from informants. The court rejected the newspaper's arguments that it would be too much trouble to produce photographs and material for anyone who wanted to use them in a lawsuit. The News previously provided photographs for anyone who requested them at the price of $5, the ruling said. The newspaper could seek a court order to protect it from requests that were harassment, oppressive or unduly expensive, the ruling said. In a dissent, Judge John H. Shepherd said reporters should be protected unless their information is essential to the civil case and unobtainable elsewhere. Allyn Kantor, attorney for American Employers, did not return a telephone call seeking comment.

DOC.HEAD: Upper-Caste Students Protest Hiring Plan That Favors Lower Castes
LaserPhoto DEL1
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of students battled police and hijacked buses today during protests against a government plan to reserve jobs for low-caste Hindus. The students tried to storm Parliament and hurled rocks at police and government buildings. Police responded with tear gas and tossed some of the rocks back at the demonstrators. The daylong protest brought traffic and business to a halt in many districts of the capital city of 8 million people. Police and paramilitary troops went on alert after students surged into streets, stopping traffic and urging motorists to join their campaign. The students commandeered dozens of city buses and drove them to Parliament. They tried to storm the massive, circular building but police beat them back with steel-tipped bamboo poles. The police set up rope and metal barricades and fired repeated rounds of tear gas when the students tried to form a human chain around the Parliament building in downtown New Delhi. ``We don't want the politicians to come out of the Parliament. Let them perish there,'' said Vinod Kumar Bist, a first-year university student. Angry students attacked policemen with rocks and tree branches. Some hurled empty soft drink bottles. At least 75 students were arrested, Assistant Police Commissioner R.K. Neogi said. He did not say if they would be charged or how long they would be held. Neogi said the students damaged at least 50 buses. Protests started three weeks ago and have spread to six states. One of the first flashpoints was Bihar, India's poorest state, where at least three people have died. The trouble began when Prime Minister V.P. Singh announced that the government would reserve an additional 27 percent of public sector jobs for special categories of low-caste Hindus. Some lower castes and tribes already are protected by quotas. The latest plan would bring reserved jobs to 49 percent, leaving 51 percent of government jobs awarded on merit. Singh said ``disadvantaged communities'' comprise 52 percent of India's 880 million people but have only 12.5 percent of government jobs. His plan angered students from higher castes, who called it ``reverse discrimination'' that would hurt their chances of finding work after graduation. Government jobs are prized because they provide security and benefits, such as free housing. Hindus have a complex social system with hundreds of castes and subcastes that divide them into a rigid hierarchy. High-caste Hindus usually are better off economically. Discrimination on the basis of caste is banned by law, but the system still permeates Indian society, especially in rural areas. Successive governments have tried to discard the caste system, but caste practices have persisted in this nation, which is 85 percent Hindu.

DOC.HEAD: Rains Flood Part of West Virginia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 3-4 with 3 grafs to UPDATE with details from hatchery.
DOC.TEXT: More than 3 inches of rain fell in two hours today in the West Virginia mountains, flooding roads, homes and businesses and apparently washing away tiny trout from a fish hatchery, authorities said. About 35 homes near Marlinton, in the eastern part of the state, suffered minor damage, said county emergency services Director Richard Barlow. Rising water flooded the hatchery's concrete-lined ponds and washed away about 30,000 fingerling trout, said Don Phares, director the the state's trout hatchery program. ``The good news is we didn't have a lot of trout in the area that was flooded. The bad news is we lost those that we did have there,'' Phares said. As a result, some lakes and streams may have to be stocked in the fall with fewer three-inch trout, he said. Stoney Creek near Marlinton overran its banks early today, covering U.S. 219 with a foot of water and flooding a state garage and a building supply store, authorities said. A flash flood warning also was in effect for parts of Webster County as the Elk River neared flood stage, the National Weather Service said. Rain could continue tonight in the mountainous regions of West Virginia, but skies should start clearing this weekend, Charleston meteorologist Jerry Orchanian said. In Wayne County, meanwhile, residents still are cleaning up from flash floods Wednesday that damaged more than two dozen homes near East Lynn. Jack Ross lost more than 100 chickens, a source of food for his and other families in the area. ``I went down to the chicken house trying to get them out but they went up in their roosts and I couldn't get to them,'' Ross said. ``People say they are lying in the creek all the way to the end.'' Today's flooding came one day after the one-year annivesary of floods that washed out roads, swept away cars and trucks and destroyed property in central West Virginia. On Aug. 23, 1989, 5 inches of rain fell in one hour. No one was seriously injured in that flooding.

DOC.HEAD: Biotech Critic Asserts Gene Splicing Led to Human Deaths
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to UPDATE with filing of FDA petition; rewrites 8th graf, `He said...' to conform.
DOC.TEXT: A biotechnology watchdog who blames the deaths of 27 Americans directly on gene splicing asked the Food and Drug Administration today to stop approving genetically engineered products. ``This is the first case on record directly connecting the recombinant DNA process to the death and injury of human beings,'' Jeremy Rifkin said Thursday. The 27 Americans died after taking L-tryptophan, which is sold in health food stores as a remedy for insomnia, appetite control and depression. They were among 1,500 Americans who developed an unusual blood disorder called eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, or EMS. It is characterized by muscle and joint pain, breathing difficulties, swelling and rashes. The FDA ordered all L-tryptophan off the market in March after the substance was implicated as the illness's cause. In a report in the Aug. 9 New England Journal of Medicine, doctors in the Minnesota Department of Public Health linked the deaths to a single manufacturer's use of a new strain of genetically altered bacteria or the maker's reliance on less carbon to filter out impurities. Rifkin said that study and another unpublished study link the deaths directly to the genetic engineering process. The president of the Washington-based Foundation on Economic Trends, he has been a persistent critic of biotechnology, calling for more stringent regulation and using legal tactics to force the government to respond. He sent a petition to the FDA today asking it to stop its approvals of genetically engineered products. The petition does not ask for a recall of existing products, he said. The study's authors did not link genetic engineering with the deaths. ``Based on our data, we don't have sufficient information to say whether it was the strain or the amount of powdered carbon that contributed most,'' said Dr. Edward Belongia, one of the that study's authors. ``And until we have more information about what the specific impurity was that's triggering EMS, how that impurity arose and how it's synthesized, it's very difficult to make any statement about what needs to be done to make sure it doesn't happen in the future.'' Rifkin said that part of the support for his petition comes from an article submitted to Science by the Minnesota researchers but not yet published. He said he did not have a copy of the Science article. The L-tryptophan was made by Showa Denko K.K. of Japan. The company inserted a new gene, through genetic engineering, into strains of the bacteria Bacillus amyloliquefaciens to enable the bacteria to produce L-tryptophan. In the strain linked to disease, the inserted gene ``probably coupled with another tryptophan gene in the bacteria and increased the contaminant in the process that killed the 27 Americans,'' Rifkin said. Rifkin's petition also asks that the FDA label all genetically engineered products now on the market, and that it assess the risks of genetically engineered products in light of the new data.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Calls Gorbachev Decree a `Mistake'
DOC.TEXT: Boris Yeltsin, the president of the Russian republic, said today that Mikhail S. Gorbachev made a mistake by nullifying the republic's bid to control its vast natural resources, a news agency reported. Gorbachev issued a presidential decree Thursday invalidating a resolution passed by the Russian parliament's presidium to seize control of the republic's raw materials, such as gold and diamonds, from the central Soviet government. Yeltsin, one of Gorbachev's most outspoken critics, said the decree was a blow to their efforts at cooperation. ``The movement toward each other is not easy,'' Yeltsin told the independent Interfax news agency in an interview from South Sakhalinsk, a Pacific coast city he is visiting as part of a barnstorming tour across the Russian republic, the largest in the Soviet Union. Gorbachev's decree also was denounced by Russian parliament leader Vladimir Isakov who told the official Tass news agency that Gorbachev, the Soviet president, overstepped his authority. Yeltsin said he believed Gorbachev had the right to cancel the parliament's decision because it was a resolution by the body's presidium and not an act of the full legislature. But he said it was ``another mistake'' by Gorbachev who was ``infringing on Russia's sovereignty,'' Interfax reported. The Russian parliament acted because ``we saw that hard currency and gold were slipping away from Russia, but we do not know through what channels, where, to whom, and how much,'' Yeltsin was quoted as saying. ``This begins to look like crime. I think a special deputies' commission will have to be established to look into the matter and tell the people how much gold was exported, where it went and what purposes it served,'' he added. Russia had declared invalid all contracts, signed without its approval, to sell the republic's diamonds, metals, oil, gas, uranium and even any manufactured product it considers strategic. The Aug. 10 declaration had thrown into question scores of lucrative contracts, including a $5 billion diamond deal with the De Beers firm, the leading diamond export dealer. But on Thursday, Russian Deputy Prime Minister Gennady Filshin said the republic had now decided to honor all agreements, even those forged without its consent, Interfax reported. He specifically mentioned the diamond contract, which was considered lucrative to both the republic and the Soviet Union. Gorbachev said Russia's initial stand could have caused ``serious damage to the country's interests, by complicating possibilities to buy goods and win credits, which are needed so badly amid current economic difficulties. ``It is effectively directed at undermining the economic sovereignty of other union republics since it usurps the right to manage products belonging to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics,'' he said. Gorbachev said Thursday he would meet soon with Yeltsin to coordinate plans to shift the Soviet Union to a market economy. The two men appointed a joint commission this summer to develop a blueprint for abandoning the centrally planned economy.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Aunt Ill
DOC.TEXT: The aunt of President Bush, Nancy Walker, became ill today at the family compound on Walker's Point, and an ambulance was dispatched there, the White House said. The elderly woman, who appeared feeble in a wheelchair this week at the funeral for Bush's uncle, John Walker, is the sister of Bush's mother, Dorothy Walker Bush. The nature of her illness was not immediately known, said White House press information officials. Bush's personal physician, Dr. Burton Lee, was monitoring her condition. It was not clear whether she would be taken to a hospital or whether the ambulance actually was needed, said spokesman John Herrick. He said her condition did not appear to be as bad as originally thought.

DOC.HEAD: Two Government Ministers Resign in Haiti
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Two Cabinet ministers resigned today, one day after seven political parties called for the resignation of President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot and the suspension of elections. Social Affairs Minister Claudette Werleigh and Agriculture Minister Lionel Richard said their resignation from the president's 13-member Cabinet was effective immediately. ``I cannot endorse misappropriation of public funds and permissiveness towards criminal supporters of dictatorship,'' said Werleigh, who was appointed in March to the president's interim government. He did not elaborate or provide evidence to support his accusations against the president. Richard said he had no comment on his reasons for resigning. On Thursday, seven of the 12 political organizations that appointed Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot president in March asked for her resignation and the postponement of elections, now scheduled for Nov. 4. Last week, the 19-member Council of State called the president an ``obstacle'' to elections and broke off relations with her. The Council of State rules alongside Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot. Under the interim government agreement, the council can veto her Cabinet appointments and major decisions. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot, a former Supreme Court judge, was named to head the interim government with the main task of organizing elections. She came to power after the fall of Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril. Critics charge her government is corrupt and does not have control over the army. The uncertain climate led to the recent return of several former officials linked to the 29-year Duvalier rule that ended in 1986. Many Haitians fear that the return of former officials of the authoritarian rule will lead to the disruption of the elections. Arrests warrants have been issued for two of the former officials: Roger Lafontant, the reputed head of the dreaded Tonton Macoute paramilitary police, and Williams Regala, a retired army officer who is believed responsible for the November 1987 Election Day massacre of 34 voters at the polls. The men remain at large.

DOC.HEAD: Neighbors Stunned by News of Arrest in Killing of Two Boys
DOC.TEXT: Two boys, ages 13 and 10, were charged in the sexual assault and murders of two younger boys who were strangled with their own shoelaces. The suspects were not identified because of their ages, but news reports said one was the 13-year-old brother of one of the victims. The naked bodies of Benjamin Hurt, 8, and his friend, Todd Pigg Jr., 7, were found Aug. 14 after a frantic search in the woods where they had been riding their bicycles. Authorities said the boys were strangled with their shoelaces. ``We think they were sexually motivated crimes,'' said police Chief Patrick McCarrick at a news conference Thursday. The older suspect was charged with two counts of second-degree murder and two counts of sodomy, he said. The younger suspect faces a felony charge of hindering prosecution. ``Action has already been initiated to appropriately deal with the respective juveniles given the gravity of the alleged offenses,'' said Maj. Thomas O'Conner, who headed the St. Louis Major Case Squad's investigation. He declined to give details. Under Missouri law, a youth must be 14 years old to be certified for trial as an adult. The suspects were in juvenile custody Thursday after being arrested Wednesday and authorities said their parents were cooperating with investigators. Neighbors who were stunned at the news of the crimes were shocked with the arrests of the young suspects. ``Those dear little boys, what terrible, terrible deaths they had,'' said Pauline Boucher, who lives down the street from Todd's family and around the corner from the Hurts. ``To think it was a 13-year-old boy _ it's just terrible.'' ``I know the Hurt family. We used to live next door to them,'' said Amy Seiler, a 16-year-old high school student. ``All the kids used to just go out and play and they were just normal kids.'' Seiler was taking a water break during a mid-day softball practice in Kiwanis Park, across the road from the woods where Todd and Ben were found. Across the road from the park, yellow police tape still blocked off bike paths leading into the dense woods that neighborhood kids call ``the trails.'' ``It's definitely scary down here,'' Seiler said. The woods where the bodies were found were in the same area where another boy, Scott Kleeschulte, 9, vanished more than two years ago. Police said they saw no connection between last week's murders and the 1988 disappearance.

DOC.HEAD: Diplomats Who Reached Baghdad Unable To Move On
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New thruout to UPDATE with White House and other administration officials; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Iraq is detaining about 100 American diplomats and dependents who fled to Baghdad from the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, the Bush administration said today. So far, Iraq has not directly linked closing the embassy in Kuwait City to permitting the Americans in Baghdad to leave Iraq, a U.S. official said. But others said their plight obviously was tied to the dispute over the embassy, which the Iraqis have said must be closed today. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, with President Bush in Kennebunkport, Maine, called on Iraq ``to permit and facilitate the immediate departure'' of the Americans from Baghdad. He said Iraqi troops were at the embassy in Kuwait and were not allowing anyone to leave or enter the building. However, Fitzwater said, ``they have not made any move against the embassy or intruded in any fashion,'' the spokesman said. Appeals through the night to the Iraqi government in Washington and in Baghdad failed to break the deadlock, officials in Washington, speaking on condition of anonymity, told The Associated Press. One denounced the holdup as ``contrary to explicit commitments.'' The officials also said that about a dozen Iraqi soldiers appeared overnight at the embassy in Kuwait City. ``They are not surrounding it. The situation seems to be fluctuating,'' an official said. Fitzwater said the Americans were supposed to go to Turkey. That was the first disclosure of their projected destination. Left behind at the embassy was a group of about a dozen U.S. diplomats headed by Ambassador Nathaniel Howell. Diplomats from a number of other governments who also fled to Baghdad from Kuwait City also are stranded in the Iraqi capital, the official said. ``We have been working all night, here and in Baghdad, to pressure the Iraqi government to rescind the order,'' an official said, adding he did not expect a prompt resolution of the dispute. About 100 are in the group, including nearly 30 children. They made the trip from Kuwait City in a 33-car caravan, arriving in Baghdad early today after a journey of nearly 20 hours. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had promised them safe passage even though 2,500 private U.S. citizens in Kuwait and more than 500 in Iraq are being refused permission to leave. Howel and the other U.S. diplomats left behind in Kuwait City are under instruction to keep the embassy open in spite of an order by Saddam that it close by the end of today and shift operations to Baghdad. Their primary mission is to keep in touch with the Americans trapped in the country and termed hostages by President Bush. A number of other nations, faced with the same order to close, also will try to keep their embassies open. According to reports, Iraqi troops surrounded at least five embassies in Kuwait City this morning. Iraq has said keeping embassies open would amount to an ``act of aggression'' and that diplomats would no longer be protected by diplomatic immunity, meaning they could be rounded up and held as hostages. The State Department on Thursday said Jordan's border with Iraq had been closed. Jordan's King Hussein has been critical of Bush's dispatch of troops to Saudi Arabia. Even so, thousands of refugees were able to cross, and the Jordanian interior ministry said today the border would be open. The king has cast himself in the role of diplomatic middleman. He has flown to Yemen to try to launch mediation. One of the Americans evacuated from the embassy was injured in a collision and was left behind to be hospitalized in Kuwait City. Her identity was not disclosed.

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopian Government Cites Pilot Error in Crash That Killed Leland
DOC.TEXT: The plane crash in Ethiopia that killed Rep. Mickey Leland, D-Texas, and 15 others last year probably was caused by pilot error, an Ethiopian government investigation found. The Ethiopian Civil Aviation Authority said the pilot may have felt pressured to fly in bad weather because of the ``importance of the mission.'' The report was released today by the National Transportation Safety Board, which assisted in the investigation. A Canadian safety expert also participated because the plane was built in Canada. Leland, who was chairman of the House Select Committee on Hunger, was flying from the Ethiopian capital of Addis Ababa to Fugnido, a refugee camp on the Sudanese border, to inspect relief efforts. Three congressional staffers also were killed in the crash. The plane ran into a mountainside more than an hour after takeoff Aug. 7, 1989. The crash destroyed an emergency transmitter on the plane that could have helped rescuers. The wreckage wasn't found for a week. ``The accident was most probably due to pilot error in that, by pushing too far and flying into an area of bad weather at very low altitude, the flight crew may have failed to maintain visual contact with the ground and unknowingly collided with a mountain,'' the report said. The report said the plane, a 1980 Twin Otter, had no defects. Investigators faulted the pilot and flight crew for not properly studying weather along the route. The report said the flight schedule was tight considering the weather. Organizers of the trip, including Leland, and the flight crew discussed delays caused by the weather, the report said. ``The long delay on the one hand and the importance of the mission on the other may have created undue pressure and uneasiness on the flight crew,'' it said. The intended route was cloudy and rainy. The plane was plotted to fly at 12,500 feet and the pilot acknowledged reaching that altitude shortly after takeoff. But witnesses who saw the plane about 25 miles before it crashed told authorities it was flying below the clouds at a low altitude. The plane burned after crashing into a boulder 800 feet below the summit of a mountain. The report said investigators could not determine whether the pilot or co-pilot was flying the plane when it crashed. Leland was making his second trip to the border region to focus attention on the hunger needs of Sudanese whose homes had been ruined by civil war.

indicted today under a federal anti-corruption law banning acceptance of money or gifts in return for votes or favors. State Reps. Robert Kohn, Luther Taylor, Robert Brown, Danny Winstead and state Sen. Rick Lee were all indicted under the Hobbs Act. Winstead also was indicted on a second count of obstruction of justice, Assistant U.S. Attorney John Barton said. The indictments followed Brown's resignation Thursday and Circuit Judge Tee Ferguson being temporarily suspended from his duties as a judge. The federal Hobbs Act bans taking money or gifts in return for votes or favors. Conviction carries a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Lee, 37, who served in the House from 1979 to 1984 and in the Senate since 1985, has been charged with promising to support a bill that would have let voters decide whether they wanted pari-mutuel betting in South Carolina. The indictment charges Lee received a $2,000 payment for his support of the bill. There was no indication of where the $2,000 payment originated. Winstead, 44, was indicted on two counts. The first alleges he ``knowingly and intentionally attempted to commit extortion'' in connection with the pari-mutuel bill. It also charges that Winstead ``by extortion'' got a $1,000 cash payment ``from and with the consent'' of Ron Cobb, a lobbyist reported to have been involved in the FBI investigation within the legislation. The indictment alleges that on or about July 20, Winstead ``did knowingly and intentionally attempt corruptly'' to persuade Kohn ``with intent to influence'' Kohn's testimony in an ``official proceeding.'' According to the indictments, Brown, 34, allegedly promised to support the pari-mutuel bill and to work ``behind the scenes'' for passage in exchange for $2,000. The indictment allegedly took the payment on or about April 19. Brown has served in the House since 1983. He was chairman of the Labor, Commerce and Industry Committee until his resignation Thursday. The indictment said Taylor, 40, and Kohn, 45, allegedly agreed to be paid to vote for the pari-mutuel bill. They allegedly agreed to become members of a ``core group'' of legislators working to pass the bill in 1990. The indictment states that about Oct 17, 1989, Kohn met with Cobb in a room at the Town House Hotel in Columbia where they discussed the possiblity of the bill's passage. About Jan. 10, Kohn met with Cobb and indicated he would support the bill for $10,000, the indictment said. He also reportedly told Cobb that another House member could help move the bill offthe contested calendar. ``The investigation is continuing and more indictments will be handed down in the next few months,'' said U.S. Attorney Bart Daniel. The probe has been under way for 16 months, according to John C. Harley Jr., FBI special agent in charge. Harley verified earlier reports that the FBI used a fictitious organization referred to as the Alpha Group based in Atlanta as a business front. He said the FBI received cooperation from Cobb and Kohn and that Cobb is at an unidentified location. In his resignation letter Thursday to House Speaker Bob Sheheen, Brown wrote: ``I hope my work and dedication to improving the quality of life in my county and our state will not be totally overshadowed by any mistakes I have made.'' Ferguson, who served in the House of Representatives for six years until his election to judge this spring, asked to be suspended ``until such time as the matter concerning alleged votes for cash is resolved in so far as it seeks to implicate me.'' Chief Justice George Gregory suspended him until Jan. 7. A woman who answered the phone in Ferguson's office Thursday said he would not comment. Sources have said the FBI set up a sting operation in which former House member-turned lobbyist Cobb, working undercover, offered lawmakers cash in exchange for votes on legislation to legalize pari-mutuel betting in South Carolina. Brown's committee approved that legislation in 1989. In late July, shortly after news of the investigation surfaced, Brown filed an amended campaign report that disclosed he had received $2,500 cash from Cobb in either April or May. The reports were due in June. At the time, Brown denied he took the money in exchange for his vote. ``I've never taken a dime with strings attached,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Aide Says Quayle Following Mideast Crisis During His Vacation
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle is closely following the crisis in the Middle East while vacationing in Arizona, a spokesman said Friday. ``He's in daily contact with what's going on,'' said spokesman Craig Whitney. ``He knows all the developments.'' Quayle, his wife and their three children are spending most of the month at his parents' vacation home in Wickenburg, Ariz. ``I'm sure some golf is possible, but the vice president wanted a chance to spend time with his wife and family,'' Whitney said. The spokesman said Quayle's staff in Washington is monitoring developments in the Middle East and in Kennebunkport, Maine, where President Bush is vacationing. ``The vice president receives all of the paperwork and communications out there that he would if he were here,'' Whitney said. Quayle returned to Washington for two days last week and was briefed by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. He had a lengthy conversation earlier this week with Brent Scowcroft, Bush's chief national security adviser. ``I'm sure he has talked with the president but I can't tell you how many times or when,'' Whitney said. The vice president ``was in on the early meetings where a lot of the strategy was charted'' on how the United States would respond to Iraq's takeover of Kuwait, Whitney said. Quayle left Washington on Aug. 11, more than a week after the invasion. Quayle's next scheduled public appearance is a speech to the 75th annual convention of the American Legion in Indianapolis on Tuesday. Whitney said Quayle had not decided whether to return to Washington immediately after that speech or delay his return until later in the week.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Federal Judge Strikes Down Key Portions of Abortion Law
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; ADDS comments from ruling, reax, editing throughout. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today struck down provisions of Pennsylvania's abortion law that helped make it the most restrictive in the country. Senior U.S. District Judge Daniel H. Huyett 3d ruled on challenges to the law by Planned Parenthood of Southeastern Pennsylvania and five abortion providers. Huyett struck down portions of the law that require a woman to notify her husband before getting an abortion; wait 24 hours before getting an abortion; and require minors to obtain the consent of at least one parent, or a court order, before an abortion. The U.S. territory of Guam had banned all abortions except where the mother's life is threatened. A federal judge ruled that law unconstitutional Wednesday. In the Pennsylvania ruling, the judge said that requiring parental notification ``unduly burdens a minor woman's right to elect to end her preganancy.'' Attorneys for both sides have said they would probably file appeals first to the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals and eventually the U.S. Supreme Court. ``Safe, legal abortion continues to be accessible to women in Pennsyvlania because of the court's decision today,'' said Elizabeth Hrenda-Roberts, executive director of Planned Parenthood Pennsylvania Affiliates. ``Pennsylvanians would be well served if the Commonwealth accepts this decision and stops squandering taxpayer's money to promote government interference in personal matters and threaten women's lives,'' she said. Robert Gentzel, a spokesman for state Attorney General Ernie Preate Jr., said the ruling would be appealed within 30 days. ``Judge Huyett's decision is disappointing but not unexpected. It is the attorney general's duty to defend the constitutionality of state statutes and he intends to pursue all appropriate appeals, including appealing to the United States Supreme Court if necessary,'' Gentzel said. Huyett quoted Supreme Court Justice Harry Blackmun's warning about eroding abortion rights: ``The signs are evident and very ominous, and a chill wind blows.'' ``What the future holds is not certain,'' Huyett said. ``But one thing must be evident. Individuals can no longer feel as secure with the protections provided by the judiciary in this area. Instead, a woman's privacy rights and individual autonomy may soon be subjected to the vicissitudes of the legislative process.'' Abortion opponents want to use the case to return the abortion issue to the U.S. Supreme Court to provide it with an opportunity to reverse the 1973 Roe v. Wade decision that legalized abortion. Gentzel called the Pennsylvania law ``a reasonable, responsible approach to dealing with a very difficult question. The Legislature and governor were fully aware when this statute was enacted and signed that it would face challenges, and that those challenges would take time to resolve.'' Huyett also ruled in the clinics' favor in their challenge of the state's definition of medical emergency, which the clinic said was too vague and would leave doctors in a quandary. Most of the the disputed parts of the law were suspended pending Huyett's ruling. Some of the sections were rewritten from a 1982 statute, much of which was struck down by the U.S. Supreme Court in 1986. The disputed portions were amendments made in 1988 and 1989 to the Abortion Control Act, adopted in 1982 following the landmark ruling of 1973. In a three-day trial in Reading earlier this month, lawyers for the state argued that the law would protect the interests of women and families. The abortion clinic argued that the law would strip women of dignity, could endanger their health and have a chilling effect on doctors who perform abortions. ``There can be no doubt the challenged provisions burden women's rights to abortion,'' said Thomas Zemaitis, an attorney for the clinics. The state argued that similar parental-consent laws had been upheld in other states and that the husband should be told because the state had ``a legitimate interest in protecting the spouse's interest.'' Zemaitis said requiring parental consent ``creates an impossible ethical dilemma for the minor.'' He said anyone who arranges for an abortion has already thought it through and that the waiting period was written in to discourage abortions.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Patrol Near U.S., Other Embassies in Kuwait as Deadline Nears
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with White House saying troops patrolling near U.S. Embassy, Americans detained, details. Pick up 12th pvs, The United...' Minor editing thereafter to trim and conform.
