DOC.TEXT: Iraqi troops patrolled near the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait City and at least seven others today, and a European envoy said Baghdad threatened to use force to remove diplomats remaining at their posts Saturday. The White House, meanwhile, said lraq had reneged on its promise toallow U.S. Embassy personnel to leave Baghdad and was detaining them. The more than 100 American men, women and children had left the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait and were staying in the U.S. Embassy in Baghdad, said spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Fitzwater said Iraqi military forces ``of one kind or another are around the embassy'' in Kuwait, where Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and a handful of aides remained. ``They have not made any moves against the embassy or intruded in any fashion, but they are nevertheless present. It would appear that people are not being allowed to enter or leave the embassy,'' Fitzwater said at a briefing in Kennebunkport, Maine. Iraq, which invaded and annexed Kuwait earlier this month, has given foreign governments until 9 p.m. (1 p.m. EDT) today to vacate their embassies in Kuwait. Diplomats in Washington, however, said that deadline had been extended to midnight. Baghdad said keeping embassies open would amount to an ``act of aggression'' and that diplomats would no longer be protected by diplomatic immunity, meaning they could be rounded up and held as hostages. Spain's Ambassador to Amman, Ramon Armengod, told a news conference in Madrid today that Iraqi authorities told Western embassies in Kuwait that they now had until 8:30 a.m. Saturday (12:30 a.m. EDT) to close. He said that after that deadline, Iraqi troops would forcibly remove remaining Western diplomats from their missions. The Japanese Foreign Ministry, meanwhile, said Iraqi soldiers told the two Japanese diplomats remaining in Kuwait today that their diplomatic immunity had been revoked but made no attempt to remove them from the embassy. There were conflicting reports of the extent of troop activity around embassies. Officials reported that troops were surrounding or patrolling near the American, British, French, Japanese, Norwegian, Swedish, Romanian and Hungarian embassies. The officials said they received the information from their embassy personnel in Kuwait. Ambassador Howell and a dozen other Americans stayed at the palm-shaded American compound, a rectangle facing a six-lane highway bordering the Persian Gulf. Marine guards were among 33 carloads of embassy personnel who drove to the Iraqi capital Baghdad on Thursday. The United States, Canada, Japan, Switzerland, Austria and the 12 European Community nations were among those who announced they would defy the order and remain in the occupied oil-rich kingdom. Britain's Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said today the soldiers posted outside the British Embassy ``appear to have instructions not to allow people in or out.'' He said British staff there would decide for themselve how to oppose the Iraqis. ``I don't expect, no one expects, unarmed diplomats to give physical resistance to physical force,'' he said. ``We don't know how many soldiers there are, their intentions, but there must be a lot, enough to completely surround the entire building,'' said Bjoern Blokhus, a Norwegian Foreign Ministry spokesman commenting on the situation at the embassy in Kuwait. Blokhus said the Iraqi soldiers had made no move against the diplomatic personnel inside the embassy. Egypt took one of most defiant stances, announcing Thursday that it would not close its embassy or reduce its staff of 20. In Cairo, four truckloads of riot police remained outside the Iraqi Embassy where they have been stationed since the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Soviet officials said in Moscow they had evacuated all of their embassy personnel from Kuwait, but that they did not consider the mission closed. The Philippines, India and Lebanon are among those nations why said they would obey the order and close. About 60 countries have embassies in Kuwait. Personnel at the Western embassies were reduced to a symbolic few. Staff and dependents from many embassies left Kuwait City over the past few day. Fitzwater said Thursday that the U.S. diplomats would remain in Kuwait ``as long as there are Americans they can assist.'' About 3,000 Americans are among the 21,000 westerners stranded and threatened in Iraq and Kuwait. There are also about 3,000 Britons. The U.S. and British embassies are along the same corniche as those of Saudi Arabia, U.A.E., Qatar, Egypt, Lebanon, India, Jordan, Turkey. Saudi Arabia's Foreign Ministry rejected Iraq's demand Thursday that missions close, but the Saudi embassy has been locked since the invasion and the ambassador is back in the kingdom. Travelers from Kuwait have reported that scores of nationals from Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates have sought sanctuary in their embassies. The respective ambassadors have been trying unsuccessfully to organize evacuation convoys.

DOC.HEAD: Demand For Gas Masks Forces Startup Of Barcelona Firm
DOC.TEXT: The heavy demand for gas masks from Middle Eastern distributors has forced a Barcelona firm to cut short vacations and begin round-the-clock production, one of the company's owners says. Jeroni Llorca of Llorca Protective Systems said Thursday the company planned to start producing its new Vispro civilian-use gas mask in September. But frantic calls from distributors in Saudi Arabia, Jordan, Syria and Israel persuaded the firm to begin immediately. Llorca said employees were producing about 1,500 of the masks a day. He expected his first shipment to go out Sept. 15.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Hands Over `Birth Certificate' to Australia
DOC.TEXT: Ninety years after it officially became a commonwealth, Australia has received its ``birth certificate.'' British Deputy Prime Minister Sir Geoffrey Howe on Thursday night handed Prime Minister Bob Hawke one of the two originals of the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act. That was the legislation, passed by the British Parliament on July 5, 1900, which turned six colonies into the Commonwealth of Australia. Although the document has been on loan in Parliament House here for the last two years, it has taken a lot of tough talking with the British, from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher down, to turn the loan into ownership. The problem for the British was that in giving the document away, it may have created a huge precedent. As Howe said, Britain's constitutional archives were preserved in an unbroken series stretching back to the 13th century and were a cherished part of its heritage. Never before had an original copy of a British act been given away. So carefully guarded was the collection that it required an act of the British Parliament before it could be handed over.

DOC.HEAD: Comics Try Laughter in the Face of War
DOC.TEXT: While the Middle East situation deteriorates, comics Jay Leno and Johnny Carson managed some laughs. ``Ever thought you would see the day when you would miss the Ayatollah?'' Leno asked Wednesday on ``The Tonight Show With Johnny Carson.'' ``President Bush has frozen Iraq's assets and he's seeking the proper economic sanctions to punish them,'' Leno continued. ``How about putting all their assets in the savings and loans, then they'll be real sorry.'' The comic also made this observation: ``I notice we haven't had any oil spills since it got so expensive.'' Roseanne Barr's name has also come up in connection with the Middle East conflict. The Washington gag goes that President Bush will name Miss Barr U.S. ambassador to Iraq, according to columnist Liz Smith. Carson picked up the theme Thursday. He suggested the United States send over a secret weapon _ Miss Barr singing the Iraqi national anthem. A new song by country singer Hank Williams Jr. _ ``Don't Give Us a Reason'' _ has been getting air time. One lyric goes: ``And if you take some innocent lives, that's when the fur really flies, ``Hey man, back off and get smart, don't give us a reason. ``Don't give us a reason to come gunning for you, ``Cuz the odds don't look so good, your neck is in a noose ...'' And what about a USO Tour to the Middle East? Television's ``Entertainment Tonight'' says Hollywood celebrities are being lined up for a trip, but the USO says names and details are being kept secret for security reasons. Bob Hope, who went to the Middle East several years ago with Lee Greenwood, Connie Stevens and others to entertain military personnel, said he has no plans to take a USO Tour to Saudi Arabia. ``Palm Springs is my desert,'' the 87-year-old Hope said Thursday. ``The only way I'm going to the desert is going to Palm Springs.''

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Killed as Suspected Collaborator with Israel
DOC.TEXT: Masked Palestinian activists bludgeoned an Arab man to death Friday in the occupied Gaza Strip following accusations he collaborated with Israeli security agents, Arab reports said. Arab reporters identified the victim as Abdul Fattah Gharableh. They said he was visiting relatives in the Rafah refugee camp when he was attacked. The victim had a gun and held off his attackers for about 10 minutes before he ran out of ammunition, the report said. The gang then beat him to death with sticks and iron bars, they said. Gharableh's father was slightly wounded by his son's gunfire, but none of his assailiants was hit. The army said it had no information on the incident. Gharableh's death raised to 249 the number of Palestinians slain by fellow Arabs since the uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied territories began in December 1987. Most have been accused of collaborating with Israeli officials or dealing in drugs or prostitution. An additional 728 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians during the revolt, and 45 Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Diphtheria Epidemic Blamed On Poor Vaccine, Lack Of Syringes
DOC.TEXT: Eight people have died in a diphtheria outbreak in Moscow, which is the result of poor-quality vaccines and a lack of disposable syringes, a newspaper reported Friday. Moskovskaya Pravda said 154 diphtheria patients had been registered in the Soviet capital, 33 of them children. It quoted Nikolai Filatov of Moscow's Sanitary Epidemiological Station as saying the city's medical institutions received only 11 million syringes in the first half of the year instead of the required 47 million.

DOC.HEAD: Students Hijack Buses, Clash with Police To Protest Job Quota
LaserPhoto DEL1
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of students protesting a government plan to reserve jobs for low-caste Hindus hijacked buses and clashed with police Friday. The students surged into streets, stopping traffic and urging motorists to join their campaign. Arriving at the Parliament aboard dozens of hijacked buses, they tried to storm or encircle the building. ``We don't want the politicians to come out of the Parliament. Let them perish there,'' said Vinod Kumar Bist, a first-year university student. Police beat back the protesters with steel-tipped bamboo poles, set up rope and metal barricades and repeatedly fired tear gas. Traffic was paralyzed as the protests spread to major streets and intersections throughout the capital of 8 million people. Some protesters hurled stones through the windows of government buildings. Demonstrations began three weeks ago and have spread to a half-dozen states. One of the first flashpoints was Bihar, India's poorest state, where at least three people have died. The trouble began when Prime Minister V.P. Singh announced this month that the government would reserve an additional 27 percent of public sector jobs for categories of low-caste Hindus. That would bring to 49 percent the share of government jobs reserved for lower castes and tribes. The rest are awarded on merit. Singh, a high-caste Hindu, has warned that low-caste Hindus must be given government help in getting jobs to head off unrest. Singh said ``disadvantaged communities'' comprise 52 percent of India's 880 million people but have only 12.5 percent of government jobs. His plan angered students from higher castes, who called it reverse discrimination that would hurt their chances of finding work after graduation. Government jobs are prized because they provide security and benefits, such as free housing. The students shouted ``Down with V.P. Singh!'' Some chased a police dog in an attempt to place a sign reading ``I am V.P. Singh'' around its neck. Hindus, who make up 85 percent of India's population, have a complex social system with hundreds of castes and subcastes that divide them into a rigid hierarchy. High-caste Hindus usually are better off economically than members of low castes. Discrimination on the basis of caste is outlawed, but it persists, especially in rural areas. In many villages, for example, lower castes and outcasts live in segregated quarters and cannot take water from wells used by upper castes. As the students shouted anti-government slogans and burned their university degree certificates near Parliament, a street sweeper from a lower caste rested his broom to watch. ``There is no need for the drama,'' said the sweeper, Ram Prasad. ``We low-caste Hindus have suffered enough. Time has come to get our due share.''

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Upholds Espionage Charges Against Dissident Lawmaker
DOC.TEXT: South Korea's supreme court rejected appeals by a dissident lawmaker Friday and upheld espionage charges against him and a 10-year prison sentence. The court ruled that Rep. Suh Kyung-won was quilty of espionage by leaking state secrets during his trip to communist North Korea. Suh had claimed that security officials forced him to make false confessions. He said his trip to North Korea was to advance unification of the divided Korean peninsula, and he denied being a spy. With the supreme court's decision, Suh's parliamentary membership was stripped. Suh was from South Korea's main opposition group, the Party for Peace and Democracy. He was arrested in June 1989. A court sentenced him to 10 years in prison in April. South Korea prohibits unauthorized visits to North Korea, contending dialogue with communists must be handled through official channels.

DOC.HEAD: Pair of College Students Discover Anasazi Village Site
DOC.TEXT: Two college students have stumbled upon the virtually untouched ruins of a 1,100-year-old Anasazi Indian village in southwestern Colorado. The six-acre Mountain Sheep Village, the name given the site, probably had about 200 structures and may have housed 150 to 200 Indians as early as the year 850 A.D., said Kristie Arrington, an archaeologist for the Bureau of Land Management, the agency that controls the discovery site. The discovery is significant because the site is on the north side of the Dolores River, which wraps around it on three sides. Previously, Anasazi ruins have been found only south of the river. The Anasazi, or ``Ancient Ones,'' lived in the Four Corners area. Their best-known ruins are the cliff dwellings in Mesa Verde National Park in southwestern Colorado. The site discovered earlier this month by the University of Colorado students is about 60 miles northwest of Mesa Verde, not far from the Utah border. Pottery fragments recovered at the site discovered by Dave Merritt and Chris Kuzawa date the site about 300 years before the height of Mesa Verde cliff dwellings. Arrington said the people of Mountain Sheep Village may have traded big game and timber with other villages in exchange for food and pottery. She said tools associated with game procurement and processing, such as arrowheads, scrapers and knives, have been found on the ground. ``Local people hunting may have been through there and one area shows evidence that it had been `potted' a little bit,'' said Arrington. ``But it's fairly unusual that it hadn't been recorded and documented before now.'' Potting is a term used to describe the illegal digging for Indian pots. Merritt and Kuzawa are working out of the Dolores Canyon Research Center on a federal archaeology project this summer. The project involves tracking desert bighorn sheep and river otters, conducting an inventory of water invertebrates in the river and probing historic mining sites. The two were tracking bighorn sheep with another student, Patricia Dahnke, when they discovered the ruins. ``We were just hiking around and we found it,'' Merritt said. ``We were just climbing up, following bits of ceramics and lithic (flint), which were at the base of the cliffs where they shouldn't be.'' They struggled over the rim of a cliff and found mounds and vertical slabs of sandstone sticking out of the ground. The slabs are the foundations of structures made of poles, brush and adobe. ``It was pretty spectacular,'' Kuzawa said of the site, which backs up to a forest of ponderosa pine. ``Once we realized what it was, we started to look around. We stayed until dusk. We knew we were on to something pretty big.''

DOC.HEAD: Classical Musician Retires to Jazz: `It's Easier'
DOC.TEXT: Earl Summers Jr., the last original member of the Wheeling Symphony Orchestra, wants to jazz up his life now that he's stepped away from classical music. The 74-year-old violinist retired after Thursday's symphony performance, during which he played some of his favorite classical, jazz and country ``hoedown'' music before 7,000 people at the Wheeling Civic Center. Summers worked hard at his music from age 12, when he first put on a tuxedo to perform at the 1928 opening of the Wheeling Symphony. He joined while studying under his father, who headed the string section. After 62 years with the symphony, however, ``everyone's younger than I am,'' Summers said. He said he will focus on jazz in his retirement, especially the music of tenor saxophonist Coleman Hawkins. ``Jazz is easier,'' Summers said. ``You always have to practice the classical music all the time. I just don't want to work that hard anymore.''

DOC.HEAD: Precede VIENNA
Waldheim Visiting Persian Gulf Region, To Meet Saddam
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Waldheim arriving in Jordan. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `During World...'
DOC.TEXT: President Kurt Waldheim, shunned for years by Western leaders because of his wartime past, arrived in Jordan today en route to Iraq for talks with Saddam Hussein about freeing foreign hostages. Waldheim was to meet with Jordan's King Hussein, then fly to Baghdad on Saturday, his office said. Waldheim would be the first Western leader to meet the Iraqi president face-to-face since Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. A Jordanian official said the king ``might accompany Mr. Waldheim to Iraq for a short mini-summit,'' in Baghdad. He would not elaborate. Waldheim received a warm welcome from the king and other senior officials at Amman's military air base. In Vienna, Waldheim's office said he would try to use contacts from his tenure as U.N. secretary-general ``to seek in personal meetings a safe return as soon as possible of the (foreign) citizens to their homelands,'' said a statement issued by the president's office in Vienna. During his 10 years as U.N. chief, Waldheim was personally acquainted with Arab leaders, including Saddam. In four years as Austrian president, Waldheim has visited Kuwait, Syria and Jordan. Because of his wartime past, no Western governments have invited him for official visits. During World War II, Waldheim served with a German army unit in the Balkans implicated in atrocities, and later misrepresented his war record. Austrian Foreign Minister Alois Mock, who is currently visiting Amman, said in an Austrian television interview Thursday that Waldheim would ``bring to bear his exceptional standing in the Arab world.'' There are about 21,000 Westerners stranded in Iraq and Kuwait, including 3,000 Americans. They have been prevented from leaving and threatened with being used as human shields around Iraqi targets. About 140 Austrians are in Iraq and Kuwait. So far 30 Austrians have crossed the Iraqi border into Turkey.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Embassy in Kuwait: Functional, Not Fancy
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Embassy in Kuwait is not a high-tech stronghold, but rather a practical compound surrounded by a high wall. ``It's not a very fancy embassy, but a very functional one,'' said Francois Dickman, a retired Foreign Service officer who was U.S. ambassador to Kuwait from 1979 to 1983. ``It's not one of the new fortresses that many American embassies around the world are increasingly,'' said another diplomat who has served in Kuwait, speaking on the condition of anonymity. The embassy, across a six-lane highway from the beach, has become the latest storm center of the growing Persian Gulf crisis. Its usual contingent of about a half-dozen Marines were withdrawn Thursday as the Iraqi deadline for the closing foreign embassies in Kuwait approached. Dickman said the decision to withdraw the Marines made sense. ``These Marines can't do anything,'' he said. ``They don't really serve as guards. They man the entrance to the chancery and in the evening they make sure that things are locked up and provide elementary security.'' Dickman, in a telephone interview from his Laramie, Wyo., home, said the wall around the compound is eight or nine feet high. The east side of the compound faces Gulf Road, a six-lane highway. Just east of the highway is the Persian Gulf. ``It's not much of a beach,'' Dickman said. The only entrance to the compound is a steel gate on the west side, about 100 feet from the southwest corner. The compound includes the chancery, an administration building, the ambassador's residence, a warehouse, parking lot, garden and swimming pool. The embassy's security system was strengthened after a 1983 terrorist bombing, according to the diplomat who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``I suppose a tank, like an Iraqi tank, could get through, but it has been reinforced, the wall has been upgraded and the entry gates,'' the diplomat said. In the bombing, Shia Moslem terrorists crashed a truck loaded with gas cylinders through the steel gates. The truck smashed into the administration building, demolishing it and damaging the chancery and warehouse, Dickman said. None of the six people killed was American.

DOC.HEAD: Pittsburgh Surgeon Undergoes Heart Surgery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with surgery over.
DOC.TEXT: The doctor who performed the world's first successful liver transplant underwent heart surgery today at the hospital where he has performed hundreds of transplants. Surgeons began the coronary artery bypass operation on Thomas E. Starzl at 7:30 a.m. and finished nearly five hours later at Presbyterian University Hospital. Starzl was in stable condition in the hospital's intensive care unit. ``The surgery was uncomplicated and Dr. Starzl is doing well,'' said Gary Marrone, who led the surgical team. On July 9, surgeons removed a blockage from Starzl's right coronary artery after he complained of chest pains. Doctors said he was doing well following that operation. Starzl, 64, performed the first successful liver transplant in 1967 at the University of Colorado. He also pioneered development of a medical team that performed 200 kidney transplants at Colorado General and Denver Veteran's Administration hospitals. In 1981, Starzl began work at the University of Pittsburgh, which he helped make one of the world's premier transplant centers. Last year, the hospital performed more than 460 liver transplants and 210 kidney transplants.

DOC.HEAD: Fifteen Arrested in Alleged Ring of Child Sexual Abuse
DOC.TEXT: Thirteen family members and friends were in jail Friday on charges of sexually abusing an 11-year-old girl and two other children, authorities said. ``What we found was nasty business,'' said Neshoba County Sheriff Hubert G. Waddell. ``When I have to look at these people we have incarcerated it's hard for me not to vomit.'' He said the 13 men and two women are charged with capital rape, which carries a possible sentence of life in prison. Waddell said the accusations involve fondling and heterosexual and homosexual acts. Two defendants, both in their 70s, were released on $50,000 bond because of their health, Waddell said. The others either were being held in lieu of $50,000 bond or without bond pending hearings. ``The people involved are mothers, daddies, stepfathers, ex-fathers,'' said investigator Bobby Anderson of the Philadelphia Police Department. Waddell said the 11-year-old Philadelphia-area girl was sexually abused by at least nine different adults during the last two to three years. He said two young boys, whose ages were not given, also were abused. ``I've had to investigate sexual abuse cases but nothing on the scale of this,'' said Waddell. ``There is a lot of trash involved and some money did come into the picture.'' The sheriff said there also was evidence that the parents allowed the girl to be sexually abused in exchange for liquor and cigarettes. All those charged are from the mostly rural county in east-central Mississippi and included the parents of the girl and close relatives of the two boys. There could be additional arrests, authorities said. Waddell said the arrests created a space problem in his already crowded detention center. He said the jail had been redesigned to hold 24 people ``we've got 30 in there right now, including five or six state prisoners.'' Several county jails in Mississippi are crowded with state inmates because of federal court orders that limits the number of prisoners at the state penitentiary at Parchman. Waddell said a joint investigation began six weeks ago when his office and local police ``received a call from a concerned citizen who told us a baby sitter had called her and wanted her to report that this little girl had been raped.'' ``We called in the county welfare department to pick up the girl and have her checked. They put her in the hospital for treatment and got a counselor to start working with her.'' ``I did talk to the girl quite a bit but she was hesitant to talk to male officers,'' Waddell said. ``It was obvious to me that she had been abused.'' Authorities said it appeared the case reached beyond Neshoba County and that officers in Kemper, Attala and Leake counties are being forwarded information about abuse that may have taken place there. Neshoba County District Attorney Ken Turner said the case against the 15 arrested will be presented Nov. 5 to a county grand jury.

DOC.HEAD: Father of Modern Surfing Gets Statue on 100th Anniversary of Birth
DOC.TEXT: Duke Kahanamoku, considered the father of modern surfing, is being honored with a statue. But instead of facing his beloved ocean, his likeness beckons tourists on the shore. The 100th anniversary of Kahanmoku's birth was being marked Friday with the dedication of a statue in Waikiki. Kahanamoku was born in Waikiki in 1890 and died there in 1968. He fashioned long boards and set out with his friends to ride the gentle waves of Waikiki as well as the big breakers around the island. Kahanamoku also brought surfing to the mainland. Historians report he rode a redwood surfboard near a popular pier in Venice, Calif., in the first decade of the century. The statue, by Jan Fisher, is located at Kuhio Beach Park. But its placement started a controversy when the city wanted it facing inland instead of toward the ocean. Family members say the Duke never would have wanted it that way, as his life revolved around the water. Officials, however, said tourists wouldn't want to face the back of a statue, so they placed it facing land and the dense line of hotels on Waikiki beach. Kahanamoku competed in four Olympics, winning six medals _ three gold, two silver and one bronze _ for swimming. He was inducted into the U.S. Olympic Hall of Fame in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Troops Patrol Outside Embassies In Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2 grafs for graf 8 pvs, `Turkey, however...' to ADD number of refugees who have crossed into Turkey. Pickup 9th graf, `Also today...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AMM3, WX6,TOK2, LaserColor NY146
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi troops today deployed near at least eight embassies in Kuwait _ including the U.S. mission _ where diplomats were defying shutdown orders from Baghdad. ``They have not made any moves against the embassy or intruded in any fashion, but they are nevertheless present,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, with President Bush in Kennebunkport, Maine. ``It would appear that people are not being allowed to enter or leave the embassy.'' In other developments in the Persian Gulf crisis, the Pentagon today began began calling reserve units to active duty to assist in the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf area, and Austrian President Kurt Waldheim set off for the Mideast on a peacemaking mission that was to include a meeting with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. The Japanese Foreign Ministry, meanwhile, said Iraqi soldiers told the two Japanese diplomats remaining in Kuwait today that their diplomatic immunity had been revoked but made no attempt to remove them from the embassy. Amid the brewing embassy standoff, about 100 American diplomats and dependents who left the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait have been indefinitely detained in the Iraqi capital, Baghdad, officials in Washington said today. The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, linked the detention of the group to the U.S. refusal to close its embassy in Kuwait, and said it was ``contrary to explicit commitments'' by Iraq of free passage for the Americans. But another escape route for foreigners remained open _ the Jordanian border. Jordan had said Wednesday it would close the frontier with Iraq to refugees, but it allowed thousands of people, mainly Arabs, to cross today. Turkey, however, said it might close its border with Iraq unless foreign governments made arrangements for speedy transit of refugees. Officials fear an influx of Pakistanis. Since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, 7,532 people have entered from Iraq, officials at the Habur crossing said. Of these, 3,000 were Turkish workers returning home and 2,903 were Pakistanis. Also today, Western diplomats said they expected the Security Council to vote today or Saturday on a resolution resolution allowing the use of military force to put teeth in the U.N. embargo against Iraq. In addition to patrolling near the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, Saddam's troops, who invaded the emirate Aug. 2, were out in force near the British, French, Japanese, Norwegian, Swedish, Romanian and Hungarian embassies, said diplomatic officials, citing information from embassies in Kuwait. ``We don't know how many soldiers there are, their intentions, but there must be a lot, enough to completely surround the entire building,'' said Bjoern Blokhus, a Norwegian Foreign Ministry spokesman commenting on the situation at his country's embassy in Kuwait. The Japanese Foreign Ministry said Iraqi soldiers told the two Japanese diplomats remaining in Kuwait today that their diplomatic immunity had been revoked but made no attempt to remove them from the embassy. There was uncertainty about the Iraqi deadline for the embassy shutdowns. The Iraqi News Agency has said foreign governments have until 9 p.m. (1 p.m. EDT) to vacate the 60 embassies in Kuwait. Diplomats in Washington, however, said the deadline was extended to midnight. Spain's ambassador to Jordan, Ramon Armengod, told reporters in Madrid today that Iraqi authorities were saying foreign embassies had until 8:30 a.m. Saturday (12:30 a.m. EDT), to close, or they would be removed by force. U.S. Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and perhaps a dozen other Americans stayed at the palm-shaded American compound in Kuwait City. Concrete barriers and steel spikes are among the security at the U.S. Embassy complex on Arabian Gulf Boulevard. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater told reporters Thursday at President Bush's summer home in Kennebunkport, Maine, that U.S. diplomats will remain in Kuwait ``as long as there are Americans that they can assist.'' Most U.S. diplomatic personnel were evacuated Thursday. Marine guards were among 33 carloads of Americans who drove to the Iraqi capital. ``A few Marine guards aren't going to fight off the entire Iraqi army,'' a senior government official said Thursday in Washington. In addition to the United States, those countries ignoring Iraq's shutdown order included Japan, the 12 European Community nations, Switzerland and Austria. The Dutch ambassador to Kuwait, Joop Veling, was advised by his Foreign Ministry ``not to engage in any exaggerated heroism,'' a government spokesman said in the Hague. Saddam claimed Kuwait as Iraqi territory after his invasion and subsequent annexation of his oil-rich southern neighbor. Baghdad says keeping embassies open in Kuwait would amount to an ``act of aggression.'' On Thursday, Saddam appeared on television with British children and other captives, ruffling the hair of a small boy, smiling and joking _ but making it plain their fate depends on how the Persian Gulf confrontation goes. He told about 20 adults and children they were ``guests'' being held ``to prevent the scourge of war.'' State Department spokesman Richard Boucher denounced the TV display as ``shameful theater.'' About 3,000 Americans are among the 21,000 Westerners stranded in Iraq and Kuwait, kept from leaving by Saddam and threatened with being used as human shields around Iraqi targets. In another development Thursday, a U.S. intelligence source reported that Saddam's elite Republican Guards, which led the attack into Kuwait, are being replaced on the front lines of his defenses by other troops. But the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Guards _ numbering perhaps more than 50,000 according to NBC News _ could still be used in an Iraqi attack on Saudi Arabia from Kuwait. It was fear of such an attack that prompted the United States to mount the multinational Operation Desert Shield in the Saudi desert to protect the kingdom and its huge oil reserves. U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney on Thursday approved plans to call 10,000 military reservists to active duty over the next week and nearly 50,000 by October to support the deployment of U.S. troops, ships and warplanes to the Persian Gulf. The U.S. aircraft carrier Dwight D. Eisenhower and six escort ships sailed through Egypt's Suez Canal today en route from the Red Sea to the Mediterranean canal officials said. The Eisenhower apparently was relieved by the carrier Saratoga in the Red Sea and may be relieved in the Mediterranean by the carrier Kennedy, which left Virginia last week. The U.S. Navy has a total of 37 ships either in the gulf or en route, an unofficial count showed. Among them were four aircraft carrier battle groups and the battleship Wisconsin. Waldheim's office said he was flying to Amman today for talks with Jordan's King Hussein, and would travel to Baghdad Saturday for a meeting with Saddam. The Austrian president has been shunned by Western leaders because of his wartime past, but has maintained friendly ties with Arab leaders including Saddam.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey, Flooded With Refugees, Hints at Border Closure
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Turkey, feeling the strain of a refugee influx from neighboring Iraq, said Friday it may have to close its only border post with Iraq unless arrivals are quickly taken in by their home nations. Premier Yildirim Akbulut said Turkey had information that refugees were massing on the Iraqi side of the border. The Habur crossing gate was built for truck traffic and lacks facilities for large numbers of people, he said. Turkey realizes the difficulties these people face and wants to do its humanitarian duty, the premier said in a written statement. ``But I must emphasize that it is not possible for us to provide food, housing and transportation for tens of thousands of people.'' Special measures on passage may have to be taken or ``closure of the border may come on the agenda,'' he warned. Jordan has faced a similar problem since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. It announced Wednesday it was closing its border with Iraq, although people continue to cross the frontier. Turkish border officials say that since Aug. 2, 7,532 people have entered Turkey through Habur. Of these, only 3,000 were Turkish people returning home. Another 2,903 were Pakistanis. The next largest groups were Romanians and Yugoslavs. Pakistan has been unable to provide planes to pick up the refugees. Turkey is still dealing with refugees who poured into the country during other crises in recent years. About 60,000 Kurdish refugees fleeing Iraqi chemical bomb attacks poured into Turkey two years ago. Close to 40,000 of them still remain in refugee camps in southeast Turkey. Last year, Turkey also faced a serious refugee problem when 320,000 ethnic Turkish Bulgarians fled to escape persecution by the Bulgarian government. Since the ouster of Bulgaria's Communist leaders, many ethnic Turks have returned to Bulgaria, but about half stayed in Turkey. Turkey is also home to an estimated 1 million Iranians who fled Iran during the Iran-Iraq war. Meanwhile, Turkey's military chief of staff, Gen. Necip Torumtay, and force commanders traveled to the southern city of Diyarbakir north of the Iraqi border to check defense measures undertaken by land and air force units. The manager of the state-owned tire factory Petlas told the Anatolia news agency the factory had been asked to increase production to meet the needs of military vehicles. A state-owned company producing gas masks announced Thursday it was increasing production by 50 percent. Some units of the Turkish air force and several land forces brigades in the southeast have been placed on a state of advanced readiness. Officials have said they do not anticipate an Iraqi attack but that high tensions warrant taking defensive military measures.

DOC.HEAD: Chairman of Miss Texas Pageant Steps Down
DOC.TEXT: The man who has been chairman of the Miss Texas Scholarship Pageant for 20 years has resigned after reports of impropriety, including off-color remarks to contestants. B. Don Magness kept a low profile Friday. ``No, he's not (in) and he does not wish to make any comments or make any appearances,'' said a woman who answered the phone at his office. Magness resigned the volunteer job Thursday night, telling the Miss Texas board of directors that he was unfairly depicted in a Life magazine article as a dirty old man who made lewd comments to pageant contestants. Magness, 58, has been associated with the pageant for 29 years, and will continue on the board of directors. News reports after the Life article reported other complaints about Magness' behavior, including an accusation from a former pageant director that Magness had attempted to influence the outcome of a local pageant. Some contestants and local pageant officials also said Magness gave his blessing to so-called ``living room pageants'' in which would-be contestants or their relatives bought franchises and staged sham pageants that allowed some contestants to move into the state show. Magness issued a statement telling the pageant board he was disappointed ``by the unfair, biased, negative and inaccurate writing ... by Life magazine.'' Magness said he was leaving because he feared the negative publicity could have a detrimental effect on the current Miss Texas, Suzanne Lawrence, who will leave Saturday to compete in the Miss America Pageant in Atlantic City, N.J., Sept. 4-8. Magness also complained that his hometown newspaper, the Fort Worth Star-Telegram, did a ``hatchet job'' on him. Magness is director of public events for the city of Fort Worth. Executive Editor Michael Blackman defended the newspaper's coverage. ``For better or worse, given the environment in which he works, he is going to be subject to scrutiny,'' Blackman said. Michelle Royer Jefferson, 1987 Miss USA and a former Miss Texas contestant who claimed Magness made advances to her, said she was surprised that Magness decided to step down. ``I think that just lends credence to everything that was said about him,'' she said. But Regina Nelson, pageant director for Grayson and Denton Counties, was furious over the resignation. ``You have actually crumbled a man's life, destroyed part of a man's career,'' Nelson, whose daughter is the reigning Miss North Texas, told a reporter. Magness estimated that 30,000 contestants participated in local and state pageants during his tenure as chairman. Two of them, Phyllis George and Shirley Cothran, went on to become Miss America. Seventeen Miss Texases placed among the top 10 finishers in Atlantic City during the past 20 years.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Simon Intervenes in S&L Dispute With Developer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT that settlement not worked out.
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Paul Simon, a frequent critic of the government's handling of the savings and loan crisis, reportedly helped a developer last month who owed millions of dollars to a troubled thrift. The Chicago Sun-Times today in a copyright story reported that after Simon approached thrift officials on behalf of the developer _ a longtime Simon supporter _ talks got under way and the S&L now is in the final steps of working out a negotiated settlement to a lawsuit it filed against the developer. Simon, D-Ill., told reporters today he did nothing wrong. ``I did the same thing that I did for thousands of other citizens,'' Simon said. ``I did not pretend to know any of the details.'' Simon told the newspaper he was unaware that he was intervening in a matter that involved a troubled savings and loan and did nothing improper. The thrift's officials said Simon's call did not influence their actions. Simon asked the president of First Nationwide Financial Corp. in San Francisco to work out an agreement with Stephen Ballis, who owes $5 million to the institution, the newspaper said. First Nationwide received taxpayer help recently to buy Pathway Financial of Chicago, which was the second-largest troubled savings and loan in Illinois until it was bailed out by the government at the end of 1988. Ballis' company, Dayton Resources, defaulted on a Pathway loan used to build a 19-unit condominium complex, the newspaper said. First Nationwide then sued to foreclose on the property and have Ballis replaced by a court-appointed receiver. The S&L has now nearly finalized a negotiated settlement to that lawsuit, the newspaper said. After meeting with Ballis in Chicago this summer, Simon said he called First Nationwide's president. During the conversation, Simon said he told the president he didn't know the details of the dispute, ``but costly litigation could be avoided if they sat down with (Ballis) and worked things out.'' ``I just said, `Take a look at it. You can save a lot of money,''' Simon recalled. ``I did not push anyone to do anything improper, and I would not do that.'' First Nationwide President John Devine said the call prompted him to look into the Dayton Resources loan but did not influence the way the S&L handled the case. Ballis said he had campaigned and raised funds for Simon since his first senatorial race, but Simon said Ballis' support had nothing to do with his intervention. ``I help people whether they are contributors or not,'' Simon said. Simon last week held a Chicago hearing on the savings and loan crisis, in which he urged stricter prosecutions of those who defrauded the nation's thrifts in what has been estimated to be a $500 billion boondoggle for taxpayers. After the phone call, Ballis was contacted by First Nationwide and worked out a settlement of the dispute, Ballis said. In April 1989, Ballis ran out of loan money for the condominium project and Pathway's new owners refused to come up with any more money, the newspaper said. Dayton Resources than stopped work on the still incomplete project. Ballis blamed cost overruns on design changes made at Pathway's request.

DOC.HEAD: Tadzhikistan Declares Sovereignty
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Central Asian republic of Tadzhikistan declared sovereignty today, becoming the 13th of the 15 Soviet republics to make some move toward greater autonomy, a news service reported. The republic's Supreme Soviet, or parliament, passed the declaration after a stormy six-hour session, the independent news service Interfax said. The measure said Tadzhikistan's laws will take precedence over Soviet laws. On Thursday, Soviet Armenia took a stronger step, declaring independence, and the republic of Turkmenia declared sovereignty. Only the republics of Kazakhstan and Kirghizia have not made such moves. The declarations are signs of further fragmentation of the Soviet Union. The three Baltic republics have insisted they want independence and want no part of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan to reconfigure the nation into a looser confederation with more local autonomy for the republics. Tadzhikistan said its declaration on state sovereignty would be the basis for a new constitution and treaty of union with the central Soviet government, Interfax reported. The Supreme Soviet rejected a proposal to create a separate army for the republic, saying that Tadzhikistan has no money for one, Interfax said. The Soviet Union's Central Asian republics, which are predominantly Moslem, have been slower to embrace the more radical course pursued by nationalists in other republics.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service, Workers Ready for Contract Talks
DOC.TEXT: Postal officials and union leaders on Friday formally opened what will likely be months of grueling contract talks. ``I hope that the parties will communicate together and work together to gain a contract marked by fairness and flexibility,'' said Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank. Vernon H. Meier, president of the 85,000-member National Rural Letter Carriers Association, said he views the talks as ``a challenge and an opportunity.'' The financially-strapped Postal Service is preaching moderation, meaning it hopes that workers will hold down their financial demands. But union leaders say their members shouldn't suffer because of management's inability to improve efficiency and hold down costs. ``We don't want the public to be gouged, but we're not going to take the blame for poor management either,'' Moe Biller, president of the American Postal Workers Union, said prior to the talks. Labor contracts between the U.S. Postal Service and its four largest unions expire Nov. 20. The labor groups represent 660,000 workers. Biller's accusations center on the service's push towards automation, which he said has wasted money without improving efficiency. He says automation also costs thousands of jobs. Postal Service spokesman Lou Eberhardt called charges of mismanagement ``pre-bargaining rhetoric.'' Automation joins wages as a key issue in efforts to agree on new three-year contracts. The Postal Service faces a deficit of between $1.4 billion and $1.6 billion this fiscal year, which ends Sept. 30. Because the agency, no longer subsidized by taxpayers, must break even over time, the board of governors has proposed to raise the cost of mailing a letter from 25 cents to 30 cents next spring. Testifying in March before Congress, Frank called on the unions to show ``constructive restraint'' in wage demands. He said 83 percent of the Postal Service's costs go for wages and benefits. As of this month, letter carriers receive a starting salary of $24,381, which includes a cost-of-living adjustment, the Postal Service says. Most clerks and carriers earn a maximum of $31,516, which also includes a cost-of-living increase. The Postal Service says employees receive an additional $8,560 in benefits and premium pay. Joseph Mahon, assistant postmaster general for labor relations, said that the average $20 an hour makes postal workers better paid than their counterparts in private business. The average hourly wage for American workers is $10. Workers with tasks similar to those of postal workers make more than the average worker, though. For instance, United Parcel Service workers just ratified a new contract giving them nearly $18 an hour by 1992. The Postal Service has not drafted specific wage proposals to take to the bargaining table. Biller's union is the largest, representing 334,000 clerks, maintenance employees, drivers and special delivery messengers. Other bargaining groups are the National Letter Carriers Association, representing 234,000 urban letter carriers; the National Postal Mail Handlers Union, representing 50,000 mail handlers; and the National Rural Letter Carriers Association, representing 42,000 rural letter carriers. Glenn Berrien, president of the mail handlers union, says postal workers deserve raises because layoffs in recent years force many to do the jobs of two. He said postal workers are also exposed to hazards, handling ``everything from bees to farm chemicals.''

DOC.HEAD: Doctor in Camarena Torture-Murder Case Ordered Held Without Bail
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge refused today to allow the release of a doctor spirited out of Mexico at the behest of U.S. drug agents for trial on charges he participated in the torture death of Enrique Camarena. Camarena, a Drug Enforcement Administration agent, and his pilot, were tortured and killed in 1985 in Guadalajara. Nearly 50 people have been arrested in the case in Mexico and the United States. Several have been convicted. Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain was charged with violent crimes in aid of racketeering, conspiracy, kidnap and murder. Prosecutors said he administered drugs to keep Camarena alive while he was being tortured prior to death. Alvarez was ordered detained without bail by U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie, who ruled Aug. 10 that Alvarez he was kidnapped illegally and should be returned to Mexico. Federal prosecutors appealed that order to the 9th Circuit Court of Appeal, which issued an emergency order late Thursday to stay Rafeedie's decision. Rafeedie said earlier this month that the United States abducted Alvarez in violation of an extradition treaty with Mexico, that the kidnapping was an offense to Mexico's sovereignty, and his court lacked jurisdiction to try the physician. If convicted, he could be sentenced to life in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rallies Slightly, Gold Drifts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout. A version on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rallied slightly against most major currencies in European trading today as markets remained focused on the prospects of a war in the Middle East. Gold drifted as investors waited for further developments in the Gulf crisis. London dealers said dealing centered on the possibility that hostilities in the Gulf over Iraq's annexation of Kuwait could break into open warfare. Traders in London said dollar activity was subdued for most of the day. The dollar failed to react to a slight revision of figures for the U.S. second-quarter gross national product, which showed an unchanged annual growth rate of 1.2 percent. Most traders had expected a slight upward revision. ``The market at this stage is concentrating on the Middle East crisis, pure and simple,'' said a London trader. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 145.70 Japanese yen from 145.88 at Thursday's close. Later in London it rose to 146.45 yen and in early-afternoon New York trading it fetched 146.62 yen. In London, the British pound fetched $1.9445, cheaper than $1.9515 late Thursday. In early-afternoon New York trading the pound fetched $1.9460. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday: 1.5575 German marks, up from 1.5478; 1.2685 Swiss francs, up from 1.2598; 5.2275 French francs, up from 5.1835; 1.7550 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7390; 1,157.50 Italian lire, up from 1,151.25; 1.1335 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1313. Other early-afternoon dollar rates in New York included: 1.5445 marks, 1.2623 Swiss francs, 1.1346 Canadian dollars and 1,154.12 Italian lire. Zurich bullion dealers said most investors were neutral towards gold Thursday in the absence of significant developments in the Gulf. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $411.75 a troy ounce, down from $412.75 bid late Thursday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $410.75, down from $411.75 late Thursday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $2.61 to close at a bid $410.95. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid price of $5.14 a troy ounce, down from $5.15 late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Recover, Oil Recedes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with latest prices. No Pickup. A version also moved on financial wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices rebounded in Tokyo, Europe and New York today even as tensions intensified over Iraq's deployment of troops near foreign embassies in occupied Kuwait. ``All the (overseas) markets were sharply better,'' said Tom Finnerty, senior vice president for international stock trading at Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. in New York. ``U.S. shares are following the European markets.'' Oil prices declined after matching record highs during Thursday trading. The price of the benchmark U.S. crude was down 68 cents to $31.25 per barrel at mid-afternoon on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Traders said they were encouraged by the possibility of increased oil production by OPEC nations when several oil ministers meet this weekend in Vienna. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks was up 11.88 points to 2,495,30 in afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange, after falling 76.73 points in heavy trading Thursday to 2,483.42. The market traded as much as 35 points up this morning before falling back slightly. Traders bought shares to take advantage of the recent declines and to bulwark positions to hedge against developments over the weekend. The rally was attributed in part to a belief that the market has been oversold since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The index shed 516.33 points, or 17 percent, through Thursday since closing just below 3,000 on July 17. Bond prices, meanwhile, gave back early gains on pessimism about oil prices, inflation and the possibility of war in the Middle East. The U.S. Treasury's 30-year bond was down 5-16 point, or $3.13 per $1,000 in face amount, at mid-afternoon as its yield climbed to 9.16 percent from 9.13 percent late Thursday. The bond market had rallied slightly on a government report that the economy grew at a lackluster annual rate of 1.2 percent in the April-June quarter. That boosted bonds on a belief the Federal Reserve may be forced to lower interest rates to stimulate the economy, which many experts believe was verging on a recession even before the Mideast turmoil. Stock markets in Tokyo, London and Frankfurt, West Germany, were higher today. Prices rose in Tokyo after fluctuations influenced by reports that elite Iraqi invasion forces in Kuwait were being replaced by second- and third-string troops. The Nikkei Stock Average closed up 428.13 points at 24,165.76, a 1.8 percent rise, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The index lost 1,473.28 points Thursday, its fourth-largest one-day drop. In foreign exchange trading, the dollar fell in Tokyo to 145.70 Japanese yen from 145.88 yen at Thursday's close. Later in London it rose to 146.45 yen and in early-afternoon New York trading it fetched 146.62 yen. The dollar closed higher against most other currencies in London after sinking to new lows against the German mark and Swiss franc a day earlier. The Nikkei started lower today on rapid selling but regained nearly 700 points as market players began buying after an NBC news report that Iraq had ordered some elite troops withdrawn from the Kuwaiti-Saudi Arabian border, said Tomoya Koda, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. The market first took the news as a sign that Iraq was withdrawing from the border, because many investors were desperately seeking an excuse to buy after Thursday's huge losses, Koda said. But Iraqi President Saddam Hussein replaced the elite forces with lesser units, and the Nikkei lost some of this morning's earlier gains when investors started selling, Koda said. Markets remained nervous as foreign diplomats in Kuwait defied orders to shut down, and the skeleton staff at the U.S. mission braced for possibilities ranging from a takeover to a supply cutoff. The financial market sell-off has been tied to uncertainty over the future of world oil supplies, which have been reduced because of an international embargo of Iraqi and Kuwaiti crude. The prospect of war has worsened fears. On Thursday, crude oil settled at $31.93, up 71 cents, after reaching $32.25 a barrel, matching the highest level since futures contracts for oil were inaugurated in 1983. In March 1980, after the 1979 Iranian revolution that ousted Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi and curtailed world oil supplies, crude reached a peak of $39.80 per barrel.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Crashes in Crowded Neighborhood, Major Developer Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs with reports on other victims; picks up 9th graf, `Spear, who...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX5
DOC.TEXT: A twin-engine private airplane crashed today in a driveway between two houses in a crowded residential neighborhood, killing the president of a major urban development firm and two other people, officials said. The crash, which occurred in fog and light rain, also set the two houses on fire, but the residents apparently escaped unhurt. Killed was Michael Spear, the president of the Rouse Co., a downtown developer whose projects included the Harbor Place on the Baltimore waterfront, the Faneuil Hall shopping area in Boston, the South Street Seaport in New York and the revitalization of Underground Atlanta. Phil Orlandella, spokesman for the agency which runs Logan International Airport, identified Spear, 49. Federal Aviation Administration officials at Logan said the plane was about 20 miles from the airport when he was asked by the tower to climb. He then reported having trouble climbing and smoke coming from an engine. The Piper Cheyenne turboprop was then lost from the radar screen at about 6:30 a.m. Visibility at the time was one-quarter mile, said Gail Lattrell, a spokeswoman for the Federal Aviation Administration. The flight plan indicated there were three people on the plane and that it was flying from Chatham on Cape Cod, where the Spears have a home, to Boston and planned to return to Chatham, Lattrell said. Spear, a pilot and an athlete, has been president of the Rouse Co., the largest publicly held real estate development company in the nation, since 1986. Orlandella said he could not confirm reports that the two other victims were relatives of Spear, but statements from others indicated his wife, Judy, and a daughter were killed. ``This is a terrible loss to the Rouse Co. and to the country,'' said James W. Rouse, retired founder of the company. ``Mike Spear was a brilliant, compassionate, wise man. His leadership was tremendous. In many respects, he is irreplaceable. Judy was a wonderful woman who made a great contribution in her own right, as well as to Mike's work.'' John Stanton, whose son, Michael, was dating 20-year-old Jodi Spear, said his son had stayed at the Spear home Thursday night and learned of the deaths when police came to the house in Chatham today. Spear, who lived in Columbia, Md., joined Rouse in 1967 as director of market research and project evaluation. From 1971 to 1978, he was general manager of the Columbia project. Spear was named executive vice president for development in 1978. Police Commissioner Francis M. Roache said apparently no one on the ground was hurt in the crash. The airport was closed to arrivals for more than an hour after the crash. The fire destroyed two single-family houses on Lorna Road, and the plane incinerated a car between the houses, setting off a series of explosions. Neighbors said no one was at home in one house; residents of the other escaped. A resident of one house said he threw his wife and three children out a first-floor window of their burning home. ``I don't know how I got out myself,'' said Suliman Kemokai, 39. His wife, Evelyn, was too shaken to speak. Their daughter, Monique, 17, said she heard the crash and the next thing she knew the house was on fire and her mother was trying to round up the children. Monique said they tried to get out the back door, but it was locked and they could not find the key.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Aunt Suffers `Fainting Spell'
DOC.TEXT: Nancy Walker, an elderly aunt of President Bush, suffered a ``minor fainting episode'' at the family's Walker's Point compound Friday, the White House said. An Air Force ambulance stationed in this coastal resort town and a local ambulance responded to a call from the president's physician, Dr. Burton Lee. ``However, the ambulances were not needed and soon returned to their stations,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. Bush is vacationing at Kennebunkport. Fitzwater said the president's aunt ``had a minor fainting episode and has fully recovered.'' She is the older sister of Bush's 89-year-old mother, Dorothy Walker Bush. Their 81-year-old brother, Dr. John Walker, died last Thursday of an aneurism at a nearby hospital after being stricken at Walker's Point. Nancy Walker attended the funeral Tuesday in a wheelchair.

DOC.HEAD: Disneyland Gives Abe Lincoln Show Reprieve
DOC.TEXT: Abe Lincoln, the robot, beat Kermit the frog in a quiet civil war at Disneyland. Disneyland will keep the ``Great Moments with Mr. Lincoln'' show, which park officials had planned to close this weekend. No longer would the nation's 16th president rise from his chair, 51 times a day, to deliver excerpts from his speeches. Park operators reportedly planned to replace the show with a new Muppets attraction. But tourists and park employees were irked by the idea and Disneyland officials apparently backed off from their plans _ for now. ``If you'd asked a few days ago, I'd have said that being a 25-year-old attraction, its popularity has passed,'' said park spokesman Paul Goldman. ``But there seems to be a lot of sentiment for Lincoln.'' For one park visitor, 12-year-old Abby Hangsleben of East Grand Forks, Minn., Kermit just can't compare to Honest Abe. ``Lincoln was president. Kermit is a frog,'' she said. Disney officials refuse to disclose attendance figures but acknowledge that park visitors recently haven't shown a lot of interest in the Lincoln show. Reports had circulated for months among Disneyland's 8,000 employees that the Main Street opera hall, which houses the Lincoln show and exhibits honoring park founder Walt Disney, would be turned over to Kermit, Miss Piggy and Big Bird. Last week, officials said the Lincoln exhibit would be closed on Sunday for the ``refurbishing'' of the opera house. But Goldman said Thursday park planners were looking at several other sites for the Muppets, including an area near the ``It's a Small World'' attraction. ``It's a matter of shoe-horning things in,'' he said. Disney purchased rights to several of the Muppets characters last year and plans to use Kermit, Miss Piggy, Big Bird and the gang in shows and parades at the park.

DOC.HEAD: Defy Deadline to Close Embassy in Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 3-4 with State Department saying Iraqi troops controlling entry to embassy
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said today that Iraqi troops are blocking the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait and that Saddam Hussein's government is preventing a large group of American diplomats and dependents from leaving Iraq. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the Iraqi troops outside the embassy in Kuwait ``are not allowing people to enter or leave.'' However, he added, ``I'm not aware of any confrontations between the Iraqi soldiers and the small group of Americans inside the facility,'' led by Ambassador Nathaniel Howell. In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said Iraqi ``guards are controlling entry and exit from the compound.'' He said one embassy vehicle was prevented from entering the grounds today. Boucher said the small staff was still in contact with some Americans trapped in Kuwait but was hindered by restraints on their movements and ``because we know that the Iraqis are monitoring the embassy's local telephone calls in an attempt to locate American citizens.'' Iraq has demanded that the embassy be closed and the administration has refused. Instead, it reduced the staff to a minimum, and an estimated 100 diplomats and dependents travelled overnight to Baghdad. That's the group that Fitzwater said is being prevented from departing the country for Turkey or other destinations. ``They are safe,'' he said, but unable to depart. He said the administration holds Iraq responsible for the safety of all Americans in Iraq and Kuwait. The spokesman said Bush continues to follow developments in the Persian Gulf crisis carefully, and had met during the morning with his national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and others. Fitzwater also said it was ``sick beyond expression'' that Saddam Hussein appeared in a videotape on Thursday with British children being held hostage in Iraq. It showed the ``cynical and inhuman view'' that Iraq's leader holds for human life, he said. With thousands of American troops already in the Persian Gulf and thousands more on the way _ and a partial call-up of the reserves ordered _ Fitzwater said Bush would return to Washington on Tuesday to meet with congressional leaders on the crisis. Fitzwater told reporters the Iraqis had reneged on their ``explicit commitment'' to permit American diplomats and families in Kuwait and Iraq to depart. He called on Iraq to heed a United Nations resolution that would permit these people to leave the region, and said: ``The United States also reminds Iraq that it will be held responsible for the safety and well-being of American citizens being held hostage,'' he said. There are an estimated 2,500 private U.S. citizens in Kuwait and more than 500 in Iraq. As for the embassy facility in Kuwait, which Iraq has ordered shut down, Fitzwater stressed the administration will not comply. He said Iraqi soldiers are around the embassy, and ``it would appear that people are not being allowed to leave or to enter the embassy.'' He said the facility has electrical and water service despite the presence of Iraqi troops outside. ``They have not made any move against the embassy or intruded in any fashion,'' he said of the Iraqi forces. He also said the situation was duplicated around other embassies in Kuwait, although he did not identify them by name. Fitzwater said American officials are in contact with Howell. Asked what the ambassador would do if the Iraqis tried to forcibly invade the embassy, he said: ``Force has not been applied. Should he be subject to that he will have to act accordingly,'' Fitzwater said. The United States withdrew the complement of Marine guards that normally protects the embassy. One official said at the time the announcement was made that the decision was made to protect American lives, and noted that a few Marines could not fight the Iraqi Army. The decision to leave Howell and a handful of aides in the nearly empty embassy was made ``as a symbol of our rejection of Iraq's illegal occupation and annexation of Kuwait,'' Fitzwater said. An official said one woman traveling with the group to Baghdad was injured when two of the cars collided at the start of the trip. She was left at a Kuwait City hospital. President Bush started his day with a dawn golf game with his two sons, Jeb, of Florida, and George W., of Texas. Bush refused to answer reporters' questions on the Persian Gulf crisis. He sped away in his golf cart, saying, ``New policy,'' an apparent reference to his recent ruling that he will not answer questions on serious matters while golfing. Bush went boating Thursday with national security adviser Brent Scowcroft and playing tennis at his seaside home while monitoring the tense Persian Gulf developments. Fitzwater sought to put out assurances that ``this is a matter that is constantly with him,'' even though he is away from Washington. On a separate front, the White House kept close tabs on progress in United Nations talks on whether to sanction use of force to back up the trade embargo against Iraq. The Soviet and U.S. ambassadors disagreed on whether the five permanent Security Council members had reached agreement on a resolution allowing ``minimum force'' to halt all ships bound for or leaving Iraq. Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said the U.S. Navy has boarded ``a handful'' of ships in its week-old effort to halt Iraqi shipping. He said he could not give a definitive number nor say when or where the boardings occurred. Bush said earlier he was willing to give the U.N. some time to see if it would agree on a resolution endorsing military enforcement, but also has said the United States already has the legal authority it needs to carry out such enforcement unilaterally. At the Pentagon, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney approved plans to call 10,000 military reservists to active duty over the next week and nearly 50,000 by the end of September. The reserves will back up the huge U.S. military presence in the Persian Gulf. The Pentagon also announced the first deployment of American forces from European NATO bases to the Middle East buildup. Troops from the U.S. Army Europe's 7th Medical Command, based in West Germany, are heading to the Persian Gulf area as part of Operation Desert Shield. Bush today also planned to turn to domestic affairs. He scheduled a meeting at his vacation home with Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and Budget Director Richard Darman to discuss deficit-reduction talks that will resume in September with congressional negotiators.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Government In Setting Auto Mileage Standards
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court ruled Friday that the government is acting properly in setting auto mileage standards without preparing formal Environmental Impact Statements. The court, in a 2-1 decision, rejected a series of lawsuits by the state of California, the cities of Los Angeles and New York, and several environmental and safety groups challenging the way the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration sets annual standards for the auto industry. Chief Judge Patricia M. Wald dissented, saying the agency acted arbitrarily when it determined its mileage standards would have no significant impact on global warming. The traffic agency sets mileage standards that automakers must achieve as an average for their models each year. It was 26 miles per gallon for model years 1987-88 and was slightly higher at 26.5 for 1989. The government entities, the Center for Auto Safety, Public Citizen, the Union of Concerned Scientists and the Natural Resources Defense Council filed suits covering mileage standards for 1987-88. Most of the same plaintiffs joined a suit over the 1989 standards. The court ruling rejected all of the complaints. The plaintiffs argued that failure to implement higher standards would cause more air pollution and said the agency should be required to determine exactly how the air would be affected in various cities. The court said the traffic safety agency conducted extensive evaluations of the impact of its standards on fuel consumption and emissions. It said the agency also has committed itself to preparing a cumulative Environmental Impact Statement on the entire mileage standards system. ``That program should provide additional assurance ... that the agency is not making decisions with environmental consequences that escape its full consideration,'' Judge Douglas Ginsburg said in the majority decision. Wald, in dissenting, proposed that the matter be sent back to the agency for a better explanation of its decisions under environmental laws, but she said there was no need to immediately roll back the standards. She said the agency ``fails completely to explain how the cumulative effect it anticipates will affect the non-attainment areas,'' referring to communities that have failed to meet clean air standards set by the Environmental Protection Agency. Those include Los Angeles, other California cities and New York.

DOC.HEAD: Tank-Killing Helicopters Flying Near Saudi-Kuwait Border
EDITOR'S NOTE: The following is based on a pool dispatch.
DOC.TEXT: Frequent Iraqi troop movements keep tank-killing American Apache helicopters ``locked and loaded and ready'' in the air near the Saudi-Kuwait border, Army officers said Friday. The Iraqis, one officer said, ``move around so much you can't always be sure right away what they're up to, so you stay ready'' even though an invasion of Saudi Arabia is not considered imminent. A small group of reporters visited the aviation brigade of the 101st Airborne Division, an air-assault unit, at its base in the Saudi desert. It was the first time reporters had been allowed into the base camp, which is within range of Iraqi forces just over the border in occupied Kuwait. Several AH-64 Apache pilots and co-pilots interviewed Friday said they had been on missions to the border area to familiarize themselves with flying conditions and the terrain below. The Apaches, with Hellfire missiles and multiple rocket pods, are the military's main weapon against Iraqi tanks. The helicopters are designed for both night and day combat. ``We can take out 200 tanks easy in about two hours,'' said Lt. Col. Dick Cody, commander of an Apache battalion. ``It's a (tactical) fighter's dream out here.'' Additional air-defense systems were installed in the Apaches before they were sent to Saudi Arabia, and even more advanced systems designed to detect and defend against enemy fire are expected to be brought into Saudi Arabia for front-line units, the officers said. ``They were upgraded to match what they've (Iraqi forces) got,'' one pilot said. The camp, which would be used as a staging area for repair and refueling bases in the event of combat, is expanding each day as more men, equipment and supplies arrive. Ground rules for the Pentagon pool operation prohibit the disclosure of its location. Most details of the Apache defense systems are classified, but they are designed to destroy approaching enemy fire or to confuse guidance systems. During a display for the journalists, two Apaches flew north over the Saudi desert, hugging the ground and sometimes hiding behind sand dunes. The reporters watched from a Blackhawk helicopter. Col. Tom Garrett, the brigade commander, said the division receives constant updates on Iraqi troop and tank movements and could quickly respond to an incursion into Saudi Arabia. ``We've been told we should get a 6- to 8-hour heads up when they start moving around, but we can be ready pretty fast if need be,'' Garrett said. ``We're not worried about it,'' he said of the Iraqi tank threat. ``We are locked and loaded and ready to go.'' The Apaches are equipped with state of the art radar and other scanning systems, and the weapons use laser and computer-controlled guidance systems. The Hellfire never has been used in combat, but Garrett said it had performed well in training missions. Live-fire training is planned for the Saudi desert, he said. The Apaches, because of the anti-tank capabilities, were among the earliest arrivals in Saudi Arabia. Their engines are being flushed daily because of sand, but Garrett and several pilots said they had experienced few weather-related problems. ``We've got two enemies out here,'' Garrett said. ``One is the environment. The other is the Iraqis.''

DOC.HEAD: 110 Hospitalized After Chemical Factory Explosion
DOC.TEXT: A series of explosions and a fire at a chemical factory in the Urals Mountains injured 110 people and forced authorities to evacuate thousands of people, the Tass news agency reported Friday. The news agency said the fire burned several hours at the factory in the city of Ufa before firefighters put it out. It said three people suffered serious injuries. Most of those hospitalized were firefighters. The water supply for 60 percent of the city's 1 million people was cut off by contamination from the phenol-acetone factory and foam sprayed by firefighters, Tass said. Drinking water was shipped in from other areas. Authorities evacuated 4,000 hospital patients because of dangerous fumes.

DOC.HEAD: Former CIA Agent Must Face Iran-Contra-Related Tax Charges
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge refused to dismiss tax charges brought against a former CIA agent, saying Iran-Contra independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh has the jurisdiction to bring the case, officials said Friday. As a result, Thomas G. Clines' trial on the four-count indictment will begin as scheduled Sept. 4 in Baltimore, said Mary Belcher, spokeswoman for Walsh's office. Clines assisted the Nicaraguan Contra arms resupply network run by Richard V. Secord and Albert Hakim and overseen by then-White House aide Oliver North. He helped locate a European arms dealer as a source of weapons, helped arrange for shipping and lined up crews to transport the supplies to the rebels. Accused of hiding arms sales profits from the government, Clines was indicted Feb. 22 on charges of under reporting his income to the Internal Revenue Service and failing to report foreign financial accounts to the Treasury Department. If convicted on all counts, he could face a maximum of 21 years in prison and $950,000 in fines. The ruling Thursday by U.S. District Judge Norman P. Ramsey in Baltimore came as no surprise to Clines' attorney, Paula Junghans. ``He basically told us that orally months ago,'' Junghans said. ``All he was doing was cleaning up the record and writing it down.'' Ramsey rejected both Clines' bid to dismiss the charges and to suppress financial records obtained through the use of a U.S.-Swiss treaty. Clines had contended in his motion to dismiss that the alleged tax crimes were ``without any relationship whatsoever to the events of the affair.'' Junghans said the tax case were outside the Iran-Contra prosecutor's jurisdiction because ``Mr. Clines has not been charged with committing any crime by virtue of his participation in the purchase, sale or transfer of arms ... nor has he been charged with any crime relating to ... support to the Contras.'' However, Walsh's office had argued that ``crimes involving the attempt to hide arms sale profits'' were within Walsh's purview. The independent counsel said Clines ``illegally misrepresented ... on his tax returns the full amount of his arms sales profits and that he illegally hid from the United States government the existence of the foreign financial accounts in which he maintained some of his profits.'' Ramsey agreed with the prosecutor, saying, ``The court finds that the alleged criminal activity falls within the independent counsel's jurisdiction.'' In addition, Ramsey rejected Clines' motion to suppress financial records on Swiss bank accounts because they were obtained through use of the U.S.-Switzerland treaty. Prosecutors said the only Swiss records to be used are those produced by Hakim. The judge ruled that even if the government used information obtained through the treaty, Clines would have no standing to challenge their use as evidence.

DOC.HEAD: Okla. State Treasurer Punched on the Campaign Trail
DOC.TEXT: Democratic state Treasurer Ellis Edwards was punched in the jaw after he stuck a campaign sticker on a woman's purse. ``This is election time. I guess some people get hot about elections,'' Edwards said. Edwards, who is running for re-election, said he asked a man at a banquet Thursday night if he could put a campaign sticker on his clothing.
