Much of the fighting has pitted hostel dwellers against township residents. Mandela said the ANC told Vlok last week that police should monitor the hostels, prevent armed people from leaving them and also stop area residents from attacking hostel dwellers. In Kagiso on Friday, youths set fire to five factory buildings, causing thousands of dollars in damage, police said. Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu visited the township and heard angry residents demand that the hostels be torn down. Business Day newspaper reported the Kagiso violence caused residents to stay home instead of going to work at the neighboring Chamdor industrial area. Tom Wilson, a Chamdor manager, told the newspaper half the workers were absent and production was down about 50 percent. Police also clashed Friday in Vosloorus township with stone-throwing protesters who tried to block streets with burning tires and other debris. The fighting has continued despite pleas from government and black leaders for peace and a strong police and army presence in the townships. It is considered the most serious violence since nationwide unrest in the mid-1980s. The ANC blames Inkatha for spreading black factional fighting from the eastern Natal province to the townships near Johannesburg. Inkatha accuses the ANC of trying to wipe out any competition for power among black opposition groups. Both groups oppose apartheid, the system of segregation and white dominance, but they differ on the shape of a future South Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Colorado Students Discover Anasazi Village Site
DOC.TEXT: Two University of Colorado students who were tracking bighorn sheep in southwest Colorado stumbled upon the virtually untouched ruins of a lost Indian village more than 1,100 years old. The 6-acre Mountain Sheep Village, as the site is being called, probably had about 200 structures and may have housed 150 to 200 Anasazi Indians as early as the year 850 A.D., said Kristie Arrington, an archaeologist for the Bureau of Land Management. The students, Dave Merritt and Chris Kuzawa, struggled over the rim of a cliff and found mounds and vertical slabs of sandstone sticking out of the ground at the site by a forest of ponderosa pine. ``We were just hiking around and we found it,'' said Merritt. The slabs are the foundations of structures made of poles, brush and adobe. ``It was pretty spectacular,'' Kuzawa said. ``Once we realized what it was, we started to look around. We stayed until dusk. We knew we were on to something pretty big.'' The discovery is significant because the site is on the north side of the Dolores River, which wraps around it on three sides. Previously, Anasazi ruins have been found only south of the river. The Anasazi, or ``Ancient Ones,'' lived in the Four Corners area. Their best-known ruins are the cliff dwellings in Mesa Verde National Park in southwestern Colorado. The newly discovered site is about 60 miles northwest of Mesa Verde, not far from the Utah border. Pottery fragments discovered by the students date the site about 300 years before the height of Mesa Verde cliff dwellings. Arrington said the people of Mountain Sheep Village may have traded big game and timber with other villages in exchange for food and pottery. She said tools associated with game procurement and processing, such as arrowheads, scrapers and knives, have been found on the ground. ``Local people hunting may have been through there and one area shows evidence that it had been `potted' a little bit,'' said Arrington. ``But it's fairly unusual that it hadn't been recorded and documented before now.'' Potting is a term used to describe the illegal digging for Indian pots. Merritt and Kuzawa were working out of the Dolores Canyon Research Center on a federal archaeology project this summer. The project involves tracking desert bighorn sheep and river otters, conducting an inventory of water invertebrates in the river and probing historic mining sites. Arrington said BLM officials will have to decide how to manage the site. ``It needs mapping. ... We would like to get an idea of what was going on there day by day.'' He said no massive excavation is planned.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Rain In East Causes Flooding
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell over much of the East on Friday, causing flooding in West Virginia, and rain also fell over parts of the South and the Plains. Showers and thunderstorms during the afternoon reached from New York state and the southern half of New England across Florida. More than 3 inches of rain fell in two hours during the morning in the mountains of eastern West Virginia, flooding roads, homes and businesses and washing away young trout from a state fish hatchery, authorities said. About 35 homes near Marlinton, W.Va., suffered minor damage, said Pocahontas County emergency services director Richard Barlow. High water flooded part of a fish hatchery near Marlinton and washed away about 30,000 fingerling trout, said Don Phares, director the the state's trout hatchery program. In addition to the loss of fish and damaged pools, the flood caused about $15,000 in damage to supplies and equipment, Phares said. ``The garage has a foot of mud in it. We probably lost 2,300 pounds of trout food,'' he said. Heavy rain fell around Long Island Sound, between New York's Long Island and Connecticut. Rainfalls of 4 and 5 inches on Long Island caused extensive street flooding, the National Weather Service said. On the north side of the sound, streets and highways flooded across Bridgeport, Conn., the weather service said. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 4.93 inches at Islip, N.Y., on Long Island; 1.31 inches at Bridgeport; and 4.10 inches at Norfolk, Va. Showers and thunderstorms also extended over Louisiana, eastern Texas and the Texas Gulf Coast, Oklahoma, western Iowa, southwestern Minnesota, eastern South Dakota, central North Dakota, eastern Nebraska, Wisconsin and southwestern Lower Michigan. Elsewhere, rain also fell over western Montana, Idaho and northeastern Nevada. A flood crest that has been moving down the Wabash River in Indiana for several days reached Covington at almost 4 feet over flood stage, the weather service said. Advisories for high heat indexes _ calculated from a combination of temperature and humidity _ were posted through Saturday over much of Arkansas. Indexes reaching 105 to 110 were forecast over all the state except the northeast section, the weather service said. Tucson, Ariz., cooled to a record low of 65, one degree below the previous record for the date. Friday's low for the Lower 48 states was 36 at Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 56 at Salmon, Idaho, to 99 at Waco, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Denounces Saddam Over Embassy Showdown
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 2nd graf with 2 grafs to update with move unlikely immediately and official saying report seems credible
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration on Friday leveled a barrage of accusations and protests at Iraq as troops blocked the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait and more than 100 American diplomats and dependents were detained in Baghdad. The Iraqi news agency later carried a government announcement that the dependents of foreign diplomats would be permitted to leave Baghdad, but U.S. officials said Iraq had not notified Washington and were unlikely to on the Moslem holy day of the week. ``This seems to be a credible report and if it turns out to be true we will begin to move people out tomorrow,'' a U.S. official told The Associated Press. While President Bush pondered his next moves and one of Saddam Hussein's deadlines for closing the embassy passed, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater denounced the Iraqi leader for enveloping Americans and other foreigners in a ``pattern of harassment.'' Richard Boucher, the State Department spokesman, accused Iraq of ``an outrageous breach of international law'' in preventing the diplomats and family members, including about 30 children, from leaving Baghdad after they had been promised safe passage. Boucher called it ``another stark example of Iraqi duplicity.'' After the Americans had left Kuwait in a 33-car caravan the Iraqis invoked new regulations to keep them in Baghdad at the end of their 19-hour journey, Boucher said. The regulations, which were relayed from Iraqi Foreign Minister Tarik Aziz to the Iraqi ambassador here, prohibit the departure from Iraq of personnel from foreign embassies in Kuwait that stay open in spite of Saddam's order, the State Department spokesman said. Iraq had given two deadlines _ noon and midnight, Kuwait time _ for the missions to close. Boucher said that up to a dozen soldiers appeared at the U.S. Embassy about 11 a.m. (3 a.m. EDT). An embassy vehicle was stopped as it tried to enter the compound. One person inside, a private U.S. citizen, was permitted to leave, Boucher said. Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed Sadiq al-Mashat informed David Mack, a deputy assistant secretary of state, of the new regulations in a middle-of-the-night telephone call. Boucher said Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and his staff of about 10 would stay, keeping in touch with the 2,500 Americans trapped in Kuwait ``as much as circumstances allow.'' They were keeping telephone conversations short because Iraqis were listening in, the U.S. official said. Iraqi guards had stood outside the embassy since Bush retaliated against Saddam's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by organizing an economic boycott of Iraq and dispatching a massive U.S. land and sea force to the Persian Gulf area. But the troops that appeared Friday were the first to move into position to block entry and exit from the embassy, Boucher said. Fitzwater, briefing reporters at Kennebunkport, Maine, as Bush huddled with Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser, said he was not aware of any confrontation between the Iraqi soldiers and the Americans inside. ``They have not made any move against the embassy or intruded in any fashion,'' the president's spokesman said. Boucher said at least 20 other countries were refusing to abandon their embassies, while a few had decided to close. ``I think what is clear to us is that Iraq has tried in a most callous way to barter the security of foreign citizens for concessions on the presence of diplomatic missions in Kuwait, and that most countries are resisting this blatant violation of diplomatic practice and international law,'' he said. The Americans who fled to Iraq were to be evacuated to Turkey, Fitzwater said. He called their detention ``another troublesome element in the overall pattern of harassment and hostage-taking kinds of activities that Saddam Hussein has been engaged in.'' Asked what Howell and his staff might do if the Iraqi soldiers applied force, Fitzwater said: ``Should he be subject to that he would have to act accordingly.'' Thousands of American troops and an armada of warships are within range of Iraq and Kuwait, but Bush gave no hint how he might respond if Saddam attempted to overrun the embassy. Marine guards were withdrawn in the scaling down of the U.S. diplomatic corps in Kuwait City. Officials said their primary mission would have been to dispose of sensitive files and could not have withstood a massive assault in any event. Even with the mounting crisis, Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III mixed vacation with a long series of consultations. Bush went boating Thursday and played golf Friday morning with two of his sons, George and John. Baker, while remaining at his ranch in Wyoming, spoke by telephone twice with Bush, and also talked to Foreign Ministers Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union and Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Rocket Could Be Hanging On to Magellan; More Venus Pictures Released
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 10 grafs with NASA backing off report that brake rocket might not have separated; picks up 9th graf pvs, `Magellan first...' ^LaserPhoto LA4
DOC.TEXT: NASA is investigating the possibility that Magellan keeps losing touch with Earth because its braking rocket might not have fully separated after the spacecraft reached Venus, engineers said Friday. Meanwhile, NASA released new photographs from Magellan that showed a lava-filled, 20-mile-wide meteorite crater on the planet. Magellan project manager Tony Spear said another theory for the lapses in radio contact is that the braking rocket pulled some cables off or burned some cables as it was jettisoned when the spacecraft went into orbit around Venus on Aug. 10. The braking rocket, which slowed Magellan so it could enter orbit, was supposed to separate nine hours later, and most signs are that it did so or at least started to do so, Spear said during a news conference at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``I believe personally the solid rocket motor is far away and not bumping'' the craft, he said. But the possibility it didn't must be considered, said Frank McKinney, program manager for Martin Marietta Corp., which built Magellan. ``It's a possibility we're investigating,'' said spacecraft system engineer John Slonski. Two hours after the news conference ended, the laboratory's public relations office issued a statement saying there was ``currently no doubt the separation was complete.'' Spokesmen refused to elaborate when asked to explain the contradiction between that statement and those made by Slonski during the news conference. Even if the rocket had not completely separated, it wouldn't prevent Magellan from conducting its $744 million mission to use radar to make maps and pictures, Spear said. Mapping is likely to start no earlier than mid-September, two weeks later than planned, he said. Magellan first lost radio contact with controllers on Aug. 16. Until engineers identify and fix the problem that cut the radio link, Spear said, ``I think it's likely to happen again.'' If so, engineers are ready with new computer commands to ``kick start'' Magellan's automatic safety systems and make the spacecraft re-establish contact with Earth immediately, Spear said. Pictures released Friday, including a computer-processed three-dimensional view, showed a meteorite impact crater that has a very smooth floor and a central peak. The smooth floor indicates the crater was flooded by volcanic lava, either because the meteorite punched through Venus' hot, thin crust, or because the impact created cracks that let lava ooze into the crater at some later time, said Magellan chief scientist Steve Saunders. He said he favors the second theory. The crater first was observed by the Soviet Venera 15 and 16 spacecraft in the mid-1980s. Their pictures were 10 times less detailed and couldn't determine if it was an impact crater or created purely by volcanic eruption, Saunders said. He said the crater is relatively young geologically: 100 million to 150 million years old. It is named after Soviet sculptor Anna Golubkina, who lived from 1864 to 1927. Other pictures from Magellan showed intense ``Venusquake'' faulting, lava flows and a network of intersecting ridges and valleys. Scientists also displayed a three-minute videotape assembled from still pictures. It provides a Magellan-eye view of Venus as the spacecraft swept over the planet. Contact with Magellan was lost for more than 14 hours starting Aug. 16 and for 17{ hours starting Tuesday night. ``My heart can't stand this 17-hour loss of signal'' again, Spear said. ``There are moments of terror and of great happiness after we recovered the signal.'' Engineers also are considering the possibility the communications failures were caused by problems with Magellan's computer hardware or programs, or the unlikely chance Magellan is being affected by previously unknown electrical fields around Venus. ``Possibly we're making a scientific discovery, but this is a hard way of doing it,'' Spear said. Evidence suggests that during its second radio outage, Magellan wobbled back and forth ``at a high rate,'' using 5.7 pounds of fuel as its thrusters kept firing, Slonski said. That still leaves 251 pounds of fuel, far more than needed to keep Magellan in orbit for years longer than originally planned. The spacecraft used much less thruster fuel than expected when it slipped into orbit. Magellan was launched from the shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989, and traveled a looping 948 million-mile route to Venus.

DOC.HEAD: Irishman Freed in Lebanon after Four Years as Hostage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with Keenan reported in Syrian hands, to be handed over the Irish foreign minister on Saturday. Picks up 13 pvs, `Keenan was ...' ^LaserPhoto NY29
DOC.TEXT: Irish hostage Brian Keenan was freed by his Lebanese captors on Friday after more than four years in captivity, the fifth Western hostage released in five months. He was reported en route to Damascus. The Irish government confirmed in Dublin a report from Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency that the 39-year-old teacher was free, and Irish Foreign Minister Gerry Collins said: ``I can tell you Brian is now on his way from Beirut to Damascus.'' Iran, which has considerable influence among Shiite Moslem fundamentalist groups in Lebanon, said it had worked for months to help secure the release. A shadowy group calling itself The Organization of the Islamic Dawn announced the release in a terse, typewritten Arabic statement delivered to the Beirut newspaper An Nahar. ``We have decided to release Irish hostage Brian Keenan,'' it said. ``This was done at exactly 9 p.m. Beirut time (2 p.m. EDT).'' No group had claimed responsibility for kidnapping Keenan from the time he was abducted until he was freed. An informed Syrian source said Friday night that Keenan ``was in Syrian hands'' but would not appear in public and until Saturday, when he would be handed over to the Irish foreign minister. The source, who spoke on condition he not be further identified, would not say if Keenan was spending the night in Damascus or somewhere in Syrian-controlled Lebanon. Almost all hostages released in Lebanon have been handed to Syrian officers there and escorted to Damascus overland _ a trip through winding mountainous roads that takes 2{ to 3 hours. Thirteen Westerners are still believed held by extremist Moslem groups in Lebanon _ six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans and an Italian. Most have been held more than three years, and Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, has been held since March 16, 1985. The statement Friday from The Organization of Islamic Dawn was just the second it has made a statement on hostages. On April 30, it said it was freeing U.S. hostage Frank Reed. The Malden, Mass.-born educator was released that day. Hostage Robert Polhill of New York was freed on April 22, and two Swiss Red Cross workers, Elio Erriquez and Emmanuel Christen, were freed this month. Reed, held 3{ years, said later he had been with Keenan. Reed's wife, Fifi, said Friday that her husband would fly to Ireland later to meet with Keenan. In Dublin, a sister of Keenan, Elaine Spence, burst into tears of relief and joy at the news of her brother's release. She and Keenan's other sister, Brenda Gillham, had driven there from Belfast Friday as speculation grew stronger that their brother, after many disappointments, would finally go free. The sisters were to fly to Syria early Saturday with Collins to greet Keenan, the Irish foreign minister said in Dublin. Keenan was kidnapped by gunmen on April 11, 1986 in west Beirut while walking to the American University in Beirut, where he worked as a teacher of English. He was born in Belfast and was traveling on an Irish passport, but is also a British citizen. IRNA had reported Thursday that a European hostage would be released soon. On Friday, Iran's deputy foreign minister, Mahmoud Vaezi, told the Tehran Times newspaper Keenan would be released and said: ``We are thankful to the Islamic groups in Lebanon who once more showed their goodwill toward the West.'' Vaezi said the release resulted from ``several months of efforts of the Iranian officials and Islamic groups in Lebanon.'' ``We expect that the West will take similar steps for the freedom of Lebanese prisoners and Iranian hostages. Such a move will make our efforts for the freedom of a hostages easier.'' Iran has linked the fate of Western hostages to that of four Iranians kidnapped by Christian Lebanese Forces militiamen in July 1982. The four are widely believed to have been killed. But Iranian leaders have stressed they would use their influence to help free Western hostages in exchange for help in freeing the Iranians. Keenan spent most of his life in strife-torn Belfast, and he dismissed the dangers of Beirut when he went there to teach in 1986. For four months, he taught at the university, writing home about the beauty of Lebanon and the fine cuisine and nightlife in Beirut. On April 11, 1986, he rushed out of his apartment, late for an 8 a.m. lecture, and was abducted. His sisters said Keenan's mistake was to forget his Irish passport when he left. They believe his kidnappers thought he was American or British, rather than a citizen of a small neutral country. Keenan was dubbed Britain's ``forgotten'' hostage because his plight did not receive the same publicity as that of Anglican Church Envoy Terry Waite and British television journalist John McCarthy.

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Boycott Schools in North Florida County for Second Day
DOC.TEXT: Civil-rights leaders and school officials met Thursday to end a boycott of classes by black students who want more black administrators and teachers. The boycott at Jefferson County's three schools began Wednesday after students learned a white teacher had been hired to replace a vacancy left when a black teacher decided to take another job. A committee representing the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People presented school administrators with a list of the students' demands, which included the hiring of black administrators and black male teachers for the elementary school, and that at least half of the school district's teachers be black by 1993. Superintendent Bill McRae said he supported all those demands. ``The things they want are the things we want,'' he said, calling the meeting ``very congenial.'' ``I think the attitude of the school board finally gelled into the realization that they had real problems before them,'' said T.H. Poole Sr., head of the NAACP in Florida. Neither McRae nor Poole could say late Thursday afternoon if the boycott would continue Friday. A total of 1,055 of the 2,150 students expected to enroll this academic year were absent Thursday, said Alicia Dery, a school secretary. About 1,200 did not go to school Wednesday, the first day of the school year. Blacks comprise about 70 percent of the students at the elementary, middle and high schools in Jefferson County, which is just east of Tallahassee. Although only 36 percent of the teachers are black, the statewide percentage of black teachers is just under 15 percent, said Betty Messer, McRae's assistant. McRae said school systems throughout Florida are having a hard time finding qualified black teachers. The pool of applicants includes about 10 percent to 15 percent black teachers, he said. Jefferson County had planned to hire four black teachers and four white teachers for the new school year, but earlier this month one of the black applicants took a job in Georgia, McRae said. A white teacher who had resigned at the end of last school year was hired for the spot. The Jefferson school board Wednesday afternoon approved the hiring of a fourth black teacher to replace another teacher expected to take maternity leave this fall.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed in Tribal Violence; ANC Says Talks May Begin Soon
DOC.TEXT: Xhosa and Zulu war bands fought running battles Thursday despite police efforts to keep them apart with repeated volleys of tear gas, and four blacks died. The African National Congress said it could soon begin peace talks with the Zulu-based Inkatha movement. Supporters of the two groups are the main combatants in tribal fighting that has killed more than 500 people in 12 days. Hundreds of heavily armed Xhosas said they wanted to destroy a migrant workers hostel occupied by Zulus in Kagiso township west of Johannesburg. ``I don't care if I die. We just want to fight with the Zulus!'' screamed one enraged Xhosa clutching a butcher knife. The two sides fought with spears, axes and clubs as police fired tear gas. Roaming gangs of Zulus with red headbands looted and burned deserted homes. Xhosas burned houses belonging to Zulu residents. Police spokeswoman Lt. Henriette Bester said four people died, including a woman shot by police trying to stop a crowd from damaging and looting houses. Zulu and Xhosa leaders later held talks mediated by police, but it seemed unlikely the meeting would end the bloodshed. Fighting between Zulus tied to the conservative Inkatha movement and Xhosas, mostly followers of the ANC, erupted Aug. 12 and spread throughout black townships around Johannesburg. Police said most townships were quiet Thursday except for scattered incidents. The Zulu-Xhosa war has continued despite pleas for peace from government and black leaders and a strong police and army presence in the townships. It is considered the most serious violence since nationwide unrest in the mid-1980s. Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu cut short a visit to Canada because of the violence. On Thursday he toured parts of Tokoza, a hard-hit township. ``We have come to express solidarity with them,'' Tutu said of the residents. ``Their pain is our pain.'' Tutu asked for an international peacekeeping force to halt the fighting. Political violence between ANC and Inkatha supporters has killed about 5,000 blacks in Natal in the past five years. Inkatha accuses the ANC of trying to wipe out any competition for power among black opposition groups. Both groups oppose apartheid, the system of racial segregation and white dominance, but differ on the shape of a future South Africa. Also Thursday, about 40 people, including ANC regional leaders, were arrested at a demonstration in Cape Town protesting alleged police torture. Other protesters, claiming human rights violations, marched in Vereeniging, near Johannesburg; in Bloemfontein, to the south; and in the Gazankulu homeland in the northeast.

DOC.HEAD: Mideast Tension, Texas Refinery Troubles Send Oil Prices Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-6, `Traders responded ...,' with 4 grafs to tighten second sentence in 5th graf, UPDATE with Arco raising wholesale price of gasoline, EDIT for transition; picks up 7th graf, `Unleaded gasoline ... A longer version moved on the financial wire.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Markets, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Oil matched an all-time high and unleaded gasoline notched a seventh-straight record in the futures market Thursday, as traders worried about the threat of combat in the Mideast and troubles at two Texas refineries. ``Again, it's the possibility of war and the probability of damage to Saudi oilfields if a war did occur,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. The price of light, sweet crude reached a high of $32.35 per barrel for October delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange, before slipping back to a close of $31.93, up 71 cents from Wednesday. The high equaled a record set Aug. 2, 1983, the Merc said. It was the second day oil stayed above the $30-per-barrel mark, last seen in late 1985, but the market ``didn't have quite the charge that it did yesterday,'' Hittle said. ``It was not quite such a rush.'' Traders responded to concerns over the international showdown coming Friday, the deadline set by Iraq for nations to empty their embassies in Kuwait. The United States has refused to comply with Iraq's demand. Atlantic Richfield Co., which had frozen its wholesale price of gasoline two weeks ago, on Thursday rose prices by an average of 2.5 cents a gallon. Arco had been able to hold prices down because it refines its own crude, rather than buying in the volitile spot market. However, increased demand has forced the company to pay high spot-market prices and left as many as 160 stations running out of gas every day, said George Babikian, head of Arco's marketing and refining division. Arco said it was risking the wrath of consumers by not being able to resupply stations quickly. The futures price of gasoline also rose Thursday, partly because of problems at two Texas refineries. Unleaded gasoline hit an all-time high of $1.11 per gallon for September delivery on the Merc, before settling at a record-high closing price of $1.086, up 4.44 cents from Wednesday. Unleaded gasoline has hit record closing prices every day since Aug. 15, with prices at the pump rising in response. Shell Oil Co. said 165,000 barrels of crude cannot be refined daily because of a fire Thursday at its plant in Deer Park, Texas, although a spokesman was not sure how long repairs might take. Also, a leak at the Crown Central Petroleum Corp. refinery in the Houston area forced a partial shutdown that analysts said would probably not disrupt supplies for more than a day or two. Hittle called the shortfall ``a pretty significant volume, particularly given that we're already facing potential declines in imports.'' But analyst Bob Baker at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said markets might have overreacted to the news from Texas. In other trading Thursday, home heating oil rose 4.88 cents per gallon to close at 96.23 cents on September contracts, while natural gas remained sluggish, falling from $1.555 to $1.545 per 1,000 cubic feet.

DOC.HEAD: North, South Korea Inch Closer to Talks Between Prime Ministers
DOC.TEXT: North and South Korea inched closer to historic talks between their prime ministers Thursday when both sides agreed to travel and telephone arrangements for the Sept. 4-7 meeting. Liaison officers met at the border village of Panmunjom and agreed North Korean delegates would cross the heavily fortified border by car and that the two sides could use Red Cross phone lines. They agreed to meet again before September. In an interview with the newspaper Chosun Ilbo, President Roh Tae-woo said South Korea would propose gradual arms reduction at the meeting. He said the Communist North must give up its efforts to overthrow the pro-Western South and accept his call for free travel and economic exchanges between the two Koreas. Roh told his administration Thursday the talks could lead to political and military discussions that could ease four decades of bitter hostility on the divided Korean peninsula. The prime ministers _ Kang Young-hoon of South Korea and Yon Hyung Muk of North Korea _ are figureheads with little policy-making power, but the meeting would have symbolic significance as the highest-level contact ever between North and South. Opening the borders is seen as a step toward reunification of the Koreas, which were divided in 1945 following Japan's collapse in World War II. The two Koreas remain technically at war because they never signed a peace treaty at the end of the Korean War in 1953. About 200 radical students yelling anti-government slogans battled riot police with rocks and firebombs Thursday at Seoul's Dank University. Riot police drove students back with tear gas. ``Down with Roh's deceitful unification policy!'' students shouted. Radicals have accused Roh of insincerity in talks with North Korea. They say he is trying to divert public attention from pressing domestic issues and has no intention of following through on his promises. The two Koreas have yet to solve several issues regarding the prime ministers' meeting, including a memorandum guaranteeing visitors' safety. The safety issue blocked a planned border opening in mid-August after North Korea refused to discuss safety guarantees in writing and asked for direct contacts with South Korean dissidents. The border has 1.5 million troops on each side.

DOC.HEAD: Attorney General Says Rape Victims' Names Not Confidential
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf, `In response...' with Branstad seeking to change law; picks up 4th graf pvs, `The issue...
DOC.TEXT: Iowa police must release the names of most rape victims to the news media, the state attorney general's office said Friday, but newspaper editors and broadcasters said they would continue to protect the names. The opinion quickly drew the wrath of a victim services counselor, who said it would make sexual assault victims reluctant to report crimes. In response to a request by Gov. Terry Branstad, assistant attorney general Gordon Allen said state law does not permit police to keep the names of rape victims confidential. The only exception, he said, is when release of the name would jeopardize the investigation or put the victim in danger. Branstad will seek to change the law to assure confidentiality, said Richard Vohs, a spokesman for the governor. The issue came up earlier this year when The Des Moines Register challenged the practice by Des Moines police of routinely suppressing names and other information about rape victims. The department has since released the names, but none has been used in news stories. Although release doesn't mean the news media would use the names, Polk County Victim Services counselor Terry Shock said many victims won't understand that distinction. ``There will almost certainly be misconceptions,'' she said. She said society places a negative stigma on rape victims, as if the woman somehow brought on the crime, and most victims simply do not want anyone to know. ``Face it, people will be people. A lot of them will blame the victim. A lot of people aren't going to report the crime or won't even go to the hospital for fear that the hospital has to report it,'' Ms. Shock said. She also said that when reporters have the names, there's room for error that would allow the name to get in print. ``And somewhere or sometime, there's going to be journalists who simply don't care,'' she said. ``It's just very unfair to the victims.'' Allen said he was sensitive to arguments about not releasing the names, but he said the law makes no exception for rape victims. ``Due to the strong presumption in favor of disclosure of governmental records frequently reiterated by the Iowa Supreme Court, it is our view that (any doubts on the issue) would be resolved in favor of disclosure,'' Allen wrote. The law allows police to withhold information which ``would plainly and seriously jeopardize an investigation or pose a clear and present danger to the safety of an individual.'' But Allen said this exception cannot be applied to all rape cases. ``To the best of my knowledge, there is no other law in the nation that attempts to devastate victims' lives like that,'' said Anne Seymour, spokeswoman for the National Victim Center, based in Fort Worth, Texas, and New York City. ``I'm 99 percent sure.'' ``One of the critical reasons why victims say they don't report the crimes ... is the fear of exposure,'' she said from New York. The National Victim Center serves over 7,000 local victim service groups, Ms. Seymour said. Virtually all of Iowa's newspapers and radio and television stations have said they would not use the name of rape victims without permission from the victim. Mark Bowden, managing editor of The Gazette in Cedar Rapids, said the opinion will not change his paper's policy of not publishing the names. But Bowden said mistakes leading to the broadcast or publication of a name could be made regardless of the law. ``You might have an inexperienced reporter, but is that any different than having a rookie at the police desk?'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: American Legion Post Will Invite Rejected Black To Apply
DOC.TEXT: An American Legion post that has been closed since it refused to admit a black Vietnam veteran last month has agreed to allow him to reapply, the state American Legion commander said Thursday. The veteran, Thurman Thompson, said he planned to submit another application. ``What I would hope is that those who didn't want me, they would re-evaluate their thoughts and situations,'' Thompson said. ``I hope that everything ends on a positive note.'' Norris Kinion, the state commander for the American Legion, said the Fred H. Sexton Post 1 in Florence, 80 miles east of Columbia, would be permitted to resume its normal activities if it accepted black members. The post was suspended last week after it was disclosed that six members of the post had decided not to accept Thompson because they didn't want blacks joining their group. Thompson, a former Navy petty officer and signalman who served in Vietnam in 1972-73, works at General Electric Co. At the time of the vote against Thompson, the post required just two votes to reject an applicant. But the post changed its bylaws Tuesday to allow a majority vote on all applications, Kinion said. The chapter's suspension has not been formally lifted, he said, ``but they're being permitted to function until such time as the investigative committee can make its report.'' The committee looking into the case will meet at the annual convention of the American Legion starting Friday in Indianapolis, Kinion said. Al Stein, commander of the Florence post, did not return a phone call Thursday afternoon. The post's rejection of Thompson prompted several members to resign. Maria Lewis, the post's secretary, was fired from her job as the county veterans affairs officer. She had opposed Thompson's membership on the grounds that the post's bylaws prohibited integration. The American Legion has had black members since the organization was created in 1919.

DOC.HEAD: Forest Service Authorizes Telescopes on Mount Graham
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Forest Service said Thursday it had authorized the University of Arizona to build three telescopes on Mount Graham after determining construction wouldn't harm an endangered squirrel. The Justice and Agriculture departments signed off on the project, saying a study by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service had satisfied worries that the observatory, which would include the world's most powerful telescope, would threaten the habitat of the Mount Graham red squirrel. ``As soon as we can we'll sign relevant construction documents and obtain our permit,'' said university spokesman Steve Emerine. He said work would begin as soon as possible. Maricopa Audubon Society spokesman Robin Silver said in Phoenix that attorneys for environmental groups opposed to the $200 million project would be in court by Friday morning seeking a temporary restraining order. Expert witnesses in the hearing ``will now include members of Congress, the Fish and Wildlife Service, Forest Service biologists and the General Acounting Office,'' Silver said. Rep. Morris K. Udall, D-Ariz., and other members of the Arizona delegation oppose construction of the telescopes without further study. Udall was out of town and couldn't be reached for comment. A survey earlier this year determined there were fewer than 150 of the half-pound rodents _ one of 25 genetically distinct subspecies of the red squirrel _ scurrying over the mossy, spruce-covered slopes of 10,500-foot Emerald Peak. The Justice Department had been reviewing a recommendation by a team at the Fish and Wildlife Service that another biological study be undertaken before construction begins on the mountain 125 miles northeast of Tucson. Emerine said the university would work with the Forest Service and Fish and Wildlife Service to create a buffer zone around the construction site so as not to disturb the squirrel. A statement from George M. Leonard, associate chief of the Forest Service, said further consultations would be made if the project resulted in the deaths of more than six squirrels in any one year. The university proposed the construction of the observatory in 1984. Its partners include the Smithsonian Institution, the Max Planck Observatory of West Germany and the Vatican Observatory. In March, U.S. District Judge Alfredo C. Marquez granted the request of environmental groups and issued a four-month injunction barring construction on Emerald Peak. But an appeals court in San Francisco overturned the delay in May. General Accounting Office investigators testified before a congressional hearing in late June that the squirrel's fate had become more precarious since the 1988 congressional act that authorized construction of the telescopes. A springtime count indicated there were between 132 and 146 of the squirrels left on the mountain, their only habitat.

DOC.HEAD: Man Stabs Crook Posing as Detective
DOC.TEXT: A robber masquerading as a police detective was chased down a street by a group of angry residents and stabbed to death, police said Thursday. The incident began Wednesday night when two men, identifying themselves as police and displaying a gold badge, gained entry to Carlos Rosario's apartment in the borough of the Bronx, police said. Once inside Rosario's apartment, one of the men announced a robbery, and hit Rosario over the head with the butt of a gun. ``They took jewelry, and attempted to tie up the victim and his wife,'' said detective Lt. James Malvey. Rosario began struggling with the robbers as his wife fled screaming from the apartment. The two men also ran, with Rosario chasing them, Malvey said. Rosario and about 10 other residents pursued the men for about two blocks until one of the pair pulled a knife and stabbed Rosario in the shoulder. The other robber fled. As Rosario ran for help to an ambulance parked across the street, an unknown man jumped from the group and stabbed the fake detective twice in the chest, said police spokeswoman Sgt. Tina Mohrmann. The ambulance driver took the robber, who was identified as Jose Abreu, 49, to Jacobi Hospital, where he was pronounced dead, Mohrmann said. Rosario was treated at Jacobi for his stab wound. No arrests were made in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Back U.N. Sanctions Enforcement After Gorbachev Warns Saddam
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with Soviets dropping objections to U.S. resolution on using force to halt trade with Iraq; DELETES outdated material; ADDS background; more than 20 countries defying Iraqi order to close embassies in Kuwait. Picks up 12th pvs, Gremitskikh said ...
DOC.TEXT: Just hours aftger President Mikhail S. Gorbachev issued a stern warning to Iraq, the Soviets said Friday that they were ending objections and backing Washington's call for using force to ensure a U.N. trade embargo. In a message to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, Gorbachev said the situation in the Persian Gulf had become ``extremely dangerous.'' He said that Iraqi failure to comply with U.N. Security Council resolutions _ by pulling out of Kuwait _ would ``inevitably prompt the Security Council to take corresponding additional measures,'' the official Tass news agency said. Later Friday, Soviet U.N. Ambassador Valentin V. Lozinskiy said the Soviets would now back a U.S. resolution in the Security Council authorizing the use of ``minimal force'' to halt all trade with Iraq. He also said the Soviets were considering participation in an international naval police force that would enforce the tightening of economic screws on Iraq. The United States, Britain and France had been trying to gain Soviet support for a Security Council resolution approving the use of force to impose the economic embargo on Iraq. The Security Council was expected to vote on the U.S. resolution late Friday or early Saturday. Also Friday, the Soviet Union withdrew its embassy staff from Kuwait before an Iraqi deadline ordering embassies there to close. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Four days later, the U.N. Security Council ordered an international boycott of trade with Iraq and called for restoration of Kuwait's sovereignty. The council also denounced the Iraqi annexation of the oil-rich emirate and demanded that Baghdad allow all foreigners to leave. Soviet media did not carry the text of Gorbachev's message. But Tass said he reiterated the Soviet position that Iraq's annexation of Kuwait was illegal and ``described the situation in the Persian Gulf as extraordinary and extremely dangerous.'' ``How the Security Council acts now depends fully on Iraq,'' Tass said. ``Gorbachev in his message urged the president of Iraq to immediately take appropriate steps.'' At the United Nations, Lozinskiy emphasized that the use of even minimal force should be as a ``last resort,'' and said political and diplomatic efforts to diffuse the Persian Gulf crisis should take precedence. He made his comments after the council's five permanent members _ the United States, Soviet Union, China, France and Britain _ ended more than four hours of informal meetings. Earlier in Moscow, Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri Gremitskikh said all Soviet embassy personnel had been evacuated from Kuwait to comply with an Iraqi demand to cease diplomatic activity. ``The staff of the Soviet Embassy came back to Moscow since the situation in Kuwait made it impossible for them to continue their work there,'' Gremitskikh told a news conference. ``From today the embassy is empty. There are no personnel. It is shut, maybe locked. I don't know what the procedure is.'' He said that under international law, the embassy remains open, but vacant: ``We are not in international legal terms closing the embassy. It remains there.'' The United States and more than 20 other countries said they would defy Iraq's demand to remove all embassy personnel. Gremitskikh said the decision to evacuate does not change Moscow's position that the invasion and annexation of Kuwait were illegal acts that should be reversed. ``We believe that the decision of Iraq to close all the international embassies in Kuwait runs counter to international law,'' he said. ``The Soviet Union considers Kuwait to be a participant of the world community and has diplomatic relations with it.'' Asked what circumstances made it impossible for the embassy to continue working, he said: ``The security of the people is first and foremost.'' Earlier in the week, Gremitskikh said the Soviets would consider evacuating their diplomats if the Iraqis shut off food, water or electricity supplies to the embassy. On Friday, he said they decided to evacuate before any of those things happened. Gremitskikh said the government decided ``so that we would not endanger people, we would better let them come home.'' All 882 Soviets now have been evacuated from Kuwait and returned to Moscow. Gremitskikh said the evacuation of the 7,791 Soviet civilians in Iraq would begin Sunday, starting with women, children and invalids. But Soviet officials said this week that Soviet military advisers would remain in Iraq, long an ally of Moscow, because of contractual obligations.

DOC.HEAD: Restraining Order Denied in Bid to Block Telescope Construction
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Friday refused to issue a temporary restraining order environmentalists had sought to prevent the University of Arizona from starting construction on Mount Graham. U.S. District Judge William D. Browning, conducting a hearing by telephone conference call, rejected the request of the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund. The fund represents a coalition of environmental groups seeking to block the $200 million Mount Graham International Observatory. The environmentalists claim that the telescope project would encroach on the habitat of the endangered Mount Graham red squirrel. Browning said he had not heard ``anything that rises above speculation'' that construction could begin before Tuesday, when another hearing is set before U.S. District Judge Alfredo C. Marquez, who has agreed to cut short his vacation to be present. On Thursday, the U.S. Forest Service said the Justice and Agriculture departments had authorized construction of three telescopes after determining that a 1988 law passed by Congress precluded further biological study over the impact an observatory would have on the squirrel. By Friday, the university had signed a construction contract, obtained a special use permit from the Forest Service and planned to get work crews onto the mountain as soon as possible, probably by early next week. Work would center on transplanting small trees, finishing the last 200 feet of a two-mile access road, clearing a one-third acre site of large trees and preparing it for pouring concrete next year. Sierra Club attorney Mark Hughes said the restraining order was needed because the university would not promise to delay construction until the hearing Tuesday. The hearing concerns reopening a suit that Marquez stayed last month, at Hughes' request, challenging the observatory. Hughes said Marquez would be asked to enforce a provision allowing for a new biological study. The Forest Service contends a new study is not neccessary. Jim McNulty, representing the university, told Browning that with the federal agencies' green light, its ``position is stronger now than ever before'' for beginning construction. He said continued delays could jeopardize the project, which is to include the Columbus Telescope, which would be the world's most powerful. McNulty said some work might begin before the hearing, most likely preparing holes to transplant small trees from the one-third acre site for the Sub-Millimeter Telescope. However, it was unlikely heavy equipment would arrive at the site by Tuesday because crews must first be trained how to adhere to work restrictions in the officially designated ``refugium,'' the squirrel's prime habitat, he said. A spring census indicated that between 132 and 146 of the genetically distinct subspecies of red squirrels remain on the mountain in southeast Arizona.

DOC.HEAD: Salembier Resigns as Post President
DOC.TEXT: Valerie Salembier has resigned as president of the New York Post after 17 months at the newspaper's helm, the Post's owner announced Thursday. No replacement was announced. Post owner and publisher Peter Kalikow said he would reassume the title of president. Salembier, a former publisher of TV Guide, was named to the post in April 1989. Kalikow spokesman Howard Rubenstein said Kalikow had not asked Salembier to resign. He added that she was not leaving for a specific position elsewhere. ``They parted very amicably,'' he said, Salembier, who supervised business, advertising and circulation, said in a written statement that she felt it was time ``to move forward to new challenges and opportunities.'' Kalikow praised her performance. ``She has successfully structured a business operation which has effectively positioned the New York Post for sales and profit growth in the 90s,'' he said in the statement. Kalikow in 1988 bought the newspaper, which was losing money, from Rupert Murdoch. Under her tenure, the Post discontinued in November its 8-month-old Sunday edition, which failed to attract sufficient advertisers or readers and lost millions of dollars.

DOC.HEAD: Pessimism Continues to Climb
DOC.TEXT: Pessimism about the economy has reached a level unseen since 1981 and 1982, when the United States fell into the worst recession since World War II, says a New York Times-CBS News poll. Sixty percent of Americans believe the country is already in a recession, according to the poll published Friday. About 55 percent of the public believe the economy is worsening, while 40 percent said it was staying the same and 4 percent said it was improving. The negative mood about the economy has been building for months, but was deepened by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and the resultant economic bad news: rising oil prices, falling stocks and higher interest rates. A Wall Street Journal-NBC News poll in May found only 30 percent of Americans felt there would be a recession this year. A CBS News poll Aug. 8 found 49 percent of Americans who felt the country was in a recession. Still, the new poll found virtually no change in President Bush's approval rating on the economy. His handling of the economy was viewed favorably by 45 percent of respondents and disapproved of by 44 percent. More than a third _ 37 percent _ of respondents in the new poll believed prices will go up a lot in the next year. Another 52 percent said they would go up at least a little, the poll said. Seven percent said they would stay the same and the rest either didn't know or said they would go down. The survey was conducted in telephone interviews with 1,422 Americans from Aug. 16 to Aug. 19. The margin of error was plus or minus three percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Equity-Disney Work out Contract for 400 Employees
DOC.TEXT: An actors' union representing about 400 performers at Walt Disney World attractions and hotels has agreed to a three-year contract effective Sept. 9, officials said Thursday. The pact worked out by Actors' Equity and the company covers dancers, singers, actors, stunt performers, gymnasts and comedians. Neither side would disclose details of the agreement, which is to be presented to the membership in meetings Sept. 5-7, said Richard Delahanty, business representative for the Orlando-area office of Actors' Equity. Bill Ward, vice president of labor relations for Disney, said the company was pleased with the results of the negotiations. Equity Executive Secretary Alan Eisenberg also expressed satisfaction with the contract. ``This has been a long process, begun 16 months ago when we initiated our organizing campaign, and we are very pleased with the results,'' Eisenberg said in a joint statement with Ward. Performers at the park voted in May to be represented by the organization. The pact does not cover the costumed character actors such as those portraying Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck. They come under a contract negotiated by the Teamsters union.

Most U.S. reserves sent to help defend Saudi Arabia won't be driving tanks or digging foxholes. But they will tackle two of the most important tasks in desert warfare: getting water and protecting against chemical attacks. In announcing that about 46,700 reserves will be called to active duty over the next five weeks for Operation Desert Shield, the Pentagon said Thursday that most of the part-time soldiers will be posted in or near Saudi Arabia. The first telephone calls to reserve members could come as early as today, officials said. It's unclear whether any reserve combat units, such as the Georgia National Guard unit that comprises three brigades in the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division at Fort Stewart, Ga., will be dispatched to the forbidding Saudi desert. The two active-duty brigades in the 24th already are on their way there. Many of the military's key skills are held mainly by reserve units. Among those considered most important for Desert Shield are water distribution and purification specialists and experts in chemical decontamination, officials said.

The Mideast crisis has people talking about conservation again. But few are actually doing anything about it. Phone lines started ringing at energy conservation advice lines right after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, as consumers fearing higher prices sought tips to cut their consumption. In Minneapolis, the Metropolitan Transit Commission used Iraqi President Saddam Hussein's picture and the slogan ``Stop pumping him up,'' in an advertising campaign to suggest that people use city buses rather than their cars. So far, however, little suggests people are driving less, investing in more efficient home heating or following the Bush administration's cautious suggestions for gasoline savings.

The financially suffering Postal Service is asking its four unions to keep down wage demands when contract talks open today, but union leaders say their members shouldn't pay for management mistakes. ``We don't want the public to be gouged, but we're not going to take the blame for poor management either,'' said Moe Biller, president of the American Postal Workers Union. Biller's accusations center on the service's push towards automation, which he said has wasted money without improving efficiency. He says automation also costs thousands of jobs. Postal Service spokesman Lou Eberhardt called charges of mismanagement ``pre-bargaining rhetoric.'' Automation joins wages as a key issue in efforts to agree on new three-year contracts before the current pacts expire at midnight Nov. 20. The four unions represent 660,000 workers.

American Andrew Voros walked out of a jail in war-ravaged Liberia with only a pair of jeans _ and many horror stories. Voros, who spent the last four years documenting the destruction of the last virgin rain forest in West Africa, had his work looted. He also saw a friend tortured by soldiers who later told him his friend had been killed. And he has memories of bodies littering streets in Liberia's capital, Monrovia. The 33-year-old New Jersey man was jailed for eight days in Monrovia by soldiers loyal to President Samuel Doe. The U.S. Embassy engineered Voros' release, U.S. Marines got him out of the country Saturday and he returned Tuesday to his home in Rahway, 10 miles southwest of Newark. ``Since I was released, I've kept the loss of my friends and work out of my mind,'' he said Thursday by telephone from his home.``I'm so happy to be alive.''

Reports of the political demise of ousted former governor Evan Mecham may have been premature. The feisty former car dealer's campaign to reclaim the Arizona governor's office is very much alive and he remains in the thick of the five-way race for the Republican nomination. ``He has a good chance. He has a very good chance,'' said Phoenix pollster Earl de Berge. Other pollsters and consultants are careful to hedge their bets. ``If the turnout is under 35 percent, Mecham could win it,'' said Bruce Merrill, director of the media research center at Arizona State University.

DOC.NOTE: $adv27
For Release PMs Monday, Aug. 27
DOC.HEAD: Long-Term Investors Unfazed
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices may be collapsing on fears of war and energy shortages, but the focus in some quarters remains on the long run. In interviews, three big investors with very different approaches and clientele shared a belief that investing must center on fundamentals. All saw opportunities developing. Thomas O'Hara, chairman of the National Association of Investors Corp., said he and his staff were reviewing a list of buying opportunities. Even if prices continue to fall, some stocks already are buys, he said. The NAIC, which runs a mutual fund and provides advice to the nation's largest aggregation of investment clubs, tends to invest no matter what short-term conditions might be. The credo of its clubs, for example, is to invest small amounts on a regular monthly basis in basically sound, well-managed companies. Down markets are viewed as opportunities to obtain more shares for the money. Using that philosophy, the NAIC's oldest member, the Mutual Investment Club of Detroit, has averaged better than 12 percent a year for 50 years, which means it has doubled its portfolio value on average every six years. ``The difficult task in a market like this is to convince people there are opportunities, but the opportunities are great,'' O'Hara said. Andrew Lanyi, managing director of the Lanyi Division of Ladenburg, Thalman & Co., is also a fundamental investor, but the stocks he chooses may not make the NAIC lists. Lanyi seeks small, highly profitable, undiscovered companies. His better selections often appreciate three or four times _ even much more. To find such companies requires an enormous amount of effort, such as screening 30,000 companies to uncover eight possibilities. All will have the potential to grow into blue chips and be ``discovered'' by Wall Street. Shortly after the recent decline began, several of Lanyi's selections were off sharply. Asked what effect the declines were having on him, Lanyi said, ``I have become more aggressive.'' Lanyi said those who know company fundamentals _ products, sales-earnings potential, management _ can take the upsets. It takes discipline and patience. Master those, he suggested, and you can keep eyeing the opportunity. John Wright, chairman of Wright Investors Service in Bridgeport, Conn., manages billions of dollars of blue-chip investment portfolios for institutions and clients, and advises many other clients around the world. The Wright company foresaw the sharp decline and presented clients with extensive written analyses long before it occurred. As he views the sell-off, the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait was merely the trigger. ``I have thought this one would go down at least to 2,700'' points on the Dow Jones industrial average, he said. ``Then, after a rally, I thought it would decline to 2,100 points.'' ``We haven't had the rally because of the invasion,'' Wright said. While he sees a chance that the Dow's low will be between 2,400 and 2,500 points, his stronger expectation is that it will reach 2,100 or 2,200 some time in 1991. Stressing fundamental analysis, Wright's firm has averaged 12.2 percent a year from 1961 to 1990. In anticipation of a decline, he had reduced his equity portfolios sharply in recent months. At the moment, his portfolios are 50 percent stocks. Already, Wright says, some long-term bargains are appearing, but he tempers that with a rather ominous caveat, that if the Federal Reserve doesn't allow interest rates to drop, the country may fall into recession. He doesn't think it will happen. When the Middle East calms down, he believes the country will have lower interest rates and a much better-run government. A lot of changes must and will be made, Wright said. ``The United States once again will be the world economic leader,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian `Yacht People' _ Money, but Legal Limbo
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: The continuing flow of refugees from Indochina has been joined by the ``yacht people,'' Cambodians with a little money who probably are sailing into a legal limbo. Indonesian officials describe them as a ``new phenomenon'' and say many of the Cambodians, unlike the far more numerous Vietnamese, are unlikely to be resettled anywhere except back where they came from. Aid workers applied the not-to-accurate label after seeing Cambodians who were relatively well dressed come ashore from larger, better-equipped vessels than those of the Vietnamese ``boat people.'' Some had passports and money, and wanted only fuel and supplies for the journey to Australia. ``They didn't ask for asylum,'' said Ali Alatas, the Indonesian foreign minister. ``They had money to buy food and wanted to be on their way. . . . Were we supposed to say no, please stay?'' Alatas was referring to Australian allegations that, by enabling Cambodians to continue their journeys, Indonesia might be encouraging others to make the trip. Well over 200 Cambodians have reached northwestern Australia since November by sailing more than 2,500 miles through the vast Indonesian archipelago. Prime Minister Bob Hawke says the Cambodians, in general, left their homeland for economic rather than political reasons and do not qualify as refugees. Australia has made clear it does not want to become a ``first asylum'' country _ the first in which boat people arrive. Until now, that role has been played by Hong Kong and member nations of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations: Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines, Singapore and Brunei. Australia wants to continue choosing people for resettlement from those screened as refugees in the existing camps. Most Australians seem to feel they should be compassionate toward genuine refugees, but there has been a backlash recently against Asian migrants. More than 1,750 Cambodians have landed in Indonesia, most of them since February, and are held with other refugees on Galang Island, just south of Singapore. The majority are young men who tell reporters they fled to avoid being drafted to fight Phnom Penh's war with rebels. An exodus of Cambodians by boat began after Vietnam withdrew most of its occupation force in September 1989. That left the government in Phnom Penh, which Vietnam installed after invading the country more than 11 years ago, responsible for fighting the resistance. Another 300,000 Cambodians, who were uprooted by the Vietnamese invasion, languish in camps just across the border with Thailand. This is a bad time for boat people, beyond the normal perils of pirates and storms. Attitudes are hardening and they face increasing prospects of being pushed out to sea or sent back to the land they risked their lives escaping. Malaysia has turned away 8,700 Indochinese boat people since May 1989, according to diplomatic sources in Kuala Lumpur. Many of those moved on to Galang Island, which the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees built for 5,000 people and now holds more than 17,000. Indonesia regards the Cambodians as displaced persons, neither refugees nor asylum seekers. Pending a decision on their status, they are being sheltered on humanitarian grounds, said Lt. Col. Doekseno, who is in charge of Galang. As a new refugee group, they are not covered by the Comprehensive Plan of Action drawn up in Geneva under U.N. auspices in June 1989. The plan's purpose was to screen and divide Vietnamese boat people into economic migrants and political refugees. Those with justifiable fear of political persecution are entitled to resettlement and economic migrants are returned home. Alatas said Cambodian boat people should be added to the U.N. plan. Other Asian diplomats are less certain, fearing many of the 300,000 refugees along the Thai-Cambodian border might try to set sail in hope of a new life. Whether Cambodians are included may not matter, since the U.N. plan appears in danger of collapse. At the annual ASEAN meeting in July, the six members accused the United States and Vietnam of making the refugee problem worse by refusing to approve the return of economic migrants. About 80 percent of the estimated 130,000 people currently in camps in the region are non-political refugees, ASEAN officials said. Since Washington and Hanoi agreed to the U.N. plan originally, but later did not comply with the provision on economic migrants, ASEAN members have reserved the right to turn boat people away.

DOC.HEAD: A Look at American Pop Culture: `Edge' Goes Right Up To It
DOC.TEXT: Feeling a little alienated? Ever find yourself late at night wondering Just What Has Gone Wrong With the Republic? Is the social contract up for renewal in your neighborhood? And if Andrew Dice Clay did not exist, would it be necessary to invent him? For the answer to the last question and more, tune in tonight to PBS and ``Edge,'' a funny, adult and extremely well-written look at American pop culture. It will show you things you otherwise probably would never see. Vanity Fair writer James Wolcott tries to understand why people laugh at the abusive humor of the '90s in the persona of Andrew Dice Clay. Significantly, the segment is titled ``Another Day in Hell.'' This is definitely for adults only. Not only does ``Edge'' liberally excerpt Clay's raunchy, unexpurgated concert routine, but it discusses his appeal in terms of ``class hatred'' and ``marginalized'' white, working-class males. ``What's impressive about Clay is the emancipatory and truth-telling impulse in him.'' says Frederic Smoler, a professor of intellectual history at Sarah Lawrence College. ``The grimmest and saddest and thing about Clay is when he strips away a thing, debunks it, what's left to his audiences' view and his own is pretty small and ugly.'' The least accessible segment is about the faceless photographs of New York City conceptual artist Lorna Simpson. It's followed by a nice ballad (inexplicably sung on a bare city rooftop) by singer-songwriter John Hiatt. The great humorist Buck Henry comes on next with a visit to the Nixon Library in Yorba Linda, Calif. In opening his essay on the fall and rise of the elder statesman, Henry notes that Yorba Linda means ``beautiful yorba.'' There is commentary by Professor Stanley Cutler, author of ``The Wars of Watergate,'' who notes that the Nixon Library makes no mention of Nixon's accepting a pardon for any Watergate crimes he may have committed. ``Someday he'll be left alone to history,'' Cutler notes. He is smiling. Henry notes Tom Brokaw's visit to Yorba Linda, to anchor the evening news from the museum. And the Nixon birthplace, a kit-built house that cost $800 from the factory and $400,000 to restore. There's such a nice, suppressed note of hysteria and loathing to the piece. Far too soon, Henry bids a fond farewell to the Nixon complex. He waves goodbye and drives away renewed, refreshed. The host of the series, Emmy Award winner Robert Krulwich, reviews the recent history of student works at the Art Institute of Chicago. Remember when one student painted Mayor Harold Washington in brassiere, underpants, garter belt and stockings? The painting got arrested. One year later, student ``Dread'' Scott Tyler's wretched ``How to Display the Flag'' ignited the furor of veterans and flag-wavers by displaying a flag on the floor that tacitly invited spectators to walk on it. The beleaguered head of the institute school, Tony Jones, notes that people who tired of abstract art and called for the return to figurative art have gotten their wish _ with a vengeance. Then the show shows us four performance artists whose applications for federal grants were rejected. It's a delightful irony. And, with a wonderfully wry finale, the excellent comedian, actor, writer and ``Simpsons'' voice Harry Shearer explains to us just WHY anchormen are girdling the globe to cover the story. Shearer is magnificently low-key. Make time to see this pilot episode, a joint production of New York City's WNET and Britain's BBC-2. ``If successful, the pilot will be followed by 10 one-hour programs,'' says WNET. Do yourself a favor and tune in.

Elsewhere in television ... CLASSIC: ``The Wind,'' a classic silent film starring Lillian Gish, airs tonight on TNT. This is a visually stylish 1927 melodrama about a girl who goes to live on the Texas prairie with a husband she doesn't know. It's that wind that drives you crazy. It's that wind that'll getcha. NOT CLASSIC: ``P.O.V.,'' the excellent PBS series of unconventional ``non-fiction'' films on PBS, continues its wonderful season Tuesdany night, Aug. 28, with ``Motel,'' a film by Christian Blackwood. It's about motels in the Southwest and the people who inhabit them. There's the motel in Santa Fe, N.M., run by three longtime divorcees with stories to tell. And there's the motel in Florence, Ariz., right by the state prison, and the ladies in waiting there. And there's the odd tale of the only two people living in a rundown motel in Death Valley Junction. Check it out. End Adv PM Mon Aog. 27

DOC.HEAD: Adv for Use Monday, Aug. 27, and Thereafter
Bear Sightings on Wall Street
DOC.TEXT: The steep decline in stock prices this summer has left investors staring into the jaws of what some say may be Wall Street's first sustained bear market in nearly a decade. Today's generation of stock traders and analysts is by no means unaccustomed to to the phenomenon of falling markets. Most of them were around for the Crash of 1987, which provided all the conditions you could want for a baptism of fire. That debacle produced a 36 percent drop in the Dow Jones industrial average, enough to rank prominently on any list of modern-day market declines. But almost all the carnage occurred in a span of less than two months, and stocks began to recover quickly thereafter en route to new highs. Many an investor, it appeared, was still numb from the shock when the wounds began to heal. For an undisputed example of the kind of long, debilitating slide for which classic bear markets are famous, one has to go back to 1981-82, before the big boom of the '80s on Wall Street was ready to start. From April 27, 1981 to Aug. 12, 1982, the Dow Jones industrials tumbled from 1,024.05 to 776.92 as the economy struggled through a recession exacerbated by rapid inflation and high interest rates. Instead of the sudden jolt of a crash, the market in those days experienced a kind of slow, steady erosion that gave investors plenty of time to think about how much money they were losing and how bleak the outlook seemed. The question of the moment now, of course, is whether stocks are in for a similar malaise, or just undergoing one of the periodic ``corrections'' that have punctuated the long bull market since '82. Simple to ask, not so easy to answer. Incipient bear markets are notoriously cunning at disguising themselves as short-term corrections, and vice versa. On the optimistic side, however, analysts point out that authentic bear markets have seldom begun with a single event that serves as an ``explanation'' for the decline _ in this case, Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Indeed, many veteran market-watchers worry more when declines set in that have no readily discernible cause. ``Past major confrontations such as the Cuban missile crisis or other military squabbles that were resolved favorably proved to be just a blip in the stock market's general trend,'' observes Greg Smith, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities. ``We could be in one of those blips, or this could be something much more significant.'' Norman Fosback, editor of a group of investment advisory letters published by the Institute for Econometric Research in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., plants himself squarely on the ``blip'' side of the argument. ``Price weakness touched off by the geopolitical crisis does NOT constitute a bear market,'' he declared in the firm's Mutual Fund Forecaster. ``It does appear to be the 10 percent to 15 percent correction that has been long overdue. ``Midstream bull market corrections are nearly always abrupt. They shake out the market's weak participants by leading them to believe, falsely, that a bear market has begun.'' One big risk behind this view is the chance that the market has looked beyond the Persian Gulf showdown and correctly discerned the approach of a recession. It will take a good while for these overlays of uncertainty to sort themselves out, observed Morton Silverman, portfolio strategist at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis. Silverman concluded, ``it's a time for prudence, not opportunism.''

DOC.HEAD: Trying To Find Extra Cells Risks Lives and Wastes Money
DOC.TEXT: From coast to coast, the federal government is out of jail cells. Space is so short that the 52 deputy U.S. marshals in west Texas last year drove nearly 1 million miles moving prisoners _ sometimes driving all night from remote jails. It is so short that 25-30 women awaiting trial for federal crimes in New York City are held 550 miles away in Alderson, W.Va. And public defenders in Seattle daily drive 30 to 90 miles to see clients, sometimes taking all day to visit a jail on a Puget Sound island. ``There's a national jail crisis,'' said Howard Safir, operations chief of the U.S. Marshals Service for the past 12 years. ``There's just no room at the inn.'' Every day, armed deputy marshals ferry their hazardous cargo through America's towns and countrysides. The routes change often _ to prevent escapes and because yesterday's vacant jail is now full. Those involved say all this driving risks lives, wastes money and conflicts with the defendant's right to a fair trial. If someone attacks one of the marshals' caged vans to break out a prisoner, ``we've got a shotgun,'' said Chief Deputy Bob Christman of Seattle. ``So if it goes down, there's going to be somebody dead.'' Moving prisoners between jails and courts costs the Marshals Service $27.5 million a year. Assistant Director Joseph Enders said a major portion of that could be saved _ as much as 70 percent in some districts _ if there were enough cells close to courthouses. Using far-flung jails ``causes serious problems in communicating with our clients, tremendous expense and inefficiency,'' said Richard Richman, a federal public defender in Boston. Some federal officials say this crunch could have been avoided. They see it as the predictable outcome of a decade of law and order legislation and spending that added more than 4,500 lawmen and prosecutors but gave short shrift to jails, a less glamorous but crucial component of criminal justice. As a result: _ Marshals in Boston hold most of their prisoners in Connecticut and want to rent a condominium in Danbury to save hotel expenses for deputies. Defendants in Rhode Island, New Jersey, New Mexico and Oregon also are held in other states. _ Prisoners awaiting trial in Kansas, Washington and west Texas are scattered in as many as 10 jails in each state. Marshals in Miami use 11 south Florida jails. _ In Oregon, marshals spend more than half their time hauling prisoners. Marshals everywhere complain that the driving drains manpower from their other duties: hunting federal fugitives, serving court orders, guarding courthouses and protecting threatened witnesses and judges. At the federal level, jails hold people awaiting trial; convicts go to prison. For years the federal government did not have its own jails because most federal defendants got out on bail before trial. Now, it has 14 jails and only four _ Chicago, New York, Los Angeles and San Diego, fit the ideal: a downtown site connected to or near a federal courthouse. The rest are detention wings carved out of prisons, nearly all in rural areas. Most federal cells still are leased in state, county or city jails. When President Ronald Reagan took office 1981, he was determined to use federal power to curb street violence with new agents and new laws. There were 477 vacant beds in federal jails then. In 10 years, Republican administrations added 1,770 prosecutors, 1,015 drug agents and 1,740 FBI agents, but fewer than one jail bed for each new prosecutor. The agents arrested far more defendants than that, and the new laws assured that many more people would be jailed before trial. And the inmates became more dangerous because the 1984 Bail Reform Act and the 1988 drug control law required preventive detention for those charged with violent or drug crimes. During the decade, the average daily number of federal jail inmates exploded from 3,618 to 13,916. But the federal government itself only added 1,669 jail beds. And on top of that, 607 local jails threw their federal boarders out. The local jails had grown even more overcrowded than federal jails as states mimicked the federal get-tough policies. They got so packed that state and federal judges limited the crowding. Now more than one in four large urban jails is under court order to reduce its population. And the Bureau of Prisons has 5,984 inmates in federal jails built for 3,272. So the marshals reach farther into the countryside to find vacant cells. ``The farther you take a prisoner, the more potential there is for an escape or a traffic accident,'' Safir said in an interview before his recent retirement. He thinks the marshals are fortunate that no one has escaped in transit during the last four years and accidents have been fender-benders. ``Every time you move a guy in custody, it's a security risk to deputies, to communities we drive through, to all the drivers on the freeways,'' said Christman in Seattle.
