DOC.HEAD: With AM-Out of Jails
If a Prison's a Jail, Why Isn't a Jail a Prison?
DOC.TEXT: ``The ordinary person, even the ordinary politician, has a difficult time distinguishing a prison from a jail.'' It's a difference Howard Safir had to explain over and over for the last 12 years. As operations director of the U.S. Marshals Service, Safir was responsible for finding jail cells _ not prison cells _ for federal inmates. Safir, who recently retired, got them from the U.S. Bureau of Prisons or leased them from other governments. The U.S. Justice Department uses jails differently from the states, counties and cities. Federal jail cells house only individuals who have been denied bail while they await trial or for those convicted but awaiting sentencing. State and local jails do that, too. But they also hold individuals serving short misdemeanor sentences. The federal government sends such convicts to low-security prisons and prison camps. Many states now also keep some more serious offenders in jails, because their prisons are overcrowded. Marshals, lawyers and judges agree that the most efficient jails are connected by secure tunnel or bridge to the courthouse where the inmates are tried. ``A prison in a cornfield works fine. A jail doesn't,'' Safir said. ``Because jail inmates have to go to court each day. They need access to their lawyers. They are almost all still not-guilty prisoners under our system. They have more rights than convicts.''

DOC.HEAD: East German Educators Go Back to School
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Wolfgang Jung had spent his first two years in college absorbing communist economics when, abruptly, the world changed. So did his homework. Jung is spending his last two years of college cramming for capitalism at East Berlin's College of Economics, where even the teachers are taking a crash course in free-market thinking. The college is part of a vast educational system that is both trying to reshape itself quickly and continuing to train young people for jobs that may not exist on graduation day. Nearly 2.1 million East Germans from elementary to graduate level are beginning a new school year that will be much different from the previous 42. Millions of new textbooks free of communist ideology have flooded in from West Germany. Bloated departments devoted to Marxist-Leninist theory have been dissolved. Hundreds of Russian-language teachers spent the summer learning to teach English. More than one-third of the nation's 1 million teachers are enrolled in retraining programs. On the secluded campus where the Communist secret police once learned their fearsome skills, music, science and languages are taught to an ordinary student body. Still, experts say, the changes are almost superficial. Most of the old teachers, former guardians of ideology and components of a vast domestic intelligence network, will be back in their classrooms. All principals, rectors and chancellors were fired, but the communities entrusted with refilling those jobs returned more than half to their former positions. What has happened to East Germany's schools in the year since communism fell is only the beginning of a process that may need a generation to complete, the experts say. For Jung and others in the Class of '92, that is too long. ``I didn't know what a corporation was when we began learning a market economy,'' said Jung, 24, sitting in the school cafeteria bent over a West German textbook. ``It was socialism, socialism, socialism. Now we have to go back to the beginning.'' The democratic government elected in March has only begun decentralizing the system, reteaching the teachers and eliminating the rigidity of lesson plans, said Hans-Joachim Meyer, the education minister. Meyer believes the five state governments that will be created Oct. 14, to fit in with the West German system, will have a more formidable task when they assume full responsibility for the schools. He said the hardest job will be to change the way people think, to instill individuality and imagination in a system dulled by decades of restrictive, paranoid Stalinism. ``We need probably four to five years to introduce the necessary structures,'' he said. ``But in order to develop new attitudes toward life, toward society: yes, that will take a generation.'' Meshing the East German education system with West Germany's is another problem. East German students, for example, need 12 years of schooling to qualify for a university, while West Germans must have 13. ``It is a major problem to get East Germany to fit into the whole context,'' said Monika Renz, a researcher for the Standing Conference of Education Ministers of the 11 West German states. The group is debating how to merge the systems, and ``not all the states are convinced'' East German schools are up to par, she said. All have agreed, some grudgingly, to allow East Germans equal access to West German universities, with admission quotas based on percentages of East German applicants. East German educators bristle at criticism of their schools and what they feel is condescension by West Germans. ``They give us their textbooks, their lectures, their seminars,'' said Heidi Klemm, who teaches English. ``They say, `It's all rubbish, your schools'.'' She pointed out that the exodus to West Germany last year, which helped bring down the Communist government in East Germany, was largely of people judged to be highly skilled. Ms. Klemm spoke while strolling across her college campus outside the small farm community of Golm, 25 miles south of Berlin and just outside Potsdam. Ivy covers many buildings and barbed wire rings the periphery. The college was the officers' training school of the former Stasi secret police, where only the brightest in the feared organization could gain admittance. Stasi students and faculty were expelled late last year and the school was converted into an extension of a teacher's college in Potsdam. The Potsdam school occupies beautiful colonnaded buildings in a complex of 19th century palaces and gardens built for Frederick the Great, the Prussian king. In them, nearly 3,000 students study languages, medicine, art and geography. It is the largest teachers' college in East Germany, and has a severe case of nerves. All administrators of all schools were dismissed in June. Committees of local officials, students, parents and teachers have been meeting to recommend who should be retained. The Potsdam school's committee began work Sept. 1. ``If you come here in January, maybe someone else will be sitting here,'' Knut Kiesant, the vice chancellor, said in his spacious office. Kiesant has been with the school for six years and Wolfgang Strauss, director of international relations, for 25. Both say people who rose to high levels in the old regime are being persecuted. ``Whether I am good or I am bad is not a question of black or white, as a child would decide,'' Strauss said. Both men said they favor the new politics in East Germany. Most school committees have completed their work and more than half, perhaps 65 percent, rehired their old administrators, said Meyer, the education minister. He attributed that to a lack of qualified alternative candidates, apathy in local committees and deference to the old headmasters. Meyer predicted more administrators would be replaced when the new state governments took over, but recommended against wholesale dismissals of teachers. Teachers are such a large group, he said, that they deserve a chance to change with the changing society. Many may be weeded out by economic collapse. Unpaid bills are mounting at the Potsdam school and it has a 5-1 ratio of students to teachers, compared with 30-1 in West Germany, Strauss said. Economic problems are increasing across the country, presaging hard times for students nearing graduation. Agriculture students have learned techniques applicable only to the dying collective farms. Thousands of trade school students are apprenticed to factories expected to close. No school has had to shift gears more quickly than the 4,500-student College of Economics. About 60 of the 200 professors have been replaced with Western experts, said Hans-Peter Krueger, the new vice chancellor. Krueger said the school added crash programs so students and teachers could catch up with capitalism. ``We not only have to learn how to teach a market economy, we have to teach how to live in a market economy,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: in Seattle.
DOC.TEXT: A year ago, Marshal Bill Jonas of San Antonio heard of a plot to attack a marshals' van and free two prisoners, so he flew them 180 miles. Nine months earlier, he changed routes to elude ``someone (who) tried to set up a roadblock'' on the 108-mile route from San Antonio to Bastrop. Another risk is boredom. ``We had a fellow resign the other day,'' said Kernan Bagley, marshal in Portland, Ore. ``He told me, `I'm not going to spend my life transporting prisoners.''' Bagley said that task consumes 55 to 60 percent of his deputies' time, twice what it would if jails were nearby. ``It burns my people out,'' said Seattle's Christman. To bring prisoners from Tacoma, ``my people have to get up at 4:15 a.m., drive two rush hours and work a full day. They get home at 8 p.m. ``It's not good for the prisoners either. It's not good for the attorneys who can't get to their clients as easily as they should. These people are still innocent and have a right to see attorneys,'' Christman said. ``If we're lucky,'' said Richman, the Boston public defender, ``the closest we get our clients is an hour's drive away.'' Judges regularly postpone trials and order marshals to drive prisoners hundreds of miles to get an hour a week with their attorney, Richman said. The eight federal public defenders in Seattle, each handling up to 30 cases, spend up to one-fifth of their time driving to see clients, according to Public Defender Tom Hillier. Private defense lawyers like Barry Wilson in Boston have to charge their clients for time spent driving to see them. ``Why should a person have to pay more money to his lawyer because he can't make bail?'' Wilson asked. ``All this was predictable when you added those agents and laws,'' Safir said. ``We've been waving this (red) flag for five years.'' Stan Morris, Marshals Service director until last fall, said he could not get Attorneys General Edwin Meese and Dick Thornburgh to pay attention to jails _ not even by sending Thornburgh a weekly memo on a problem in his hometown, Pittsburgh. Bureau of Prisons Director J. Michael Quinlan granted that ``growth has been a little greater than we anticipated,'' but said ``I don't believe we should have asked for more'' money for jails. ``It's important not to overbuild,'' Quinlan said. At Justice, Associate Deputy Attorney General Margaret Love conceded the shortage ``became acute in 1986.'' She said Thornburgh set up a jails task force _ in March of this year. Safir said Justice finally ``is beginning to focus on the problem'' and cited three promising moves: _ Using new legislation, marshals for the first time have hired a private company to build and operate a federal jail, in Kansas, and plan another in New England. _ The Bureau of Prisons plans to build 4,772 jail cells by mid-1993. If President Bush's budget is approved, another 1,250 would be added. But the marshals expect to have 16,000 additional daily inmates by 1995. _ This spring, Justice got Congress to switch $20 million from prison construction to a program that pays local governments to build jails in return for 15-year federal leases on some beds. The program will have $35 million this year. Safir said local governments already have applied for $129 million. The marshals think even more will be needed. Marshal Bagley in Oregon asked that jail space be added to federal buildings under construction, but was turned down. Marshal Jonas in west Texas thinks downtown federal jails will be needed in 21 big cities; only 10 are planned. Some defense lawyers, members of Congress and prison officials think the government cannot build its way out of the problem. They think far more defendants are jailed than ever committed crimes or fled while on bail. But they are not expecting a quick change. As Public Defender Hillier said, ``I'm an advocate of changing some of these mindless laws and throwing fewer people in jail, but that's probably not realistic in this dark age.''

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis: Americans Wrestle With Mixed Emotions and Daily Fears
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein's troops marched into Kuwait on Aug. 2, and suddenly summer stalled. Overnight, America entered a conflict defined by diplomats and kings, economics and complicated moral stands. It is an unhappy new world, and Americans are still trying to sort it out. Many are able to reduce the Persian Gulf crisis to red, white and blue. But others are wrestling with shades of gray. ``Some people react with anger. Some people react with a feeling of needing to share love. The feelings are massive and different,'' said Betty Walters, whose son and grandson are with the Army in Saudi Arabia. ``The one feeling everyone seems to share is fear: fear of the unknown.'' America has been wrenched, thrown from the euphoric fall of communism into the sudden threat of a desert war. Patriotism confronts history, pride meets pragmatism. Feelings are all in a jumble. Passions explode and recede. ``The world is very big, remote and complicated,'' said sociologist Todd Gitlin of the University of California at Berkeley. ``It gets simplified on an occasion like this.'' In Cleveland, a radio station stages a ``Saddam Hussein Firing Squad.'' Pelt a stand-in for the Iraqi leader with overripe tomatoes and vent your anger. It's a dollar a chance and the proceeds go to Myrtle Beach Air Force Base. Outside Cleveland City Hall, a woman is arrested after about 30 protesters burn a flag to protest America's stand in the Middle East. In Lincoln, Neb., Vietnam War veterans burn Iraq's flag in solidarity with U.S. troops overseas. A convoy of soldiers from the 101st Airborne Division at Fort Campbell, Ky., slips by flag-waving supporters along Interstate 75 through Tennessee and Georgia. They head for Mayport, Fla., and deployment in the Persian Gulf. ``We want them to know we care,'' said Don Gage, who unfurled a 50-foot flag at one overpass. ``And I'll tell you this: We can't wait to put it on the northbound side to welcome them back.'' At a Pittsburgh synagogue, worshipers donate 300 prayer books for Jewish soldiers they suspect will still be in Saudi Arabia during the High Holy Days of Yom Kippur and Rosh Hashana next month. In Valdosta, Ga., some minds are otherwise occupied. ``Iraq may have invaded Kuwait, but all that really matters in the world is that Georgia high school football is less than three weeks away. Take that, Saddam Hussein,'' challenges a local newsletter. Country music star Hank Williams Jr. writes a song suggesting that Arabs ``take their poison gas and stick it in their sassafras.'' Similar ditties blare on local radio stations broadcast at the beach, the lake, at the mall. Workmen building a 30-story pyramid arena in Memphis attach a 300-foot-long yellow ribbon for the 3,000 Americans held in Iraq and Kuwait. But the wife of a Texas oil worker captured by Iraqi troops receives an anonymous call from the angry mom of a soldier: ``(She) asked why our government should go and protect someone who's just earning a living for their family ... (She) thinks it's my fault that her son's going.'' Two decorated Vietnam War veterans take sides. Retired Army Staff Sgt. Buck Buchanan, who holds three Purple Hearts, says history shows ``if you're going to cock the gun, you better pull the trigger.'' But retired Army Col. James Burkholder decides to return his Legion of Merit awardto protest the government's ``all or nothing'' military stance. Some say oil is good enough reason to go to war. They post signs that say, ``Get the gas and kick their ass.'' Others say no: ``We've been taught to hate Arabs and love our pocketbooks,'' Ramsey Clark, U.S. attorney general during the Vietnam War, said at a news conference last week. But everywhere, there is anxiety and confusion. Two 10-year-old girls, their fathers dispatched to Saudi Arabia, wrote a song: ``What's going on over the seas? ``It's been a disaster, but it's not up to me. ``We hate to see the people cry.'' Many, like Betty Walters, look to each other for comfort. The Osseo, Minn., housewife has received calls from around the nation since she organized ``Support Our Country's Military'' soon after the U.S. military entered the Middle East conflict and her boys were sent to Saudi Arabia. ``Whether we are supporting this or not, everyone is feeling this pressure of waiting,'' she said Friday. ``It tears families apart.'' It tears parents apart. ``It's breaking my heart and I believe the hearts of a lot of parents across the country,'' said Alex Molnar, a University of Wisconsin professor whose son's Marine unit was also sent to Saudi Arabia. Molnar and his wife cried when they heard. They cut short their vacation and went to see their 21-year-old before he shipped out of North Carolina. ``The first thing my son said to me was: `Dad, we're going to war with these guys,''' Molnar said Friday. ``As a parent I can tell you that (George Bush) has his hands around my heart. (He) is telling me my child might be killed for a purpose that he describes as important.'' The Rev. Edwin Davis of Koran, La., knows the confusion. He has waited more than three weeks for word from his daughter, son-in-law and grandson. The family, he believes, is laying low in Kuwait. But how long can they hide? ``There's a lot of anxiety mixed up in this,'' the retired minister said. ``You can't cowtow to Iraq's demands ... (but) there's a lot of people involved: soldier boys, our government, other people's loved ones and our own. ``It's a dilemma ... you can't hardly understand.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Aug 26

DOC.TEXT: U.S. stock prices fell to the lowest level in more than a year and the cost of oil approached record highs as mounting tensions in the 3-week-old Persian Gulf crisis shook world financial markets. Trading activity in securities, oil and foreign currencies was nervous and heavy around the world Thursday, driven by fears of war between Iraq and an international force led by the United States. ``God only knows what could happen,'' said Robert Brusca, chief economist for Nikko Securities International Inc. in New York. ``At this point nobody wants to take any risk.''

The nation's top antitrust prosecutor has summoned major oil companies to talk to him as he determines whether they used illegal tactics to drive up gasoline prices following Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``I have called the major oil companies and requested that they come in on a one-by-one basis to meet with the staff and on several occasions with me,'' Assistant Attorney General James Rill said Thursday. Oil companies have denied charges of price-gouging.

Factory orders for ``big-ticket'' durable goods rebounded 2.9 percent in July, the government said. But analysts said the zig-zag performance outlined in Thursday's report indicates a listless manufacturing economy that could worsen because of the Middle East crisis.

Mid-August vehicle sales by the nation's major automakers fell 4.7 percent from the same period last year, although General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. reported strong truck sales. The figures, released Thursday, indicated no dramatic effect on sales due to rising gasoline prices in the first complete reporting period since Iraq invaded Kuwait. The Big Three automakers _ GM, Ford and Chrylser Corp. _ said their cars and trucks sold at an average daily rate of 32,674 from Aug. 11-20.

Banking lawyers are dusting off the statute books to examine a 50-year-old law slashing the interest rate some active-duty servicemen pay on a wide range of loans to 6 percent. Bankers said Thursday they have no idea how many people pressed into service by the Persian Gulf crisis might seek breaks on their student loans, credit cards and home mortgages under a section of the Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act of 1940. Potential beneficiaries include the roughly 50,000 reservists being called up.

The Middle East crisis, highlighting America's reliance on foreign oil, is spurring renewed calls for energy conservation, including demands that automakers build more fuel-efficient cars. A group of environmentalists and alternative fuel advocates on Thursday chastised President Bush for not producing specific programs aimed at cutting energy use and for opposing legislation that would toughen automobile fuel efficiency requirements.

A federal judge upheld the government takeover of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, saying the operation of the thrift by Charles H. Keating Jr. and his associates ``amounted to looting.'' Judge Stanley Sporkin dismissed Keating's suit to recover the collapsed institution from Irvine, Calif., on Thursday. The judge said it was ``abundantly clear'' that officials of Lincoln's holding company, American Continental Corp. of Phoenix, ``abused their positions.''

Florida's attorney general is seeking to open a secret stock settlement between Times Publishing Co. and Texas billionaire Robert Bass, saying it may harm the non-profit Poynter Institute. Attorney General Bob Butterworth, in a letter to institute President Robert J. Haiman, said Thursday he would take the issue to court unless the institute immediately provides details of the settlement, which were not made public as part of the agreement. ``We need numbers. We can't go with these broad statements that everything is great,'' the attorney general said in an interview.

Honeywell Inc. said 120 employees will be cut from its defense and marine systems unit, which employs about 8,300 people. The reduction, effective Sept. 6, results from reorganization in preparation of a planned spin-off by Honeywell and efforts to improve its competitive position in the defense industry, the company said Thursday.

Heavy selling sent stock prices tumbling to their lowest levels in more than a year Thursday. The Dow Jones average plunged 76.73 points to 2,483.42, its lowest close since it stood at 2,462.44 on July 6, 1989. Since July 17, it has fallen 516.33 points. The dollar fell broadly against major Western currencies Thursday, with gold prices mostly higher. Government bond prices fell Thursday in light trading. Cattle futures prices, pork futures also suffered a setback Thursday, particularly bellies, which were down the limit for the third consecutive day. Grains and soybeans advanced.

DOC.HEAD: Read Bush's Lips On Saving Energy, Then Check His Fuel Bill
DOC.TEXT: Even while urging Americans to conserve energy, the vacationing President Bush has been guzzling fuel by land, by sea and by air. His most conspicuous fuel consumption has come at the helm of his twin-engine Cigarette speedboat, Fidelity. But the boat is just one of the entries on his vacation fuel bill. He burns thousands of gallons of fuel while jetting back and forth between Washington and his vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine. More fuel is burned by Marine One, the Sikorsky H-3 helicopter that takes Bush from Air Force One at Pease Air Force Base in New Hampshire to the helipad in his yard in Maine. Another visible energy drain are the golf carts he and his partners use on the president's high-speed runs around the golf course. Public images of Bush in motion are a sharp contrast from the 1970s television shots of President Carter, who donned a sweater as the government urged less energy consumption during a previous energy crisis. Asked about the differing images, White House spokesman Steve Hart said, ``It'd be kind of inappropriate to go on TV in front of a fire now.'' Jets, helicopters and limousines are ``part of the presidency,'' Hart maintained. ``I think most Americans would support his need to do that in order to do his job,'' he said. Soon, Bush will burn even more jet fuel when he takes to the skies in a new, jumbo Air Force One with a bigger gas tank, according to spokesmen at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland, where the planes are kept. The Boeing 707s that now serve as Air Force One are to be replaced by a new Boeing 747, which was delivered to the Air Force Thursday. Andrews spokesman Sgt. Jim Guthrie estimated the old Air Force One burns 15,000 pounds per hour and the new one 22,000 pounds an hour. Another base official, Master Sgt. Rick Fuller, said seven pounds of jet fuel equals 1 gallon. This means Bush's old plane burned $1,350 worth of fuel an hour _ about the flying time to Kennebunkport from the White House _ based on the average price of about 63 cents a gallon prior to the Mideast crisis. Based on the more recent price of $1.08 a gallon, the bill would be $2,314.29 an hour. The new plane will burn $3,394.27 worth of fuel an hour at current prices _ 46.6 percent more. Guthrie said the older presidential jets can hold 23,800 gallons in their tanks, while the new 747 will have a capacity of 53,862 gallons. Neither official knew how much fuel Air Force One uses in a year. ``That would vary from year to year. That would vary from president to president,'' Fuller said. Former President Reagan's trips to his ranch in California, for example, used up more fuel per trip than Bush's flights to Kennebunkport. But Bush has been a more frequent flier. ``President Reagan didn't fly quite as much as President Bush, so it might average out in the long run,'' Fuller said. Bush publicly defended his boat excursions in response to reporters' questions Wednesday. ``I'm going to keep using my boat, and I hope the rest of America will prudently recreate,'' Bush said at a Kennebunkport news conference. Spokesman Hart was unsure how much fuel is used by the president's speedboat. Workers at Southern Maine Marina, where the boat is docked, declined comment. A man at a nearby Kennebunkport marina said the twin-screw Fidelity is not among the worst gas guzzlers on the high seas, but neither is it particularly fuel-efficient. ``He uses big carburetors on it,'' said John Daley, of Chick's Marina Inc., where gasoline cost $1.60 a gallon Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Old Bank Law Sparks New Concerns on Loans to Reservists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Banking lawyers are dusting off the statute books to examine a 50-year-old law slashing the interest rate some active-duty servicemen pay on a wide range of loans to 6 percent. Bankers said Thursday they have no idea how many people pressed into service by the Persian Gulf crisis might seek breaks on their student loans, credit cards and home mortgages under a section of the Soldiers' and Sailors' Civil Relief Act of 1940. The potential beneficiaries include the roughly 50,000 reservists being called up. The law has always covered military personnel but is rarely invoked because few volunteers and career servicepeople enter the military already in debt. ``You don't join the army to get a 6 percent mortgage,'' said Saul Kramer, a partner with the New York law firm Proskauer Rose Goetz & Mendelsohn. The American Bankers Association, which represents the nation's commercial banks, said its members ``have a long history of compliance _ through World War II, the Korean War and Vietnam _ and will continue to comply,'' said spokesman Mark Burneko. A GI would make a request for interest reduction to his or her bank, which would require verification of active military service. The government is not required to reimburse the banks for the rate reduction. The law only covers debts incurred before the serviceperson or reservist begins active military duty. It was designed to ``protect them from going unduly into debt as a result of service,'' Kramer said. Donner Day, a spokesman for the Department of Veterans Affairs in Washington, said many people with large incomes who are called to active duty ``all of a sudden have their salaries transformed to $500 a month. They're unprepared to satisfy their financial obligations.'' Most servicemen are unfamiliar with the law, Day said. Citibank, the nation's biggest bank and largest consumer lender, has received a just few dozen calls from customers who may qualify. Many bankers say it will probably be a month before they have an idea of the demand for interest forgiveness. The basic savings account was paying about 2 percent interest when the act was instituted, and Congress has not adjusted the 6 percent cap since the law took effect, Kramer noted. ``Obviously the government has great power during times of distress, like we're in now,'' he said. Mortgage rates currently are running slightly above 10 percent; personal loan rates can approach double that. But experts say that banks' liability under the law _ spread out among institutions nationwide _ would be negligible. ``It's peanuts,'' said Stephen Berman, an analyst at County Securities USA, when asked what the law could cost banks. The nation's financial institutions have been under pressure for some time because of bad Third World debt, a shaky real estate market and a slowing economy. Among individual banks, Citibank and Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. were among the first to acknowledge they will honor requests from servicepeople who qualify. Both institutions have begun setting up verification procedures, spokespeople said. ``Unless someone lists themselves as a private or a sergeant on a loan application, or lists their employer as the military,'' the bank would not know, said Citibank spokesman William Ahearn. ``With reservists, it's almost impossible'' for the bank to know, he added. Not everyone being called to duty is likely to qualify for the break. And the dollar figures involved are not necessarily large. The average outstanding home mortgage balance is roughly $55,000, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. Many homeowners are carrying loans at lower than current rates. And recent bank industry statistics show the average credit card holder has amassed a debt of just $2,042 on his or her credit cards. One banker, who asked not to be identified, said any lost revenue resulting from the law would amount to ``a hiccup.''

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Could Benefit Construction Firms with Middle East Ties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The Middle East crisis has caused a dip in stocks of big construction companies that work in that part of the world, but some analysts believe they're still a good investment. Fluor Corp., an Irvine-based construction and engineering firm, has seen its stock tumble more than 25 percent since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, closing Wednesday at a near 52-week low of $32\. On Thursday, it closed down further at $31| in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Many investors are nervous about Fluor. The company once had most of its business in the Middle East and just recently won a contract in Saudi Arabia potentially worth billions of dollars. But securities analyst John N. Simon and fellow analysts suggest Fluor and other major construction and engineering firms are in better shape than many people believe and may even benefit from the crisis. Analysts pin the stock price drop on a misunderstanding of Fluor's Middle East role and general Wall Street jitters. ``Is Fluor underpriced? What's underpriced when everybody's panicking?'' asked Simon, with Seidler Amdec Securities Inc. in Los Angeles. ``I certainly haven't told anyone to sell their Fluor stock, which has gotten some people (mad). To me that's a market reaction, not a reaction to the current circumstances.'' Fluor, like Bechtel Corp. in San Francisco and Parsons Corp. in Pasadena, stands to gain if oil prices stay high and the world starts looking for oil in places other than the Middle East, some analysts said. The analysts anticipate the demand for oil will increase, with big construction and engineering firms expected to play a large role in oil projects in under-tapped regions like Canada and Vietnam. ``A number of both real and emotional factors are moving stock,'' said Rick Maslin, a Fluor spokesman. ``(But) the price of oil is going up and it's probably going to mean opportunities will exist in other parts of the world.'' Construction and engineering companies with Middle East ties have put themselves over the last decade in a better position to weather Gulf crises. Fluor and Parsons, both heavily involved in the Middle East in the 1970s, are now considerably more diversified, analysts said. Even current Middle East projects do not appear to be threatened. Both Fluor and Parsons this summer won contracts from Saudi Aramco to build and refurbish oil and gas facilities in Saudi Arabia. The contracts could each be worth more than $4 billion over the next nine years. ``So far, that schedule and work contract have not been impacted at all,'' said Debra Williams, a spokeswoman for Parsons, a closely held firm. Ms. Williams did not want to speculate at any length on whether the firm would benefit down the road by the Middle East crisis, but she added: ``At least at this point, it hasn't impacted the growth of projects that we're involved in.'' However, the Middle East crisis has hurt engineering and construction firms in other ways, from Fluor's stock decline to concerns about the safety of Middle East employees. Parsons has been unable to locate about 100 employees on public works projects in Kuwait since the Aug. 2 invasion. Among the missing are 12 U.S. citizens and their eight dependents. ``From a business standpoint, we're OK,'' said Williams. ``Our primary concern is for the people. ... There's basically around-the-clock attempts at direct communication, and around-the-clock communication with the State Department.'' Fluor evacuated dependents of workers on Saudi Arabia projects and moved employees near the Saudi Arabia-Iraq border to safer locations. About 100 employees remain in Saudi Arabia, said Maslin. Bechtel earlier this month evacuated from Saudi Arabia an unspecified number of what it called ``non-essential'' workers, along with employees' dependents.

DOC.HEAD: Prospect of $1.50 or More a Gallon Not As Frightening As It Seems
DOC.TEXT: Despite the skyrocketing price of gasoline and rampant accusations of price-gouging, petroleum experts say consumers aren't feeling the pain nearly as badly as they did during the oil shocks of the 1970s. Some contend oil prices would have to reach $60 a barrel and gasoline would have to hit $2 a gallon at the pump to make the situation analogous to the rapid rise in fuel costs Americans absorbed back then. Three weeks after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait sent world petroleum markets into a frenzy, no one seems ready to predict with certainty that prices will rise to those levels. But industry and government experts said Wednesday they weren't ruling anything out, with oil prices surging over the $31 barrel mark for the first time in nearly five years. They said all bets would be off if the Middle East standoff develops into combat that destroys oil facilities in Saudi Arabia, which has the world's largest known crude oil supply. ``If we lost Kuwaiti, Iraqi and Saudi Arabian oil, there would be a real deficit,'' said Bill Hermann, chief economist for the Chevron Corp. ``You'd have to cripple most of the Saudi exporting facilities before that would happen. That would imply a shooting war, and we would take out (Iraqi) facilities as well.'' A clash of that magnitude could remove almost a fifth of world production from the markets, Hermann said. Although gasoline prices have jumped about 16 cents to the $1.24-a-gallon level since the Middle East crisis began, oil economists said the increase is mild compared with the 1970s price spirals, after inflation is accounted for. Some experts say the inflation-adjusted cost of driving is about as low as it was more than 40 years ago. ``It's the cheapest to propel a car; for one mile it's less than 5 cents,'' Hermann said. He cited Chevron figures, which when adjusted for inflation, show that it cost 10.5 cents to drive a mile in 1980 and 8 cents in 1960. The Energy Information Administration, an independent statistical agency of the Energy Department, uses figures that indicate 1988 was the cheapest year ever for gasoline. Oil prices peaked in 1981, following the Iranian revolution. Unleaded gasoline hit $1.42 per gallon at its height. Federal statisticians say the pump price would have to climb to $1.98 to reach the same real price today. ``I don't know of anyone who's predicting prices like that,'' said an official with the Energy Information Administration who spoke on condition of anonymity. His agency is refraining from making predictions about prices at this point. ``There's just too much uncertainty,'' spokesman Jonathan Cogan said. ``At some point, we will have to go out on a limb and make some forecasts.'' Hermann believes that real pump prices of gasoline won't move back up to the early 1980s levels unless a full-scale war breaks out and the price of crude oil shoots up to around $40 per barrel. The government statisticians estimated it would take a crude price of above $60 a barrel. Three weeks after the Kuwait invasion, crude prices were hitting levels only half that size on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The American Automobile Association said this week that its nationwide check of unleaded self-serve regular averaged $1.237 a gallon on Monday, up 2.1 cents from a week earlier. At the time of the latest AAA survey, the pump price had gone up 16.2 cents since the latest oil crisis began. But other observers say consumers are paying far more for their energy as their tax money is used to pick up the tab for the deployment of the largest U.S. military force since the Vietnam War. The president of the National Defense Council Foundation, a Washington-area think tank, said that if one includes the extra cost of the military buildup in the Persian Gulf, Americans are probably paying more than $70 a barrel for oil. ``If hostilities break out, you're talking about $100 a barrel,'' Milton Copulos said. A Ralph Nader consumers group, Buyers Up, agreed that energy has its hidden costs. ``A lot of costs we pay for our oil is not factored into the price,'' research director Christopher Dyson said. Environmental costs are another factor in the price of energy that is not felt every time a consumer fills up the family car, Dyson said. Despite the statistics that show pump prices are lower when adjusted for inflation, the Nader group accuses oil companies of gouging the public by being too quick to pass on price increases and too slow to pass on price decreases. ``We think they are gouging,'' Dyson said. ``We think the price increases have been unjustified.'' Oil companies have in recent weeks mounted a public relations offensive to proclaim their contention that the industry as a whole is not taking an unfair advantage of the situations. Any improper pricing has been done on a small scale by retailers, the oil giants have said, adding that consumers can always drive their cars down the street to cheaper competitors if that happens.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Losing ``Safe Haven'' Status In Times of Turmoil
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Once upon a time when the world convulsed with political turmoil or war, global investors would funnel money into dollars as a ``safe haven'' strategy to preserve their wealth. No more. Judging by the reaction of investors to the Mideast upheaval, the dollar has been shunned for German marks, British pounds and Japanese yen, showing the U.S. currency has lost its pre-eminent status as an investment refuge, some economists say. In the past, the mere threat of war was enough to unleash a torrent of investments in the dollar and dollar-denominated securities such as U.S. stocks and bonds. The enormous demand for dollars from abroad typically sent the value of the currency soaring relative to yen, mark, pound and other foreign money. But since the dollar's brief jump following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, its value against most other major currencies has slumped, reaching an all-time low against the mark and a nine-year low against the pound. What went wrong? Some experts say the change is the inevitable outcome of the end of the Cold War. Previously, investors feared any conflict could escalate into a superpower confrontation, with European security at risk, said David Wyss, chief financial economist at DRI-McGraw-Hill Inc., a Lexington, Mass., research firm. But with U.S.-Soviet relations vastly improved, the prospect of a global war has all but disappeared, and investors feel secure leaving their money in Europe or sending it there instead of the United States, he said. ``There isn't the old specter of a European conflagration that would wipe out all their capital,'' said John McCarthy, chief currency dealer for Amsterdam Rotterdam Bank in New York. ``In the past you'd see people liquidating marks, liquidating Swiss francs, to physically get their capital out of the battlefield.'' Another reason the dollar hasn't benefited is that currency can be moved around the world more quickly than a decade ago, experts say. Electronic funds transfer can be accomplished almost instantaneously. Legal hurdles to shifting funds also have receded. ``People don't feel they have to make these asset-allocation decisions as quickly as they had in the past,'' McCarthy said. However, should the Persian Gulf standoff escalate into a shooting war, the dollar could still benefit, McCarthy said. Other experts say the value of the dollar is depressed for reasons that overshadow its security as an investment. Chief among them are worries that the nation is about to enter a recession, which could erode the value of the currency, said Lincoln Anderson, an economist at the investment house Bear, Stearns & Co. Anderson said he isn't convinced the dollar has lost its safe-haven status. Another factor is the rise in interest rates abroad, particularly in Germany and Britain, compared with U.S. rates. As interest rates climb elsewhere, dollar-denominated investments such as U.S. Treasury bonds look less attractive since they don't earn as high a rate. Wyss said the main beneficiaries of the interest rate differential appear to be the mark and the pound, while the yen has gained to a lesser extent. The dollar bought 1.5885 marks and 147.18 yen at the close of trading on Aug. 1, the day before Iraq's invasion. By midweek, the dollar had fallen to about 1.5480 marks _ an all-time low, and about 146.00 yen. The pound cost $1.8555 on Aug. 1. By midweek it took about $1.9275 to buy one pound, the highest value for the pound since December 1981. ``German interest rates are at least as high as ours, Germany looks at least as safe, their inflation rate is lower and you no longer have that military threat from Eastern Europe to worry about,'' Wyss said. The pound and British government bonds have attracted investors because Britain supplies all its oil needs domestically from the North Sea, easing inflationary fears associated with the rise in oil prices, he said. Investments in both German and British government bonds are giving a greater return that U.S. Treasury bonds after each nation's inflation rate is accounted for, he said. The yen and yen-denominated investments have not benefited as much despite the rise in Japanese interest rates. That's mainly because Japan is so dependent upon imported oil, leading to concern about inflation eroding the value of the investments, Wyss said. The slump in the Japanese stock market hasn't helped matters, he said. Wyss said the apparent lessening of the dollar's safe-haven status could turn out to be a blessing for the United States. ``What we hope this will result in is a more stable dollar, one that doesn't swing as much on these crises. That is good not only for the U.S. but for world financial markets,'' he said. A weaker dollar is not necessarily bad news. It makes imported goods more expensive, but U.S. exporters should benefit because their products are now more competitive price-wise on world markets. That could help ease the nation's trade deficit.

DOC.HEAD: Questions and Answers on the Falling Dollar
With PM-Hazardous Haven
DOC.TEXT: The dollar has lost strength for several months, a trend that continued after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait _ a reversal from the usual trend in times of turmoil, when investors typically bid up the value of the dollar. Is a falling dollar good or bad for average Americans? The answer, economists say, is ``it depends.'' Here are some questions and answers about the dollar's recent decline:
DOC.HEAD: Who determines the exchange-rate value of the dollar?
DOC.TEXT: Until 1971, its value was rigidly set, first to a certain weight of gold and later to exchange rates of other major nations' currencies. But since then, its price has floated, determined by market forces. Each day, hundreds of billions of dollars are bought and sold by traders in foreign exchange markets in exchange for currencies of other nations. These traders are usually commercial banks or other large institutional buyers that trade currencies for profit. Central banks like the Federal Reserve or the Bank of Japan also get involved when an exaggerated move by a currency requires them to buy or sell a currency to stabilize the market.
DOC.HEAD: What makes a dollar ``strong'' or ``weak?''
DOC.TEXT: The dollar is subject to the same laws of supply and demand as any commodity traded openly, such as oil or soybeans. Heavy buying of dollars on exchange markets drives up the dollar's price, making it ``strong'' compared with other currencies. Heavy selling of dollars sends the price down, making it ``weak.''
What's better, a strong dollar or a weak dollar?

It depends. A strong dollar makes Americans' cash go further overseas and reduces import prices _ generally good for U.S. consumers and for foreign manufacturers. But if the dollar is overvalued, as nearly all economists agree it was in the early 1980s, U.S. products are harder to sell abroad, where locally made goods may be cheaper, and at home, where they compete with low-cost imports. That helped give the United States its record-breaking trade deficit. A weak dollar can restore competitiveness to American products by making foreign goods comparatively more expensive. But too weak a dollar can spawn inflation, first through higher import prices and then through spiraling prices for all goods. Worse, a falling dollar can drive foreign investors away from U.S. securities, which lose value along with the dollar. Foreign investment is critically needed to help finance the large U.S. budget deficit.
If the dollar's value is solely set by market forces, what steps can governments take to stabilize it?

Through two basic ways: exchange-market intervention and by coordinating interest-rate changes. Intervention is the direct buying or selling of currencies by central banks. If the purchases are large enough, that can influence prices directly. When the Fed, or the Bank of Japan, or the German Bundesbank, buys dollars directly, that reduces the supply of dollars available and sends up the price. Changes in interest rates affect exchange rates more subtly. But generally, high interest rates in the United States, compared with low interest rates abroad, will attract money to dollar-denominated investments. That raises the value of the dollar. Investors will flock to where they can get the highest return.

DOC.HEAD: NASD's Plan For Early Trading To Be Delayed
DOC.TEXT: The National Association of Securities Dealers' plan to extend trading hours before dawn has been delayed by at least a month, thanks to a regulatory snag. NASD President Joseph R. Hardiman said Thursday that on-going negotiations with the Securities and Exchange Commission will push back the expected start of early hours trading from September until later in the fall. The NASD, which oversees the over-the-counter market _ stocks that are traded through an electronic market system rather than a stock exchange _ planned to begin a trading session that started at 3:30 a.m. New York time next month. The early start would allow members of the NASDAQ automated stock quote system in the United States and Britain to trade in more than 300 securities of U.S. companies, including about 70 now traded on the London International Exchange, before the markets opened in this country. The move was seen as a step toward round-the-clock trading, which many say is necessary to keep American markets competitive with those overseas. But the SEC wants more stringent transaction reporting, which NASD fears will spook London traders who are used to reporting less information. Hardiman, however, said he was confident the difficulty could be overcome. ``It's a hurdle not a roadblock,'' he said, adding ``When you're the first organization that's trying to introduce an offshore market, you're forging new ground and you have to deal with some rule and regulatory issues, not all of which can be anticipated. ``We're dealing with this one with the SEC. We're negotiating with them and I think we'll reach a suitable compromise,'' he said. He said he expected trading to begin SEC officials could not be reached for comment. Hardiman explained that in the NASDAQ system in this country, every trade is reported and disseminated within 90 seconds of its execution. But in the more thinly traded British market, the stock ticker reports trades only after three minutes. And in large block trades, the information is held up for 90 minutes before it is disseminated. NASDAQ had planned not to issue data on every trade but to report price quotes and volume periodically, which the SEC said wasn't often enough for the protection of U.S. investors.

DOC.HEAD: Fannie Mae to Repurchase Up to $5 Billion in Warrants and Common Stock
DOC.TEXT: The Federal National Mortgage Association says it will buy back up to $500 million of its securities to show management's confidence in Fannie Mae's ability to ride out an economic downturn. Shares of Fannie Mae closed at $26.62{ Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange, down 12{ cents. The stock had been trading as high as $43.75 on June 12. Fannie Mae shares had traded as low as 24~ before the company announced its plan to buy back common stock and warrants. ``If we thought the company's future financial prospects were materially diminished by the current environment, we wouldn't be as comfortable considering share repurchasing,'' said Timothy Howard, Fannie Mae's chief financial officer. Shares in Fannie Mae, the nation's largest investor in home mortgages, usually rise when interest rates fall and drop when the interest rate rises, reflecting the mortgage industry's dependency on interest rate movement. Fannie Mae is a publicly owned, congressionally-sponsored corporation that buys mortgages from lenders and resells them to investors. Officials of the Washington-based corporation said the stock buyback reflects management's confidence in the company's financial position and future earnings power despite increasing signs of a pending recession. ``We think the overall market in general and Fannie Mae in particular is down by far more than the company's financial conditions and prospects would warrant _ even if the economy were to enter into a recession with high inflation, as seems to be the current concern,'' said Howard. As of June 30, Fannie Mae had about 34 million warrants and 241 million shares of common stock outstanding. A warrant is a security that serves as an advance purchase, for a lower price, of an equal amount of stock to be issued later. Warrants are usually offered as an inducement or sweetener to investors to get them to buy accompanying fixed-income securities such as bonds. To offset the buyback, Howard said Fannie Mae will be receiving up to $500 million in February from the conversion of the outstanding warrants. ``We do not have a fixed time frame in mind,'' he said. He said buying back shares with the proceeds of exercised warrants was ``a fairly common technique for dealing with equity conversion.'' In announcing the buyback, Fannie Mae Chairman David O. Maxwell repeated the company's plan to add between $2 billion and $2.5 billion in capital by the end of next year. The company has been criticized in the past for not having enough capital _ about $3.5 billion _ compared to its more than $300 billion holdings in mortgages and mortgage securities, to protect it in times recession or a real estate bust.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Fate Decided By All Powerful Commission
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump's financial fate last week lay in the hands of two former state senators, a former county clerk, a retired IRS administrator and an attorney. Those five people make up the New Jersey Casino Control Commission. On Tuesday, they approved a Byzantine financial deal that allowed Trump to receive a $65 million emergency loan with his three Atlantic City casinos put up as collateral. The deal is no guarantee Trump will succeed in his attempt to handle the $3.2 billion in debt he has amassed to build his fortunes here and in New York, according to a report by the state Division of Gaming Enforcement. The commission is focusing on Trump's overall financial stability with relicensing hearings moved up to October for all three of his casinos. The hearings would come just before Trump is scheduled to make a $47 million bond payment due Nov. 15 on the Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort. As evidenced by this case, the commissioners, who each make less than $100,000 a year, command a great deal of power as written by the authors of the 1977 Casino Control Act. Critics have long charged the commission with abusing that power, but defenders say the commission has done its job, keeping the casinos free of organized crime and fostering a climate that tries to balance everybody's interest. Casino executives lauded the appointment Wednesday of Steven Perskie, Gov. Jim Florio's chief of staff, as the new chairman of the commission. His appointment returns acting chairwoman Valerie Armstrong to a commissioner's role and replaces E. Kenneth Burdge, a former county clerk, whose term expired. Perskie, as a state senator from Atlantic City's county, helped to write the 1977 Casino Control Act. ``This is a very positive move for the industry and a very positive move for Atlantic City,'' said Al Glasgow, publisher of the gaming newsletter ``Atlantic City Action'' and a consultant to Trump. ``He understands Atlantic City.'' Aside from Perskie, these are the remaining players: _ Ms. Armstrong, an Atlantic County attorney and former admininstative law judge, is generally credited within the industry with shifting the commission toward what they perceived as fairer treatment than that of her predecessor, Walter ``Bud'' Read. Ms. Armstrong, who was appointed to the commission in 1985, is not an industry captive. She told attorneys for Trump that, in essence, they would have to persuade bankers to wait until Tuesday for a commission ruling because the panel needed time to digest the thousands of pages of documents submitted by Trump. Her ruling Tuesday insisted that Trump's casino licenses be examined in October, months ahead of their spring due date. _Commissioner Frank J. ``Pat'' Dodd is seen as a friend of the casino industry who acts as a ``lone voice'' on the panel. His only questions during the hearings on Trump were for new Trump chief financial officer Stephen Bollenbach to evaluate the future of the casino industry. Dodd came to the commission in March 1989 after a varied career. He served as a state senator from Essex County, state Senate president, failed Democratic gubernatorial candidate in 1981, chairman of the Hazardous Waste Facilities Siting Commission _ a panel equal to the casino commission as a lightning rod for anger _ and owner of a string of bars along the shore. _Commissioner W. David Waters, appointed in 1986, is seen as the antithesis to Dodd and a holdover from the Read era. He has been a strong advocate of ensuring that the 50,000-employee casino industry hires minorities and women. His questions during the Trump hearings asked pointedly about the absence of a plan detailing an expected trade by Trump of part of his casino equity to reduce his debt. He said he reluctantly voted to approve the deal Tuesday and hoped Trump's problems show other casinos the danger of piling on too much debt. Waters, a Camden County resident, had been retired from his job as regional administrator of the Internal Revenue Service when he was appointed to the commission in 1986. _James Hurley is the most recent nominee, coming aboard in December as the last appointee of the departing administration of Gov. Thomas Kean. The former Republican state senator from Cumberland County has yet to carve out a role on the commission, usually voting with the majority. He was silent during the question part of the hearings.

Stock prices turned upward today in what analysts described as a technical rebound from the market's free-fall slide of the past several weeks. DOC.HEAD: World's Major Airlines Plan Talks On Fare Hikes
DOC.TEXT: Major airlines will meet next week to discuss international passenger fare hikes in response to soaring fuel prices caused by the Persian Gulf crisis, an industry association said Friday. Thirty to 40 major carriers from all over the world are expected at the three-day emergency conference starting Wednesday in Geneva, the International Air Transport Association said. Representatives will seek to set a new common fare policy seen as reasonable enough to gain quick approval by governments, IATA officials said. Industry sources said higher international fares are likely to start Oct. 1 at the latest. One source, who declined to be identified, said fares could rise by up 10 percent. Crude oil prices have hit their highest levels in five years after Iraq's occupation of Kuwait and the U.N. trade embargo against Iraq. Insurance premiums for Middle East flights have jumped as tension rose in the region. Insurance costs are to be discussed at the meeting. One way airlines could pass on the increase to passengers is through insurance surcharges on Middle East routes, sources said. Whatever the big airlines decide at the IATA-sponsored meeting will effectively serve as guidelines for other, smaller passenger carriers. Charter fares are expected to rise more sharply than those of scheduled flights because fuel accounts for a greater proportion of charter airlines' costs. IATA is a group of 200 airlines in 122 countries.

DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices opened slightly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade today, but other commodities showed some weakness. Corn and soybean futures were under pressure from selling to take advantage of high prices after Thursday's substantial gains. In addition, the was some moderate farmer selling of soybeans overnight. Trading action in the wheat pit was light and choppy, with only minor selling interest. Some commission house buying in the opening minutes gave the wheat market its initial support. Live cattle were .02 cent lower to .18 cent higher with the October contract at 76.85 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent lower to .10 cent higher with August at 88.80 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .33 cent higher; and frozen pork bellies were unchanged to the limit 2 cents lower with August at 41.72 cents a pound. On Thursday, livestock and meat prices were mostly lower.

DOC.HEAD: Oil, Gasoline Prices Dip
DOC.NOTE: Eds: NEW throughout to UPDATE with morning trading; EDITS to tighten, delete dated material; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices dropped in early trading today on hopes for increased OPEC production in response to the Middle East crisis. Light, sweet crude was down 86 cents to $31.07 per barrel on October contracts late morning on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Oil prices broke $30 a barrel this week for the first time since late 1985. ``I think the market is reflecting here on the prospects of higher OPEC production,'' said Bob Baker, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has declined to meet formally to discuss higher production in the wake of the international embargo of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. But some producing states planned to meet on their own this weekend in Vienna. On Thursday, crude matched its record high futures price during the trading day before closing at $31.93 per barrel, up 71 cents. Unleaded gasoline hit a closing record high for the seventh straight day. This morning, unleaded regular gasoline fell 2.4 cents to $1.061 per gallon this morning on September contracts. Home heating oil dropped 1.98 cents to 94.25 cents per barrel for September delivery. Natural gas stayed sluggish, falling from $1.545 to $1.530 per 1,000 cubic feet. During Thursday's trading, crude oil hit $32.35 per barrel for October delivery, equaling a record set Aug. 2, 1983, the year oil futures were introduced on the Merc. The exchange is the leading market for petroleum futures contracts, which determine prices over the next several months. After the 1979 Iranian revolution that ousted the Shah and curtailed world oil supplies, the cash price of crude reached a peak of $39.80 per barrel in March 1980. Unleaded gasoline hit an all-time high of $1.11 per gallon for September delivery Thursday before settling at a record-high closing price of $1.086. Gasoline has set new record closing prices every day since Aug. 15, with prices at the pump also on the rise. Gasoline futures rose in part because of a fire and a leak at two Texas refineries that were cutting back an already tight supply of petroleum products. Shell Oil Co. said 165,000 barrels of crude cannot be refined daily because of a fire at its plant in Deer Park, Texas, although a spokesman was not sure how long repairs might take. Another Shell spokesman said customers would be supplied through other plants. Also, a leak at the Crown Central Petroleum Corp. refinery in the Houston area forced a partial shutdown that analysts said would probably not disrupt supplies for more than a day or two. Some analysts said the shortfall was significant in light of further potential declines in imports because of the Middle East crisis.

DOC.HEAD: London Asks Oil Companies to Explain Gas Price Hikes
DOC.TEXT: The British Office of Fair Trading asked major oil companies Friday to explain the increase in gasoline prices since the outbreak of the Gulf crisis. Prices have risen from around 2.041 pounds ($3.98) a gallon on July 25 to 2.178 pounds ($4.24) a gallon this week. That's a rise of 87.6 cents to 93.4 cents per liter. The Office of Fair Trading, an arm of government that acts as an independent consumer watchdog, said it asked Shell, Esso, BP, Texaco and Mobil for ``an account of the impact which the current Middle East crisis has had on the companies' operations.'' The oil companies said they welcomed the request because it would enable them to disprove allegations that they have been profiting unfairly from the rise in oil prices since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. They noted that the industry had already been investigated and cleared by anti-trust agencies. ``We will as usual cooperate fully with this request and we welcome the opportunity to help clear the air,'' BP said. Shell said it is losing one million pounds ($1.95 million) a day on gas station sales because pump prices are failing to keep pace with oil price increases.

DOC.HEAD: GE Cuts Jobs in Massachusetts, Alabama
DOC.TEXT: General Electric Co. said Friday it would cut more jobs due to a shrinking military budget. GE Aerospace said it would eliminate 650 jobs in Burlington by 1992 and will close a facility in Huntsville, Ala., by the end of next year. The Alabama site employs 400 people, and about half the workers will be offered jobs in Daytona Beach, Fla., under a consolidation plan, said Terry Dunn, a GE spokesman. Last week, GE Aircraft Engines announced it was eliminating 1,500 jobs from its plants in Lynn, Mass., and Evendale, Ohio. About one-third of those jobs will be lost through layoffs. As with the previous announcement, GE cited military spending cuts in its decision. ``To stay competitive in a smaller and rapidly changing defense market, we need to make the most efficient use of our manufacturing facilities and other resources,'' Mike Smith, vice president of the aircraft electronics division, said in a statement. Products at the Burlington plant include automated test equipment for such military vehicles as tanks and helicopters. Huntsville has served as a development site for an electronic test system for the Navy. Under the new company structure, Burlington will focus on automated test equipment but other product lines will be transferred to other sites. The cuts in Burlington and Huntsville ``will result largely from layoffs,'' GE said. But Dunn said the company hoped to minimize the extent of layoffs through attrition and worker relocation. GE said it would offer a severance package and would help employees find new jobs.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Expected to Announce New Mainframe Computers
DOC.TEXT: IBM is expected to announce Sept. 5 plans for introducing new mainframe computers twice as powerful as the current systems, a market research group said Friday. Richard Imershein, senior vice president of Stamford-based Gartner Group Inc., said the announcement will come in two phases. The Sept. 5 announcement will introduce upgrades for IBM's highly successful 4381 line of minicomputers and a related family of smaller minicomputers, the 9370, Imershein said. Toward the end of next year, he said, IBM will announce new technology to replace the current systems and more than double their capacity. ``The announcement on (Sept. 5) will be the announcement of the move,'' Imershein said. ``The first deliveries will basically be some new covers and some new frames and some new power supplies. ... But the actual new machine itself, we don't believe will come until the second half of 1991.'' Amos Kermisch, spokesman at the company's headquarters in Armonk, N.Y., confirmed that IBM would be making a major announcement Sept. 5, and that mainframe computers would be part of that announcement. The announcement will be made at IBM's Poughkeepsie, N.Y., plant, which makes mainframes, Kermisch said. ``We're doing it where we manufacture large systems, but there's something for just about everybody in the announcement,'' he said. Kermisch declined to release details about the announcement. Imershein said Gartner Group believes IBM is making the announcement next month in response to competitive pressures from Hitachi and Amdahl Corp., which have been improving their mainframe product lines. ``They really would have preferred to do it in the second half of '91, but they can't wait,'' he said. The bulk of IBM's customers aren't expected to leap quickly to the new mainframes, Imershein said. ``The people who are at the front end, (who) need the capacity, will make the move,'' he said. ``The rest of them will kind of lay back and wait.''

DOC.HEAD: Consortium Developments Small Computer Device
DOC.TEXT: Sematech, a group of leading U.S. electronics firms, announced Friday what it called a state-of-the-art technology breakthrough with the development of a super-small computer device. Sematech made a device one-half micron thick that will be used to build integrated circuits, which are components of computer chips. One-half micron is one millionth of a meter. The current industry edge is 0.8 micron circuitry, Sematech's chief administrative officer, Peter Mills said. The smaller, half-micron size means 2{ times more information can be stuffed onto the same size chip, he said. ``Half-micron technology is leading edge and state of the art,'' Mills said. ``This is another milestone that indicates that the investment the American taxpayer has made here is a good investment,'' said Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, who with Rep. J.J. ``Jake'' Pickle, D-Texas, was on hand for the announcement. ``It is yielding a rate of return in terms of American competitiveness, which means higher standards of living, more jobs, better jobs for our people,'' he said. Sematech was created to regain U.S. superiority in the semiconductor industry. Its $226 million annual budget is split between the federal government and the 14 private company members. Development of the one-half micron device keeps Sematech on schedule in its plan to achieve manufacturing parity with Japan, Mills said. In the late 1980s, Japan surpassed the U.S. in the worldwide semiconductor market, he said. Mills said the device was made with American equipment by American-trained semiconductor manufacturing specialists. He said the next step will be to manufacture a 0.35 micron device. This, he said, would help the U.S. reclaim its leadership in the semiconductor industry.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Finish Higher
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices held on to strong gains posted earlier and moved even higher on Friday at the Chicago Board of Trade. ``After yesterday's strength, nobody wanted to sell,'' said Mickey Luth, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``The fundamentals were there to drive it higher.'' Combining to give soybeans a boost were lower carryover stocks, reduced South American production and smaller amounts of competing crops. Grain prices, on the other hand, were weak. ``They don't have the dynamics of soybeans,'' said Luth. ``The corn supply is getting bigger, not smaller. And there's no risk of frost.'' The latest 6- to 10-day forecast calls for warm temperatures in the main corn-growing regions, and Luth said he feels confident the crop will make it past Oct. 1 and into the harvest season without suffering any severe frost damage. At the close, wheat was 1 cent lower to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.85 a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1} cents lower with September at $2.57\ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to } cent higher with September at $1.19 a bushel; and soybeans were 3 cents lower to 5 cents higher with September at $6.30{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Data General to Lay Off 2,000 More Workers
DOC.TEXT: Data General Corp., which has repeatedly cut its payroll while trying to end a string of losses, announced Friday it would lay off more than 2,000 additional workers over the next several weeks. The announcement was widely expected by Wall Street analysts, but some questioned whether the cost-cutting steps would allow the computer company to turn a profit. Because of the layoffs and accompanying severance payments, the company will record a charge of approximately $70 million against the fourth quarter, which ends Sept. 29. Data General expects to suffer a loss in the quarter. Friday's announcement marked the sixth time the Westboro, Mass.-based company has cut sharply into its work force since 1985, the last year Data General reported a profit. Since that year, employment at Data General has shrunk from 17,700 to its current level of 11,700, which does not include Friday's cuts. Data General, like other Massachusetts computer companies, has suffered from declines in the market for mid-size minicomputers. Data General has tried to revamp its product line, marketing smaller, desktop computer workstations. Part of the strategy is to make products that operate according to industry standards. Data General President Ronald L. Skates said in a statement that the company now has ``the organization in place and the appropriate mix of employee resources to compete successfully in today's information technology marketplace.'' ``That is a well-worn phrase from these guys,'' said Christopher Mines, an analyst with Cowen & Co. in Boston. Analysts say the new products are performing well, but they have not yet offset the continuing losses in minicomputers. As a result, overall revenues have remained weak. For the first nine months of the current fiscal year, the company had revenues of $907 million, compared with $957 million for the same period a year ago. Data General also faces stiff competition for its new products, and analysts say the company must show it can turn a profit in order to attract more customers. ``It's one of these spiral things,'' Mines said. ``You erode customer confidence ... with every losing quarter that goes by.'' Data General says its primary goal is to become profitable. ``Today's announcement indicates we have to reduce costs,'' said James Dunlap, a company spokesman. But he added: ``Our hope is this will be the final time we will have a major reduction.'' But as long as the revenues remain uncertain, more cost-cutting steps might be needed, said Barry Willman, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein in New York. The company did not immediately specify where the layoffs will occur. But Dunlap said Massachusetts, where the company employs 3,200, will be among the areas largely affected.

DOC.HEAD: UAW Has All Three Proposals; Mulling Strike Target
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers union on Friday perused contract proposals from each of the Big Three automakers, starting the process of choosing which company it will choose for negotiations in the next three weeks. The UAW got the first comprehensive contract proposal from Chrysler Corp. on Friday, the day after it received documents from General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. ``Loosely speaking, they are all in the American League, if not the same ballpark,'' a UAW source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Friday. ``There are some conspicuous absences in the Chrysler proposal. GM's is a slightly fleshier proposal than is Ford's.'' The UAW and industry observers have been wondering if Chrysler will be successful in breaking from the tradition of pattern bargaining and negotiate an agreement significantly different from that at the other two U.S. automakers. In pattern bargaining, the UAW chooses one of the three companies, reaches and agreement and in effect imposes it on the other two automakers. Chrysler, on the shakiest financial ground of the Big Three, has indicated it may not be able to afford a contract reached with the richer GM or Ford. But the UAW said it has no plans to break with the pattern bargaining tradition. Union and company officials publicly have declined to discuss the proposals' details, which doubtlessly will change in the days ahead. Each company's initial offer gives a broad idea of what it is seeking, but is also an attempt to persuade the union to choose it as the UAW target company. During the past week, after visiting the main bargaining tables at each of the Big Three, UAW President Owen Bieber has said the proposals will play major parts in next week's decision of which company will become the target. The UAW leadership meets Monday and Tuesday in Detroit to choose a target, widely believed to be GM. The union's current contracts with the Big Three expire Sept. 14 and cover more than 450,000 active workers. Employees on layoff and retirees, also covered by the contracts, add thousands to the total. The union has targeted job security as its overriding concern during this year's negotiations. Companies have said they will be seeking increased flexibility of the work force and reductions in their health care expenses.

DOC.HEAD: High Gasoline Prices Aren't So Bad If You Consider Inflation
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Motorists may be fuming as gasoline prices seem to get higher with every fillup, but petroleum experts say consumers aren't getting squeezed nearly as badly as they were a decade ago. Some contend oil prices would have to reach $60 a barrel and gas would have to hit $2 a gallon at the pump to make the situation analogous to the rapid rise in fuel costs in the months after the Iranian revolution. Oil prices peaked in 1981 after the revolution, and unleaded gasoline hit $1.42 per gallon at its height. But federal statisticians indicate the pump price would have to climb to $1.98 to reach the same real price today. The American Automobile Association reported Friday that prices at the pump had risen to their highest levels since the 1982 Fourth of July weekend, averaging $1.274 nationwide for a gallon of self-serve regular unleaded. That's up 3.7 cents since Monday. But it's far below the $2 mark that would have to set in before gasoline could take an early '80s-style bite out of the family budget. Between the days of peak gasoline prices and the current oil crisis, fuel prices have dropped to their lowest level since the end of World War II, when adjusted for inflation. ``It's the cheapest (time) to propel a car _ for one mile it's less than 5 cents,'' said Bill Hermann, chief economist with Chevron Corp. Company figures, when adjusted for inflation, indicate it cost 10.5 cents to drive a mile in 1980 and 8 cents in 1960. The Energy Information Administration uses figures that indicate 1988 was the cheapest year ever for gasoline. Even though nobody in the industry or the government seems willing to predict $2-a-gallon gas, the experts refuse to rule anything out. Oil prices shot past $30 a barrel this week for the first time since late 1985, in a futures market that has traded nervously since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Several experts contacted by The Associated Press said all bets would be off if the Middle East standoff develops into combat that destroys oil facilities in Saudi Arabia, which has the world's largest known crude supply. ``If we lost Kuwaiti, Iraqi and Saudi Arabian oil, there would be a real deficit,'' Hermann said. ``You'd have to cripple most of the Saudi exporting facilities before that would happen. That would imply a shooting war, and we would take out (Iraqi) facilities as well.'' A clash of that magnitude could remove almost one-fifth of world production from the markets, he said. Hermann believes that real pump prices of gasoline won't move back up to 1981-scale levels unless a full-scale war breaks out and the price of crude shoots up to $40 per barrel. Government statisticians estimated it would take a crude price above $60 a barrel. Those who follow the industry also point out that U.S. consumers pay far less than their counterparts in most other nations. Gas in Britain, for instance, was about $4.24 a gallon this week, according to that government's Office of Fair Trading. But other observers say U.S. consumers are paying far more for their energy as their tax money is used to pay for the deployment of the largest military force since the Vietnam War. The president of the National Defense Council Foundation, a Washington-area think tank, said that including the extra cost of the military buildup, Americans are probably paying more than $70 per barrel of oil. ``If hostilities break out, you're talking about $100 a barrel,'' Milton Copulos said. Despite the statistics that show pump prices are lower when adjusted for inflation, a Ralph Nader consumers group, Buyers Up, accuses oil companies of gouging the public by being too quick to pass on price increases and too slow to pass on decreases. Oil companies in recent weeks have mounted a public relations offensive to dispel such accusations. Spokesmen for three major companies said Friday they were glad the Justice Department's Antitrust Division was looking into pricing practices because they believe the probe will show the industry is playing fairly.
