DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises Ahead of Uncertain Weekend
DOC.TEXT: The dollar repeated what is becoming a usual Friday performance _ rising ahead of an uncertain weekend in the tense Persian Gulf. Gold prices advanced after drifting lower overseas. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold settled at $415 a troy ounce, up $3 an ounce from Thursday. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $414, up $2.75 an ounce. After falling in the previous session to new lows against the German mark, the Swiss franc and the British pound, the dollar was ripe for a technical rebound. The currency began rising in Asian trading and continued to gain ground when activity shifted to Europe and then the United States. Traders continued to focus on developments in the Middle East, where a tense standoff got under way at foreign embassies in Kuwait. The U.S. embassy and at least seven other missions were encircled by Iraqi troops as diplomats defied an order to close their doors. ``There's a threat of military conflict over the weekend, and despite all the obvious concerns over the economy, the knee-jerk reaction says you buy dollars,'' said Earl Johnson, a vice president at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. Traders agreed that if hostilities do not break in the next few days, the dollar is likely to resume its descent. ``Events are arguing for a higher dollar, but fundamentals are arguing for a lower dollar,'' said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. Indeed, the Commerce Department reported the economy grew at a sluggish annual rate of 1.2 percent in the second quarter. Though traders said there was little reaction to the report, they said that the notion of broad economic weakness is not being lost on the market. Further underscoring the economy's softness, the department said after-tax corporate profits slipped 0.2 percent in the period, the worst showing since a 5.9 percent decline in the third quarter of 1989. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 145.70 Japanese yen from 145.88 at Thursday's close. But it rose later in London to 146.45 yen and continued to gain ground, settling in New York at 146.75 yen, up from 146.12 yen on Thursday. In London, the British pound fetched $1.9445, cheaper than $1.9515 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.9400 to buy one pound, less expensive than Thursday's $1.9570. DOC.HEAD: Plane Crashes Into Boston Neighborhood, Kills Developer, Wife and Daughter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for AM-Plane Crash-Rouse on Business news Digest. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BX2
DOC.TEXT: A developer whose firm rejuvenated urban centers around the country was killed along with his wife and daughter when their private plane crashed between two houses Friday. The two houses went up in flames, but their occupants escaped injury. Killed were pilot Michael Spear, 49, president of The Rouse Co., his wife, Judy, 47, and their 19-year-old daughter, Jodi, police said. The company's projects include Boston's Faneuil Hall shopping area, Harbor Place on the Baltimore waterfront, South Street Seaport in New York and Underground Atlanta. ``This is a terrible loss to the Rouse Co. and to the country,'' said James W. Rouse, retired founder of the Columbia, Md.-based company. ``Mike Spear was a brilliant, compassionate, wise man. His leadership was tremendous. In many respects, he is irreplaceble. Judy was a wonderful woman who made a great contribution in her own right, as well as to Mike's work.'' The Spears lived in Columbia, Md., but had a summer home in Chatham on Cape Cod. Spear joined Rouse in 1967 as director of market research and project evaluation. From 1971 to 1978, he was general manager of the Columbia project that established the planned city between Baltimore and Washington. Spear was named executive vice president for development in 1978. He became president in 1986. He and his wife had three other daughters. Federal officials are investigating the cause of the crash. The plane went down on a dead-end street in the city's Mattapan section. The small white airplane crashed into a driveway between two houses, incinerating two parked cars and setting the houses on fire. Spear left foggy Cape Cod around 6 a.m. in his two-engine Cheyenne turboprop, bound for Logan International Airport. His daughter was to fly from there to Tokyo, where she planned to study this fall, said a friend of the family. The aircraft was 20 miles from Logan when Spear reported engine trouble, said Michael Ciccarelli, spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration. About seven miles from the airport he began efforts to land. Spear first reported lack of speed, then smoke, then that an engine was out. At 6:30 a.m. the plane disappeared from the radar screen. Visibility was one-quarter of a mile, said FAA spokeswoman Gail Lattrell. People in the neighborhood said they heard a low-flying aircraft, the sound of an engine cutting out and then a thud as the plane hit the ground. ``I was in bed, not asleep, when I heard this tremendous explosion,'' said Neal Silver, 66, who lives a few houses from the crash site. ``My neighbors were pounding on the door. I looked out and I could see these whole two buildings engulfed in flames.'' Neighbors poured into the street as thick black smoke billowed to the sky. Mayor Raymond Flynn sent dispatched teams of post-trauma experts to the neighborhood to help people there deal with the disaster. The Red Cross and other agencies offered emergency assistance to the displaced families.

The Russell 3000 index of companies with the largest market value closed at 170.52 Friday, down 9.48, or 5.27 percent, from a week ago and down 26.76, or 13.56 percent, this year to date. The Russell 1000 index of the largest companies, closed at 160.78 Friday, down 8.67, or 5.12 percent, from a week ago and down 24.33, or 13.14 percent, this year to date. The Russell 2000 index of smaller companies, closed at 134.23 Friday, down 11.42, or 7.84 percent, from a week ago and down 34.08, or 20.25 percent, this year to date.

DOC.HEAD: Arco's Gas Price Freeze Ends, But PR Benefits May Linger
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS analyst comment in two grafs after 19th graf, `It's difficult.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Pump Prices, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The gasoline prices at Edmond Nassar's Arco station were stunning to Ron and Nancy Sutton, who needed some good news after a Yosemite vacation interrupted by wildfires. Preparing for the last mountainous stretch back to Los Angeles, they pulled off Highway 99 on Thursday to see it posted in big black letters: unleaded gas, 93.9 cents. Just down the road, a Texaco station was charging nearly $1.20. But the low price wouldn't last. Later in the day, Atlantic Richfield Co. said it would end a two-week freeze and raise wholesale prices 2{ cents per gallon on average to its dealers. The company said it could no longer supply enough gas to meet demand for the lower prices. That means Arco, the eighth-largest U.S. oil company and largest gas marketer in the West, has ended an action that not only increased its market share, but yielded a rare public relations dividend at a time when other big oil companies were accused of gouging consumers. Iraq's invasion of tiny, oil-rich Kuwait has caused prices to soar for both crude oil and gasoline. A barrel of crude has risen from $21 to $30, while the price of unleaded regular gasoline increased from $1.075 per gallon on Aug. 1 to $1.237 this week, according to a spot check of self-service stations by the American Automobile Association. Arco was able to freeze prices because it normally gets 100 percent of its crude oil from its own Alaska operations. Eugene Nowak, the head of the energy research group at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said that ready supply provided a cushion for the company as it decided to freeze prices. Arco, considered a low-priced marketer, also relied on its West Coast refineries and all-self service stations to keep prices 2 to 3 cents cheaper than competitors. Its wholesale prices had fallen as much as 13 cents per gallon below competitors in some markets since the Iraqi invasion. But those low prices caused a surge in sales volume that approached 20 percent by Thursday, overtaxing Arco's ability to re-supply many stations, said George H. Babikian, president of marketing and refining. ``We had our refineries at capacity, we were delivering every drop we could with our own fleet, we were working people on overtime to exhaustion, we hired every common carrier we could find, and still we were running out at 150 to 160 stations a day, sometimes for four hours,'' Babikian said. Babikian disputed suggestions that the company's price freeze was intended to curry favor with Washington in hopes that more Alaska land will be opened to exploration, or that a return of a windfall profits tax on oil can be headed off. ``I think our motive was very pure, to help the president in this very difficult situation,'' he said. President Bush appealed for voluntary price restraints following the invasion. Babikian said the plea ``sounded like a very reasonable request to us, and so we did it. To the extent that it generates good will in Washington, heck, we need all the help we can get. ``And the same thing goes for good will at the pump,'' he said. ``But those weren't the reasons we did it.'' Scott Jones, a former Arco staff economist who is now president of AUS Consultants in suburban Philadelphia, said he believes the freeze was intended to increase market share. He said the move helped reassert Arco's image as a low-price leader and win good will for its corporate citizenship. It also smooths the way for the introduction this fall of additional lower-polluting fuels. The new gasolines, replacing unleaded varieties, cost more to make and presumably will cost more at the pump. ``It's difficult to appeal to people's sense of the environment at $1.30 a gallon, where it would have been easy at $1.05,'' Jones said. ``But if anyone can do it, (Arco) can, given the good will they've generated.'' But George Baker, an analyst with Merrill Lynch Research in New York, dismissed market share as a major reason for Arco's action, saying he believed the company was already satisfied with its inroads. Perhaps more important strategically to Arco, Baker said, was the hope it can help calm congressional critics accusing the oil industry of price gouging. ``I think they (at Arco) do want the oil business to be in a stable political and economic environment,'' he said. Babikian said Arco would not increase the wholesale price of its gasoline beyond increases in its refineries' crude oil prices, which he said track the world market. Now that Arco has ended the freeze, dealers in southern California, Arizona and Nevada will pay up to 5 cents per gallon more for their stocks, although company officials and dealers say Arco's prices will still be the lowest around. Nassar, the Bakersfield dealer, said Arco had always supplies him gas cheaply enough to allow him to meet his goal _ beating or meeting the lowest priced competitors in town. ``Even with the price increase, we're still the lowest,'' Nasser said. ``So we still have a great deal of room to play without losing our competitive edge.''

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Prices Highest Since 1982
With AM-Gulf-Pump Prices, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline prices have climbed 19.9 cents per gallon since Aug. 1, making for the most expensive fillups in more than eight years, the American Automobile Association said Friday. Self-serve regular unleaded gasoline averaged $1.274 nationwide, up 3.7 cents since Monday, the AAA reported. The price is the highest since the Independence Day 1982 price of $1.296. The survey is based on a review of 5,000 stations nationwide. The nation's supplies of gasoline are adequate in spite of the Mideast crisis caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the AAA said. But it is urging motorists to practice energy conservation. Average regional per-gallon prices from Friday's survey: New England, $1.277; Mid-Atlantic, $1.236; Great Lakes, $1.289; Midwest, $1.281; Southeast, $1.249; Southwest, $1.241; and West, $1.359.

DOC.HEAD: Mortgage Rates Up
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.29 percent this week, up from 10.05 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. It was the highest level since a similar 10.29 percent rate was posted last June 1. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.36 percent, up from 8.31 percent last week. The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices staged a sharply rally near the close Friday in what analysts described as a technical rebound from the market's free-fall slide of the past several weeks. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had plunged 173.02 points over the three previous sessions, climbed 49.50 to 2,532.92. The average finished the week with a net loss of 111.88 points, for its biggest weekly decline since it fell 118.67 points Jan. 22-26. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 956 up, 649 down and 410 unchanged. Analysts said buyers were encouraged by hopes that the markets had gone too far in their appraisal of the potential calamities resulting from the showdown in the Middle East. But by near-unanimous agreement the mood in the marketplace remained cautious and touchy. It will take months, economists observe, to gauge the effects on business aactivity of the upsurge in oil prices and interest rates that followed Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Even without that disruptive influence, the domestic economy was widely believed to have been verging on a recession as it began the second half of 1990. Brokers said traders' spirits apparently got a lift from a flurry of announcements of corporate stock-buyback plans, in a manner reminiscent of the aftermath of the 1987 crash. In one of the most notable early instances, Federal National Mortgage Association said it had earmarked as much as $500 million for purchases of its common shares and warrants. Fannie Mae shares, which traded as low as 24~ Thursday before the company made its announcement, rose 2] to 29 in Friday's trading. Among actively traded blue chips, General Electric rose 2~ to 61]; International Business Machines 3{ to 100]; Boeing 3] to 45~, and American Telephone & Telegraph 1] to 31~. Recently-battered closed-end country funds also scored some notable gains. Germany Fund picked up 1~ to 12]; Thai Fund 2\ to 16{, and ROC Taiwan Fund 1 to 6~. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 199.04 million shares, against 250.44 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 241.11 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $36.56 billion, or 1.26 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 2.17 to 171.05. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 6.52 to 368.75, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 4.45 at 311.51. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market jumped 7.11 to 367.33. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 316.29, up .44.

DOC.HEAD: With Stock Prices Depressed, Companies Buy Back Shares
DOC.TEXT: The stock market's depressed levels opened the door Friday for a number of companies to launch or extend stock buyback programs. A.O. Smith Corp., which had suspended a share repurchase program in June 1989, said it was resuming stock buybacks. The company, a manufacturer of auto, truck and farm equipment, allocated $7.5 million for the repurchases. The toymaker Hasbro Inc. said its board approved the buyback of up to 3 million shares. Western Publishing Group Inc., First Illinois Corp., First Financial Holdings Inc. and Bernard Chaus Inc. were among other companies announcing stock buybacks Friday. Other firms have already been in the market this week, picking up their own shares at bargain prices. On Tuesday, the investment firm Bear, Stearns & Co. repurchased 2.36 million shares of its stock when the price hit a 52-week low. A.O. Smith vice president Edward J. O'Connor attributed the timing of the firm's resumption of its buybacks in part to the declines on Wall Street over the past month. A.O. Smith stock closed at $14.87{ Friday, up 25 cents in American Stock Exchange trading. Since the stock market reached an all-time closing high of 2,999.75 on July 17, the Dow Jones industrial average has fallen nearly 470 points as Wall Street was wracked by concerns about a recession in the United States and war in the Middle East. The Dow Jones average has dropped more than 366 points since Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait. The closely-watched index closed Friday at 2,532.92, up 49.50. The flurry of repurchase plans recalls the October 1987 stock market crash, when firms including International Business Machines Corp., USX Corp., Citicorp, General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. began to scoop up their own shares at lower prices. Stock buybacks are popular among shareholders. Since repurchases reduce the number of shares available, they tend to support the price of a company's stock, and also enhance a firm's balance sheet by raising its earnings per share. Dexter Corp., which also extended its stock repurchase program Friday, also wanted to provide a market for shareholders who wanted to unload their stock but couldn't. ``There are times when there are virtually no buyers of the stock and we can provide liquidity for our stockholders who want to sell,'' said Dexter executive vice president Robert E. McGill. Buybacks also represent a vote of confidence in a firm by its management, which takes millions of dollars from corporate coffers to repurchase the shares. The stock market's decline prompted Penn Central Corp. to lower the price on its tender offer for 10 million of its shares. Penn Central said Friday it would pay $23 per share, instead of the $26 it had offered earlier. The company blamed the tensions in the Middle East ``and the consequent deterioration in general market conditions, including the market price for the company's common stock'' for the change in its offer. Penn Central's announcement also harks back to the 1987 crash, when several tender offers or buyout plans were canceled or put on hold. Penn Central stock closed Friday at $21.87{ a share on the New York Stock Exchange, up 12{ cents. And Sun Microsystems Inc. said it was withdrawing a planned stock offering because of deteriorating market conditions. Sun had announced plans for the offering earlier this month.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Hit Lull as Traders Pocket Their Profits
With AM-Gulf-Markets, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices fell back Friday, as traders saw little news from the Middle East and decided to take their profits from a week of high prices that broke some records and tied others. Light sweet crude fell $1.02 per barrel to $30.91 for October delivery on the New York Mercantile Exchange, but never dropped below the $30 mark it hit Wednesday for the first time since November 1985. ``We're really not down very much,'' said Bob Baker, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Unleaded gasoline also closed lower Friday, down 3.89 cents to $1.047 per gallon for September delivery. The drop broke a seven-day streak of record high closes that began Aug. 15. Later contract months were also down, as were contracts for light sweet crude. During the week's trading, crude matched its all-time high futures price of $32.35 per barrel, and unleaded gasoline set an all-time record of $1.11 per gallon. Both highs came Thursday. As the wild week came to an end, analysts said the price of petroleum products, including gasoline and heating oil, had risen too high in proportion to the price of crude, so they had been destined to fall. ``Products were under pressure, simply from being exceedingly high,'' Baker said. ``What we saw, basically from the beginning of the day, was profit taking,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. ``A lot of players wanted to take their profits for the weekend.'' The closing price of crude oil Friday was up $2.28 per 42-gallon barrel for the week. Unleaded gasoline, which traded above $1 per gallon on the Merc for the first time ever on Monday, stayed above that level all week for an 8.7 cent increase on September contracts. Home heating oil closed at 90.96 cents per gallon for September delivery, down 5.27 cents for the day but up 10.42 cents for the week. Natural gas closed at $1.525 per 1,000 cubic feet for October delivery, down from $1.545 on Thursday but up from $1.440 a week earlier. Although a lack of news from the Middle East stirred concerns and uncertainties that sent markets soaring earlier in the week, traders viewed Friday's lack of major developments as a calming factor, Hittle said. A day earlier, traders had worried about the pending showdown as the United States refused Iraqi demands that the embassy in Kuwait be closed by Friday. Iraq reportedly threatened Friday that it would use force to remove the diplomats on Saturday. ``The fact that nothing happened eased things a bit,'' Hittle said, although traders remain nervous about the possibility of military escalation. The rising fuel costs have been taking their toll on motorists who see prices going up at the pump. The American Automobile Association reported Friday that its latest nationwide survey of pump prices showed an average price of $1.274 for a self-serve gallon of regular unleaded. That was a 3.7 cent rise since Monday and represented the highest cost at the pump since the 1982 Independence Day weekend, the AAA said.

DOC.HEAD: Recession Fears Pressue Cattle Futures
DOC.TEXT: Cattle futures prices slipped lower Friday at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange under continuing fears of a recession. On other markets, oil prices turned lower; soybeans and wheat advanced while corn was lower; and gold posted some minor gains. Cattle prices are vulnerable on a number of fronts and are now at the mercy of the Mideast energy crisis and the potential for a recession, said Paul Hare, an analyst in Chicago with Linnco Futures Inc. ``There's also some concern about the profitability for cattle prices this fall because of the extremely high prices that were paid for feeders in the early spring and midsummer,'' he said. The cash market isn't helping, either, with cash feeders falling $2 to $5 per hundredweight on Friday, Hare said. In contrast, pork futures showed some stability following a period of sharp declines in cash prices. With the price for pork products on the decline, traders were hoping these items would be featured at the meat counters and give a boost to demand. Cattle futures settled .25 cent to .75 cent lower with the contract for delivery in October at 76.17 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .55 cent to 1.15 cents lower with August at 88.17 cents a pound; hogs were unchanged to .33 cent higher with October at 48.42 cents a pound; and frozen pork bellies were 1.82 cents lower to .30 cent higher with August at 41.90 cents a pound. Soybean futures prices advanced on the Chicago Board of Trade. ``After yesterday's strength, nobody wanted to sell,'' said Mickey Luth, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``The fundamentals were there to drive it higher.'' He said bean prices are benefiting from lower carryover stocks, reduced South American production and smaller amounts of competing crops. Grain prices, on the other hand, were weak. ``They don't have the dynamics of soybeans,'' said Luth. ``The corn supply is getting bigger, not smaller. And there's no risk of frost.'' The latest 6- to 10-day forecast calls for warm temperatures in the main corn-growing regions, and Luth said he feels confident the crop will make it past Oct. 1 and into the harvest season without suffering any severe frost damage. Wheat was 1 cent lower to 1} cents higher with the contract for delivery in September at $2.84} a bushel; corn was 1\ cents lower to \ cent higher with September at $2.57} a bushel; oats were 1\ cents lower to } cent higher with September at $1.18 a bushel; and soybeans were 1{ cents lower to 5 cents higher with September at $6.30 a bushel. Petroleum futures concluded a week of Mideast-inspired price increases with declines across the board at the New York Mercantile Exchange. Light sweet crude oil retreated 58 cents to $1.72 with the October contract settling at $30.91 a barrel; heating oil was 5.27 cents to 5.94 cents lower with September at 90.96 cents a gallon; and unleaded gasoline was 2.05 cents to 4.44 cents lower with September at $1.0466 a gallon. Precious metals futures erased losses and settled for small gains on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The decline in oil prices led to profit-taking in the metals early in the session, but the continuing fears over the Middle East gave the market late support, said Stephen W. Platt, an analyst in Chicago with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``No one was really willing to commit in any big way one way or another,'' he said. Gold settled $2.80 to $3.60 higher with the December contract at $423.20 a troy ounce; and silver was 6 cents to 7.9 cents higher with August at $5.187 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rally, Oil Prices Fall as Pessimism Wanes _ For Now
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS amount of Dow Jones drop in 18th graf, The stock; EDITS to conform. Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market rallied and oil prices eased Friday as the world's battered financial markets staggered into the weekend optimistic that a Middle East war had been averted _ for now. But the recovery worldwide was based more on a belief that stock prices had bottomed out and oil prices shot up too rapidly over $31 a barrel than on the latest tense developments in the Iraq-U.S. standoff. ``The fear from the selling has run its course like a fever runs its course and then breaks,'' said Christopher P. Baker of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in Boston. ``Maybe Monday morning there will be some more panic, but for the time being it's gone.'' On Wall Street, the Dow Jones average rose 49.50 points to 2,532.92, erasing most of a 76-point drop Thursday. But the Dow average, which measures 30 big industrial company stocks, still ended the week down 111.88 points. Stocks also rebounded in Europe and Japan. But despite the gains, the crisis spawned by Iraq's takeover of Persian Gulf neighbor Kuwait has erased hundreds of billions of dollars in the value of U.S. stocks. The price of the main blend of U.S. crude oil fell $1.02 per barrel to $30.91 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Crude peaked Thursday after tying an all-time high during that trading day. After Iraq let a deadline pass for Western countries to empty their embassies in Kuwait, many financial market participants traded as if the threat of an armed conflict had receded. That occurred despite a barrage of accusations by the Bush administration and the presence of Iraqi troops around the U.S. embassy in Kuwait City. Significantly easing market worries, Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev messaged Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein indicating Moscow would back Western powers pressing for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait and free foreign hostages. ``The feeling was there might not be any conflict over this, which was not the case before,'' said James Steel, an oil analyst with Refco Inc., a commodities trading firm in New York. ``The psychology turned rather rapidly.'' Financial markets fear a desert war that could knock out oil production by world leader Saudi Arabia and drastically reduce world supplies, making oil scarcer and more expensive. That in turn would translate to higher inflation and economic instability worldwide. In foreign exchange trading, which is highly sensitive to political developments, the dollar rebounded against major foreign currencies after falling in the previous sessions to new lows against the German mark, Swiss franc and British pound. The dollar rose against the yen in New York at 146.75 yen, up from 146.12 yen on Thursday. The British pound fell to $1.9400, less expensive than Thursday's $1.9570. Against the mark, the dollar rose to 1.5575 from 1.5445. Bond prices bucked the positive trend, continuing to fall on concern over hostilities. The government's 30-year bond lost $2.19 per $1,000 in face amount while its yield climbed to 9.15 percent, highest since April 1989. Stock markets worldwide posted gains. Japan's Nikkei Stock Average rose 428.13 points to 24,165.76, a 1.8 percent rise after its fourth-largest drop ever Thursday. The Frankfurt market gained about 38 points, while London's stock exchange closed higher for the first time in seven trading days. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones average soared nearly 40 points in the first 15 minutes of trading before dropping back until an afternoon rally fed by Gorbachev's comment and heavy buying by institutional and individual investors. ``The market's very oversold. This is a technical rally,'' said Manny Geranimos, head of block trading for Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. The stock market also was calmed by the stabilized dollar, the foreign market rallies and the oil drop. Still, traders noted the market remains down more than 460 points since reaching a historic peak July 17 _ a drop nearly as big as the October 1987 crash. ``When we got down 500 in 1987 it was time to buy,'' said James J. Cramer, a New York money manager, who said he made large stock purchases Friday. ``Now we're down 500 in '90 and maybe it's time to buy again.'' But he added: ``I think we're in a horrible bear market. In all bear markets there are these moves upwards. Markets don't go down in a straight line.''

The stock market rallied and oil prices eased as the world's battered financial markets gained optimism that a Middle East war had been averted _ at least for a while. But the recovery Friday was based more on a belief that stock prices had bottomed out and oil prices shot up too rapidly over $31 a barrel than on the latest tense developments in the Iraq-U.S. standoff. Traders termed Friday's action a chance to buy stocks at low prices following a sharp drop in the Dow Jones industrial average during the week.

The U.S. economy grew at a sluggish annual rate of 1.2 percent from April through June, the government said in a report that showed widespread economic weakness even before the Persian Gulf crisis. The Commerce Department report Friday showed the gross national product, the total output of goods and services, grew for the fifth consecutive quarter at a pace below 2 percent. Many economists had been looking for at least a small upward revision.

Gasoline prices have climbed 19.9 cents per gallon since Aug. 1, making for the most expensive fillups in more than eight years, according to the American Automobile Association. Self-serve regular unleaded gasoline averaged $1.274 per gallon nationwide, up 3.7 cents since Monday, the AAA reported Friday in its nationwide survey of 5,000 stations. The price is the highest since the July 4, 1982, price of $1.296.

The stock market's depressed levels opened the door for a number of companies to launch or extend stock buyback programs. A.O. Smith Corp., which had suspended a share repurchase program in June 1989, said Friday it was resuming stock buybacks. The company, a manufacturer of auto, truck and farm equipment, allocated $7.5 million for the repurchases. The toymaker Hasbro Inc. said its board approved the buyback of up to 3 million shares. Western Publishing Group Inc., First Illinois Corp., First Financial Holdings Inc. and Bernard Chaus Inc. were among other companies announcing stock buybacks.

A federal appeals court said the government is acting properly in setting auto mileage standards without preparing formal Environmental Impact Statements. The court, in a 2-1 decision Friday, rejected lawsuits by the state of California, the cities of Los Angeles and New York, and several environmental and safety groups. They had challenged the way the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration sets annual standards for the auto industry.

Federal Reserve policy-makers concluded in July that inflation remained high enough to maintain current interest rates despite a relatively slow economy, newly released records show. ``The staff projection prepared for this meeting suggested that the economy would expand over the remainder of 1990 at around the rate estimated for the first half of the year and at a slightly faster pace in 1991,'' said minutes of the July meeting, which were released on Friday.

Corporations' after-tax profits, reflecting the generally weak overall economy, edged down 0.2 percent in the April-June quarter, the government reported. The Commerce Department said Friday that the decline was the first since a 5.9 percent drop in after-tax profits in the July-September quarter last year. In the fourth quarter, profits rose 1.7 percent followed by a 0.5 percent first-quarter increase.

Data General Corp., which has repeatedly cut its payroll while trying to end a string of losses, said it will lay off more than 2,000 additional workers over the next several weeks. The announcement Friday was widely expected by Wall Street analysts, but some questioned whether the cost-cutting steps would allow the computer company to turn a profit. Data General expects to suffer a loss in the quarter.

A developer whose firm rejuvenated urban centers around the country was killed along with his wife and daughter when their private plane crashed between two houses. Killed were pilot Michael Spear, 49, president of The Rouse Co., his wife, Judy, 47, and their 19-year-old daughter, Jodi, police said Friday. The company's projects include Boston's Faneuil Hall shopping area, Harbor Place on the Baltimore waterfront, South Street Seaport in New York and Underground Atlanta.

Stock prices rallied sharply near the close Friday in what analysts termed a technical rebound from the market's recent slide. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had plunged 173.02 points over the three previous sessions, climbed 49.50 to 2,532.92. It ended the week down 111.88 points. The dollar rose sharply and gold prices were higher. Bond prices continued lower on Middle East tensions. Cattle futures prices slipped, soybeans and wheat advanced, while corn was lower.

DOC.HEAD: Up on Technical Reasons and GNP, Down on Gulf Blahs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf pvs, `Yields on. . . to CORRECT change in one-year bills; PICKS UP 16th graf, `A basis. . .
DOC.TEXT: Persian Gulf paranoia overtook the bond market Friday, driving down prices and capping one of the worst weeks for investor confidence since the financial gyrations from the Black Monday crash three years ago. The Treasury's key 30-year issue, a sensitive barometer of interest rates and the economy, fell 7-32 point or about $2.19 per $1,000 in face amount, extending its loss for the week to more than $22. Its yield, which rises when the price falls, reached 9.15 percent, the highest since April 12, 1989, and an indicator that many investors don't want to tie up their money for such long periods. By contrast many funneled money into 3-month Treasury bills to minimize the risk created by a possible Mideast war. ``Investors were so emotional this week, they really threw away their good common sense and were hanging on every minute development from the Middle East,'' said Marshall B. Front, economist at the Stein Roe & Farnham investment and mutual fund firm in Chicago. ``The bond and stock markets were driven by a level of emotionalism rarely seen since the stock market crash in 1987,'' he said. ``Investors in both stocks and bonds were looking at the worst possible scenarios.'' Bond strategists said prices strengthened early Friday on internal market technical influences and the Commerce Department's gross national product report, which showed the economy grew by only 1.2 percent in the April-June quarter, less than many forecasters had envisioned. The GNP report suggested serious economic problems confronted the United States that required the need for lower interest rates, which tends to boost the value of bond prices. But the effect of the statistic quickly faded as investors refocused attention on rapid developments in the Persian Gulf, where a showdown loomed between U.S. and Iraqi forces over Iraq's seizure of Kuwait on Aug. 2. The financial markets have become obsessed with the Persian Gulf conflict because it has disrupted the flow of oil from the industrial world's leading source of petroleum. Oil prices have reached five-year highs as a result, threatening to tip the U.S. economy into a recession. Although oil prices eased and stocks rallied a bit going into the weekend, investment strategists said there was no trace of optimism in the bond market. ``We did well on the GNP numbers, but then the Middle Eastern blahs took over from there,'' said Micheal W. Casey, international economist with Ramirez Capital Consultants Inc. ``People are just very apprehensive.'' In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments 1-16 point, intermediate maturities fell 3-16 to 9-32 point and long-term issues fell 7-32 point, the Telerate Inc., a financial information service reported. The movement of a point equals a $10 change in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, fell 1.94 to 1,133.39. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.69 percent as the discount fell 7 basis points to 7.45 percent. Yields on six-month bills fell to 7.86 percent as the discount fell 3 basis points to 7.47 percent. Yields on one-year bills were unchanged from Thursday's auction level of 7.94 percent as the discount held at 7.40 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 percent, down from 8 1-16 percent late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell 17-32 point. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.76 percent from 7.71 percent late Thursday.
